title: Townsend, Orrell lead Warriors
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Townsend, Orrell lead Warriors

 April 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 679
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — They weren't together when they spoke, but all three struck a similar theme."We needed this win going into next week," Easton High head softball coach Ryan Brice said Wednesday after the Warrriors churned out 16 hits en route to an 18-0 feel-good victory in five innings over Wicomico.
"We needed it big time," said Olivia Orrell, who celebrated senior day by launching a two-run homer to center field that gave Easton a 3-0 first-inning lead.
"I think the whole team needed it," chimed junior pitcher Sammy Townsend, who registered a season-high 15 strikeouts while spinning a three-hitter.
One day after getting blanked for the first time this year by two-time defending North Bayside champion North Dorchester, Easton (7-4) faced a Wicomico team that has yet to win this season. Sure, the Warriors were a heavy favorite, and took care of business early on the way to just their second win in five games.
But with key dates looming with Kent Island and Cambridge-South Dorchester next week, Easton not only got a desired result against the Indians (0-9) but a much-needed boost of confidence.
"We needed all the hits today because the past couple games we haven't really been hitting," said Orrell, who finished 3 or 4 with three RBIs, four runs scored and her second homer of the season. "So I think that boosted our confidence level. And it definitely boosted the team morale."
Brice agreed, especially after last week's losses to Stephen Decatur and Colonel Richardson, and Tuesday's setback at North Dorchester.
"Dropping the couple games last week really affected us," Brice said. "So we really needed this one today so we can get some traction going into the meat of the season. We have Kent Island coming up. We have Cambridge coming up. Those are good ball clubs so we got to be on our toes."
Townsend (3-3) seemed to be on her game from the beginning, fanning the first two batters she faced before plunking Amber Moore, and then striking out Aleah Shah to end the first.
"I feel my curve was really tight today, and I feel my riser was good as well," said Townsend, who notched all 15 outs via strikeout. "I feel like I had a natural rise going on today and I got a lot of hitters out with that. I was focused. I feel like this is what we needed."
Joseline Gabriel singled through the left side of the infield with one out in the second inning for Wi-Hi's first hit. But Townsend fanned the next two batters to end the frame, then struck out the side swinging in the third.
The Indians had their best chance to spoil Townsend's shutout bid in the fourth. Shah hit a one-out single to right and advanced to second on an error. Townsend struck out Kennedi Hull. Gabriel then reached on an error, sending Shah to third. But the Indians' lone baserunner to reach third would remain there, as Townsend got an inning-ending strikeout.
"I can't say enough about Sammy," Brice said. "There was freshman sensation, then sophomore sensation. Now, she's a junior sensation. She needed this win as well. She had a couple of rough outings the past couple of games, but she needed the win."
Wicomico put two runners on in the fifth with two outs, but Townsend punctuated Easton's third shutout of the year with her 15th K.
After scoring three runs on four hits in the first, Easton batted around in the second, pushing six more runs across with five hits. Gemma Vogel (2 for 3) opened the inning with a double, stole third and scored on an error. Lyla Roe (2 for 3, RBI), Orrell, and Townsend (3 for 4) each stroked singles in the rally, and Lane Kennedy (2 for 4, 2 RBIs) doubled.
Easton widened its lead to 12-0 in the third before scoring six more in the fourth.
"We did what we were supposed to do today," Brice said. "I can't complain. We hit the ball very well today. We haven't in the past couple of games. So today hopefully going into next week we keep the bats rolling."

title: Easton man pleads guilty to possessing child pornography
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Easton man pleads guilty to possessing child pornography

 January 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Crime 
 
 385
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — An Easton man pleaded guilty to four counts of possession of child pornography during a plea hearing on Thursday in the Talbot County Circuit Court.In June, Travis Schwaninger, 43, was arrested on eight counts of possessing child pornography following the execution of a search warrant where detectives from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office found evidence of child pornography on Schwaninger's electronic devices.
Before his arrest, the Easton Police Department Criminal Investigations Unit had received several tips about Schwaninger from the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children.
On Thursday, Maryland Circuit Court Judge Theresa Adams suspended all of the five-year sentences for each of the four counts Schwaninger pleaded guilty to. This means he will serve no jail time.
Adams said Schwaninger will have to serve five years of supervised probation, register as a Tier I sex offender and submit to supervision, meaning that he will have to comply with a sex offender management program.
The state agreed not to prosecute the remaining four charges Schwaninger faced.
Before handing down Schwaninger's sentence, Adams said that by obtaining and possessing the videos, Schwaninger was participating in the child pornography industry.
"The most important thing we can all do is protect children," she said.
During the plea hearing, Talbot County State's Attorney Joseph Coale gave descriptions of the four videos that Schwaninger pleaded guilty to having. He said the children in the videos were real children, not created by artificial intelligence.
Coale said that although Schwaninger had not manufactured the videos, his "participation in that market allows the market to flourish."
Schwaninger's attorney Thomas Maronick Jr. said his client "looked at some pictures he should not have" and didn't distribute them. Maronick said Schwaninger has since met with a counselor experienced in treating sex offenders. Maronick said the counselor did not feel that Schwaninger had a problem that requires "lengthy" therapy.
This was "a crime of curiosity," Maronick said, later adding that Schwaninger didn't realize the industry he was supporting.
Schwaninger told Adams that he came across the videos on social media toward the end of 2023.
"It was like watching a train wreck," he said about the videos. "I know better."
Schwaninger said the videos were on an old phone and didn't realize they were on the phone he was using at the time of his arrest. He said he thought he had deleted the videos.

title: GREENSBORO CANDIDATE: Paula Turner
author: Staff Writer
content:
GREENSBORO CANDIDATE: Paula Turner

 October 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Caroline

 PAULA TURNERAge: 54Family: Mother of two successful grown daughters, 2 great son-in-laws and GiGi to 4 of the world's cutest and most amazing grandchildren.
Education: 1989 Kent Co High School Graduate
Occupation: Licensed Life and Health Insurance Agent; I also have a background in banking and investments.
Previous political experience: None.
1. Why are you running for Greensboro Town Council?
Trust me, this was not planned or even an aspiration of mine however, once I started seeing my responsibilities as a homeowner becoming more costly with nothing changing for the better, I began attending town council meetings. I found like minded people asking the same questions.The more I showed up and listened, I realized that we've been going around in circles, with no improvement in sight. I finally decided to be a part of the change that I'd like to see.
2. What issues will you prioritize if elected?
To ensure that the most qualified people are employed by our town and ensure they have what they need to be productive and successful. To call for accountability of rental landlords and property owners on the upkeep and condition of their properties. If anyone needs help, we guide them to the resources they need. Sending out fines to already struggling families only causes hard feelings and more trust issues. Create and maintain safe neighborhoods by working with & alongside the Greensboro Police Department.
3. Transparency with the residents has been questioned by Greensboro residents. How would you plan to be transparent with the residents?
Through honesty and respect, by allowing the community to have a voice in decisions that directly affect them. I would like to create a monthly/quarterly newsletter (put together by volunteers) that would include a calendar of events, our meeting dates/times, church services and our food pantry schedule.
4. Multiple solar projects have been proposed for Caroline County. What rules should Greensboro have in place for these projects?
Unfortunately you are asking this question a few months too late. I petitioned the courts along with 2 other residents to block Halo from being able to move into our town but because those that came before us and not looking ahead, we lost. We will need to look outside of the box and stay up on the local and state happenings so that we can stay ahead of the curve. Thinking that "it won't happen here" has not done our town much good.

title: Men For Change recognizes volunteers' service
author: Tom McCall
content:
Men For Change recognizes volunteers' service

 July 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 532
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FEDERALSBURG — On July 20, about 80 people gathered at the Federalsburg Volunteer Fire Company banquet hall to recognize Men For Change's People of the Year.The Federalsburg nonprofit's slogan is "changing our community through service." They are geared toward mentoring youth and trying to help them make productive choices. This was the 14th year of the recognition awards.
There were six people honored for their work: Federalsburg's District One Councilman Brandy James, Principal of Federalsburg Elementary School Stephanie Brohawn, coach and volunteer William Eric Smith, community activist Cynthia Fletcher, Haitian community liaison Cederick Turner and Roberta Butler of the NAACP.
Betty Jarman, the media spokesperson for Men For Change, said, "The keynote speaker for this event was Vaughn Evans Sr. He was the principal of the North Dorchester Middle School in Hurlock.
She said, "The Men For Change theme this year was 'Let's Get Busy,'" which featured heavily in Evans' address.
In his speech, Evans urged the audience to get busy doing productive, positive things to support youth with the resources they need to become successful.
"They are our future leaders and enterprising entrepreneurs," he said.
He said that the essence of his message aligns with Colossians 3:23-24, which encourages community service and giving back. The bible verse starts, "And whatever you do, do it heartily, as to the Lord and not to men."
James, whose son was in the program years ago, said she is something of a "behind the scenes person" for the nonprofit.
"I am just part of a puzzle, and it takes more than me to push the wheel. It is a community effort," she said. "It was exciting to be acknowledged, but it was more exciting and more rewarding to see the others who were acknowledged.
"So much greatness being acknowledged — magnificent work. It is because of those individuals that so much goodness is happening in Federalsburg," James said.
Recognizing these volunteers is part of MFC's mission. They want the community to know what is happening.
"This is important because we want the broader community to know the people that are doing outstanding volunteer, work without any fanfare. These people are not looking for recognition. We want them to know that we appreciate the work that they are doing," Jarman said.
State Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) made citations for all the honorees, though he was unable to attend the event in person.
A recent graduate who participated in the program was also honored Saturday evening. 2024 Colonel Richardson High School graduate Elson Davis was presented with a certificate.
Jarman said, "The event was well attended by young people, young Black men. I thought that was a wonderful thing that they were there to support the honorees."
Jarman also took the opportunity to highlight an upcoming partnership between Men for Change and another local organization, the Federalsburg Activity Center.
"We are also partnering with the Federalsburg Activity Center and their after school mentoring program and other activities going on at the center," Jarman said. "It is still in construction, but we hope it will be open by September."
This project, still under construction, is repurposing the Dollar General in Federalsburg. Men For Change is still open to receiving donations.
"Once the center is open, we will need more volunteers," Jarman said.

title: QAC achieves significant milestone in reducing marine industry plastic waste
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
QAC achieves significant milestone in reducing marine industry plastic waste

 July 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 440
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Queen Anne's County has achieved a remarkable success in its ongoing efforts to reduce plastic waste generated by the marine industry. The county's recent initiative to recycle single-use boat shrink wrap has resulted in a significant increase in the amount of plastic diverted from landfills.In the second year of the program, the Queen Anne's County government, in partnership with Plastic Free QAC and the Marine Trades Association of Maryland, has seen a 370% increase in the amount of recycled shrink wrap compared to last year.
This year, a total of six tons pounds of plastic shrink wrap was collected and recycled, a substantial increase from the 1.62 tons collected in 2023.
Queen Anne's County Commissioner Phil Dumenil expressed his enthusiasm, stating, "This significant increase in our recycling efforts underscores the dedication and commitment of our residents and businesses to protect our county. By expanding the availability of MTAM recycle bags and increasing the public awareness, we have made it easier for everyone to participate in this important initiative."
Key highlights of this year's success include:
Increased participation from individual boat owner with a notable rise in the number of individual boat owners participating in the recycling program, showcasing the community's growing environmental consciousness.Expansion of recycling bag pickup locations; the program expanded from one to four convenient pickup locations for MTAM recycle bags, including:West Marine in Chester, Rommel's Ace Hardware in Stevensville, Centreville Town Hall and Refill Goodness in Stevensville.Commitment from local marinas and boat companies. Several local businesses committed to responsible disposal of shrink wrap, among them: Bay Bridge Marina, Bosun's Marine, Atlantic Yacht Services and Pocket Yacht Company
The MTAM recycle bags, sponsored by the County Commissioners, were provided free of charge and made available at multiple locations. The dedicated MTAM shrink wrap dumpster at the Grasonville Transfer Station facilitated easy and eco-friendly disposal for boat owners from early April to June.
This initiative is part of Queen Anne's County's broader commitment to environmental stewardship and sustainability. By continuing to work together, the county aims to set an example for other communities across Maryland and beyond.
Plastic Free QAC started in 2018 with the mission to reduce single-use plastic usage in general and places focus on education and building public awareness, according to Sara Shelley, president of Plastic Free QAC.
"We are really thrilled with the community response," she said.
Understanding that old habits with single-use plastics can be hard to shake, Plastic Free QAC looks to continually build involvement by connecting with individual boat owners and hosting community-wide clean ups, Shelley said.
For more information about the recycling program, including where to pick up MTAM recycle bags and drop off cleaned shrink wrap, visit https://lnk.bio/RecycleBoatShrinkwrap.

title: Contractor bringing Oxford's Strand project up to specifications
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Contractor bringing Oxford's Strand project up to specifications

 April 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 318
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD — Efforts to complete the first phase of the Strand Beach project are underway this week after it was determined the project was not finished to the specifications originally presented to the town.During a Commissioners of Oxford meeting March 25, Oxford Town Manager Holly Wahl said work to complete the project would begin the week of March 31.
In order to finish the first phase of the project, the contractor, Underwood and Associates, will lower the islands on the beach, remove temporary access to the islands, purchase and install native plantings and install a grassy strip along the roadway to prevent sand from flowing into the roadway, Wahl said. All of these items are to be completed to match the approved permit and site plan.
Wahl said Underwood and Associates is required to complete this phase of the project by April 19.
In December, the Commissioners of Oxford announced that although the Strand Beach project was signed off on in June by previous Town Manager Cheryl Lewis, the project had not been completed to the specifications that Underwood and Associates had originally presented.
The plan for the project was to create a berm, place hooks along the east and west areas of the Strand to bring in sand, create small islands in the water to reduce waves coming onto the beach and plant low marsh grasses on those islands. During the commissioners meeting in December, Commissioner Katrina Greer said not all the grasses had been planted on the islands and the islands were two feet higher in elevation than they were supposed to be.
That month, Greer brought together the Maryland Department of the Environment, the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, Underwood and Associates and the organizations that funded the project to ensure Underwood and Associates would bring down the elevation of the islands and take out the sand that goes out to the headlands at no cost to the town.

title: Larry L. O'Ferrall
content:
Larry L. O'Ferrall

 December 14, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: B7 | Section: Obituaries 
 
 284
 Words 

 Read News Document

 LANHAM - Larry Lee O'Ferrall passed away on December 5, 2023 at the age of 84 with his family by his side. He was born near East New Market in 1939, to the late Margaret and William O'Ferrall. Larry had three brothers Franklin, William, and Daniel O'Ferrall. He attended North Dorchester High School and graduated in 1957.Larry married Helen Hurlock on August 7, 1960 in Hurlock, MD. They moved to the suburbs of Washington, DC and in 1966, they had a son, Larry Allen O'Ferrall. Larry Lee has two grandchildren, Steven and Shannon O'Ferrall.
Larry worked in the computer field for the Central Intelligence Agency from 1960 to 2005. After retiring he briefly worked for the US Army as a contractor.
Larry was an avid sports fan who played baseball and football in High School as well as softball and football with the CIA. For over a decade he played softball on the same team with his son.
He was an avid reader and interested in history.
He enjoyed crabbing and fishing in the rivers on the Eastern Shore as a youth. He was a devoted family man and a proud grandparent. He was always in attendance at his grandchildren's events and games.
Besides his wife Helen, Larry is survived by Larry Allen O'Ferrall, his daughter-in-law Elizabeth O'Ferrall, his grandchildren Steven and Shannon O'Ferrall, his sister-in-law Barbara O'Ferrall and several nieces and nephews. He is preceded in death by his parents and brothers.
A viewing and funeral service will be held at the Zeller Funeral Home in East New Market, MD on Sunday, December 17th. The viewing will be at 1 pm and service at 2 pm. The burial will follow immediately at the Unity Washington Cemetery in Hurlock.

TODAY IN HISTORY/Nov. 5

 November 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Columns

 On Nov. 5, 1872, suffragist Susan B. Anthony defied the law by casting a vote in the presidential election; she was later arrested and charged with "knowingly voting without having a lawful right to vote." Found guilty at trial, she was fined $100, which she refused to pay.Also on this date:
In 1605, the "Gunpowder Plot" failed as Guy Fawkes was seized before he could blow up the English Parliament.
In 1912, Democrat Woodrow Wilson was elected president, defeating Progressive Party candidate Theodore Roosevelt, incumbent Republican William Howard Taft and Socialist Eugene V. Debs.
In 1930, novelist Sinclair Lewis became the first American to win the Nobel Prize in Literature.
In 1940, President Franklin D. Roosevelt won an unprecedented third term in office as he defeated Republican challenger Wendell L. Willkie.
In 1968, Republican Richard M. Nixon won the presidency, defeating Democratic Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey and American Independent Party candidate George C. Wallace.
In 1994, George Foreman became the oldest heavyweight boxing champion at age 45, knocking out Michael Moorer in the 10th round of their title bout.
In 1996, President Bill Clinton won a second term in the White House, defeating Republican candidate Bob Dole.
In 2006, Saddam Hussein was convicted and sentenced by the Iraqi High Tribunal to hang for crimes against humanity.
In 2009, a shooting rampage at the Fort Hood Army post in Texas left 13 people dead; Maj. Nidal Hasan, an Army psychiatrist, was later convicted of murder and sentenced to death. He has not yet been executed.
In 2017, a gunman armed with an assault rifle opened fire in a small South Texas church, killing more than two dozen people; the shooter, Devin Patrick Kelley, was later found dead from a self-inflicted gunshot wound.
In 2021, a crush of fans during a performance by rapper Travis Scott at a Houston music festival left 10 dead, as people were squeezed so tightly they couldn't breathe.

title: A LEGEND LOST - Orioles great and 16-time Gold Glove winner Brooks Robinson dies at 86
content:
A LEGEND LOST - Orioles great and 16-time Gold Glove winner Brooks Robinson dies at 86

 September 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 40 | Section: Sports 
 
 1312
 Words 

 Read News Document

 BALTIMORE - Hall of Fame third baseman Brooks Robinson, whose deft glovework and folksy manner made him one of the most beloved and accomplished athletes in Baltimore history, has died. He was 86.The Orioles announced his death in a joint statement with Robinson's family Tuesday. The statement did not say how Robinson died.The Orioles held a moment of silence before their game against the Washington Nationals, and the teams lined up outside their dugouts to pay their respects.Also before the game, fans gathered around the 9-foot bronze statue of Robinson inside Camden Yards."Great player, great guy on the field, great guy off," said fellow Orioles Hall of Famer Jim Palmer, who was overcome with emotion."Respectful, kind. And you don't meet too many guys like that. Brooks was a genuine person. There was no acting. Brooks was just a genuine person."Coming of age before the free agent era, Robinson spent his entire 23-year career with the Orioles. He almost single-handedly helped Baltimore defeat Cincinnati in the 1970 World Series and homered in Game 1 of the Orioles' 1966 sweep of the Los Angeles Dodgers for their first crown.Robinson participated in 18 All-Star Games, won 16 consecutive Gold Gloves and earned the 1964 AL Most Valuable Player award after batting .318 with 28 home runs and a league-leading 118 RBIs."An integral part of our Orioles Family since 1955, he will continue to leave a lasting impact on our club, our community, and the sport of baseball," the team said.He finished with 268 homers, drove in 1,357 runs and batted a respectable .267 in 2,896 career games. Not bad for ol' No. 5, the boy from Arkansas.MLB Commissioner Rob Manfred described Robinson as "one of the greats of our National Pastime.""Brooks stood among the greatest defensive players who have ever lived," Manfred said in a statement." He was a model of excellence, durability, loyalty and winning baseball for the Orioles."I will always remember Brooks as a true gentleman who represented our game extraordinarily well on and off the field all his life."MLB Player Association Executive Director Tony Clark cited Robinson's role as an advocate for his fellow players."Tributes to Brooks Robinson will duly note his brilliance at third base . But his impact transcended the field - as a prominent voice in the early days of the MLBPA and a relentless advocate for his fellow players through his work with the Major League Baseball Players Alumni Association. His humanity, kindness, integrity and commitment will long endure."The Hall of Fame applauded Robinson's role as a member of its board."For generations of fans, Brooks Robinson's talent on the field was surpassed only by his incredible character and integrity. His love of the Hall of Fame brightened Cooperstown, as did his devotion to the Museum as a long-standing and valued member of our Board of Directors."Robinson will be forever remembered for his work ethic and the skill he displayed at the hot corner, where he established himself as one of the finest fielding third baseman in baseball history, whether charging slow rollers or snaring liners down the third-base line."Brooks was maybe the last guy to get into the clubhouse the day of the game, but he would be the first guy on the field," former Orioles manager Earl Weaver said. "He'd be taking his groundballs, and we'd all go, 'Why does Brooks have to take any groundballs?' "I wouldn't expect anything else from Brooks. Seeing him work like that meant a lot of any young person coming up. He was so steady, and he steadied everybody else."Robinson arrived in Baltimore in September 1955 as an 18-yearold after spending most of his first professional season in baseball with Class B York. He went 2 for 22 with the Orioles and struck out 10 times.He jockeyed between the majors and minors until July 1959, when he stuck around in Baltimore for good."I think maybe he always knew what it's like to be in the big leagues at 19. And then I think when you get to the big leagues, you get here, you got to stay here, you got to figure out how to get better," Palmer said. "You have to decide who you want to be like. I think for all of us who knew him he was the best."Brooks Calbert Robinson Jr. was born in Little Rock on May 18, 1937. He eventually made Baltimore his home but never really lost his southern twang, which was just fine with fans in blue-collar Baltimore, who appreciated his homespun charm and unassuming demeanor.Dubbed "Mr. Oriole," he was a sports hero in Charm City, in the pantheon with former Colts quarterback Johnny Unitas and Orioles infielder Cal Ripken, who performed for a different generation.Many Orioles rooters who never got to see Robinson play still were able to enjoy his observations as he was part of team broadcasts.Ripken was known as The Iron Man because he played in 2,632 consecutive games, but Robinson wasn't fond of sitting on the bench, either. From 1960-1975, he played in at least 152 games in 14 seasons and in 144 games the other two years."I'm a guy who just wanted to see his name in the lineup everyday," he said. "To me, baseball was a passion to the point of obsession."Robinson retired in 1977 after batting only .149 in 24 games. His jersey was retired that year.Robinson's most memorable performance came as MVP of the 1970 World Series, when the Orioles bounced back from their stunning defeat to the New York Mets the year before and Robinson redeemed himself after batting just 1 for 19 in that series.Because he was so sensational in the field during Baltimore's fivegame triumph over the Reds, few remember he hit .429 and homered twice and drove in six runs - or that he made an error on his first play in the field.In Game 1, Robinson delivered the tiebreaking home run in the seventh inning. One inning earlier, he made a sensational backhanded grab of a hard grounder hit down the line by Lee May, spun around in foul territory and somehow threw out the runner.Robinson contributed an RBI single in the second game and became forever a part of World Series lore with his standout performance in Game 3. He made a tremendous, leaping grab of a grounder by Tony Perez to start a first-inning double play; charged a slow roller in the second inning and threw out Tommy Helms; then capped his memorable afternoon with a diving catch of a liner by Johnny Bench. The Series ended, fittingly, with a ground out to Robinson in Game 5, a 9-3 Orioles win."I'm beginning to see Brooks in my sleep," Reds manager Sparky Anderson said during the Series."If I dropped this paper plate, he'd pick it up on one hop and throw me out at first."Anderson also said, "He can throw his glove out there and it will start 10 double plays by itself."Palmer and other teammates would say that the country got to see what Robinson did routinely during the regular season. Robinson used to blush when asked to recall his heroics in October 1970."I tell people that I played 23 seasons and I never did have five games in a row like I did in that World Series," he said. "It was a once in a lifetime five-game series for me, and it just happened to be in a World Series."His legacy in Maryland continued long after his retirement.There's a Brooks Robinson Drive in Pikesville, and the annual state high school All-Star game played at Camden Yards is named in his honor.

title: 16-year-old charged with attempted murder for incident in Federalsburg
author: Konner Metz
content:
16-year-old charged with attempted murder for incident in Federalsburg

 May 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Caroline 
 
 223
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FEDERALSBURG — A 16-year-old is being charged with attempted murder after allegedly stabbing a woman in a Federalsburg parking lot, according to police.The incident occurred just before noon on Monday, the Caroline County Sheriff's Office said in a press release. The juvenile allegedly stabbed the woman multiple times during an altercation.
The 16-year-old suspect, who was not publicly named, is charged as an adult with attempted first- and second-degree murder, first- and second-degree assault, reckless endangerment, and possession of a dangerous weapon with intent to injure.
Police also arrested Franky Florestal, 29, and charged him with two counts of accessory after the fact to attempted first-degree murder.
Florestal, a Federalsburg resident, posted $5,000 unsecured bond following a bail review Thursday, according to court records. A preliminary hearing is scheduled for June 16.
The juvenile is being held without bond at the Caroline County Detention Center, police said.
The woman, 20, sustained life-threatening injuries but is now in stable condition, police said.
According to the Sheriff's Office, police in Seaford, Delaware responded to a local hospital where the woman was dropped off with multiple stab wounds. Per investigators, Florestal and the 16-year-old "transported the victim to the hospital before fleeing the scene."
The Caroline County Sheriff's Office, at the request of the Federalsburg Police Department, is actively investigating the incident. Anyone with information is asked to contact 410-479-2515 or info@carolinesheriff.net.

title: Easton follows great loss with victory
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Easton follows great loss with victory

 April 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 1245
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Easton High assistant baseball coach Matt Blue died Friday night after a 17-month battle with cancer.Less than 24 hours later, the Warriors were back on the field, having decided to go forward with Saturday's home game against Southern-Anne Arundel.
And Blue's son Dustin wanted the ball.
"He wanted to pitch," Easton head coach Albert Pritchett said of his sophomore right-hander. "We talked before the game. He wanted to pitch."
Dustin Blue pitched three-plus innings of two-hit ball before running into a jam in the fourth inning, but by then the Warriors had built a lead that was never in jeopardy en route to an emotional 11-2 victory.
"He wanted to play last night," Pritchett said of Dustin Blue. "As soon as we knew (of Matt's passing), the kids, the players and families wanted to play. We felt that was the best way to honor Matt. Matt would have wanted us to play. I think we showed it was the right decision."
Matt Blue was a three-sport athlete at Easton High before graduating in 2002. He went on to play goalkeeper for Salisbury University's soccer team before returning to teach in Talbot County. The former boys' head soccer coach at Easton High, he was diagnosed with cancer in December, 2022. Matt continued teaching at Easton Middle School, and remained an assistant on Easton's varsity baseball team until he passed Friday. Matt Blue was 40 years old.
"I thought the kids responded," Pritchett said. "They loved Matt Blue. They loved the coach. The community has a tremendous loss. It's going to be hard to replace him. I don't think we will.
"So I thought the kids, in the face of a lot of emotion, a lot of feelings, and a lot of loss, they did a good job," Pritchett continued. "They were here together playing the sport they love, supporting Dustin, the family. I'm very proud of them."
Matt Blue gave a speech prior to last year's St. Michaels at Easton game on April 13. Before Saturday's game, the public-address announcer reminded players, coaches and the large home crowd settled behind the backstop of one of Blue's main themes of recognizing the moment.
His son did just that on a wind-chilled afternoon of gray clouds and big patches of blue sky.
"It's incredible," Southern head coach Kyle Lynch said of Dustin. "The effort. Obviously the emotion. You don't know what's going through his head, but he threw tremendously. He was great. We have a lot respect for them and coach Pritchett. But what Dustin did was truly pretty special. Been around baseball for a long time and haven't seen anything like that."
Dustin's first pitch of the game was a strike to Thomas Martin. He got Martin on a grounder to short, then hit JC Wilson with a pitch. Easton catcher Colin Moody threw out Wilson trying to steal second then watched Dustin get a called strike three on Gavin Crandall to end the inning.
Easton's starting pitcher issued a one-out walk to Owen Meyers in the second, induced Andrew Cook into a fielder's choice, then zipped a pickoff throw to first that led to Cook getting caught in an inning-ending rundown.
Southern's Brendan Hinkle was hit by a pitch to lead off the third. But Nick Youmans grounded into a fielder's choice, struck out Dylan Clarke looking before Martin hit a deep fly that Warrior left fielder Carter Mooney made a nice play on.
Wilson lined Dustin's first offering of the fourth sharply through the middle for Southern's first hit. Wilson was erased on a fielder's choice. O'Brien was then hit by a pitch before Meyers dumped a singled into shallow left, loading the bases. Cook hit into a fielder's choice to plate the Bulldogs' first run before Pritchett came out to relieve Dustin with Garrett Fink.
"I thought he threw great," Pritchett said of Dustin (2-0), who remained in the game at shortstop. "I think (he threw) 60-something percent strikes. He commanded all three of his pitches. Again under a tremendous amount of pressure and emotion. Just showed a lot of character; lot of grit. It's a tremendous effort again in the face of tremendous loss and emotion. He's a tough kid. I'm proud of him."
Easton (3-1) scored all the runs it needed during a six-run second inning — all with two outs — against Bulldogs starter Crandall (1-1). Carter Mooney began the scoring, lining a stand-up RBI double down the left-field line. After Cullen Murphy walked, Dylan Cassell roped another run-producing double to left. Murphy scored on a wild pitch. Josh Dressler (2 for 4) singled to score Cassell for a 4-0 lead. Dressler eventually scored on a wild pitch before Dustin capped the scoring with an infield, RBI single.
The Warriors tacked on another five runs with two outs in the third for an 11-0 bulge. Murphy singled to center off reliever Rhett Dorval and was lifted for courtesy runner Mikey O'Connor. Cassell was hit by a pitch. Dressler singled into the hole at short, plating O'Connor. CJ Dugan (2 for 4) delivered the inning's big blow with a two-run single. Dustin (2 for 4) followed with an infield single.
Fink, who escaped a bases-loaded jam in the fourth, yielded a run in the fifth, but didn't give up a hit in two innings. He was relieved with two outs in the bottom of the sixth by O'Connor, who struck out three of the five batters he faced to close the win.
"I think it's a healthy distraction," Pritchett said of playing the game. "I think the kids needed it. They wanted it. And they proved it was a good decision for all of them. I thought their energy was high. They were positive despite the emotion."
After the game, Pritchett handed the game-ball to Dustin.
"Dustin looked fabulous," Pritchett said.
COLONEL 10, NORTH DORCHESTER 5
AMERICAN CORNER — Senior Daniel Hesson hurled a complete game Saturday morning, striking out nine, as the Colonels remained undefeated.
Derrick Mitchell hit a two-run homer for Colonel Richardson (5-0) and finished with three RBIs. Jordan Regulski and Johnny Beaven each had two hits.
SOFTBALL
NORTH DORCHESTER 7, COLONEL 2
AMERICAN CORNER — Emilee Cohee surrendered four hits, struck out 12 and issued one walk Saturday as the defending Class 1A state champions stayed unbeaten.
Cohee, Mackenzie Lewis, Maggie Hubbard and Maddie Nagel (two RBIs) each had two hits for the Eagles.
Makayla Newcomb suffered her first loss of the season as North Dorchester totaled 11 hits. Newcomb struck out six and walked two. Aubrey Taylor led Colonel with two hits, including a double.
QUEEN ANNE'S 8, CHESAPEAKE 5
CENTREVILLE — Abbie Denes blasted a three-run homer in the first inning and Autumn Huber was 3 for 4 with a four-inning homer Saturday to lead the Lions.
Caroline Taylor and Reece Brooks each had multiple-hit games for Queen Anne's. Hannah Martin earned the win, allowing just one run and four hits over six innings.

EASTON 9, STEPHEN DECATUR 8
BERLIN — Drew Schmidt scored the game-winner in overtime Friday night as the Warriors edged the Seahawks in a rematch of last year's Bayside Conference championship.
Schmidt finished with a hat trick, Hudson Royer had four goals and an assist, and Tyler Rardin added two goals for Easton (1-1). Warrior goalie Jack Kilbourne made 11 saves.

title: Easton man convicted of child abuse, assault
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Easton man convicted of child abuse, assault

 April 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Crime 
 
 325
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — An Easton man was convicted of first-degree child abuse and related charges Thursday.According to a news release from Talbot County State's Attorney's Office, Earl Andrew Kautz, 31, was found guilty on all charges, which include two counts of first-degree child abuse, one count of second-degree child abuse, two counts of second-degree assault and one count of reckless endangerment.
The charges stem from the abuse of a one-year-old boy and the assault of a 13-year-old girl, both of whom lived with Kautz at the time of the incidents.
According to the news release, the trial included testimony of the 13 year old and her mother, and expert medical testimony by the medical director of Pediatric Urgent Care Services at Johns Hopkins Hospital.
Evidence used in the trial include a May 2023 interview with the 13-year-old that was conducted by Talbot County Department of Social Services, according to the news release.
After the interview, the 1-year-old boy — who was 18 months old at the time — was taken to Johns Hopkins Hospital for a skeletal survey that revealed healing fractures in both of his tibias. A second survey taken two weeks later showed the same thing. According to the news release, the fractures were "deemed highly indicative of non-accidental injury" by Johns Hopkins medical staff.
According to the news release, witnesses at trial testified they had observed Kautz shaking the 1-year-old boy on multiple occasions in 2022. Witnesses also testified to observing bruises on the child's body when he was returned from visitations with Kautz.
"These cases involve children who are too young to testify or to speak on their own behalf and are therefore difficult to prosecute," Talbot County State's Attorney Joseph Coale said in the news release. "We are extremely grateful to the investigators at the Talbot County Department of Social Services, Easton Police Department and to the doctors at Johns Hopkins who came together to achieve justice in this case."
Kautz's sentencing is scheduled for June 10.

title: Voter turnout: 13M more nonvoters than Trump backers; Harris got 10% fewer votes than Biden
author: Mike Sunnucks
content:
Voter turnout: 13M more nonvoters than Trump backers; Harris got 10% fewer votes than Biden

 November 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks | Section: News 
 
 1205
 Words 

 Read News Document

 More than 89 million voting eligible Americans didn't vote in the 2024 elections, according to the latest tallies collected by the University of Florida's Election Lab.That accounts for more than 36.4% of the U.S. total electorate of 244.7 million people (voters and nonvoters).
There are still some votes being counted in California and Arizona.
But as it stands as of Thursday, Nov. 14, there were 13.2 million more nonvoters than supporters of now President-elect Donald Trump in the 2024 White House race.
Trump — who defeated Vice President Kamala Harris — has received close to 75.9 million votes, according to tallies Thursday from The Associated Press.
That accounts for just over 50% of the popular vote. But if nonvoters are included Trump got 31% of the electorate (voting and nonvoting).
Harris, the sitting U.S. vice president, has received close to 72.9 million votes, as of Thursday's counts.
That is more than 16.2 million fewer votes than the number of non-voters. As it stands, Harris got 29.7% of the total U.S. electorate.
Harris was installed at the top of the ticket after President Joe Biden was pressured by Democratic Party leaders and donors to quit the race in late July over concerns about his advanced age. There were some polls showing U.S. voters viewing that installation as 'undemocratic.'
Biden got close to 81.3 million in 2020 when he defeated Trump. That is more than 8.3 million more votes than Harris got in 2024. There were also more than 4.1 million fewer voters overall in 2024 compared to 2020.
Ani Ruhil, associate dean for research and planning and professor at Ohio University's Voinovich School of Leadership and Public Service, said ongoing vote counts could impact final turnout figures.
But Ruhil sees lower turnout as a key trend line in the 2024 race that saw Trump return to the White House.
"Only seven states exceeded their 2020 turnout rate — Georgia, Michigan, North Dakota, Vermont and Wisconsin," Ruhil said. "Washington, D.C., had an especially poor showing compared to 2020. So did Oregon, New Jersey, Maryland, Alaska, Illinois, and Utah."
The number of voters casting ballots in 2024 was down 11.6% in New Jersey, 11.2% in Illinois, 8.9% in Oregon and 4.6% in Washington state compared to 2020.
Nationally, turnout stands at 63.6%, according to the University of Florida. Ruhil said turnout in 2020 — which totaled 66.6% nationally — was a political aberration.
The Biden-Trump 2020 race occurred in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic, which saw more than 1.1 million deaths in the U.S., millions of workers facing job cuts and reduced hours, mask mandates and closures of schools, business and social events.
"Turnout was fanned by fear and anger," he said.
"In comes President Biden, with the singular charge of steering the country through the pandemic, and of making sure the economy did not fall to pieces. But by 2023, as we came out of the pandemic, inflation had taken its toll. Now was not the fear of a virus, but rather of gaping holes in the pocketbook. But there was no comforting plan being put forth by the White House," Ruhil continued.
He sees some voter fatigue with continued efforts by federal and state prosecutors to go after Trump.
Seventy percent of voters said the U.S. is headed in the wrong direction, with two-thirds stressed about inflation and the economy. Prices are up more than 20% since the pandemic and from when Biden and Harris took office in 2021, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Voters worried about the economy and high prices favored Trump in the 2024 race, according to exit polls.
The war in Gaza between Israel and Hamas after the Oct. 7, 2023, attacks also challenged Harris.
Anti-war voters (including Muslims and Arab Americans) are upset with U.S. military support for Israel. In the other corner, supporters of Israel (including more conservative Jewish voters) didn't trust Harris to continue U.S. support for Israel . The U.S. has allocated $17.9 billion war aid to Israel since Hamas's 2023 attacks, according to Brown University.
Harris got just over 80,000 fewer votes in Michigan, where the Israel-Hamas war is an issue for Arab-American and Muslim voters, than Biden 2020.
She lost to Trump by just over 80,600 votes in Michigan.
Ruhil said the enthusiasm was let out of the turnout balloon for many Democratic voters.
"The late switch, fevered fundraising, and a hastily assembled campaign did nothing to instill confidence," he said, stressing the lack of a convincing economic message from Harris.
Harris' campaign raised more than $1 billion and had another $649 million in backing from outside groups, according to the Center for Responsive Politics. Trump raised $381.5 million and was aided by $711 million in outside spending, according to CRP.
Harris' campaign focused heavily on support for abortion rights, casting Trump as a fascist threat to democracy and procuring celebrity endorsements including Oprah Winfrey, Jennifer Lopez, Beyonce, Willie Nelson and Bruce Springsteen.
The effort fell short with Harris underperforming Biden by 8.4 million votes (or 10.3%) nationally. She saw lower turnout or flat support levels in key Electoral College battlegrounds that Trump won.
Harris got 6.6% fewer votes than Biden in Arizona.
There was also the dynamic of Trump carrying states such as Montana, Missouri, Arizona and Florida, where there were abortion rights measures also on the ballot.
Those measures all passed and in Florida an abortion rights measure got 57% of the vote (failing to meet the state's 60% threshold). Trump got 56% of the vote.
In Montana, Trump carried the state with 58%. An abortion rights measure got the same percentage.
Trump favors allowing states to decide the abortion issue versus Harris, who backs nationally enshrining abortion rights.
Abortion rights groups were among the top backers of Harris.
"This result is devastating. There has been no greater champion for reproductive freedom than Vice President Kamala Harris," said Mini Timmaraju, president and CEO of Reproductive Freedom for All, a leading abortion rights advocacy group.
"We know the American people are with us, and they showed us that when they passed ballot measures and elected candidates in key states to protect their rights, said Timmaraju, who worries about Trump and the GOP in charge of the White House and Congress.
Harris and Democrats had hoped for a wave of women voters supporting abortion rights in the race against Trump.
But exit polls showed Trump carrying a majority of white women who voted, and voters were more evenly split on which presidential candidate they trusted on the abortion issue than in pre-election polls.
Abortion rights opponents argue Harris' focus on expansive abortion rights turned off some voters.
"Kamala Harris and Tim Walz support abortion anytime, anywhere, and under any circumstances. Supported by the abortion industry and its allies, Harris and Walz campaigned with fanatical fervor on abortion — and the voters rejected them," said Carol Tobias, president of National Right to Life.
Trump carried 58% of the Catholic vote versus 40% for Harris, according to NBC News exit polls. In 2020, Biden and Trump were evenly split with Catholics (49% to 50%), according to the Associated Press.
Trump won 63% of the votes from white working class women, made inroads with Hispanics (especially Hispanic men) and edged Harris with working class households, according to NBC News exit polls.
According to the University of Florida, there were 15.5 million fewer early votes in 2024 compared to 2020 (85.9 million versus 101.45 million).
That's a 15% drop.

title: Lauren Rose named TCPS Teacher of the Year. Giovanni Wynn is Support Staff of the Year
author: Konner Metz
content:
Lauren Rose named TCPS Teacher of the Year. Giovanni Wynn is Support Staff of the Year

 April 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 514
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Lauren Rose and Giovanni Wynn were overcome with emotion Wednesday night when Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi called their names during the district's annual Talbot Stars celebration.Rose, band director at Easton High School, and Wynn, family service coordinator at the St. Michaels Judy Center, were named the 2025-26 Talbot County Public Schools Teacher of the Year and Support Staff of the Year, respectively.
They were showered with hugs and applause from a room full of family, friends and fellow educators at the Easton Elks Lodge.
St. Michaels Elementary School principal Indra Bullock spoke of Wynn's passion and dedication in her role at the Judy Center, a family learning hub designed to prepare children up to 5 years old and their families for early education.
"She understands the unique challenges that each family faces and tailors her support to meet their specific needs," Bullock said. "Her compassionate nature allows her to build strong and trusting relationships with both parents and children, as well as staff, making them feel valued and understood."
In addition to Wynn, the finalists for Support Staff of the Year honored Wednesday included: Stacie Rice, special education secretary at Easton Middle; Jane Tillman, math and reading interventionist at Chapel District Elementary; and Christina Titz, instructional assistant at Easton Middle.
Rose was honored by Easton High School principal Sherry Spurry, who read aloud a student's nomination of Rose for the Teacher of the Year award.
"Mrs. Rose has a unique ability to transform the band room into a place where students feel safe, supported and encouraged to grow," the nomination read. "Whether it's a new decoration on the walls or a thoughtful conversation with a student, she makes the space her own, turning it into a welcoming environment for all of us."
The nomination stated Rose has been integral in facilitating band fundraisers and advocating for the band to be centrally located in the stands at Easton High football games.
"Mrs. Rose has been a guiding force in my own development," the student's nomination continued. "She has helped me overcome self-doubt, and has always been there to offer guidance during challenging times. Mrs. Rose's love for her students and her dedication to making our school a better place are truly inspiring."
Rose was one of four finalists for Teacher of the Year, alongside Rebecca Phillips, kindergarten teacher at Chapel District Elementary; Kathy Regan, third grade teacher at St. Michaels Elementary; and Holly Sump, kindergarten teacher at Chapel District Elementary.
Helga Einhorn, assistant superintendent of school leadership and student success, thanked the teachers for their hard work in the demanding field of education.
"Each of you exemplified the best of our profession, a profession that really is fraught with challenges, even on the best of days," Einhorn said. "Despite this, each one of you enter your schools and your classroom each day only seeing opportunities."
Board of Education President Emily Jackson said the staff and teacher finalists are life changers, motivators and inspirations.
"To all of our nominees, tonight is for you," Jackson said. "Thank you for everything you do, and I hope you feel celebrated and appreciated and seen for your unique and outstanding contribution."

Teen shot at Delaware car meet at industrial park

 August 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 195
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A 17-year-old boy is recovering after being shot during an unsanctioned car meet in an industrial park near Newark.The incident happened just before 1:30 a.m. Sunday on Tyler Way in the Delaware Industrial Park, located off South Chapel Street between Scottfield and Interstate 95.
According to Delaware State Police, the teen was part of a large crowd that had gathered for the car meet. At some point during the event, he got into an argument with another attendee, and that attendee threatened to shoot him.
A few minutes later, a second person approached the teen and fired a handgun at him. The teen suffered multiple gunshot wounds to his legs and was treated and released at a hospital, police said.
The man who argued with the teen was described as a Middle-Eastern man wearing a white hooded sweatshirt. The shooter was described as a light-skinned Black male with dreadlocks wearing a black hooded sweatshirt and a mask covering his face.
Both suspects drove away in a silver sedan.
Detectives are asking anyone who has information regarding this incident to contact Det. M. Conway at 302-365-8411. Information can also be provided by contacting Delaware Crime Stoppers at 1-800-847-3333 or delaware.crimestoppers.com.

title: Trappe Council introduces ordinance to raise water and sewer usage fees
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Trappe Council introduces ordinance to raise water and sewer usage fees

 May 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 381
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TRAPPE — On Tuesday evening, the Trappe Council introduced an ordinance to raise water and sewer usage fees.The introduction of Ordinance 3-2024 would amend section 14 of the Trappe Town Code to increase the water and sewer monthly fees for usage.
The monthly water usage rate is $4.70 per 1,000 gallons, and it's being proposed that it go to $6.20 per 1,000. The monthly sewer usage rate is currently $10.98 per 1,000, and it is proposed that it go to $11.48 per 1,000.
The base fees would not be increased, but the usage fees would be. Commissioner Brian Schmidt, council president, said that though the council does not like to increase fees, the town is in "desperate" need of it.
Schmidt said Trappe currently has three pumping stations that need repair, which would cost roughly $3 million. He also added that Trappe has a $13 million wastewater treatment plant that also needs repairs.
"While we hate to increase rates, the financial stability of the town is kind of in need of it," Schmidt said.
Additionally, the council approved introducing Ordinance 2-2024, adopting the FY2025 budget. This budget established a property tax rate of 33 cents per $100 of assessed real property value and 75 cents per $100 on commercial or business, personal property or public utility.
It also established an annual fee of $182 per residential household for trash collection service and adopted an enterprise budget for the town's water and sewer operations.
Erin Braband, Trappe administrator, pointed out that the tax rate for assessed real property and business personal property is not increasing, and the trash rate is not increasing.
Finally, the council approved the transfer of wastewater allocation from six lots in the Lakeside at Trappe development to the community pool for Lakeside residents.
Lakeside has purchased 120 units and issued 114 permits for homes to be built. The remaining six lots will go toward the community pool.
"We're transferring the sewer allocation from those six lots to the community center lots, so there's sewer allocation for the restrooms in the community center," Attorney Ryan Showalter said. "And this agreement basically says we're not going to build houses on those lots for occupancy, we're not gonna open anything for occupancy until the new treatment plant is open."
The council unanimously approved the agreement for wastewater allocation and development restrictions.

title: How much growth is too much for Easton? Balance between housing needs, infrastructure unsettled
author: Konner Metz
content:
How much growth is too much for Easton? Balance between housing needs, infrastructure unsettled

 August 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 1988
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The predicament on the minds of many Easton residents and leaders continues to be just how much the town can afford to grow.Easton is under a period of significant residential growth with multiple large-scale housing projects under construction. In 2000, the town's population was 11,708, according to census data. Ten years later, it rose to 15,945, and since, it's grown at a slower pace to 17,101 in 2020.
The boom has raised a litany of concerns, from increased traffic to a change in the town's small-town complexion.
Some residents, and a few officials, think Easton should press the brake pedal. But local real estate agents contend that a halt to growth could box out lower- and middle-class buyers and renters.
Martha Witte Suss, an associate broker for Coldwell Banker Realty and Easton resident, said the housing market has been in a crunch since the pandemic. She said there's not enough reasonably priced homes or rentals to satisfy employees who commute from outside Talbot County.
"We have plenty of housing that they can't afford," Suss said. Residential growth, if it focuses on affordability, could cure that dry spell, she added.
Michael Ports, vice chair of the Easton Planning Commission, poses the town's conundrum like this: "What are the housing needs of the people currently, and can we achieve that in a way that doesn't compromise everyone's needs for services?"
It's a question town leaders are taking on, even if there's no easy answer.
This fall, 136 apartments on Elliott Road will begin opening. Two large communities are under construction east of Route 50, combining for over 450 projected single-family homes. Near Easton's downtown, a developer plans to transform two former Perdue AgriBusiness sites into housing projects, totaling 144 units.
In all, roughly 1,127 units are recently finished, under construction or approved by the town's public bodies, according to information from town planners and developers of the 17 listed projects.
The pipeline of projects has yielded varying opinions from town leaders. Some don't want any new large housing projects approved in the next few years. Others prefer a case-by-case approach.
Mayor Megan Cook said the right answer is "probably somewhere in between." The town should focus on the current projects but not be too quick to disregard new ones, she said.
The mayor said growth is a charged topic and especially complicated due to affordable housing needs. No solution is a "silver bullet," Cook and others have repeatedly said.
"It is a balancing act," Town Council President Don Abbatiello said. "There would have to be a project come along that would fit that need, that workforce housing, that affordable housing piece."
In interviews with The Star Democrat, Easton officials weighed in on the town's current list of housing developments. When asked about infrastructure, the most recognized concerns included roads, fire and police services and schools.
They offered thoughts on where the town should focus its residential growth. Most leaned toward building from the inside-out. Planning Commission Chairperson Phil Toussaint is of that opinion. He hopes the sprawling, single-family developments are coming to an end.
"We wouldn't really want to support any development on the outskirts at all," Toussaint said.
And broadly, the 1,127-unit mark can be misleading since some units aren't under construction and may not be for years, Toussaint and others said.
"(People) think they're gonna appear tomorrow," Toussaint said. "They're not."
Single-family home neighborhoods typically take years to build out, such as Easton Village off of St. Michaels Road, a project of around 250 homes first approved in 2003 and just now reaching completion. So far, the 200-home Gannon Range and 252-home Four Seasons projects only have 18 and 11 building permits, respectively, according to Easton planning and zoning director Miguel Salinas.
"It's a daunting number. It's hard to hear," said Cook, who as mayor doesn't have a vote on housing applications. "But at the same time, you look at some of the examples as a community, the neighborhoods that we've had. They're built out over 20 years."
THE PIPELINE
Since town planners prepared a list of Easton housing projects this winter, chatter of "the pipeline" has been frequent at Town Council and Planning Commission meetings. Those two bodies are responsible for approving most of the projects.
The commission is made up of volunteer members and often can only make a recommendation to the council, whose members are elected. But sometimes, the commission holds final say, such as when it approved the 116-apartment Easton Crossing complex on Brookletts Avenue this year.
The five members of the council and six members of the commission offer a range of opinions when it comes to the town's growth.
Town Council Ward 3 representative David Montgomery provided perhaps the most rigid perspective.
"I want to stop for at least five years before we add anything more to this backlog," Montgomery said. "I want to see how fast it actually grows, it's actually built out."
Others were less firm on completely stopping growth, though all council members interviewed for this story said, at the very least, the town needs to be mindful. Some prefer a project-by-project approach, such as Abbatiello, who said future housing proposals need to be the "right fit" for Easton.
"I think right now, there's enough in the pipeline for us to say, 'Let's see how the projects impact the town's resources before we go adding a lot more to that list,'" Abbatiello said.
Planning Commission members have mixed thoughts, too.
Ports, the commission's vice chair, said Easton is "missing a good bit" even with the current project inventory. He said the missing units largely fall between expensive single-family homes and for-rent apartments — a sphere urban planners call "the missing middle."
"The reality is that the median sale price of a home right now is almost twice what a family of four making the absolute average income here in Easton can afford," Ports said. According to Maryland Realtors, the July 2025 median sales price in Talbot County was $545,000, the third highest in the state.
Tom Klein was the commission's lone vote against the Easton Crossing project, citing traffic and parking concerns. He said the need for more affordable housing is clear. But Klein would prefer to have a target number. At times, it feels like Easton is "chasing something" it doesn't know, he said.
"How many more do we need? Do we just keep assuming we keep needing more?" Klein asked. "That, to me, is something I don't really know the answer to. I think it would be helpful to know that so we don't just blindly build."
'MORE AND MORE CROWDED'
Town planners and engineers have processes to gauge the impacts residential projects will have on the town, such as traffic and environmental studies or reviews by the town's nonprofit utility, sewer and water company, Easton Utilities.
Even with project-specific studies, many town leaders believe traffic is a top-of-list concern, along with other infrastructure matters.
Montgomery said town staff should be "much more skeptical about the traffic impact studies" submitted alongside housing proposals. Ward 4 representative the Rev. Elmer Davis said the traffic issue is obvious to the human eye.
"I don't need a traffic study to tell me that the traffic in Easton, periodically, is a problem at best," Davis said.
Handling traffic backups is a tricky matter, Cook said, since some roads are state-run, others are under county purview and many downtown are maintained by town engineers and public works employees.
Off of Route 328, or Matthewstown Road, 136 apartments are opening soon, while 200 single-family homes will be built just down the road. It's an area residents have flagged during council and state transportation meetings.
"(Route) 328 is going to become busier and busier, and folks, I fear, are going to have more and more challenges getting out to (Route) 50," said Councilmember Robert Rankin, who represents residents in the Route 328 area.
A State Highway Administration planning and environmental study is underway to assess pedestrian and traffic needs on the busy state road that funnels onto Ocean Gateway. Previously proposed concepts by the state include adding left-turn lanes on Matthewstown Road and adding a second through lane on Goldsborough Road as drivers cross Route 50.
Traffic has consistently been brought up as a reason to lean away from annexing land for residential growth outside of Easton's core. Nearly all commission and council members interviewed for this story said they prefer to keep growth within the area encircled by Route 50 and Easton Parkway (322).
The Planning Commission has especially expressed that preference during workshops updating the town's comprehensive plan, which lays out the town's vision for handling growth in the next decade.
In July, the commission rejected the Fox Chase Estates, a 365-unit, mixed-use development proposed near a warehouse and industrial park north of Easton Airport and near the under-construction Shore Regional Health hospital. Town Council members maintain final voting power on the project, though it's unclear when or if it will come before them.
The Planning Commission voted unanimously to recommend against the development, citing a lack of connectivity as a main reason. The vote lines up with the commission's recent direction as they draft the new comprehensive plan: build from the inside-out.
"We'd rather see infill," Klein said. "We want to see connected neighborhoods."
That line of thinking, shared by many Town Council members, still leaves Easton with infrastructure challenges, such as downtown streets, utilities and safety. The latter was emphasized by Cook and council members as a chief priority.
Funding for the Easton Police Department and Easton Volunteer Fire Department makes up around 40% of the town's general fund budget. Abbatiello, who volunteers for the fire company, wants to hold off a massive increase in the cost for fire services by maintaining the department's volunteer status for "as (long) as possible."
"The biggest tax increase residents of Easton are ever going to see is if the Town of Easton needs to go to a paid (fire) department," Abbatiello said.
Easton Utilities evaluates water demands annually. According to a statement from Doug Abbott, director of engineering and water/wastewater departments, the utility is using 60% of its water and wastewater capabilities, leaving 40% "to accommodate future growth."
And as for downtown traffic, some town leaders are worried infill will do more harm than good.
"Our streets are becoming more and more crowded, and I am concerned the more that we have infill development, the harder it is to maneuver around this town," Ward 1 Councilmember Maureen Curry said at a comprehensive plan workshop Aug. 25.
"I just don't accept that assumption," Toussaint, the commission chair, later said. He argued that concentrating growth downtown will take cars off town streets and improve walkability.
Overall, the Aug. 25 meeting yielded a key takeaway: the new comprehensive plan is likely to include a preferred annual population growth rate around 1.75%. Planners initially proposed not to mark an annual growth rate in the plan, a change from the 2010 version, which stamped the rate at 1%.
Town Planner Lynn Thomas said at the meeting that without a growth rate, the plan would use historic projections to determine if the town should consider adopting policies to remedy growth trends either "significantly lower or significantly higher" than expected.
But Town Council members said a rate should be clearly stated to keep the town honest.
"I do think it would be helpful to have at least something to point toward," Rankin said. The Planning Commission will adjust the drafted plan later this fall, likely reinstating an annual growth rate, before hosting a public hearing.
The town's Affordable Housing Board and Attainable Housing Task Force are other bodies taking cracks at addressing the housing-growth debate. The task force is currently producing a list of recommended housing policies for the Town Council to consider.
Cook acknowledged that while town boards and discussions are great, "actionable items" — such as the comprehensive plan and policies — are on the way and will bring true benefits to residents. But nevertheless, she's happy Easton is addressing its growth problem head-on.
"No one else around here is having these conversations, but the Town of Easton is," Cook said. "They're difficult conversations. They're polarizing conversations, they're very emotional conversations. But we're having them."

title: Thanksgiving leftovers: What to do with them
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Thanksgiving leftovers: What to do with them

 November 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: News 
 
 1137
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Thanksgiving dinner is over, and there are lots of leftovers to be eaten in the days to come. My family always said the first round was great, the second round was good and thereafter was "OK."Today I will share some recipes and ideas for moving those foods.
Line the countertop with plastic containers that have lids to package small individual meals. Place a small amount of each food in the containers to be reheated. Lunch is packed or a quick meal-on-the-run. Maybe a shut-in or elderly neighbor would appreciate a dish or two.
Freeze any food that could be eaten in a week or so. Those turkey leftovers are great frozen to be used in that pot of soup on a cold winter day, especially the carcass with a little meat on it.
TURKEY POT PIE2 tbsps butter, 1 onion (chopped), 2 stalks celery (chopped), 3 carrots (chopped), 4 tbsps flour, 4 cups chicken or turkey stock, 2 potatoes (peeled and diced), 2 cups shredded turkey, 2 tbsps chopped parsley, 1/2 cup frozen peas (thawed), 1 prepared pie crust, 1 egg (lightly beaten).
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Melt butter in a saucepan and cook chopped onion until tender. Stir in celery and carrots and cook for 2 minutes. Stir in flour and cook for 2 minutes. Add chicken stock and bring to a simmer. Add potatoes and simmer until tender. Stir in turkey, parsley and peas. Pour mixture into the casserole. Top with pie crust and brush with egg. Bake for 30 minutes until the crust is golden.
THANKSGIVING POTATO SKINS6 to 8 small to medium russet potatoes, 1 tbsp extra-virgin olive oil, Kosher salt, 1 1/2 cups leftover mashed potatoes, 1 1/2 cup leftover turkey (chopped or shredded), 1 1/2 cups leftover stuffing, 1 cup grated sharp white cheddar, 1/2 cup cranberry sauce.
Preheat the oven to 425 degrees. Scrub potatoes well, then gently pierce with a fork five to six times. Place on a parchment-lined baking sheet. Roast potatoes until tender and a knife can be inserted without resistance, 50 to 60 minutes. Let cool on a baking sheet. Cut each potato in half lengthwise. Using a spoon, carefully scoop out potato flesh, leaving a 1/4-inch border; reserve potato flesh for another use. Using a pastry brush, lightly brush inside and outside of potato skins with oil; season with salt. Reduce oven temperature to 400 degrees. Set a wire rack in a baking sheet. Arrange potato skins skin side down on rack and roast until just beginning to crisp, 25 to 30 minutes. Let cool slightly. Layer each potato skin with leftover potatoes, leftover turkey, and leftover stuffing, then top with cheese. Continue to roast until the cheese is melted and the filling is warmed through, about 15 minutes more. Arrange potatoes on a platter. Top with cranberry sauce.
DEEP FRIED GREEN BEANSToss 1 pound leftover cooked or raw green beans with 1 tsp salt, 1/4 tsp cayenne pepper and 1 cup buttermilk. Soak for 15 minutes. Season 1 cup cornmeal with salt and cayenne. Dredge the green beans in the cornmeal, then deep-fry in 2 inches of 375-degree vegetable oil until golden brown, 2 to 3 minutes.
LEFTOVER TURKEY AND STUFFING REUBENS4 tbsps unsalted butter (room temperature), 8 slices rye bread, 4 tbsps Russian dressing, 8 slices Swiss cheese, 2 cups leftover stuffing (warmed slightly), 2 cups sauerkraut, 1 pound leftover thinly sliced turkey, salt and freshly ground black pepper.
Position a rack about four inches from the broiler heat source and preheat. Line a baking sheet with foil. Spread some butter on one side of each slice of bread. Place four pieces, buttered side down, on the prepared baking sheet. Spread some of the Russian dressing on the sides facing up. Top each with a slice of cheese and evenly crumble some of the stuffing over the cheese. Top each with some sauerkraut, turkey and then the remaining cheese on top. Put the open-faced sandwiches under the broiler and cook until the cheese melts, about 2 minutes. Remove the baking sheet from the broiler. Spread the rest of the dressing on the uncovered side of the four remaining bread slices, place on top melted cheese and push down, buttered side up to finish the sandwiches. Return to the broiler and toast sandwich, carefully turning once so both sides get nice and golden brown, about 2 minutes total, serve hot.
GRILLED TURKEY SANDWICH¾ cup mayonnaise, ¼ cup basil pesto, 4-6 slices crusty Italian bread or sourdough, 1/4 cup butter or margarine, 8 or so slices of your baked turkey, artichoke hearts, sliced tomatoes, whatever cheese you like (such as provolone cheese or sliced mozzarella).
In a small bowl, mix mayonnaise and pesto. Spread 1 side of each bread slice with butter. Turn bread slices butter sides down; spread other sides with 1 tbsp pesto mixture each. Top eight bread slices with turkey, artichokes, tomatoes and cheese. Top with remaining bread slices, butter sides up. In a sandwich grill or 12-inch skillet, cook sandwiches over medium heat for 3 to 4 minutes, turning once, until bread is toasted, and cheese is melted.
THANKSGIVING LEFTOVER NACHOS1 cup sour cream, 1 tbsp minced chipotle chile in adobo (plus more sauce for serving), 10 cups tortilla chips, 2 cups shredded leftover turkey meat, 3 cups shredded cheddar cheese, 2 cups shredded Monterey Jack cheese, 2 cups thinly sliced leftover cooked Brussels sprouts, 1 1/2 cups leftover cubed roasted butternut squash, 1 cup packaged french-fried onions, 1 cup lightly packed cilantro leaves or parsley leaves, 1/2 cup sliced black olives, 1/4 cup chopped pickled jalapenos.
Preheat the oven to 425 degrees. Stir the sour cream and chipotle chile together in a small bowl. Cover with plastic wraps and refrigerate. Scatter half the chips on a rimmed baking sheet. Top with one-third of the turkey, cheeses, Brussels sprouts, butternut squash and fried onions. Scatter the remaining chips on top followed by the remaining two-thirds of turkey, cheeses, Brussels sprouts and fried onions. Bake until the cheeses are melted and bubbly, about 5 to 7 minutes. Drizzle the nachos with chipotle sour cream and extra adobo sauce. Garnish with cilantro, black olives and jalapenos.
I'd like to wish everyone a safe, happy and healthy Thanksgiving.
Please take the time to check on your shut-in or elderly neighbors as they might not be as fortunate as others. There is nothing that puts a smile on someone's face like a nice big plate of food.
As you sit down together at the Thanksgiving dinner table, give thanks for all that we have — no matter how little or much, give thanks to those serving our country at home and abroad, give thanks for anyone working today so others can be home, and bless the hands who prepared your meal.
See you next week as we enter December and some amazing Christmas cookie recipes. God bless you all.
