title: Trivial pursuit: New comedy film 'Quiz Lady' wins big
author: Sarah Passingham
content:
Trivial pursuit: New comedy film 'Quiz Lady' wins big

 November 2, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Sarah Passingham | Page: 9A | Section: News 
 
 555
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Fingers on buzzers! Which streamer premieres a brand-new comedy film starring Awkwafina ("Renfield," 2023) and Sandra Oh ("Grey's Anatomy") on Friday, Nov. 3? The answer is Hulu, and the film in question is "Quiz Lady," a buddy comedy about two sisters who come together to win a quiz show and save a dog.Awkwafina is Anna, the reliable, type-A sister who is called away from her work as an accountant when her mom's senior living facility reaches out to let Anna know that they had lost her mom - but not to the afterlife.The attendant corrects herself in the trailer, telling Anna, "Sorry, that was terrible phrasing. I meant we don't know where she is." After making it to the facility, Anna is joined by her estranged and distraught sister Jenny, portrayed by Oh, whose purple highlights, oversized sunglasses and flamboyant personal style contrast with Anna's head-to-toe grey wardrobe. Anna is clued in to her mother's whereabouts when a bookie informs her that her beloved pet pug, Mr. Linguini, has been kidnapped and is being held hostage over her mother's massive gambling debts.With the debts creeping up her back and seniors home infractions stacking up, Anna and Jenny's mom flees to Macau, leaving them to sort out what she owes and be reunited with Mr. Linguini. Anna's salary isn't quite generous enough to settle their mother's $80,000 tab, and Jenny's constant search for her latest passion hasn't resulted in financial stability. Two weeks is all they're given to cough up the funds.The siblings are at a loss for ways to get rich quick until Jenny sees Anna participate in her favorite game show, "Can't Stop the Quiz," from her sofa. The show is must-watch television for Anna, who tunes in daily, usually accompanied by her canine companion, and effortlessly answers every single question correctly. Seeing Anna in her element turns on a light bulb over Jenny's head.It's decided, then, that the pair will travel to Los Angeles, get Anna on "Can't Stop the Quiz," and all their problems will be solved when she wins. Leaving the safety of her routine life in Philadelphia behind, Anna joins Jenny on a wild road trip across the United States and embraces her sister's chaotic, adventurous way of life. Neither of them is completely certain that Anna's trivia skills will transfer from the comfort of her couch to the pressure of the game show's set, but this is the best chance they've got to scrape together enough money to bring Mr. Linguini home unharmed.Having spent years apart, estranged over their differences, Anna and Jenny have a lot of ground to cover - geographically and emotionally - on their road trip. Anna's strictly balanced life greatly differs from her sister Jenny's listless pursuit of purpose. They have things to learn from each other, whether it's how to let loose and go on an adventure or focus enough to successfully achieve a goal."The element that really attracted me was the sister dynamic," director Jessica Yu told Deadline at the world premiere of "Quiz Lady" at the Toronto International Film Festival in September. She added, "For one thing, I just haven't seen a lot of comedies about sisters, and the fact that at the center of this was two Asian-American sisters, made me think, 'Oh, this will be really fun to explore.'"

title: Dorchester Circuit Court orders Valley Proteins must revise permit
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Dorchester Circuit Court orders Valley Proteins must revise permit

 November 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 481
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A Dorchester County Circuit Court judge has remanded a wastewater discharge permit for the Valley Proteins plant in Linkwood.According to court documents, Dorchester County Circuit Judge William Jones said the permit needs to be revised to include terms that "ensure any discharges from the facility will conform to Maryland and federal law and ensure compliance with water quality standards in the Transquaking River watershed."
The opinion comes more than a year after the Chesapeake Bay Foundation, Dorchester Citizens for Planned Growth, Friends of the Nanticoke River, ShoreRivers and Wicomico Environmental Trust challenged the state's permit.
A news release from the Chesapeake Bay Foundation said the organizations challenged the permit in February 2023 because the permit failed to "meaningfully reduce" Valley Proteins' wastewater discharge, which contributes to "unhealthy water quality" in the Transquaking River, Higgins Mill Pond and Chesapeake Bay.
With the court's decision, the Maryland Department of the Environment will have to revise the permit.
Valley Proteins, an animal waste rendering facility in Dorchester County that processes poultry byproducts, is owned by Darling Ingredients. The Texas-based company acquired the plant in December 2021.
The Chesapeake Bay Foundation called the ruling "a huge win for clean water and the health of the Chesapeake Bay's tributaries."
Chesapeake Bay Foundation Maryland Advocacy Director Alan Girard said Valley Proteins contributes to the nitrogen discharged in the the Transquaking River watershed. He said the original permit didn't ensure the river and Higgins Mill Pond are safe for swimming, fishing and wildlife habitat.
Friends of the Nanticoke River President Jay Martin said in the news release that his organization is "encouraged" by the court's decision.
"The court has sent a clear message that we need more comprehensive oversight to ensure our waters are safe and healthy for all species that rely on them," he said.
Matt Pluta, Choptank riverkeeper and director of riverkeeper programs at ShoreRivers, said the decision "recognizes the value of clean water."
"Higgins Mill Pond and the upper Transquaking River are valuable resources that have repeatedly been neglected, and we hope that — through this remand — the state will seek opportunities to meaningfully protect and restore them and reverse the long history of pollution impacts," he said in the news release.
This is not the only time Valley Proteins has gotten into hot water for its practices.
In June, the Maryland Department of the Environment fined Darling Ingredients $15,000 for repeated pollution violations at its Linkwood facility. According to a news release from the Chesapeake Bay Foundation, department inspections revealed 51 violations made between August 2023 and March 2024 by the owner of Valley Proteins.
In 2022, the facility was put under a consent decree with the Maryland Department of the Environment, the Chesapeake Bay Foundation, ShoreRivers and Dorchester Citizens for Planned Growth. The consent degree ordered the facility owners to pay $540,000 in civil penalties to the state for its more than 40 violations of a discharge permit issued by the state.

title: ‘Hello Girl’ from Maryland may soon win a medal for her WWI service
author: ROBERT STEWART Capital News Service
content:
‘Hello Girl’ from Maryland may soon win a medal for her WWI service

 December 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ROBERT STEWART Capital News Service | Section: News 
 
 955
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Marie Edmee LeRoux has been buried at the Fort Lincoln Cemetery here for 79 years, but she may soon win a gold medal for her service in World War I.LeRoux was one of 223 bilingual women deployed to France as telephone operators, often under combat conditions, as part of the U.S. Army Signal Corps. They were the country's first women soldiers, popularly known as the "Hello Girls."
They've been long overlooked for their service. But now the U.S. Congress has approved a special congressional gold medal as part of the National Defense Authorization Act for the coming year. The measure now goes to President Joe Biden for consideration.
"It's a story that's been forgotten and needs to be told," LeRoux's granddaughter, Catherine Bourgin of McLean, Va., said. "With the passage of the Congressional gold medal, that's what I want."
Women like LeRoux braved German submarines on the transport to the war front and disease and bombardment to serve in the signal corps under the American Expeditionary Forces. Their service helped set a precedent for women's service in the U.S. military and influenced support for the 19th amendment, guaranteeing women the right to vote.
Gen. John Pershing requested that bilingual women operators deploy to France. They were more skilled and experienced at operating the new telephone systems of the time, and the AEF needed bilingual people to communicate with the French forces.
LeRoux had those skills. She was born in Montreal and grew up speaking French and English before moving to the U.S. at age 10, according to Bourgin. She was a passionate singer but, according to Bourgin, LeRoux abandoned her music career to answer the call.
LeRoux traveled to France in 1918, operating the switchboards that connected military commanders with the front lines and their French counterparts. She stayed in France after the war to restart her music studies. When war threatened France again in 1939, LeRoux fled the country with her 4-year-old daughter in tow. She eventually came to live near family in Prince George's County.
She passed away in 1945 and was interred in an unmarked grave here, according to her granddaughter. She did not receive a military headstone because she was not considered a veteran.
Many women who served in the U.S. Army signal corps found out they weren't considered "soldiers" when they applied for benefits after the war. They received no veteran medical care and no federally funded rehabilitation training.
This was only remedied in 1977 when Congress acknowledged them as veterans, following decades of petitioning by Hello Girls like Merle Egan Anderson. Most had already passed away by then.
While Bourgin was researching her grandmother's history, she discovered LeRoux was a member of the Hello Girls. She also learned that a congressional commission had recommended these female veterans receive a Congressional Gold Medal collectively.
So, in 2023, Bourgin began working with others to help her grandmother and the other Hello Girls get that medal.
Bourgin refers to the advocacy group as the "Hello Girls Family," and she joined them to bring their story to Capitol Hill. Elizabeth Cobbs' 2017 book also helped reintroduce the women operators' war contribution into the mainstream.
"The telephone," Cobbs said, "was the only way that they could rapidly communicate with troops who were facing mechanized onslaughts of the most destructive machinery ever devised by humans."
Women could operate the war switchboards faster than their male counterparts, she said. They couldn't even vote at the time, nor serve on juries in most states.
Chris Christopher led the advocacy charge.
As a former staffer on the World War I Centennial Commission that recommended in 2018 that the Hello Girls receive the award as part of the country's formal efforts to commemorate the war, Christopher thought getting the award across the finish line was important. In 2023, with no bill passed, Christopher decided to tackle the issue head-on.
"I sat down," Christopher said, "and wrote a letter to every single senator who was not already a co-sponsor."
If a senator was not a co-sponsor, Christopher said, he researched and included World War I registration documents of a relative or ancestor of that senator to personalize the letters. He then made sure those were hand-delivered to the senators.
Volunteering in his free time, he also coordinated the network of history buffs and Hello Girl descendants and supporters for virtual meetings and lobbying on the Hill.
Catherine Bourgin had just discovered her grandmother's unmarked grave in Fort Lincoln Cemetery, in a plot next to her great-grandmother's. She also connected with Christopher at the same time.
Bourgin said her grandmother's grave was symbolic of what happened to the Hello Girls. LeRoux was in an unmarked grave, Bourgin said, just miles from the nation's capital but nevertheless lost to history.
While lobbying on Capitol Hill a few months later, Bourgin said, she told other advocates about the unmarked grave. The group got fired up, she said, and decided to change that.
They procured the grave marker and arranged for a military honors ceremony at the cemetery.
"The folks that did what they did for my grandmother," Bourgin said, "they truly made an indelible mark on my family's history."
Bourgin thinks the ceremony drew attention to the gold-medal cause. They made sure members of Congress were invited.
Now it seems the advocacy may have worked. Senators are expected to take up the defense act in the coming days.
Both Bourgin and Christopher hope that the award will bring attention to the untold stories of the country's first female soldiers, and ensure that all of them have veteran's grave markers.
"There are so many stories out there like this," Bourgin said, "and we just have to discover them."
"Hopefully once we get past all this, this is going to be something that will generate an ongoing effort," Christopher said. He wants "to get all of the Hello Girls their appropriate grave marker."

 The application process for the 2025-2026 Talbot County liquor licensing period is now available to the public.Businesses and individuals interested in applying for a new license, or renewing current licenses, can access the application on the board's webpage at talbotcountymd.gov/liquorboard.
All applications must be completed and submitted by March 31. Applicants are encouraged to review the application requirements and guidelines thoroughly to ensure compliance with local and state regulations.

All 2024-2025 alcoholic beverage licenses expire on April 30. The new license must be posted in the business by May 1.
"Our goal is to provide a streamlined and transparent process for applicants," said Victoria Bradley, secretary for the Talbot County Liquor Board. "We're here to assist individuals and businesses in navigating the application process successfully."
For questions or additional assistance, applicants can contact the Talbot County Liquor Board office at 410-770-8019 or via email at vbradley@talbotcountymd.gov. The office is open from 8 a.m. to noon and 1 to 4 p.m. Monday through Friday.

title: Bay Bridge traffic situation only getting worse
author: MICHAEL SAKATA
content:
Bay Bridge traffic situation only getting worse

 July 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MICHAEL SAKATA | Section: Columns 
 
 718
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Weekends are no longer sustainable on the Eastern Shore. Nor, for that matter, are most weekdays.The 16-mile traffic backups that paralyzed Maryland's Mid-Shore and Upper Shore on July 6, as thousands of weary families spent the waning hours of their holiday weekends languishing on westbound U.S. 50, were unsurprising to those who cross the Bay Bridge and travel this corridor on a regular basis. To their credit, our state and local leaders have used every available Band-Aid to mitigate this crisis — from eliminating the outdated booths at the Bay Bridge's eastbound toll plaza, to closing westbound access roads to weekend through traffic.
Despite their best efforts, though, the situation will only get worse.
As the population of the Eastern Shore continues to climb, regional policymakers work to expand housing inventories in order to meet demand, and the Shore becomes an increasingly popular destination for year-round entertainment and tourism, congestion will only intensify. There will, inevitably, come a time when backups of this magnitude are a daily occurrence and Shore residents are effectively cut off from jobs, emergency services and one another.
Given the inevitability of these trends, and the amount of time it takes for transportation projects to be funded and built in the state of Maryland, we must recognize that the time for action is now. By waiting any longer to commit to a visionary transportation mobility plan, we will only put these Marylanders' lives, livelihoods and quality of life at severe risk.
Given the stakes, Gov. Moore and the Maryland General Assembly are to be commended for committing an additional $500 million to some of our state's most urgent projects this past legislative session. This was a vital first step, but with more than $3 billion in unsatisfied priorities and a statewide network of roads, highways and bridges that continue to crumble with age, it is now time to take a quantum leap forward.
The Maryland Transportation Builders & Materials Association, which represents roughly 240 businesses (and therefore over 100,000 Maryland employees) across the DMV region, has developed a comprehensive regional approach to the U.S. 50 congestion crisis. An approach that recognizes this situation is much bigger than any single project and, therefore, addresses the challenge at multiple chokepoints and safety hazards.
Specifically, our plan calls upon our state leaders to wrap up what has been an interminable Chesapeake Bay Bridge Crossing Study, determine the best strategy for adding significant lane capacity and begin the arduous process of securing the massive funding that will be necessary to move the project forward. We do so, however, knowing that expanded Bay Bridge capacity alone will not solve the problem entirely.
Therefore, we are also calling for action on the following projects — all of which are in the Maryland Department of Transportation's six-year program — and are highlighted in our "25 for 25" campaign. These projects will help our state to meet the demands of the mid-21st century and beyond:
Construction of a grade-separated interchange at U.S. Route 50 and 213 in Wye Mills.Safety improvements at the highly perilous intersection of U.S. 50 and the Easton Bypass.Widening of I-97 to six lanes between U.S. Route 50 and state Route 32.Addition of lane capacity at U.S. Route 50 and Ritchie Highway.Capacity, safety and functionality improvements along the state Route 90 corridor, from U.S. 50 to Coastal Highway.Replacement of the unreliable Sinepuxent Bay drawbridge at the Ocean City Inlet.
To be sure, this is an ambitious plan. In fact, likely the most thorough reimagining of the Eastern Shore's transportation capacity since the "Reach the Beach" program nearly 40 years ago. It is also an expensive ask at a time when our primary sources of transportation revenue are plummeting due to improved gas mileage, reduction in gasoline-powered automobiles and various economic pressures.
However, to suggest that these projects simply cannot be done would imply that they are merely a luxury and not a necessity. As the primary voice of Maryland's transportation industry, we believe that failure to act is no longer an acceptable option. Even in the face of unprecedented fiscal and economic challenges, our elected officials and business leaders must come together — absent the partisan and geographic rivalries that so often act as impediments to progress — and determine how, and not if, we will make this vision a reality.
We simply cannot continue to live like this.

title: Cambridge man urges water caution after 'flesh-eating bacteria' infection
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Cambridge man urges water caution after 'flesh-eating bacteria' infection

 September 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 942
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Facing a life-altering bacterial infection from the local river, a local couple is urging the community to be more informed swimmers.A typical day at the shore turned a couple's lives upside down after a sharp step opened a wound on a man's leg and exposed him to bacteria in the Chester River last summer.
For over a year, Kyle "Slade" Register, of Cambridge has been fighting Vibrio, a "flesh-eating" bacteria found in local rivers.
Register and Audra Williamson were swimming in the Chester River on Aug. 16, 2024 when Register stepped on what they presume was a sharp oyster shell and cut a small, deep gash on the inside of Register's left foot. The couple quickly went to work cleaning the wound with peroxide and rubbing alcohol and scrubbed it with antibacterial soap before wrapping it.
Going to bed as normal, "We never dreamt we would wake up the next morning to his foot being the size of a bowling pin with a red streak starting up his leg," Williamson said.
Register spent a week at the hospital in Easton before being transferred to University of Maryland Shock Trauma, where he stayed for the following month. While there, Register had four surgeries to save his leg.
"It's been a year, and he is still going to wound care twice a week," Williamson said.
Register is unable to work full-time with the wound, as the two-inch gash ended in the entire inside of his left calf and the inside of his left foot being cut out, with a wound vac attached for months.
The couple went from having a "pretty normal life," to losing work and having their lives turned upside down, Williamson said.
Now beginning to get back on their feet, the two are sharing their story as a precautionary tale to others taking a dip.
"We just want to prevent this from happening to others," Williamson said.
According to the U.S Environmental Protection Agency, Vibrio are naturally occurring bacteria found in brackish environments like the Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries, such as the Chester River. In rare cases, swimmers can develop illnesses or infections if an open wound is exposed to polluted water.
A "tough construction worker type," who never thought twice about what was hidden in waterways, Register said his entire view of the water changed after that incident.
A "fish," all his life, Register now looks at the water with "abject sadness."
Taking it one day at a time, the Cambridge couple still drive around the Chesapeake Bay, estuaries, and areas like Blackwater National Wildlife Refuge to look at the water "but I don't go in," Register said.
Looking back on the treatment and recovery he has faced and the journey still to come, "I don't want a parent to feel that pain," Register said and seeks to share his story with others.
Not to scare people, but to help them understand the possibilities, Register said. "The public needs to be more educated about this," he said.
Williamson encouraged checking out the local environmental organizations information and the EPA website before swimming or boating.
Register welcomes the opportunities to share his story and can be reached at sladeregister81@gmail.com.
According to Shorerivers' Swimmable ShoreRivers Bacteria Monitoring Program Report, "Is it safe to swim in the river?" is one of the most common questions Riverkeepers hear from community members. There are inherent risks with coming in contact with water in a living estuary, and ShoreRivers works to understand the bacterial levels associated with enterococci, an EPA recommended indicator for human health risks.
Enterococci includes more than 17 species of fecal bacteria and is found in the intestines of warm-blooded animals. High levels of enterococci can indicate elevated risks for human contact with pathogens and other bacteria, such as E-coli. While there are natural bacteria levels in local rivers due to wildlife and decomposition, there are also pollution sources such as failing septic systems and faulty sewer lines, pet waste, mishandling of boat waste, and some organic fertilizers that can pose threats to human health.
"There are additional risks with open water swimming that we do not regularly monitor, including vibrio, toxic algal blooms, and other biological and chemical toxins," according to the report.
ShoreRivers' seasonal bacteria monitoring program regularly monitors nearly 50 sites where people frequently come in contact with water, including popular swimming locations, marinas, yacht clubs, and towns. Swim Tester volunteers collect water samples every Thursday morning from Memorial Day to Labor Day. Riverkeepers then analyze the samples and distribute data on bacteria levels in the river, aiming to provide the public with the information needed to make educated decisions about their contact with the water.
The Swimmable ShoreRivers program utilizes the standardized EPA criteria for recreational swimming of 104 Colony Forming Units (CFU)/100ml for analyzing a single bacteria sample. Anything equal to or higher than 104 CFU is a failing sample, and anything below 104 CFU is a passing sample. Not all test sites are designated swimming areas.
According to Shore Rivers, bacteria levels can change, particularly as a result of significant rain events.
ShoreRivers always recommends following best practices when recreating in local waterways including rinsing off after swimming, avoiding swimming for 24–48 hours after a rain event, and staying out of the water with open cuts or wounds to minimize exposure to potentially harmful bacteria.
As part of its ongoing work to protect and restore local rivers and creeks, ShoreRivers weekly bacteria monitoring reports are posted every Friday from Memorial Day to Labor Day at www.shorerivers.org/swim.
Though the seasonal Swimmable ShoreRivers testing has wrapped up for this year, a full report on each regularly monitored site is expected in October.
Information on how to prevent and respond to possible infections, can be found in the Maryland Department of the Environment.

title: GOP not there yet with articles of impeachment
author: Byron York
content:
GOP not there yet with articles of impeachment

 August 24, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Byron York | Page: A6 | Section: News 
 
 782
 Words 

 Read News Document

 There's a lot of talk among House Republicans about impeaching President Joe Biden. But GOP members disagree on whether there is enough evidence to go forward.On one hand, Republican investigators have made enormous progress in the past few weeks. The testimony of former Hunter Biden business partner Devon Archer demolished Joe Biden's claim that he didn't talk to his son about Hunter's shady foreign business deals.GOP lawmakers are also finding increasing evidence that foreign money flowed to multiple members of the Biden family close to Joe Biden himself."We have caught Joe Biden in so many lies," House Oversight Committee chairman James Comer told Fox News recently. "I can't even count the number of lies now. So we have put together a case that I think would stand up in any court of law in America." Of course, no one is talking about criminal charges against the sitting president of the United States. Rather, if Republicans were to take action against Biden, it would be through impeachment.GOP House members have filed several resolutions of impeachment against Biden. Now there is a new one, the first since the Archer testimony, from a member of the House Judiciary Committee, Florida Republican Rep. Greg Steube. The resolution, containing four articles of impeachment, shows why the effort to impeach Biden is just not there yet.Article One attempts to link Joe Biden to Hunter Biden's, and brother James Biden's, influence peddling operations.The article says Hunter and James Biden "sold access" to then Vice President Joe Biden and then "sold promised access" to Joe Biden before he became president.Joe Biden himself "assisted by making appearances, phone calls, meeting with business partners, and knowingly allowing his family members to promise access to him and actions by him in furtherance of these schemes." The Biden family, the article says, benefited financially from that; Joe Biden's role was an "abuse of power" and a violation of federal law.Article Two accuses Joe Biden of obstruction of justice, charging that the Biden Justice Department interfered with investigations into Hunter Biden's activities. The accusations are taken from two IRS whistleblowers who have outlined in detail how DOJ dragged its feet and actually blocked IRS investigators from looking into what appeared to be clear tax evasion by Hunter Biden."These acts constitute an abuse of power as well as obstruction of justice," the article says.Article Three accuses Joe Biden of fraud for a matter in which James Biden allegedly deceived investors in a health care company. "Access to Joe Biden and indications that Joe Biden supported these schemes were used to lure investors into the schemes," the article says.Finally, Article Four accuses Joe Biden of "financial involvement in drug and prostitution activities." The article says Joe Biden and Hunter Biden "have a long history of comingled and intertwined finances." During the 2010s, Hunter Biden was famously blowing millions of dollars on drugs and prostitutes, both of which are illegal."Given the intermingled finances of Joe Biden and Hunter Biden, Joe Biden financially supported and should have been aware of these drug transactions and prostitution transactions," the article says. "Many of these transactions would have occurred using accounts with a nexus to Joe Biden." So that is the current case against Joe Biden. The obvious weakness in all the articles is that they are based on an effort to tie Joe Biden to Hunter Biden's, or James Biden's, allegedly illegal activities. Republicans have made great progress in beginning to discover such links. They have shown that Joe Biden lied about his knowledge of Hunter's activities, which is an important breakthrough. There appears to be much left to be discovered.In addition, Republican have convincingly established that the Biden administration improperly interfered with investigation of Hunter Biden's activities. That is an important breakthrough, too, although there is much more to learn.So as far as the first two articles are concerned, there is good reason for Republicans to push forward with their investigation. The third article, about James Biden, is very iffy, and the fourth article, about Joe Biden's knowledge of Hunter's drugging and whoring, will never go anywhere.And that is the current state of efforts to impeach Joe Biden. Republicans do not yet have a convincing case for impeachment. Maybe they will get there, and maybe they won't. As far as exercising general restraint against taking the extreme measure of impeachment is concerned - well, that sort of restraint went out with Nancy Pelosi's leadership of the House. If Republicans do eventually gather enough evidence against Biden, they'll use it. Santa's Workshop in the Land of Misfits continues next 2 Saturdays in Denton

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News

 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Children gathered at the Wharves of Choptank Visitor & Heritage Center on Saturday for an afternoon full of crafts, wooden toys, painting and more as the holidays quickly approach.In an event put on by the Caroline County Council of Arts and The Foundry, its art gallery, children were welcomed to build their own toys, greet Santa and meet the Grinch. Two more Santa's Workshop in the Land of Misfits Saturdays are scheduled: Dec. 14 and Dec. 21 from noon to 4 p.m.
Caroline County Council of Arts Executive Director George Karos said the event is a "fun way to celebrate the holidays."
"Everyone can make art and spend time with loved ones — especially a win-win as proceeds go towards supporting local youth programs and spreading holiday cheer," Karos said in an emailed statement.
Megan Krizovensky, program manager for Caroline County Council of Arts, said in an interview that last weekend's event was a success. It's the first time the art organization put on Santa's Workshop.
"It was pretty good," Krizovenksy said of Saturday's turnout. "I know the first week we expected to be a little slower. But we actually had at least 50 children there, and we were prepared for over 100. So we're hoping that (Dec. 14 and Dec. 21) can pick it up much bigger just for the kid's sake."
Last Saturday, the Chesapeake Culinary Center participated in the event and donated cookies and cocoa. Krizovenksy said Earth Tones Cafe will be donating food for this Saturday.
Additionally, students from Caroline County Public Schools are volunteering, gaining student service learning hours. The first-time event runs fully on donations, Krizovenksy added.
"The event is completely donation-based with all proceeds going to support local youth programs through the Caroline County Council of Arts," she said.
Krizovensky said local artist Steve Mead, formerly the board treasurer for the arts council, was integral in the event's formulation.
The hope is that Santa's Workshop can continue in the future, with some of this year's proceeds working to fund a second annual Santa's Workshop. Registration is free with a suggested donation of $15 per child.
"The goal is to create a magical experience for kids who otherwise might not have a great holiday," Krizovenksy said. "We want to make sure that it's free. Our mission is to enrich the community through the arts, and Caroline County itself is a unique place anyway with a lot of deep-rooted tradition. So we're trying to create authentic experiences that reflect and celebrate the spirit of that community."
To register for Dec. 14 or Dec. 21, sign up at carolinearts.org/events/santas-workshop-in-the-island-of-misfit-toys/ or visit The Foundry Art Gallery at 401 Market St. in Denton.

title: Dems score coup with McCarthy ouster
author: David Harsanyi
content:
Dems score coup with McCarthy ouster

 October 11, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: David Harsanyi | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 640
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Kevin McCarthy has become the first House speaker to ever be successfully ousted in a motion to vacate vote. One day, you can tell your grandchildren you were alive to witness this completely pointless bit of history.Rep. Matt Gaetz's (R-Fla.) self-aggrandizing political stunt makes no sense and changes nothing - other than perhaps his fundraising totals.And other than some platitudinous blathering about "the establishment" and "the uniparty," I still haven't seen anyone offer a coherent reason - not even retroactively - for how any of this is the "best way to advance the conservative agenda." It would be one thing, perhaps an admirable thing, if Gaetz had gone on this crusade for a coherent ideological or principled reason. But his post-ousting demagoguery and grandstanding about issues completely unrelated to McCarthy's job performance proved it was a personal matter."I don't think voting against Kevin McCarthy is chaos," Gaetz explained."I think $33 trillion in debt is chaos. I think that facing a $2.2 trillion annual deficit is chaos." Now, there are numerous people to blame for the impending fiscal disaster, but McCarthy is no more guilty than most.One of the least convincing claims by Gaetz's defenders is that McCarthy was punished for ignoring the base. "The base," of course, is a popular euphemism for the most vociferous populist faction of the GOP.This faction enjoys blowing things up - mostly their own party's prospects. In this case, the "base" was represented by eight Republicans and the entire Democratic Party.And among these principled eight GOPers who were fighting for the honor of the base - what The New York Times called the "far-right GOP faction" - were Reps.Nancy Mace (who said Gaetz was a "fraud" the last time he tried to knock off McCarthy) and Ken Buck (who we last heard was reportedly looking for a CNN gig). I'm going to go out on a limb and say that the future of conservatism was not the motivating factor for their votes.Most Trump-endorsed candidates didn't even participate in McCarthy's removal. Donald Trump himself tepidly supported the speaker because, as he noted, the man had said "very great things" about him. And, really, what's more important? Though, I bet McCarthy was expecting a far more energetic defense after pathetically ingratiating himself to the former president a couple of weeks ago.Even if Gaetz had excellent reasons, Republicans did not eject McCarthy.Eight Republicans can't do anything by themselves. No, 208 Democrats ousted McCarthy with the help of some petulant backbenchers nursing personal vendettas. It is a political coup for the Dems.Gaetz, who only yesterday was going on about McCarthy's "secret deal" with Democrats, had no qualms sitting on the opposition side of the House plotting to oust a speaker who holds a rickety nine-seat majority. If there was actually a brewing House rebellion, Gaetz would have been able to corral far more votes.But Gaetz wanted to "break the fever" of D.C., so he teamed up with minority leader Hakeem Jeffries, "the squad," Adam Schiff and so on. Jeffries claimed he was supporting Gaetz's efforts because Republicans have shown an "unwillingness to break from MAGA extremism in an authentic and comprehensive manner." The notion that Democrats are backing a leading MAGA loyalist because they want to temper the "extremism" of Republicans makes about as much sense as Jamaal Bowman's fire alarm story. Democrats keep pretending they yearn for a more responsible GOP and stable political environment, then keep supporting every fringe effort and candidate to undermine both.Of course, no one is owed anything.McCarthy isn't the only person available in D.C. to serve as a middling speaker of the House. And, frankly, if he'd been more talented at the job, he might have headed off this challenge more effectively. But it's doubtful anyone is going to perform better with a slender majority and the Senate and presidency in Democrats' hands.But then again, none of that matters when you're having a tantrum.

Residents can vote at the Easton Volunteer Fire Department on Leonard Rieck Drive from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m.The council is made up of a president along with four representatives from the town's election wards.

Ward 2 includes a large portion of town east of U.S. Route 50 and north of Dutchman's Lane, as well as residents on the west side of the highway, south of Idlewild Avenue and east of Route 322.

Ward 4 encompasses much of Easton's downtown area in between Routes 50 and 322, including residents north of Idlewild Avenue and on the east side of Aurora Street up past Dover Road.

 DEAR HARRIETTE: I'm 28, and I live in a small apartment complex where everyone knows each other. My neighbor, a gentleman in his 50s, saw me smoking a cigarette the other day and decided to take it upon himself to lecture me on the dangers of smoking.Although I appreciated his concern, his lecture was unwelcome. I intend to quit smoking at some point, but I don't need my neighbor to intervene. I fear that the next time I bump into him, he will give me another lecture. What can I do to make him understand that his unsolicited advice is not helping? I'm a grown adult, and I don't need lectures. - Good IntentionsDEAR GOOD INTENTIONS: As you know, your neighbor expressed his concerns out of genuine care for you. Remember that when you speak to him. It is your right to do whatever you want with your life and your body. Provided that the cigarette smoke is not contaminating your neighbors' air, you should be able to smoke in peace.That said, it is likely that this man will either say something or scowl at you the next time he sees a cigarette in your hand. Can you say something?Yes, but be careful. You can thank him for his concern, but put up a guardrail. Tell him you know what you are doing. When you decide to quit, you will. Politely ask him to refrain from giving you advice on this topic in the future.Harriette Cole is a lifestylist andfounder of Dream Leapers, an initiative to help people access and activate their dreams. title: Federalsburg unveils sign to recognize historic 2023 election, people who made it possible
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Federalsburg unveils sign to recognize historic 2023 election, people who made it possible

 November 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 744
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FEDERALSBURG — The Rev. Jeffrey Butler, a Federalsburg resident, remembers when Brooklyn Avenue went from being a dirt road to a paved one in the late 1970s. He also remembers the more than 40 years it took for the town to get that road repaved."It was so bad," he said. "I mean, just tearing cars up. And we went to the town to complain. They still didn't do nothing."
"Finally, along with this lawsuit, came them also fixing this road up after 40 years," Butler said.
Since a lawsuit led to the election of the town's first two Black council members last year, the road — which is situated in a historically Black area in town — has been repaved.
On Saturday, with the newly paved Brooklyn Avenue in view, Federalsburg Mayor Kim Abner and the Federalsburg Town Council unveiled a new sign that commemorates the town's historic election and the new election system that made it possible.
The sign recognizes the individuals and groups who helped make it possible for Black Councilwomen Darlene Pitt Hammond and Brandy James to be elected to the Town Council in September 2023.
A MARKER OF PROGRESSAfter the unveiling, Hammond looked at the sign, tears forming in her eyes.
"It's a lot," she said, taking a pause, "to think that this small little town was able to stand for the rights of all people, not some people."
Hammond, who was a plaintiff in the lawsuit against the town, said the progress that has been made in the town is "heartwarming" and "breathtaking."
"It's a dream come true for me and for others that (came) before me, that we have established that everybody should be represented no matter what the color of your skin is," she said.
Although Black residents now make up nearly half of the town's population, the town had never had a minority representative on the council in its 200-year history. In June 2023 — through charter amendments, legislation and federal court rulings — the town's at-large election system was changed to a two-district system to ensure more representation of Federalsburg's Black residents.
In April, a $260,000 settlement was reached in the lawsuit filed against the town by the Caroline County branch of the NAACP, the Caucus of African American Leaders and Federalsburg residents regarding its discriminatory election system.
The settlement included a sweeping array of measures aimed at providing reconciliation after the town's previous election system was determined to have prevented Black residents from electing their chosen representatives. This includes the town apologizing to those who brought on the lawsuit, affixing a plaque to its town hall building, proclaiming Sept. 26 as Voting Rights Day and erecting the historical marker in the town's Black community.
Hammond said this sign unveiling and the first annual Voting Rights Day celebration, which was held in September, point to "a new era" in Federalsburg.
"It is a new era where everybody has a voice and everybody will be heard," she said.
After years of Butler speaking out about the need for Brooklyn Avenue to be repaved, Hammond said the new council was able to get the project done in about a year.
Before the sign was unveiled, Mayor Kim Abner said she and the council are excited about the direction that Federalsburg is going in.
"We have great things to come," she said. "We are making great progress in the town, and we are super excited that you're all here to celebrate."
Butler said he is hopeful more positive changes are coming with the current council in place.
"It's coming," he said. "We know Rome wasn't built in a day, so it's coming."
Sherone Lewis, a Federalsburg native and first vice president for the Caroline County branch of the NAACP who was a plaintiff on the lawsuit, called it surreal to be celebrating the changes that have been made.
"But I must say, the struggle continues," she said. "We still have a lot of work to do for diversity, equity and inclusion. I know those are buzz words these days. But I do believe that because I want this for my children, my grandchildren."
Willie Woods, president of the Caroline County branch of the NAACP, said the new sign is something that will be seen and read for generations.
"I hate to talk about it from this standpoint, but in the future, we will be passed on and there will be other generations," she said. "And this signage will remind them of the stance that was taken and of the progress that Federalsburg has embraced as we are moving forward."

title: R & B Singer Rudolph Isley dies at age 84
content:
R & B Singer Rudolph Isley dies at age 84

 October 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 8 | Section: News 
 
 283
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Rudolph Isley, a founding member of the Isley Brothers who helped perform such raw rhythm and blues classics as "Shout" and "Twist and Shout" and the funky hits "That Lady" and "It's Your Thing," has died at age 84."There are no words to express my feelings and the love I have for my brother. Our family will miss him. But I know he's in a better place," Ronald Isley said in a statement released Thursday by an Isley Brothers publicist.Further details were not immediately available.A Cincinnati native, Rudolph Isley began singing in church with brothers Ronald and O'Kelly (another sibling, Vernon, died at age 13) and was still in his teens when they broke through in the late 1950s with "Shout," a secularized gospel rave that was later immortalized during the toga party scene in "Animal House." The Isleys scored again in the early 1960s with the equally spirited "Twist and Shout," which the Beatles liked so much they used it as the closing song on their debut album and opened with it for their famed 1965 concert at Shea Stadium.The Isleys' other hits included "This Old Heart of Mine (Is Weak for You)," later covered by Rod Stewart, and the Grammy-winning "It's Your Thing." In the 1970s, after younger brother Ernest and Marvin joined the group, they had even greater success with such singles as "That Lady" and "Fight the Power (Part 1)" and such million-selling albums as "The Heat Is On" and "Go for Your Guns." Rudolph Isley left the group in 1989, three years after the sudden death of O'Kelly Isley, to become a Christian minister. He was among the Isleys inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1992.

 I had to smile when I saw your cartoon in the Wednesday Aug. 16 paper and the apoplectic reaction of some of your readers.Most people can see the irony in the cartoon when it is the Republican party that has dragged Christianity into the public square and wrapped itself in it. These sensitivities are rich. You don't own Christ's image. And you can't use the political process to impose your brand of Christian beliefs on the public and expect others not to see it as fair game for cartoonists.As a born-again Christian, I felt called to run for state Senate in 2018. Matthew 25 was my platform where Jesus says whatever you do for the hungry, the thirsty, the stranger, those needing clothes, the sick and those in prison you do for Me.I was at my beautiful church, New St. John's in Wittman, and was called up at the last minute to read the new testament scripture and the lectionary reading happened to include that portion of Matthew 25.That settled the debate in my head about whether to run.Before I moved to the Eastern Shore in 2010, a friend and I had a nursing home ministry where we would visit six nursing homes to conduct worship and prayer services.Since coming here, I had a worship service in the Alzheimer's unit at the Pines for four years. I studied a year of clinical pastoral education and served as an on-call chaplain at the Easton Hospital.Today I visit the women in the Talbot County Detention Center.The shame today, of course, is that one party has been wrapping itself in the cloak of Christianity for the past decade, insisting our pluralistic country is a Christian country and promoting policies that exclude the LGBTQ+ community.They even insisted that restricting gatherings including church attendance during the early days of the pandemic was anti-Christian.Their efforts to impose an abortion ban is organized around certain faith-based communities.Our beautiful country is a pluralistic one.Churches, synagogues and mosques are simply human institutions and churches in particular have shrinking attendance. These Christians should develop a sense of humor and recognize that they can't play in the public square and not expect to be called out for it.HOLLY WRIGHTEaston

title: Caroline Police Accountability Board reports progress
author: Connie Connolly
content:
Caroline Police Accountability Board reports progress

 February 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly | Section: Local News 
 
 1030
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — The Caroline County Police Accountability Board shared its second annual report with the County Commissioners at their Feb. 6 meeting.The bottom line: Of the thousands of contacts people had with county and town law enforcement officers, a handful of complaints were made, and a fraction of those resulted in disciplinary action.
Presenting the report were Police Accountability Board Chairman John Bartlett and Board Administrator Kimberly Raeder.
Bartlett said he wanted to make one "very important" point: The Caroline County Sheriff's Office had over 26,000 calls for service in 2023, which generated only six complaints, he said.
"Five of those six were exonerated, meaning unfounded, and one was a very minor infraction, which led to a written reprimand," he said. "I think that speaks volumes with law enforcement here in Caroline County."
A state mandate
Raeder explained the purpose and scope of the three police oversight boards mandated by the Maryland Police Accountability Act of 2021, which became effective July 1, 2022.
The role of the county's Police Accountability Board "is to receive police complaints, recommend policy changes and identify any trends," Raeder said.
"The second board is the five-member Administrative Charging Committee, and their role is to look over and review completed complaint investigations and recommend discipline," she said. If the Charging Committee decides to administratively charge, they use the statewide police disciplinary matrix to "decide what kind of discipline would be necessary based on the complaint."
The five members of the Charging Committee were appointed and trained in April 2023 at the Fretterd Center by the Maryland Police Training and Standards Commission.
The third board is the Trial Board comprised of retired Maryland Circuit Court Judge Owen Wise, a citizen and a police officer of the same rank, Raeder said. No complaints have been referred to this board.
"I'm proud to say that Caroline County is leading the way for other counties on the Eastern Shore who have reached out to us regarding using Judge Wise, if they need a judge for a trial board," she said.
Few complaints filed
Among the county's municipalities, 15 complaints were filed, including a pending complaint related to an April 7, 2023, incident in Denton that prompted millions of views on YouTube, Bartlett said.
A video of the incident shows Christopher Morgan threatening the residents and breaking the window of the storm door of a home while two Denton Police officers stand on the sidewalk watching.
The way the officers handled the call for service prompted Denton Police Chief George Bacorn to request the Talbot County Sheriff's Office to investigate the handling of the incident. Their findings were turned over to the Administrative Charging Committee.
There were no complaints from Ridgely or Greensboro. One was brought to the Police Accountability Board from Federalsburg, which was exonerated, Bartlett said.
The report breaks down the 15 complaints by percentages; numerically, four complaints are pending investigation, three were administratively charged, two were withdrawn by the complainant, four were exonerated and two were "not in the purview of the ACC (Administrative Charging Committee)."
The Accountability Board identified trends in the disciplinary process and didn't "recommend any changes at this time."
"A common identified trend, however, has been the lack of activation of body cameras when officers interact with the public," the report stated. "The ACC discovered this trend when reviewing completed complaint investigations which had no body camera footage for the ACC to review. The Board advised the municipal Police Departments and the Sheriff's Office to remind Officers to adhere to department policy and activate their cameras when encountering the public. The policy protects both the Officer and the Citizen if a complaint were to arise from the interaction."
Cost to the county
Bartlett thanked the commissioners for their "financial support of the committee for legal decisions when needed."
The boards' complying with the state mandates has incurred expenses for the county, although some have been covered by the Police Accountability, Community, and Transparency Grant program.
Of the $105,272 in grant funds received, the Accountability Board has spent $49,545, which includes the purchase of IAPro software for filing complaints, annual computer licensing for all board members, and pay for the Board's administrator.
The Police Accountability Board is asking the state to continue offering these grants, as well as other police-oriented grant programs for local police departments to be able to purchase "the required technology, resources, and tools to comply with the law," including software and a change in the vendor for body cameras, so that every law enforcement agency in the county has the same system.
Other costs included outside legal counsel, with expenses the County Commissioners agreed to fund to the tune of nearly $8,000.
Questions arose requiring legal clarification for both the Police Accountability Board and Administrative Charging Committee, and the county commissioners "agreed to bear the expense of hiring outside legal counsel" to represent both. "Legal Counsel attends each quarterly meeting and provides interpretation of the Maryland Police Accountability Act of 2021 as needed," the report stated.
The legal expenses for the Police Accountability Board were $3,650, while those of the Administrative Charging Committee amounted to $4,300.
PAB recommendations
The Accountability Board recommends "changing ACC training from all in-person training to online meeting based or pre-recorded online training. With one member of our ACC board resigning this past July, we have firsthand knowledge of the burden imposed on the newly appointed volunteer Board member. As terms end or resignations occur, the pool of applicants will continue to shrink when advised that members must undergo uncompensated training prior to serving."
Another unanticipated result of the law has been the withdrawing of multiple complaints, which created a legal conundrum for the Accountability Board and is currently being resolved with the Office of the Attorney General.
The report also suggested amending the law by mandating only complaints of "matters of public concern," that is, "police misconduct, such as abuse of power, false arrest, police brutality, or criminal activity" be referred to the Charging Committee, thus alleviating pressure on municipal police departments. "Rude and discourteous" behavior towards a citizen would be handled at the department or agency level, as suggested by the Accountability Board.
To read the full report, which includes rosters of members of the PAB and ACC boards, visit carolinemd.org/DocumentCenter/View/8606/2023-Annual-Report-PAB?bidId=. The last page provides links to other documents and resources provided by the PAB.

title: Sail Selina II to set sail in St. Michaels for final season
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Sail Selina II to set sail in St. Michaels for final season

 April 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 661
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — After nearly a century on the water and more than two decades guiding passengers along the Miles River, the Sail Selina II will be sailing into retirement later this year.Following its upcoming season, which begins next week, Captain Iris Robertson will be retiring. But before it departs the Bay following the end of its season in November, Sail Selina II is going out with a bang.
The boat is joining the National Park Service's Chesapeake Gateways Network, a network of places that offer opportunities for visitors to learn about and enjoy the Chesapeake Bay.
Robertson said in the last 25 years, she estimates close to 60,000 people have stepped aboard Sail Selina II. Some of those passengers, she said, might not have gotten out on the water otherwise.
"The Bay is very fragile," Robertson said. "It's at risk right now. And (for) folks that live in Pennsylvania, (it's) out of sight, out of mind. But they're on the watershed. And Selina's just been a wonderful way for people to connect to something that they participate in even though it's not necessarily in their backyard."
On April 24, there will be a ribbon cutting ceremony at the Harbour Inn Marina in St. Michaels to welcome Sail Selina II into the Chesapeake Gateways Network for its final season. The event will include remarks from National Park Service Chesapeake Gateways Superintendent Wendy O'Sullivan.
GENERATIONS ON THE WATERAlthough Robertson, who lives in Royal Oak, has been the captain of Sail Selina II for 25 years, her history with the boat stretches back to before she was born.
In 1926, Robertson's grandfather had the boat commissioned. Her grandparents kept the boat for 36 years before passing it down to Robertson's parents in 1962. In 2001, Robertson became Sail Selina II's third steward.
"From the time I was about 12, even though I've got older siblings, everybody knew she would come to me," Robertson said. "I was the kid that was aboard, participating, had the interest."
Robertson made the decision to charter the boat so that she could afford to maintain it.
After Sail Selina II's final charter season, Robertson plans to pass the yacht down to her niece, who happens to live in Greenport, New York, where Sail Selina II was built.
"It's like a full-circle thing," Robertson said about the sailing yacht. "She's 100 years old. She's going back to the town she was built in."
Robertson said she knows her grandparents and father, who have since died, would be so proud of the boat's Chesapeake Gateways designation.
"I think they'd be tickled pink to know how much she has contributed to people's joy and experience over the last 25 years," Robertson said.
STEPPING ABOARDWith a 1,000-square-foot canvas sail, the 44-foot-long Sail Selina II is a "stable" and "regal" sailing yacht, Robertson said.
"We have a lot of guests that have never been on boats before, and they're a little bit nervous when they first step on," she said. "But by the time they get off, they go, 'Oh my God, this was like being on a flying magic carpet ride.'"
From wine and beer tasting cruises, to sunset sails, to engagement cruises, to weddings, to private sailing lessons, there are many options for those who want to set sail on Sail Selina II. Robertson said the standard two-hour tour takes passengers around St. Michaels Harbor before cruising out to the Miles River and putting up sails.
"We let the wind determine our course," Robertson said. "And before you know it, two hours has gone by."
Repeat passenger Gene Pisasale said he and his wife love sailing on Sail Selina II because they love being out on the water and they love sailing with Robertson.
"She's got to be the friendliest boat captain on the Chesapeake," said Pisasale, who lives in Pennsylvania. "And she is just a gem, a real gem. A pleasure to sail with."
To charter Sail Selina II during its last season, visit sailselina.com/ or call 410-726-9400. The season will go from April 18 through Nov. 2.

title: An Italian seafood Christmas feast
author: Marie Savage; Country Cooking
content:
An Italian seafood Christmas feast

 December 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Marie Savage; Country Cooking | Page: A5 | Section: News 
 
 1407
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Recently I attended a luncheon that featured mainly Italian dishes, and I was very impressed with both the number of dishes featured and that you could tell they were a labor of love. Especially my favorite - spaghetti and meatballs!My memory went back to my late Italian friend who served Italian Christmas dinners each year in honor of her Italian ancestry. So, I decided to do an Italian dinner this year in memory of my late friend.
In future columns I will feature others. One of the traditions my old friend's family always celebrated was The Feast of Seven Fishes or, Festa dei Sette Pesci.
A southern Italian tradition known as the "Vigilia di Natale" commemorates the wait for the midnight birth of the baby Jesus. Italian-American families around Christmas time gather together to celebrate Christmas with a huge dinner made up of seven different fish and seafood dishes coming in all different types of forms.
Italian-American immigrants - homesick for the land they left behind - combined classic Italian dishes with seafood. The sea was a representation of the connection between their home country and the new one.
The number seven stems from the biblical importance of the number and its lucky connotation. While many of these symbols are taken from Catholicism and Italian tradition, the Feast of the Seven Fishes is virtually unheard of in Italy and instead is considered an Italian-American tradition.
Baked Clams, Baccala, Mussels, Calamari and Lobster are some of the dishes you'll see being served. Here on the Eastern Shore of Maryland, we have oysters, rock fish and so many other forms of seafood native to our bays and Atlantic coast.
For a holiday so widely celebrated, the traditions surrounding Christmas are as unique as the ornaments that decorate your tree.
From decor, songs, stories and gifts, Christmas looks a little bit different in every home across the world, but the "reason for the season" never changes.
Whether you're having any of the below recipes or baking a chicken or turkey or prime rib with potatoes, the time you are spending with family and friends is the most important.
CLAMS WITH LINGUINE
Kosher salt, 12 oz linguine, 4 tbsp unsalted butter, 4 cloves garlic finely chopped, 2 tbsp chopped fresh parsley, pinch of crushed red pepper flakes, 2 dozen littleneck clams (scrubbed), 1/2 cups dry white wine, juice of 1 lemon plus wedges for serving, freshly ground black pepper.
In a large pot of boiling salted water, cook pasta, stirring occasionally, until al dente according to package directions. Drain, reserving 3/4 cup pasta cooking liquid. Meanwhile, in another large pot over medium heat, melt butter.
Add garlic, parsley and red pepper and cook, stirring, until fragrant, about 1 minute. Add clams and wine. Cover pot with a tight-fitting lid and cook until clam shells open, 7 to 10 minutes. (Discard any unopened clams.) Add lemon juice, linguine and 1/4 cup pasta water, tossing frequently and adding more pasta water if needed, until glossy and warmed through, about 2 minutes; season with salt and black pepper. Divide pasta among bowls. Serve with lemon wedges alongside.
BACON WRAPPED SCALLOPS
1 lb. dry sea scallops (about 14), Kosher salt, freshly ground black pepper, 8 oz bacon (about 7 strips, not thick-cut), 2 tbsp. unsalted butter, 1 clove garlic (smashed), 1 tbsp. fresh thyme leaves, lemon wedges for serving.
Preheat the oven to 425 degrees. Line a rimmed baking sheet with foil. Pat scallops dry with paper towels; season with 1/2 teaspoon salt and 1/4 teaspoon pepper. Cut bacon slices in half crosswise so you get 3-to 4-inch long strips. Wrap bacon around scallops and secure with a toothpick. Arrange scallops on a prepared sheet. In a small skillet over medium heat, melt butter. Add garlic and thyme leaves and cook, stirring, until fragrant, about 1 minute. Spoon butter and thyme over scallops, leaving garlic in the pan. Roast scallops until bacon is crisp and scallops are cooked through, 15 to 20 minutes. Remove toothpicks.
Transfer scallops to a platter and serve warm with lemon wedges alongside.
MUSSELS WITH TOMATO AND GARLIC
2 tbsp. butter, 1 onion chopped, 3 cloves garlic minced, 1 15-oz. can diced tomatoes, 1/2 cup dry white wine, 2 tbsp. freshly chopped parsley, kosher salt, freshly ground black pepper, 2 lb. mussels (scrubbed and debearded).
In a pot over medium-low heat, melt butter. Add onion and cook until fragrant and soft, 5 minutes, then add garlic and cook until fragrant, 1 minute more. Add diced tomatoes, wine and parsley and stir until combined. Season with salt and pepper. Add mussels and simmer until all shells are open. Discard any shells that aren't open.
Garnish with more parsley and serve with a hard bread such as sour dough.
OYSTERS ROCKEFELLER
2 cloves garlic, 1 cup tightly packed fresh spinach, 1/2 cup roughly chopped green onions, 1/2 cup roughly chopped parsley, leaves and stems, 2 tsp. lemon juice, 1/2 cup (1 stick) butter softened, 3/4 cup Panko bread crumbs, 1/4 cup freshly grated Parmesan, 1 tbsp. extra-virgin olive oil, 1 lb. coarse salt, 24 fresh oysters (shucked, shells reserved), lemon wedges for serving. Position rack in top third of oven and preheat to 450 degrees. Add garlic, spinach, green onions, parsley, lemon juice, butter and Pernod to a food processor and pulse until finely chopped. In a medium bowl combine, panko, Parmesan and oil. Sprinkle coarse salt over a large baking sheet to a depth of 1/2".
Arrange oysters in half shells in salt. Divide spinach mixture among oysters and sprinkle with Parmesan mixture. Bake until the spinach mixture is bubbling and the Panko is deeply golden, about 8 minutes. Serve with lemon wedges alongside.
GARLIC LEMON MAHI MAHI
3 tbsp. unsalted butter divided, 2 tbsp. extra-virgin olive oil divided, 4 (4-oz.) mahi mahi fillets, kosher salt, freshly ground black pepper, 1 lb. asparagus trimmed, 3 cloves garlic finely chopped, 1/4 tsp. crushed red pepper flakes, 2 lemons (1 sliced, 1 zested and juiced), 1 tbsp. chopped fresh parsley plus more for serving. In a large skillet over medium heat, heat 1 tablespoon butter and 1 tablespoon oil until butter is melted. Add mahi mahi; season with salt and black pepper. Cook, turning occasionally, until golden on both sides, 4 to 5 minutes per side. Transfer to a plate. In the same skillet over medium-high heat, heat the remaining 1 tablespoon oil. Add asparagus and cook, tossing occasionally, until tender, 2 to 4 minutes; season with salt and black pepper. Transfer to a plate with fish. SteIn same skillet over medium heat, melt remaining 2 tablespoons butter. Add garlic and red pepper flakes and cook, stirring occasionally, until fragrant, about 1 minute, then stir in lemon slices, zest, and juice, and parsley.
Remove from heat. Return mahi mahi and asparagus to the skillet and spoon sauce over. Top with parsley before serving.
BAKED COD
4 cod filets (about 1" thick), Kosher salt, freshly ground black pepper, 4 tbsp. extra-virgin olive oil, 1 cup cherry tomatoes, 1 lemon, 2 garlic cloves (smashed but not peeled), 2 sprigs thyme, 2 tbsp. freshly chopped parsley. Preheat the oven to 400 degrees and pat cod filets with a paper towel until dry. Season all over with salt and pepper. Combine olive oil, cherry tomatoes, lemon slices, garlic, and thyme in a 9 by 13 inch baking dish.
Toss to coat and spread into an even layer. Nestle cod pieces into a baking dish.
Bake until fish is opaque and flakes easily with a fork, 15 to 20 minutes, depending on thickness of filets. Serve garnished with parsley, more lemon juice, and pan sauce.
GARLIC PARMESAN FLOUNDER
1/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil, 4 fillets flounder, Kosher salt, freshly ground black pepper, 1/2 cup freshly grated parmesan, 1/4 cup bread crumbs, 4 cloves garlic (minced), juice and zest of 1 lemon, fresh chopped parsley for garnish. Preheat the oven to 425 degrees. Drizzle 2 tablespoons of oil on a large baking sheet. Season flounder with salt and pepper.
On a large plate, combine parmesan, bread crumbs, garlic and lemon zest. Season with salt and pepper.
Dredge fish in bread crumb mixture, pressing to coat.
Place fish on a prepared baking sheet and drizzle with remaining 2 tablespoons of oil and lemon juice. Bake until golden and fish flakes easily with a fork, 20 minutes. Squeeze a bit more lemon on top and garnish with chopped parsley.
I wish each and every one of you a safe, warm and blessed holiday with family and friends.

title: TODAY IN HISTORY/Sept. 3
author: Staff Writer
content:
TODAY IN HISTORY/Sept. 3

 September 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Columns 
 
 322
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On Sept. 3, 1783, representatives of the United States and Britain signed the Treaty of Paris, which officially ended the Revolutionary War and recognized U.S. sovereignty.Also on this date:
In 1861, during the Civil War, Confederate forces invaded the border state of Kentucky, which had declared its neutrality in the conflict.
In 1894, the United States celebrated the first federal Labor Day holiday.
In 1935, Sir Malcolm Campbell became the first person to drive an automobile more than 300 miles-per-hour, speeding across the Bonneville Salt Flats in Utah.
In 1939, Britain, France, Australia and New Zealand declared war on Germany, two days after the Nazi invasion of Poland; in a radio address, Britain's King George VI said, "With God's help, we shall prevail."
In 1943, Allied forces invaded Italy during World War II, the same day Italian officials signed a secret armistice with the Allies.
In 1976, America's Viking 2 lander touched down on Mars to take the first close-up, color photographs of the red planet's surface.
In 1999, a French judge closed a two-year inquiry into the car crash that killed Princess Diana, dismissing all charges against nine photographers and a press motorcyclist, and concluding the accident was caused by an inebriated driver.
In 2019, Walmart said it would stop selling ammunition for handguns and short-barrel rifles, and the store chain requested that customers not openly carry firearms in its stores; the announcement followed a shooting at a Walmart store in Texas that left 22 people dead.
Today's Birthdays: Singer-musician Al Jardine (The Beach Boys) is 81. Actor Valerie Perrine is 81. Filmmaker Jean-Pierre Jeunet is 71. Rock guitarist Steve Jones (The Sex Pistols) is 69. title: MDOT updates Caroline leaders on project plans - Officials outline six year draft budget, provide key project updates
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
MDOT updates Caroline leaders on project plans - Officials outline six year draft budget, provide key project updates

 October 11, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 1A | Section: News 
 
 988
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - Maryland Transportation Secretary Paul J. Wiedefeld and other representatives of the Maryland Department of Transportation met Tuesday, Oct. 3, with Caroline County officials to discuss the department's six-year draft FY 2024-2029 Consolidated Transportation Program.The spending plan "calls for a $21.2 billion, six-year investment to create a safer, cleaner, efficient and accessible transportation system connecting Marylanders to jobs, schools, recreation, health care and essential services," according to a MDOT press release."Delivering safe, reliable, equitable and sustainable transportation is critical to Maryland's economic health and the vibrancy of neighborhoods across the state. This draft CTP is inspired by that mission," Wiedefeld said."We know there are challenges ahead, and we are committed to fiscal responsibility and collaboration with local communities, stakeholders and elected officials as we deliver the transportation network Marylanders need and deserve," he said.In addition to Wiedefeld, officials attending included State Highway Deputy Administrator for Project Development Matt Baker; Motor Vehicle Administrator Chrissy Nizer; Maryland Transportation Authority Planning and Program Development Director Melissa Williams; Maryland Transit Administration Local Transit Support Director Travis Johnston; Maryland Aviation Administration Regional Aviation Director Ashish Solanki; and District 2 Engineer Ken Fender.At the meeting, transportation officials offered details and updates of several projects and programs affecting Caroline County.Baker said the agency is planning for potential improvements along three miles of state Route 404 from Harmony Road to Greenwood Road. A study looking at pedestrian and bicyclist safety improvements and traffic operations, as well as truck and agricultural traffic, is anticipated to be completed in spring 2024. An in-person open house meeting planned for this fall. In addition, a public survey to gather feedback on the study is available at mdot-sha-md404-harmony-rd-to-greenwood-rdco219b11-maryland.hub.arcgis.com/Baker said the State Highway Administration will advertise a $1 million contract for improvements at the state Routes 404 and 328 intersection, which will add turn lanes for safer traffic flow.Some interim improvements have been made to help reduce intersection conflicts and improve traffic flow during peak school bus times.Transportation officials noted other allocations for Caroline County in the draft CTP, including more than $1.1 million in operating and capital grants to support local transit operations provided by Delmarva Community Transit. In addition, Delmarva Community Service will receive a $123,000 Statewide Transit Innovation Grant to install a propane station for propane-powered vehicles, enabling Delmarva Community Transit to transition to a low-emission fleet.As "a charter member of the Ken Fender Fan Club," Caroline County Commission Vice President Larry Porter thanked the District 2 engineer for his responsiveness, especially with improving traffic flow at the Goldsboro Volunteer Fire Company and traffic light timing at the intersection of River Road (State Route 328) and State Route 404, calling the latter a "tremendous benefit." Porter cited concerns with highway user funds being slashed to $400,00 from a high of $4 million, and a proposed mileage tax for electric vehicles.Wiedefeld said addressing changes in policy affecting EVs "is a challenge that's coming at us. We don't have any answers yet." Caroline County Commission President Travis Breeding brought up the "four old timber bridges that were built in the '30s and '40s that are on our list that need to be replaced." Breeding said someone from MDOT "actually reached out to us to start the conversation about potentially pursuing some federal funding because these bridges are probably a million dollars or better a piece to replace, and that would just be too large of a hit on our (county)." Commissioner Frank Bartz thanked the State Highway Administration for repaving Route 578 between Harmony and Bethlehem but expressed concerns about future traffic detours when the Williston bridge is eventually replaced on state Route 16.Other concerns brought up by the commissioners were the long transport times for emergency services and the effectiveness of DCT's fixed routes versus a mobility-on-demand model.The draft CTP includes funding to maintain existing transportation facilities, expand transit opportunities, invest in Maryland's economic growth and support the state's long-term goals for mobility, safety, equity, environmental stewardship and economic growth.The program allocates funding for electric vehicle infrastructure, as well as investment in the transition to zero-emission transit buses and other carbon reduction and resiliency programs, "establishing Maryland as national leader in addressing climate goals," the press release stated.The program includes funding to promote Transit-Oriented Development to spur economic growth in transit corridors, and for projects to support Complete Streets - an initiative to make Maryland's roadways safer and more accessible for all users, and help reduce the number of roadway fatalities and injuries.The program outlines investments in each mode funded by the Transportation Trust Fund: Maryland Aviation Administration, Maryland Port Administration, Maryland Transit Administration, Motor Vehicle Administration, State Highway Administration and The Secretary's Office, as well as Maryland's investment in the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority.The plan includes an additional $2.7 billion investment planned by the Maryland Transportation Authority. Receiving no funds from the Transportation Trust Fund, the Maryland Transportation Authority's toll facilities are fully financed, constructed, operated, maintained, improved and protected with toll revenues paid by customers using those facilities.Motor Vehicle Administrator Nizer discussed the state's Vision Zero initiative - the goal of achieving zero fatalities on Maryland roadways. She noted that jurisdictions and organizations are encouraged to apply for safety grants through the Maryland Highway Safety Office to use for enforcement and education efforts.The Caroline County meeting was part of the Maryland Department of Transportation's tour of all 23 Maryland counties and Baltimore City to discuss the funding plan and receive input from local officials and the public. The tour continues into November.Following the tour, the draft fiscal year 2024-2029 Consolidated Transportation Program will be finalized and submitted in January for consideration during the 2024 General Assembly session.To view the full the program, visit ctp.maryland.gov.
