title: For All Seasons gives update on human trafficking in Talbot County
author: Konner Metz
content:
For All Seasons gives update on human trafficking in Talbot County

 January 31, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 421
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Representatives from For All Seasons say the problem of human trafficking in Talbot County is persisting, though they are seeing positive gains in awareness and detection.During a Talbot County Council meeting Tuesday, Lauren Weber, the nonprofit's vice president of strategy and development, provided an update to council members regarding human and labor trafficking.
"It is happening and it's happening here. That continues to be the case," Weber said. " … There's a complexity to human trafficking that it doesn't really know county boundaries."
Weber and Katie Theeke, vice president of marketing and communications, each said the organization has a special role given its wide reach. For All Seasons' presence in the five Mid-Shore counties — Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot — is critical to providing victims with essential services.
"We know that human trafficking knows no boundaries and that it affects people of different backgrounds, races, genders," Theeke said. "We have seen several cases come through our doors, and it comes from Talbot County. It comes from neighboring counties. We really aim to be the connector to get those people the help that they need."
Council Member Keasha Haythe asked if For All Seasons is seeing a decline in human trafficking numbers. Weber said it's a "double-edged sword."
"A year ago we sat in front of you and said, when we look at our rape crisis center data, a good fifth of what was coming in was having at least one indicator of human trafficking," Weber said. " … That persists."
The organization has noticed a shift in how many people are recognizing signs of human trafficking and making those reports, Weber says.
"The folks that are self-referring, we're seeing a decline," she said. "But we're seeing a real rapid incline in folks coming to us and saying, 'Hey, I know more and now I've seen something.'"
Weber said that since September, more than 120 people have taken For All Seasons' free, online anti-human trafficking course.
For All Seasons is an official regional navigator for the Mid-Shore area, Theeke said, meaning it works on task forces and serves youth and young adults that are victims of trafficking.
At the end of the discussion, council members thanked the For All Seasons representatives for their work and presented the organization with a proclamation Tuesday declaring January as National Human Trafficking Awareness Month.
"We know that even one victim is too many," council Vice President Pete Lesher said. "We appreciate all that you do both on prevention, but also to develop and take care of those who have been victims."

title: How ARPA funds shaped Maryland’s Mid-Shore
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
How ARPA funds shaped Maryland’s Mid-Shore

 March 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 884
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Delegate Jay Jacobs, who represents Maryland's District 36 — encompassing Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil and Caroline counties — has seen the region through economic peaks and valleys. But the COVID-19 pandemic presented a crisis unlike any other.At the same time, it brought a rare opportunity.
Through the American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA), Maryland received $3.7 billion in federal relief funds. Jacobs estimated that roughly $88 million of that flowed into his district over the past five years.
"The money gave counties and municipalities a chance to get things done when they normally might not have had that opportunity," Jacobs said.
Across the district, more than 200 projects were funded through ARPA, aimed at bolstering local infrastructure, supporting nonprofits and modernizing essential services.
Rock Hall to Queen Anne's: Local Needs, Local SolutionsEach town took a unique approach, reflecting ARPA's flexible framework.
In Rock Hall, the town's aging wastewater system was a priority. Mayor James Cook said of the $1.3 million received, $300,000 went toward replacing the headworks at the sewer plant — a key filter that removes debris such as grease and rags from wastewater.
Chestertown formed a task force led by Ward 2 Council member Tom Herz to ensure transparency and community input. Of the $4.25 million allocated, local nonprofits were invited to align funding requests with the town's comprehensive plan.
In Galena, $570,000 supported road improvements designed to make parks more accessible and attract visitors.
Betterton directed its $311,000 toward modernizing its website to be ADA-compliant, enabling online payments, purchasing an air purifying unit, and upgrading pump stations with generators for resilience.
Millington received $504,821, though specific projects were not detailed.
Queen Anne's County saw one of the largest allocations: $16.3 million. Projects included installing 3,300 feet of water line at the Old Towne Shopping Center, investing $900,000 to upgrade affordable housing units, and expanding broadband access with $1.5 million. Six new consoles were also added to the county's 911 backup center, and cell phone boosters were installed in public schools to strengthen communication in rural areas.
Countywide Efforts and Broadband ExpansionIn Cecil County, where municipalities received a greater share of ARPA funds than the county itself, a major initiative focused on expanding high-speed internet. A $16.2 million broadband project combined $12.8 million in state funds, $2.5 million from internet service providers, and $900,000 in ARPA funds contributed by the county.
According to county officials, additional ARPA investments went toward two emergency medical services paramedic stations and a new training center for the Cecil County Sheriff's Office.
Rising Sun used $2,300 for infrastructure repairs, while the Town of North East applied its share to enhance police department operations.
In Caroline County, which received just under $6.5 million, part of the funding was used for infrastructure, while a portion supported reentry programs and post-release case management for individuals leaving the Ordnance Road Detention Facility.
Jacobs noted that ARPA's flexibility was one of its most valuable aspects.
"It was not one size fits all," he said. "Municipalities could use the money to meet their specific needs — with the only caveat being it must be spent by Dec. 31, 2026."
As ARPA Winds Down, Financial Pressure MountsNow, with the funding window closing, local governments are bracing for its absence. Jacobs said the drying up of ARPA funds is intensifying pressure on the state as the General Assembly works to pass the FY 2026 budget — which currently faces a $3.5 billion shortfall.
"Certain services were being relied on and now are cut off," Jacobs said. "ARPA funds possibly would have kept some of these programs afloat."
A notable cut is the reduction in senior care funding by the Maryland Department of Aging. Jacobs said the proposed $2.5 million budget — an 18% reduction — could translate to about $28,000 less per county. He warned this could destabilize staffing and services for vulnerable seniors, such as in-home care, transportation and meal delivery.
"These cuts will be felt, not by the lawmakers, but by ordinary hardworking folks who have to make decisions about affording food or putting gas in the car," he said.
Talbot County: Planning for LongevityTalbot County took a strategic approach. Officials distributed surveys to identify community priorities, which included broadband access, public health, and household assistance.
According to Cassandra Vanhooser, director of Talbot County Economic Development and Tourism, the county received about $7.2 million in ARPA funds. The goal, she said, was to ensure that projects wouldn't falter once federal dollars were gone.
"These are largely capital items, these are one-time items... a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity," said then Talbot County Council Vice President Pete Lesher. "We need to be very careful about how this is done."
Among Talbot's allocations:
- $1.75 million to Easton Utilities' Connect Talbot project to expand broadband to rural residents.
- $105,000 to the Chesapeake Center in Easton to replace a failing septic system and connect to county sewer.
- $500,000 in grants for volunteer fire company equipment upgrades.
"People recognize that this is transformational money," Vanhooser said at the time of the funding discussion, "It's a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to be a driving force for change and to impact the lives of our citizens."
Looking AheadAs the Dec. 31, 2024 obligation deadline nears, and the Dec. 31, 2026 expenditure deadline looms, local leaders are focused on maximizing remaining funds while grappling with what comes next.
Jacobs is urging urgency from lawmakers.
"With less than 20 days in session," he said, "the Assembly needs to come up with solutions — and fast."

 EASTON - The Mid-Shore Board of Realtors gave a heart-warming farewell to its outgoing president while recognizing new leadership and the achievements of its members this past year.Megan Rosendale ended her term as president of MSBR at the Oct. 26 ceremony held at Pintail Point in Queenstown, with Shelby Roney taking up the leadership role for 2024.Members who were honored at the event included Rookie Realtor of the Year Janet Powers and Shandell Green, who received the President's award for her contributions to the association.Chuck Mangold, Jr. was presented with the Community Service Award, and Kari Anderson with Oceans Lending was named the affiliate of the year.Both Annie Raymond and Shandell Green were recognized with the Diversity, Equity and Inclusion Award for their roles in overseeing the Understanding Through Diversity Summit.The Realtor of the Year award went to Laura Anderson of Coldwell Banker Realty, a past MSBR president.Anderson also received citations from Sen. Johnny Mautz and Gov. Wes Moore.Chris Hill, president of Maryland Realtors, installed the directors. Debbie Leber, association executive director, installed Shelby Roney as the newly elected Mid-Shore Board of Realtors president.Roney is with Benson and Mangold and has over 20 years of experience in real estate. She noted she feels a deep sense of purpose for the position of president and the real estate industry.Roney said changes, transitions and setbacks are all natural parts of any industry, and real estate is no different.She plans to focus on education and providing the members with quality programs that will enhance their skills to meet future challenges. Community service is also important, and Roney said Mid-Shore Board of Realtors will continue to support programs and causes in Caroline, Dorchester and Talbot counties.Outgoing president Megan Rosendale thanked those who helped her this past year and noted how this role helped her grow both personally and professionally.Rosendale said starting the Down Payment Grant was a highlight of her year. With 13 grants awarded already this year, she said she appreciated everyone who has helped with this program.The Mid-Shore Board of Realtors 2023-2024 executive committee is Shelby Roney, MSBR president with Benson and Mangold; Megan Rosendale, MSBR immediate past president with Rosendale Realty; Michelle Abplanalp, MSBR president-elect with Rosendale Realty; Shandell Green, MSBR secretary with Douglas Realty; and Trey Quinn, MSBR treasurer with Fidelity First Home Mortgage.The Mid-Shore Board of Realtors 2023-2024 directors include: Andy Beaven with Wright Real Estate; Kathleen Brenton with Brenton Realty Group; Jenn Dudley with Title Excellence; Samantha Grimes with Chesapeake Real Estate Associates; Mary Mabry with Keller Williams Select; Petra Quinn with Realty Navigator and Randy Staats with Benson and Mangold.The Mid-Shore Board of Realtors mission is to advocate for its members and the public to preserve the right to own, transfer and utilize real property.For more news and information on the grant program, visit midshoreboardofrealtors.com.

TODAY IN HISTORY/May 24

 May 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Columns 
 
 411
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On May 24, 1935, the first Major League Baseball game to be played at night took place at Cincinnati's Crosley Field as the Reds beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 2-1.On this date:
In 1844, Samuel F.B. Morse transmitted the message "What hath God wrought" from Washington to Baltimore as he formally opened America's first telegraph line.
In 1937, in a set of rulings, the U.S. Supreme Court upheld the constitutionality of the Social Security Act of 1935.
In 1941, the German battleship Bismarck sank the British battle cruiser HMS Hood in the North Atlantic, killing all but three of the 1,418 men on board.
In 1961, a group of Freedom Riders was arrested after arriving at a bus terminal in Jackson, Mississippi, charged with breaching the peace for entering white-designated areas. (They ended up serving 60 days in jail.)
In 1962, astronaut Scott Carpenter became the second American to orbit the Earth as he flew aboard Aurora 7.
In 1974, American jazz composer and bandleader Duke Ellington, 75, died in New York.
In 1976, Britain and France opened trans-Atlantic Concorde supersonic transport service to Washington.
In 1980, Iran rejected a call by the World Court in The Hague to release the American hostages.
In 1994, four Islamic fundamentalists convicted of bombing New York's World Trade Center in 1993 were each sentenced to 240 years in prison.
In 1995, former British Prime Minister Harold Wilson died in London at age 79.
In 2006, "An Inconvenient Truth," a documentary about former Vice President Al Gore's campaign against global warming, went into limited release.
In 2011, Oprah Winfrey taped the final episode of her long-running talk show.
In 2017, Ariana Grande suspended her Dangerous Woman world tour and canceled several European shows due to the deadly bombing at her concert in Manchester, England, two days earlier.
In 2018, Jerry Maren, the last surviving Munchkin from the 1939 film "The Wizard of Oz," died at a San Diego nursing home; he was 99.
In 2022, an 18-year-old gunman opened fire at an elementary school in Uvalde, Texas, killing 19 children and two teachers. The gunman, Salvador Ramos, a former student at the school, was also killed. title: The Oxford Museum celebrates 60 years with '60s theme
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
The Oxford Museum celebrates 60 years with '60s theme

 June 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 537
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD — Wanda Whedbee knows her father would have been so proud to witness The Oxford Museum's 60th birthday party on Saturday.Whedbee's father, Lee Willey founded the museum in 1964. Whedbee said that six years later, Willey died of a heart attack, and so he didn't get to see the museum's growth over the years.
"I think it's amazing how it's grown," she said. "And the reason it has grown like this is because of the people that moved (into) town. And so many of them have taken an interest in it and worked so hard to keep it going."
For many years, Whedbee was a docent at the museum. When people would come in, she said she would point to the museum's first pieces — glassware and pottery that her father excavated from the grounds of the old Maryland Military and Naval Academy in town — and tell them about the museum's humble beginnings.
"And I would say, 'Look around. And if you really work hard, that's what you can accomplish,'" she said.
Saturday afternoon, community members had the opportunity to celebrate that growth — and another year around the sun for the museum — with the museum's current exhibit, "Oxford 1964: The Times They Were A-Changin,'" and cake and ice cream.
Terrie and Barry Smale, who haven't been to the museum in a decade, were blown away when they returned Saturday. They said it has transformed since their last visit.
Terrie's favorite part of the current exhibit was the 1960s area in the back corner of the museum, which was complete with vinyl records, a TV from the '60s and a rotary dial phone hanging on the wall. Terrie said she remembered having the same TV when she was growing up.
At the event, LIza Ledford and John Tochko were named winners of the Doug Hanks Jr. Oxford Preservation Award, which recognizes the efforts of people or organizations to preserve Oxford's history and heritage.
Ledford, who is the executive director of the Oxford Community Center, said the award means everything to her.
"It means the world to me to feel recognized by the public and the town, and just to feel that people are appreciating the stuff we're putting out there," she said.
Ledford has been with the community center for seven years. She said she feels lucky that what she loves to do every day is getting appreciated by the community.
"Thank you to everyone who was part of making this happen," she said. "And I share it with everybody who's part of the Oxford Community Center."
Tochko, who could not be in attendance Saturday, has been chairman of the Museum Building Committee for the last few years. When the winners were announced, Tochko was praised for his "quiet" support of different local organizations over the years and his involvement with the community center.
Because of the high temperatures outside, the museum's birthday party was held inside the museum Saturday afternoon. The Oxford Museum Executive Director Julie Wells said she knew the event would be crowded if it was held inside the museum.
"But we like being with each other," she said, later adding, "This is such a happy event."
The Oxford Museum is open from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. on Fridays through Mondays. Admission is free.

title: Spurry's big night pace Talbot in opener

Spurry's big night pace Talbot in opener

 June 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 546
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Nathan Spurry was in a closer's role this spring for St. Michaels High's baseball team.Tuesday night he showed he's a pretty fair starter as well.
Spurry hurled a complete game and drove in Nico Nicolopoulos with the winning run in the bottom of the sixth inning, lifting Talbot Post 70 to a 4-3 victory over four-time defending Eastern Shore North Division American Legion champion Caroline Post 29 at Warrior Field.
"Just came out here trying to throw strikes; trying to produce ground balls, get outs," Spurry said.
Mixing a cutter with fastballs, Spurry allowed only two runners to reach base over the first three innings — one on an error, the other on a fielder's choice in the second inning.
Down 3-0, Caroline (0-1-1) scratched across a pair of runs in the fourth. Austin Frank drilled a leadoff double to center field. Colton Maans walked and was lifted for courtesy runner Wes Thomas. Eric Deck (2 for 3) singled to center, scoring Frank. Gavin Whitby (2 for 3) singled to load the bases before Johnny Radcliff grounded out, scoring Thomas to make it 3-2
But Spurry ended the threat there, getting a strikeout before catcher Nicolopolous alertly grabbed a ball that was chopped in front of the plate and tagged Caleb Cole for an inning-ending, unassisted putout.
Caroline rallied to pull even in the top of the sixth on Whitby's one-out RBI single. Again, Spurry escaped any further damage, retiring two of the next three batters to keep it at 3-3 heading into the home half of the sixth.
"Threw strikes," Talbot manager Albert Pritchett said of Spurry, who finished with four strikeouts and two walks. "Got ahead of every batter, mixed it up. Very impressive."
Talbot (1-0) took a 1-0 lead in the home first. Frank issued back-to-back walks to Gavin Murphy and Couper Barletta. Two batters later, Pearson Greenwood laced a double to right field, plating Murphy. Frank squelched the rally there, getting Ethan Royer to pop out and Jesus Crespo on a comebacker to the mound.
Post 70 pushed its lead to 2-0 in the second. Brennen Griffin (2 for 2) hit a leadoff single and Nathan Merchant walked. Spurry then hit an 0-2 offering into left-center field for a double that scored Griffin. Again Frank extinguished a potential big rally, striking out the next three straight batters.
Talbot made it 3-0 in the third, as Tim McGuckin worked a leadoff walk, stole second, advanced to third on Greenwood's groundout to first, and scored when Crespo singled sharply to left field.
Caroline pulled even in the sixth before Talbot moved back in front in the home sixth. Nicolopoulos worked a leadoff walk against Post 29 reliever Chase Hitchens then stole second. Hitchens came off the mound to catch Brody McDaniel's bunt attempt for the first out. Nicolopoulos advanced to third on an errant pickoff attempt. Spurry then grounded out deep in the hole at shortstop, allowing Nicolopolous to score what proved to be the winning run.
"Knocked in the winning run for himself," Pritchett said of Spurry. "Nice game.
"First game, little rusty," said Pritchett, who was without Cullen Murphy, Josh Dressler and Anthony Massaro Tuesday. "Some of the guys haven't played since high school (season ended). We could have had a few more runs, but I think the hitting will come around."

content:
Evergreen Fresh - Cawley Tree Farm offers variety of fresh trees, greens

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 15 | Section: News

 DENTON - They've been farming west of Denton more than 100 years, and for over a quarter of that century, Cawley Family Farm has branched out to become the only Christmas tree farm in Caroline County.On the Saturday after Thanksgiving, a steady stream of families rolled up the lane of the farm, past the festively decorated John Deere combine, past the Cawley family home and past a huge pavilion housing cut evergreen trees from North Carolina."It's a beautiful day," said owner Charles Cawley." It's going good. We've got good trees. I got some beautiful trees - a little pricier than last year but still beautiful trees - got a lot on the lot, as you can see. The Canaans are going out of here like crazy." In addition to Canaan firs, Cawley grows Concolor and Douglas firs, blue spruce and white pine - all on about 15 acres of the farm."We can't grow Frasers, so we bring them in," Cawley said."But we're the only one that brings in a tree, recuts it and puts it in holding tanks. No one else does that. So we sell the freshest pre-cut trees you can buy." "They're very hard to get, but we've got some beautiful Frasers," he said.Cawley said it took him a while, but he "got to how to grow" Canaan firs about 15 years ago.He pampers them, irrigating, spoon-feeding and growing them in "real thick grass. It helps keep the roots cooler because it gets too hot here," he said.According to the National Christmas Tree Association, the Canaan fir is a "relative newcomer to the Christmas tree market, with many similarities to both Fraser and balsam firs." About 500 to 600 trees are brought in from North Carolina."We sold about 200 off the lot, so we're selling between 700 and 800 a year," Cawley said.Keeping the trees fresh is important to Cawley. "When we sell one of these (Frasers) they'll hold the needles as long as one of those out in the field," he said. "And these things drink a lot of water initially. I mean, we just got these the day before Thanksgiving, and I had to fill these tanks up a couple times, they soaked up that much water." Once the trees are rehydrated, they are shaken, drilled with a tapered bit, set up on a pin stand in a shallow steel basin and kept watered. The operation has two drilling machines, three shakers and plenty of water holding bins inside and outdoors.The 55-foot by 80-foot pavilion can be closed off when the wind whips up to keep the trees from dehydrating. "If we had to add a little heat, we can, but we haven't had to," he said.Cawley clearly takes pride in his product, and his family pitches in. Arriving at 7 a.m. was his 7-year-old grandson Bryant, ready to get started - and put in a 12-hour day.Cawley's eldest daughter, Amy, makes wreaths and wood-burned ornaments from slices of sawed off stumps. The focus is on customer service, so other family members, as well as employees, wait on customers, shake needles from trees, wrap net around them and tote them to cars.Cawley is vice president of the Maryland Christmas Tree Association. He said he started out as a farmer, "but I did a lot of things in the meantime," even working for "all three levels of government - county, state and federal. You don't build this by just farming. It takes something else," Cawley said, adding that his wife Jane is a retired school nurse.Several years of drought, along with root aphids in the Douglass firs and scale on some Canaans, have affected the growth and aesthetics of a few trees in the field, so Cawley has to be vigilant."There's a challenge every year," he said.Cawley Family Farm Christmas tree sales began Nov. 21.You can visit 10 a.m. to 7 p.m.Friday, Saturday and Sunday, and on Monday to Thursday by appointment. The farm is located at 24320 Willow Pond Road, Denton. For more information, call 410-479-4780 or 410-829-4781, or email info@cawley.farm. The website is www.cawleyfarms.com.

title: Country Cooking: Shrimp, an Eastern Shore tradition
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Country Cooking: Shrimp, an Eastern Shore tradition

 July 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1529
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Growing up on the farm, surrounded by the Atlantic Ocean and Chesapeake Bay as well as the many rivers, we ate many types of seafood, but shrimp was not my favorite dish.Shrimp has a long history in the Delmarva region, particularly in the Chesapeake Bay and its estuaries. While not typically fished with a large-scale commercial harvest due to gear restrictions like the beam trawl ban, shrimp populations have been present and studied for decades. Recent observations suggest increasing shrimp populations in the area, possibly due to factors like warming waters.
Shrimp have always been found around the Chesapeake Bay, which is replete with the marshy, muddy habitat they love. Shrimp like to bury in sediment and can be found in both the Bay and its river estuaries, from shallow to deep water. Around the last week of October each year, a sudden drop in temperature drives the shrimp to funnel out of the Bay and into the southern Atlantic, where the water is a little warmer.
The shrimping industry is most popular in the Gulf states of Louisiana, Alabama, Florida and Texas. In the last five years, shrimp sales volume increased from 275 million pounds to 415 million. The percentage of households buying fish has also increased from 44.2% to 48.6%. This growth is seen in all areas of the country.
Shrimp is an excellent, affordable meal option for families. Shrimp can be enjoyed as an appetizer, snack, main course or side dish. Shrimp is a great addition to many popular favorites as it's easy to toss some shrimp into a creamy pasta or grill up some prawns to top your preferred cut of steak.
In later years, I discovered shrimp and became a "shrimp lover." My parents really didn't care for shrimp, so therefore when I became a cook in my own kitchen, I ventured into exploring many different foods. The same happens generation after generation, introductions to different foods.
JUMBO STEAMED SHRIMP
1/2 cup vinegar, 1 tbsp Old Bay seasoning, 3/4 cup water, 1 tsp salt, 1 1/2 lbs jumbo shrimp.
In a medium sized saucepan combine vinegar, Old Bay, water and salt. Bring these ingredients to a boil. Add shrimp. Stir gently to coat the shrimp in the liquid. Cover and steam for 5 to 6 minutes or until tender. Drain and serve.
SHRIMP AND RICE
1/4 cup butter, 1/4 cup chopped onion, 1/4 cup chopped green pepper, 3 tbsps flour, small can tomato sauce, 1 cup water, 1/2 tsp hot sauce, 1 1.2 lbs pre-cooked shrimp, rice.
Melt butter, add onion and green pepper, mix well with the butter. Mix in flour, stirring until bubbly. Add tomato sauce, water and hot sauce. Cook slowly for about 10 minutes. Add shrimp and cook slowly for another 10-15 minutes. Serve over cooked rice.
SHRIMP SCAMPI
1 1/2 cups olive oil, 1/4 cup lemon juice, 4 crushed garlic cloves, 1 tsp salt, 1 tsp black pepper, 4 lbs raw shrimp (shelled and deveined).
In a large skillet, place olive oil, lemon juice, garlic cloves, salt, and pepper. Heat thoroughly and add shrimp. Stir well and cook until the shrimp are pink. Serve with rice.
SHRIMP STIR FRY
2 tbsps extra-virgin olive oil, 1 lb shrimp (peeled and deveined), Kosher salt, freshly ground black pepper, 1 tbsp sesame oil, 1 small head of broccoli (cut into small florets), 1 red bell pepper (seeds and ribs removed, thinly sliced), 8 oz sugar snap peas, 3 garlic cloves (minced), 1 tbsp finely chopped peeled ginger, 1/2 cup reduced-sodium soy sauce, juice of 1 lime, 2 tbsps light brown sugar, 1 tbsp cornstarch, pinch of crushed red pepper flakes.
In a large wok or skillet over medium heat, heat olive oil. Add shrimp; season with salt and black pepper. Cook, turning halfway through, until pink, 2 to 3 minutes. Transfer shrimp to a plate. In the same skillet over medium heat, heat sesame oil. Add broccoli, bell pepper, and peas and cook, stirring and adding a splash of water if browning too quickly, until softened, about 7 minutes. Add garlic and ginger and cook, stirring, until fragrant, about 1 minute more.In a small bowl, whisk soy sauce, lime juice, brown sugar, cornstarch, and red pepper flakes. Add to the skillet and toss to coat. Add shrimp and cook, tossing frequently, until heated through, about 2 minutes.
OLD BAY SHRIMP BURRITOS
For Old Bay aioli: 1/3 cup mayonnaise, 1 1/2 tsp Sriracha, 3/4 tsp fresh lime juice, 1/2 tsp Old Bay seasoning (plus more for serving), Kosher salt. For shrimp filling: 1 tbsp extra-virgin olive oil, 1/2 yellow onion (finely chopped), 1 small green bell pepper (diced), 2 cloves garlic (thinly sliced), 1 lb small shrimp (peeled and deveined, tails removed), 1/4 tsp ground cumin, 1/4 tsp paprika, Kosher salt, freshly ground pepper. For assembling burrito: 4 large flour tortillas (warmed), 1 cup cooked long-grain white rice, 1 cup cooked black beans (rinsed and drained), 3/4 cup shredded Mexican cheese, 1 cup shredded lettuce, 1 cup pico de gallo (drained), 1 avocado (thinly sliced), 2 tbsps chopped chives (plus more for serving).
Make aioli: Whisk together mayo, Sriracha, lime juice, Old Bay, and 1 teaspoon water. Season with salt, if desired. Make shrimp filling: In a large skillet over medium-high heat, add oil, onion, bell pepper, and garlic. Cook, stirring occasionally, until lightly golden, about 2 minutes. Stir in shrimp, cumin, and paprika. Season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, until opaque and just cooked through, about 4 minutes. Assemble burritos: Lay a tortilla on a serving plate. Add 1/4 cup each of the rice and beans. Top with ¼ each of the shrimp filling, cheese, lettuce, pico de gallo, and avocado slices. Sprinkle with chives and drizzle with aioli. Roll the burrito tightly and repeat with remaining tortillas and ingredients. Slice each burrito in half and serve with more aioli, Old Bay and chives.
SWEET CORN, SHRIMP & RICE SKILLET
1/2 cup basmati rice, 1 bunch scallions (divided), 1 medium red bell pepper (chopped), 6 garlic cloves (5 roughly chopped, 1 minced), 4 tbsps white miso, 1-inch piece ginger (thinly sliced), 1 1/4 tsp turmeric powder (divided), 1 tsp Kosher salt (plus more for seasoning), 1 tsp granulated sugar (optional), 1/4 tsp ground cayenne pepper (optional), 4 tbsps extra-virgin olive oil (divided), 1/2 lb medium shrimp (peeled and cleaned), freshly ground black pepper, 3/4 cup water, 1 cup frozen corn (rinsed in warm water and drained), lime wedges for serving.
Rinse rice well, until water runs clear, then transfer to a medium bowl and cover with water. Preheat the oven to 375 degrees. Cook 5 roughly chopped garlic cloves and ginger in a pan for around 1 minute. Remove roots and ends from 4 green onions and roughly chop into pieces. Add chopped scallions to blender or food processor, along with the bell pepper, garlic cloves, miso, ginger, 1 teaspoon turmeric, salt, and sugar and cayenne if using. Blend until all ingredients are finely chopped and thoroughly mixed, then slowly drizzle in 3 tablespoons olive oil while running the food processor or blender. Blend until mixture is smooth. Pat shrimp dry and transfer to a medium bowl. Add remaining turmeric and minced garlic clove, and season with salt and pepper. Heat remaining tablespoon of oil in a 12-inch oven safe skillet over medium heat. Add shrimp and cook until opaque, 2 to 3 minutes per side. Remove cooked shrimp into a bowl just big enough to fit and cover with a plate to keep warm. Return the skillet to heat and add prepared puree. Cook on medium-high heat, stirring frequently, until the liquid has cooked out and paste has darkened, 8 to 10 minutes. (You'll know it's done when the oil starts to separate from the paste! Reduce heat to medium and whisk in water until smooth. Strain rice, and add rice and corn. Drain any cooking juices from the shrimp into the skillet, using the plate to keep the shrimp from falling in. (Be sure to keep shrimp covered. Stir to incorporate everything, then bring mixture up to a simmer. Place in a preheated oven and cover tightly with a lid or sheet pan. Bake until all liquid is absorbed and rice is tender, about 23 to 25 minutes. Meanwhile, thinly slice remaining green onions for garnish. Fluff rice with a fork, then scoop into serving dishes. Top with cooked shrimp and green onions and serve with lime wedges on the side.
SHEET PAN SHRIMP
1 lb. baby red potatoes (quartered), 1 1/2 lb raw medium shrimp (peeled and deveined), 2 ears of corn (cut crosswise into 4 pieces each), 2 links smoked andouille sausage (thinly sliced), 2 lemons (sliced), 1 tsp garlic powder, 1 tbsp Old Bay seasoning, 2 tbsps melted butter, 2 tbsps extra-virgin olive oil, Kosher salt, freshly ground black pepper, 2 tbsps freshly chopped parsley for garnish.
Preheat the oven to 425 degrees. In a large pot of salted boiling water, cook potatoes until just tender, about 10 minutes. Drain. In a large bowl, combine cooked potatoes, shrimp, corn, sausage, lemons, garlic powder, Old Bay, melted butter, and oil and season with salt and pepper. Toss until combined, then divide between two large baking sheets. Bake until shrimp is cooked through and corn is tender, 13 to 15 minutes.

title: Always plenty to be thankful for in Maryland
author: Staff Writer
content:
Always plenty to be thankful for in Maryland

 November 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editorials 
 
 740
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It should be easy for most of us to be thankful in Maryland. Thanksgiving has just about arrived, that special day for reflection, for sharing our gratitude and for enjoying a splendidly large meal with those we love.We've mostly been spared the political rancor that marked much of the election season nationwide. The local campaigning leading up to filling out our ballots earlier this fall was mostly crisp and clean.
So as we prepare ourselves for the Thanksgiving holiday, let's hope that peace and civility will prevail, at least for a day. Let's hope that when extended families convene for the old familiar feast, debate won't rage between red and blue, but about whether dark meat is more delicious than white meat as the turkey is carved.
Thanksgiving is a legacy of early colonial America, when European settlers thanked God for the harvest that allowed people to survive under difficult conditions. These days, of course, only a dwindling portion of our population here still has lives so closely tied to the harvest. Most of us take comfortable shelter and an adequate food supply for granted every day.
Did you know that we have a president, a secretary of state and the author of "Mary Had A Little Lamb" to thank for Thanksgiving becoming a fully recognized holiday in the United States?
Editor and writer Sarah Josepha Hale launched her campaign in 1827 to see the annual Thanksgiving tradition dating back a couple hundred years become an official holiday. She started with President John Quincy Adams — son of Founding Father John Adams — and finally found success many years later with President Abraham Lincoln in 1863. Secretary of State William Seward penned Lincoln's proclamation, which came in "the midst of a civil war of unequalled magnitude and severity."
"I do, therefore, invite my fellow-citizens in every part of the United States, and also those who are at sea and those who are sojourning in foreign lands, to set apart and observe the last Thursday of November next as a Day of Thanksgiving and Praise to our beneficent Father who dwelleth in the heavens," Lincoln's proclamation reads.
Well, 2024 has certainly been a year, but we still have so much to be thankful for, each and everyone of us.
In a way, we're all accidents of birth, and ongoing accidents of geography. We could be anywhere else in the world — and plenty of those places have more than enough misery to go around. Gratitude for our peace, safety and security here at home would be in order.
We should also be thankful for the people in our community who will be required to postpone their feasts to help others in need. We can take comfort in knowing that police and hospital staff will be on the job, and volunteer firefighters and other first responders could be pressed into service at any time if there's an emergency.
Then there are those thoughtful souls who make sure that anyone who wants to come out can enjoy an absolutely free hot Thanksgiving family-style meal and fellowship. Food banks, soup kitchens and churches around the region help make sure that happens.
For sure, this holiday season that officially kicks off next week and runs all the way through New Year's Day can stretch time, money and sometimes patience particularly thin. But let's face it, most of us have plenty for which to be thankful. And we should have little reason not to feel blessed and grateful on Thanksgiving and every day.
Our community is strong. And through the works large and small of all our friends and neighbors, we will only continue to get stronger. And for that, too, we offer our thanks.
Even in our nation's darkest times, Lincoln and Seward found much to be celebrated: "The year that is drawing toward its close has been filled with the blessings of fruitful fields and healthful skies. To these bounties, which are so constantly enjoyed that we are prone to forget the source from which they come, others have been added, which are of so extraordinary a nature that they cannot fail to penetrate and even soften the heart which is habitually insensible to the ever-watchful providence of Almighty God."
We can all take their words to heart as we head into the holiday season. We can look to the good. We can focus on the positive. We can find our way forward with thankfulness and love in our hearts.
We wish you all a happy Thanksgiving.

title: Community celebrates Earth Day at Adkins Arboretum
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Community celebrates Earth Day at Adkins Arboretum

 April 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 439
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RIDGELY — Swinging jazz, food, ecology and crafts for kids marked the outdoor Earth Day celebration on Saturday at Adkins Arboretum. There was also bird song from the woods and the sound of bullfrogs from the pond.The crowd was large, with 300 tickets sold for the event. Multiple environmental groups and government agencies hosted information tables.
Eastern Redbud saplings were given out for attendees to plant at home by Francis Smith of the Maryland Forest Service. There were master gardeners and monarch butterfly experts. A birding trip led into the forest in the morning.
"Earth Day heightens our awareness and appreciation. It is joyful and good to get out. And it is fun to host this site to share with other local nonprofits," said Ginna Tiernan, executive director of Adkins.
"It reminds us to breathe, step out in nature. It is incredible for your soul, your brain," Tiernan said. "It is amazing how clear you can think after a walk in the woods. I took a walk the other day, and a pileated woodpecker just swooped down in front of me. There were pine warblers in my ear. It is just affirming too that we are here on Earth with all of these animals, and we are a part of them."
Adkins celebrated the global holiday a little early this year, with Earth Day actually falling on Monday.
Earth Day is an annual event on April 22 to demonstrate support for environmental protection. First held on April 22, 1970, it now includes a wide range of events coordinated globally.
Jay Falstad, Adkins Arboretum board member and Executive Director of Queen Anne's Conservation Association, was using yellow and orange chalk to create a big sun at the arboretum's entrance.
"Earth Day is the one thing that we all share. We all share the same air, water and the same planet. We should all have an investment in protecting it," Falstad said.
There were many people who have worked hard to make this event happen. Not just organizing and planning but executing a fun educational experience.
Jenny Houghton, assistant director of Adkins Arboretum, said, "We are partnering with other environmental organizations. We thought it would be nice to show people that we are all working together. We have Pickering Creek, Tuckahoe State Park, Maryland DNR, Bartlett Tree Experts, Shore Rivers, Talbot County Master Gardeners and Phillips Wharf Environmental Center."
"The highlight is getting people outside to celebrate nature together and listening to great music, eating local food and hopefully scooping up some tadpoles in the wetland. It is good to remind ourselves that the Earth is worth taking care of, because it is all that we have got," said Houghton.

title: Visiting artists welcomed by Kent Cultural Alliance
author: Staff Writer

Visiting artists welcomed by Kent Cultural Alliance

 The Kent Cultural Alliance announces its first class of visiting artists for the SFW Residency for spring 2024.This inaugural residency session features three talented artists and educators from Alvin, Texas; Baltimore, Maryland; and Luray, Virginia. These artists will work under a collective theme of "land" as they explore agriculture, soil, family farms and more with local partners for the session — Kent County 4-H, Kent County High School Future Farmers of America, and Harborview Farms.
This social practice residency has its foundation in community engagement and seeks to create broader participation around issues important to the people who call this county home.
THE ARTISTS
Canadian-American Austen Camille is an artist, writer, builder and naturalist whose studio practice is built on her early years moving schools and cities and working to note the particularities of a place. Residing in Alivn, Texas, Camille seeks reciprocal relationships between the built and natural environment in her work. Camille's interdisciplinary practice incorporates painting, sculpture, installation, writing, research, performance, new technologies and localized materials. She seeks to forge connections between the arts and other disciplines through it. She received her BA in studio art at Reed College and her MFA in painting at Temple University.
Alyssa Dennis is an interdisciplinary artist, earth activist, educator and clinical herbalist from Baltimore, Maryland. Her art practice centers on conventional forms of building and the convenience that keeps us compartmentalized within a dangerously abstract relationship with nature and our own bodies. The imagery she creates explores the impact of manufactured landscapes on our internal and external ecosystems, shaping our existence with non-human life and, ultimately, ourselves. Dennis's work combines drawing, sculptural installation and the social/environmental practice of herbalism. In her multidisciplinary practice, she questions who the players are and what are the means for reclaiming non-human kinships as a necessary form of embodiment for the reversal of cultural and climate upheaval.
With a focus on printmaking, sculpture, storytelling and community, Dennis McNett is a multifaceted maker. Hailing from Luray, Virginia, he is known for his larger-than-life woodcut print-covered puppets and masks that are used to lead narrative ceremonies and public processions. McNett has had more than 30 visiting artist and lecturer appointments across the U.S. and abroad. He holds a BFA from Old Dominion University and an MFA from Pratt Institute, where he taught from 2004-2013. His works have been featured internationally at the Victoria and Albert Museum, the MOHS exhibit, the Museum of Print History and more.
The Kent Cultural Alliance offers several opportunities for the community to engage with resident artists. Some of those opportunities include the following dates. All events at the alliance's Raimond Cultural Center, 101 Spring Ave., Chestertown.
Thursday, April 4, 2024 at 7 p.m.: "Meet the Residents — Artist Talk"- Free. Come meet our resident artists, and learn about their practice and past projects. Reception to follow.
Saturday, April 27, noon to 3 p.m.: "Open Studio" — opportunity to see our artists at work on their "Land" project.
Friday, May 3, from 5-8 p.m.: Exhibit Opening — Come see the work created by our resident artists and learn from our partner organizations about this social practice residency experience.
Saturday, May 4 at 1 p.m.: Artist Talk, join our artists one last time and hear about their work related to this residency.
Friday, May 3 to Saturday, June 1: The "Land" residency exhibition will be open to the public for four weeks. Gallery hours will be Wednesday through Friday from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. and Saturdays from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m.

 Bay Maritime Museum's Shipyard has completed its latest project with the launch of the 36-foot Chesapeake Bay buyboat Mr. Dickie.The Shipyard team began work on the new construction build last fall after finishing up its build ofMary-land Dove and worked over the past year under the direction of Shipyard Foreman Jeff Reed to bring the vessel to life.A contract build for owners Grigg and Cindy Mullen of Lexington, Va., Mr. Dickie will be on display later this month at the Sultana Downrigging Festival in Chestertown before returning to dock at CBMM."Grigg provided the opportunity for us to have our Shipyard team do a complete build from start to finish, creating a unique object in a way that realizes Grigg and our dream of a comprehensive construction that allows for public and Shipwright education," said Vice President of Shipyard Operations Christian Cabral. "It's been an incredible experience."The construction of the unique vessel in CBMM's Shipyard offered a glimpse into the past while highlighting the future for a historic style ofvessel vital to the story of the Chesapeake Bay.Buyboats are cross-planked workboats that were traditionally used for hauling oysters from skipjacks to market in season and anything else that needed transporting the rest of the year.Today, there are estimated to be fewer than 30 buyboats that continue to ply the Bay's waters.Mr. Dickie pays homage to the 60-foot buyboat Mundy Point, designed to bring the buyboat look to a scaled-down 36-foot version. It was constructed from heart pine, white oak, Atlantic cedar and western red cedar, and outfitted with a restored late-1930s Buda diesel engine.A retired engineering professor, Grigg Mullen maintained a hands-on role throughout the yearlong construction, working alongside CBMM's Shipyard crew whenever his schedule allowed.He and Cindy were on hand for a CBMM Member Night on Oct. 12 celebrating Mr. Dickie and the Oct. 20 launch for the new buyboat that is named in honor of the late Dickie Whaley, Mullen's neighbor growing up in Queen Anne's County."It's been a wonderful year building Mr. Dickie and working with the Shipyard folks," Mullen said. "Every time there was a decision to make, it was always - if we do it this way, it's going to be better. It's turned out wonderfully."With Mr. Dickie completed, CBMM's Shipyard will stay busy with a variety of projects heading into the winter months, including ongoing work on a pair of buyboats in its historic floating fleet.Winnie Estelle, CBMM's passenger-carrying 1920 buyboat, is amidst a refit that includes the removal, fabrication, and replacement of its structural timbers. 1938 buyboat Choptank is undergoing a final fit out, which involves building out the interior with cabins and heads for expedition-style overnight trips and outfitting it with modern safety equipment and a new rig.Findmore information about CBMM's Shipyard and itsprojects at cbmm.org/ship-yard.

title: Meet the bikers who try – and fail – each year to erode Maryland’s helmet law
author: SAPNA BANSIL Capital News Service
content:
Meet the bikers who try – and fail – each year to erode Maryland’s helmet law

 March 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SAPNA BANSIL Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 945
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A group of bikers in leather vests and wispy beards greets lawmakers here each Monday of the legislative session, hoping this is the year they'll succeed in their galvanizing cause: gutting a Maryland law that requires them to wear helmets.The group, which calls itself A Brotherhood Against Totalitarian Enactments, has experienced decades of setbacks on the helmet issue. Its vociferous critics say ABATE's position is at a minimum, eccentric and at worst, dangerous.
But driven by a burning belief in personal freedom and a joy for riding, ABATE has used persistent, grassroots activism to keep the helmet issue alive in Maryland. It's why in nearly every legislative session since the state's mandatory helmet law took effect in 1992, the Maryland General Assembly has at least considered a bill that would make wearing a helmet optional for most riders.
"It's been 32 years this year to no avail," Bob Spanburgh, Maryland ABATE's board chairman, said. "But we keep introducing it. We have some pretty ardent supporters. We have a lot of people who think we're nuts, probably."
Like many of its previous incarnations over the last three decades, this year's bill would make wearing a helmet optional if a motorcyclist is at least 21 years old, has been licensed for a minimum of two years and has completed a safety course. It is named in honor of Gary "Pappy" Boward, a former ABATE executive director and motorcycle rights advocate who died in 2020 of health issues.
ABATE and other supporters insist that they aren't opposed to riders wearing helmets if they so choose. But they feel the current mandate abridges freedom of choice and represents government overreach.
"I firmly believe that we as government do better when we educate people, [rather] than legislating something," said Sen. Mike McKay (R-Allegany, Garrett, Washington), the bill's primary Senate sponsor and a friend of Boward's. "There are people that would like to have the choice [to not wear a helmet.] And I tend to believe that we should give people the choice but 100% support educating them about it."
Established in 1974, ABATE will mark 50 years of advocacy for motorcyclists' rights this June. Its animating issue has been eroding Maryland's helmet law, different iterations of which have been in place since 1968. Today, Maryland joins 16 other states and the District of Columbia in requiring all riders to wear protective headgear.
Spanburgh, a 66-year-old retired carpenter, only casually followed politics when he joined ABATE in the mid-1980s. Initially, he saw the group as a community of like-minded individuals, who shared his enthusiasm for bikes, firearms, the outdoors and rock and roll. But right away, ABATE turned Spanburgh into an unlikely activist.
"At the first meeting I went to, the thing they told me [was,] 'You got to register to vote. It's very important in this organization,'" Spanburgh recalled. "That was actually the first time I ever registered to vote in my life. I was 27 at the time."
Each legislative session, the helmet bill faces cockeyed glances and prodigious odds. Contending with a wealth of scientific evidence, which shows crashes involving non-helmeted motorcyclists are much more likely to result in severe head trauma and death, the measure almost always dies in committee.
But ABATE ensures the issue is revived and relitigated, year after year, by finding ways to get in front of elected officials, despite limited financial resources and dwindling numbers. In the past, the group used a tactic involving following lawmakers into the bathroom to gain an audience and get its message heard.
"They're diehards for what they believe in," Del. Jay Jacobs (R-Caroline, Cecil, Kent, Queen Anne's) said. "Thank God they do. They don't let go of this stuff. It's a tough fight over here to get that kind of legislation passed."
While Republicans are the most likely to sympathize with ABATE's cause, the group engages lawmakers on both sides of the aisle. This year's bill, cross-filed as HB639 and SB503, has bipartisan sponsors in both chambers.
"I don't agree with them that they shouldn't wear a helmet, but I do agree about the civil liberty issue," said Sen. Jill Carter (D-Baltimore city), one of the bill's Senate co-sponsors.
"They are adamant as dedicated motorcyclists that this is not something they want mandated to them," she added.
In a recent hearing of the House Environment and Transportation Committee, opponents included highway safety groups, medical associations and public health officials. They argued that a weaker helmet law would increase motorcyclists' risk of injury and death, impose an avoidable burden on taxpayers and encumber the healthcare system.
"A lot of people might say, 'Well, it's my free will to do whatever I want to do, no matter how stupid it is,'" Gene Ransom, CEO of MedChi, the Maryland State Medical Society, said in an interview. "The problem is, when it comes to healthcare … your decision then ends up costing the entire system a whole lot of money.
"Not only is it the right thing to do and the smart thing to do — logical people wear helmets when they ride a motorcycle or a bike or other things — it also is appropriate from a common good and cost point of view," Ransom added.
The bill is scheduled for a hearing before the Senate Judicial Proceedings Committee later this week. Spanburgh hopes to see the measure make it out of committee and get a vote on the House or Senate floor. If unsuccessful, proponents vow they won't stop trying.
"If I don't do it, who else is going to do it?" said Ken Eaton, Maryland ABATE's executive director. "We try to get other people to help us as much as possible. But if I don't do it, how can I convince other people to do it?"

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Replacing fear with love
author: KEN GEORGE Ridgely Church of the Bretheren
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Replacing fear with love

 May 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KEN GEORGE Ridgely Church of the Bretheren | Section: Columns 
 
 277
 Words 

 Read News Document

 There are many scriptures that tell us to "fear the Lord." My early Christian experiences certainly taught me that. I remember a pamphlet that showed sinners drowning in a literal lake of fire for all eternity. Scary stuff.Author and pastor Rob Bell presents us with an interesting thought though — do we really believe that God, who loves us so much, is going to condemn billions of people, and reward only a select few with heaven? Will He really condemn these billions, throughout history, with eternal torment for things they did in a few short years of their life on Earth? It's not a question I would presume to know the answer to.
I do know this, just as well as you do — our God is a God of love. He loves us so much that He gave His only begotten Son. Therefore, I prefer to substitute "fear" with "love." For instance, Proverbs 1:7 tells us, "The fear of the Lord is the beginning of knowledge. Fools despise wisdom and instruction." I like to think that "the love of the Lord is the beginning of knowledge."
I must admit, I have no fear of the Lord. Instead, what I have is respect, reverence, awe, love and an appreciation of His love for me. The love He shows us cannot not be compared to anything else. The angels who appeared to the shepherds, in the Gospel of Luke, gave us good advice: "Don't be afraid, because a savior is born."
Jesus came to us — God in the flesh — bringing love and salvation.
If we live a life of righteousness, following Christ, what do we have to fear? Nothing.

title: QA honors veterans' memories with Wreaths Across America
author: Doug Bishop; dbishop@chespub.com
content:
QA honors veterans' memories with Wreaths Across America

 December 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Doug Bishop; dbishop@chespub.com | Page: 9 | Section: News 
 
 544
 Words 

 Read News Document

 QUEEN ANNE's COUNTY - This past weekend saw the Wreaths Across America truck convoy headed to Arlington National Cemetery with thousands of Christmas wreaths.Stopping over night Thursday. Dec. 7, for the 14th consecutive year, they were again hosted by Kent Island American Legion Post 278, in Stevensville, under direction of Past Post Commander and the 2023 Maryland State Legionnaire of the Year Nikki Randolph.
Randolph has earned a reputation for her passionate care for all veterans, making sure veteran grave sites are bestowed with American flags and Christmas wreaths at appropriate times of the year, every year.
The yearly tradition began when she was then commander of Post 278 and contacted Morrill and Karen Worcester of Maine, who had already begun the Wreaths Across America program - hauling Christmas wreaths from their state to the nation's capitol to place those wreaths on all veteran's grave sites at Arlington National Cemetery.
Randolph and Legion 278 volunteers provided three meals, dinner, breakfast and boxed lunches to the convoy before they made the final leg of their journey to Arlington.
This year, the Wreaths Across America sent out over 3,000,000 Christmas wreaths across the nation to more than 4,200 locations to be placed on those grave sites. Most were placed on Saturday, Dec. 9.
Eleven wreaths were also presented to families connected to Post 278, whose veterans chose to be cremated rather than buried in a cemetery.
One of those was to the wife of the late George Dashiell, who served during World War II in Germany.
Mrs. Wally Dashiell, now 100-years-old has been a widow for the past 17 years. She said, "I'm truly grateful that the Legion honored George in this way." The wreath was placed next to the urn that holds his ashes, the American flag presented during his memorial service, and a picture of George.
Friday morning the convoy departed from Legion 278 along Route 8, children from both Matapeake Elementary and Middle Schools cheering and waving small American flags. An emotional scene, it was clear the children were excited to participate.
Saturday at noon, American Legion Jeff Davis Post 18 in Centreville, hosted their annual Wreaths Across America ceremony at Chesterfield Cemetery. Approximately 200 people were present, many of them children and teens with their parents. 
 
 Caption: PHOTOS BY DOUG BISHOP

In the background, Legion 18 member John White takes a photograph and Sea Cadet Unit members stand at attention. title: New director takes the helm at Chesapeake's Cambridge Center
content:
New director takes the helm at Chesapeake's Cambridge Center

 August 16, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A13 | Section: News 
 
 457
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - Dr. Lorelly Solano is combining her interests in education and public policy in her new role as director of the Chesapeake College Cambridge Center."I enjoyed working directly with the students - hearing about their dreams and learning about their challenges while I've helped them plan their academic journeys," Solano said. "This new role will be a bit different for me, but I will try to bring that student perspective into everything I do here." As director of the center, located on Race Street, Solano will lead the staff in providing all the services Cambridge-based students need to be successful. In the coming months, Cambridge residents are likely to meet Solano as she begins her community outreach efforts.The Cambridge Center, Solano said, is a resource for everyone in Dorchester County, playing a critical role in the economic and social health of the downtown area.In addition to credit classes in both transfer and career programs, the center also offers workforce training, personal enrichment opportunities and meeting spaces for community organizations. The center also houses the American Job Center."We're an education center for students of all ages, but I hope residents here also see us as a center of community growth," Solano said.Solano first joined Chesapeake as an English as a Second Language instructor.She was later the academic and career advisor guiding students through actionable plans to achieve their goals.A native of Costa Rica, Solano came to the United States as a graduate student.After earning her bachelor's degree in Costa Rica, she worked for an international flower exporter as she continued her studies toward licensure at the University of Costa Rica.Her future plans took a turn when a professor at UCR asked if she was adventurous.Thinking that the professor meant bungee jumping or some other daredevil sport, Solano prepared to decline. Instead, the professor asked if she would be interested in taking on a new academic challenge in a different country.He recommended her for a graduate research post at the University of Maryland.While working on "green" roof research and earning her master's degree in natural resources science at College Park, Solano's interest grew in building sustainable communities through policy and education.She went on to earn a Ph.D. in public policy and urban affairs at the University of Delaware."It's ironic that I studied urban affairs and ended up in rural area," Solano said. "Rural and urban areas face many of the same challenges, though, and people in both areas want the same things." Better lives and a greater sense of community, Solano said, are common desires for most people. The Cambridge Center provides both, she added.For more information about the Chesapeake College Cambridge Center, please visit www.chesapeake.edu/cambridge.

title: Caroline County Board of Ed declares last day of school, discuss virtual instruction
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Caroline County Board of Ed declares last day of school, discuss virtual instruction

 April 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 719
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Caroline County Board of Education declared Tuesday, June 17, as the last day of the extended school year after inclement weather closures exceeded the four days allotted.The last day will be a half day for students and a full day for teachers.
Next year, county schools will have three allotted inclement weather days. At the April 1 Board of Education meeting, district officials explored options for implementing virtual instruction should weather cause unexpected closures.
Because of the challenges presented by district officials, the board concluded it thinks the district will not be able to conduct virtual instruction on inclement weather days.
"The structure we tried to take with the presentation was a condensed version of some the requirements that the school system would have to meet if the county were to entertain virtual weather days," Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Derek Simmons said. "We walked through some real tough spots for us to get to those points."
Internet Connection and Google Meets
There are multiple factors Caroline County board of education most consider to conduct virtual inclement weather days. Including ensuring every student has a hotspot or wifi to participate in virtual learning.
Robert Wielgosz, supervisor of technology, led the discussion on cellular service, offering points on the Kajeet program.
Kajeet was a hotspot used during the pandemic for students to connect to the internet in areas where wifi access was limited and not available.
According to Wielgosz, when given the opportunity to use Kajeet, some students would use the hotspot for personal uses like video games and movies. This overloaded the hotspots and caused delays.
The estimate cost for Caroline County to provide the 700 needed Kajeet devices over five years would be about $736,000 for students and $35,000 for teachers.
Wielgosz also mentioned the need for Google Meet Breakout Rooms, which teachers use to conduct learning activities with groups in virtual classrooms. While this feature was available at no cost, it is no longer available in Caroline County's free Google plan.
"To get the feature back, it's going to cost Caroline County somewhere between $30,000 to $50,000 a year to get the premium Google aspect," Wielgosz said.
Multilingual Learners, Special Education and Homelessness
State law mandates districts "ensure that all staff and students, including students with disabilities, homeless students, and English language learners, have the necessary devices at home for virtual education days, including access to Wifi."
Providing equitable access to these services can be challenging during virtual instruction, district officials said.
Caroline County has 576 multilingual learners, 569 individualized education program students and 116 students who experience homelessness. For these students, hands-on teacher engagement and preparation is required for proper learning.
"It's very hard to keep students engaged, especially for four hours of synchronous instruction," Erica McDonald, supervisor of special education, said. "Without that in-person tangible motivating things that can keep them engaged during instruction, it can lead to increased frustration."
Providing necessary technologies and translation services are also complicated by virtual instruction, the officials said.
Teacher, staff negotiations
Some district employees work on inclement weather days, and some staff members do not work and still get paid, district officials said.
Requirements of the state say, "during virtual inclement weather days the local school system shall offer public school employees who are not assigned to work during the virtual education day an opportunity to make up the lost work through other duties before the beginning of the next school year."
The district would be responsible for determining how this work would be made up.
Virtual learning days require additional planning from teachers, which requires a negotiation with the teachers' union for proper pay.
"Our teachers work really hard. We all know are teachers work outside of hours. We have all come to accept that it comes with the job," Dr. Robert Willoughby, director of administrative services said. "However, the law does say that we may negotiate with our teachers' union. They have a right to come to negotiate if there is extra work here we would like extra compensation for that."
After going through the presentation, Simmons concluded it would be to hard for the county to pull off virtual inclement weather days.
"I don't see how as a county, with the resources we have right now, that this puts us in a great position to be able to hit all the marks to be able to pull this off effectively to meet all requirements," Simmons said.

title: APG Chesapeake hires new regional president

APG Chesapeake hires new regional president

 Words

 EASTON — Orestes Baez, Adams Publishing Group's new Chesapeake regional president, is no stranger to APG nor the Chesapeake region.Baez started the new job Monday, Sept. 30, meeting employees at the Star Democrat in Easton. He will be traveling to APG Chesapeake offices in Chestertown, Chester, La Plata, California, Prince Frederick, Dundalk and Elkton for the rest of the week.
Baez was APG's Southern Wisconsin regional president from August 2020 through 2022. A decade before that, he lived on the western shore of Maryland as the CEO of the Maryland Pennysaver.
In 2010, Baez entered the news industry when he took a job with Tribune Publishing Company in Newport News, Virginia.
"I joined newspapers in 2010 and have been with them ever since," he said.
As regional president, Baez will oversee the Chesapeake market.
"I'm excited," he said about his new role. "Adams is a great company. They've been really good to me."
Baez — who won the first ever APG Regional President of the Year award in 2021 — said one of his favorite company memories is when the company asked him for his opinion and they supported him.
"And they let me go do that," he said. "That speaks volumes for the kind of culture that the company has."
Before taking on the new role with APG, Baez was the CEO of TravelHost, a publication connecting businesses with travelers. He said that during his time in the news industry, he's enjoyed getting to connect businesses with audiences that desire the products and services of those businesses.
"That's the creative part," he said. "That's the energizing part."
Baez, whose family immigrated to the United States as political exiles from Cuba, said he is a big fan of free speech.
"From that standpoint I think journalism plays a great part," he said. "I think journalism has evolved a lot, and we continue to evolve it along with what people want. I think we have to get smarter about how we write (and) what we write about because it is something that we have to eventually monetize to sustain."
APG CEO and President Mark Adams said in a news release that Baez brings "familiarity and experience" to this position.
"It's always rewarding when we can have an executive like Orestes return to our organization," he said.
When he's not working, Baez can often be found on the pickleball courts. The three-time national champ is currently playing on the pickleball Senior Pro Tour.
His love for pickleball blossomed after decades of playing tennis. Since picking up a tennis racket at the age of 9, he has won over 300 tennis doubles titles. While in college, Baez played tennis for Clemson University. He also coached the Clemson team while in graduate school there.
It wasn't until he was in his 50s that Baez's friend convinced him to give pickleball a try. Since then, Baez has gone from playing the sport recreationally to playing in tournaments.
As he settles into his new role on the Chesapeake, Baez is looking for houses in Annapolis with his wife, Donna. He said he is excited to contribute to the Chesapeake team.
"It's about removing obstacles and helping guide," he said about his role.

Caroline’s in Denton making strides in new owners tenure

 512

 DENTON — Caroline's in Denton has been open for just about nine months under new owners and in that time has seen increased following on social media and increase revenues.Owner and Executive Chef Ken Zellers and his wife, Robin Zellers, have ideas to take Caroline's in Denton to the next level. They will be putting a permanent food truck at a new brewery in Denton called Eden Town Brewing Company.
"We purchased the food trailer out back, so we're going to be doing the food at the brewery, putting the trailer over there, next step of expansion," Zellers said.
This next step in expansion brings hopes for Caroline's in Denton to keep growing.
"That's a scary part of getting in the restaurant industry," Zellers said. "You never know how the community is going to take to you, how they're going to like your food, your drinks and what you're doing, but it seems to be working out pretty well."
Zeller took over ownership from previous owner Nancy Minahan, Zeller interviewed multiple times for the chef position at Caroline's in Denton but was never granted the opportunity, until Minahan called him about buying the restaurant.
Zeller started working at a restaurant at just 14 years old and began cooking at 16 years old and running a kitchen at 18 years old. He is an award-winning chef in Anna Arundel County including best chef of the year just last year.
One thing Zellers has done since taking ownership of Caroline's in Denton is tweaking the menu away from fine dinning to more affordable menu with high quality ingredients.
Zellers keeps the high quality ingredients by serving fresh farm to table items on the menu, fresh farm items that come from Caroline County and other counties across the Mid-Shore.
"Ingredients is always the No. 1 thing," Zellers said.
Starting with a good ingredient is important, he said, plus it supports the local economy and the community, not to mention local farms.
"I think that's the biggest thing like just the quality of the ingredient. You just put that on the plate and let it shine, and you don't have to do much to it," Zellers said. "I think it's a big part of why people have taken to our food so so much because we really can't mess it up because the flavor's there."
The Zellers have added an enclosure onto the porch for extra seating for the winter and summer days. Next to the restaurant is Caroline's side bar which features outside and inside seating with a different menu than Caroline's in Denton. Zellers called the outdoor seating "beautiful."
With plans of more expansion, Zellers says the love and growth Caroline's in Denton has seen still hasn't hit home for him yet.
"This is always going to be the baby, we're always going to make sure this is taken care of, but it's just like I said, I don't think it's hit me," Zellers said. "I could have never imagined especially a restaurant that's this beautiful that I would be the owner of it, but I fell in love with when I first interviewed with Nancy."

title: Dorchester County ballot questions will not take effect due to 'administrative error'
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Dorchester County ballot questions will not take effect due to 'administrative error'

 March 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 454
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Although Dorchester County voters who took to the polls in November voted on whether changes should be made to the county charter, those changes will not be made this year.During a Dorchester County Council meeting on March 4, Council President Lenny Pfeffer announced the county had made an "administrative error" by not advertising the referendum questions for five consecutive weeks after the council approved them.
"With it not being advertised correctly per state law, it would not make those referendum questions valid to change the charter," Pfeffer said.
The error in advertising was an accident, Pfeffer said, and he apologized to county residents.
"As far as blame for this, this entire (council) and Dorchester County takes general responsibility for this mistake," he said.
Pfeffer said the error was discovered in the process of reclaiming the county's sanitary district. He said that during the bond review process, legal counsel for the bond review discovered the oversight.
Pfeffer said the county waited for additional legal review before telling the public.
In an interview with the Star Democrat March 5, Pfeffer said the council was notified of the error a little over a month ago. He said the county had previously been trying to have the amendments made to the charter by spring.
In November, county residents voted to amend four parts of the county charter. The changes amended the charter to:
Have the review of administrative structure be conducted within the first fiscal year of each Dorchester County Council term. Currently, the charter says a review of administrative structure should take place at least every four years, but it does not state when in that four years it should take place.Push back budget-related due dates 15 days.Clarify responsibilities of the county manager, including day-to-day operations, and establish procedures for certain vacancies. Currently, the charter has procedures in place for council member and treasurer vacancies, as well as certain board and commission vacancies.Include language to ensure transparency of governmental functions as well as access to open meetings and public records.
Pfeffer said although these amendments cannot be made to the charter now, they could be voted on again in future elections.
"So it will be up to the wishes of the Charter Review Commission and the council before the next election on if any one, all of, or whatever list of referendum questions could get placed on the ballot next time," he said.
Dorchester County Attorney Chip MacLeod said the county is looking into whether the ballot questions that were approved by voters could be addressed through county code or policy changes.
MacLeod called the situation "unfortunate," but made it clear other opportunities might exist.
"One way or another, the county's going to be impacted by those charter amendments, even though they're not technically valid," he said.
