title: Department of Aging funding anticipated to remain flat, secretary says
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Department of Aging funding anticipated to remain flat, secretary says

 January 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: General Assembly 
 
 443
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Funding for the Maryland Department of Aging is expected to remain flat over the coming year, according to Maryland Secretary of Aging Carmel Roques.The secretary's comment came after Del. Chris Adams (R-Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) asked if there were concerns about the department's budget outcome during an Eastern Shore Delegation meeting Friday morning.
Concerns are not with losing funding, but with an anticipated inability to grow funding.
"The okay news is we don't anticipate our funding to be cut, but we're not going to have additional funding," Roques said. "And the way we're going to try and make that a better situation is the way we engage with, in a collaborative fashion, … our health and our housing agencies."
The majority of the department's funding comes from the federal government. State funding comprises a smaller portion of the dollars the department has to distribute.
In fiscal year 2024, Upper Shore Aging, the designated area agency on aging for Talbot, Caroline and Kent counties, received almost $782,000 from the state Department of Aging.
Queen Anne's County received about $333,000, and Cecil County received roughly $554,000.
MAC Inc., which is the area agency for Dorchester, Somerset, Wicomico and Worcester counties, received just over $1.3 million.
Knowing the funding was unlikely to grow, the department took steps early on to maximize the funding available to direct it more effectively at the local level, Roques said.
Those steps included working with stakeholder groups to look at three state programs — subsidized assisted living, congregate living and senior care money — to think about redesigning the long-term services and supports system in place from the state funding.
According to Roques, the work being done now will not "dramatically" change anything about fiscal year 2025, but it will in the coming years.
The Administration on Community Living, a federal agency that increases access to community supports for older adults and those with disabilities, also recently changed regulations to include guidance that will impact equity, she said.
Roques said the update to the regulations is "good news" for the rural elderly population, their families and care providers.
The state's rural communities have the highest populations of adults age 50 and older, according to data shared during her presentation.
The rural counties on the Eastern Shore have some of the highest numbers. In 2020, 50.8% of Talbot County's population was over age 50.
Maryland's overall population is rapidly growing older. In the next six years, the state will see more residents over 60 than under 18 — a first, Roques said.
"...What's being baked into that guidance is that rural communities need to be more heavily weighted in the formula for distribution of funds to recognize that their challenges are very different," she said.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: The Lenten season
author: DANIEL T. GEDMAN St. Luke’s GMC
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: The Lenten season

 March 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DANIEL T. GEDMAN St. Luke’s GMC | Section: News 
 
 332
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Lenten season begins today, a day called Ash Wednesday.Ashes are a sign of mortality and repentance. The uses of ashes dates back to ancient Jewish tradition and often were associated with sacrifices, mourning and fasting. A person would properly express grief, humiliation and repentance sitting in ashes or placing them on the head.
At one time, during the early centuries of the church, public penitents at Rome were ceremonially admitted on this day to begin their penance.
This ceremony fell into disuse between the eighth and 10th centuries as general penance of the entire congregation began to take place. This penance was symbolized through the imposition of ashes.
Another use for ashes in the early church (second century) included a regular ceremony of public confession and penance. This use had acquired so much significance that Tertullian (a prolific early Christian author from Carthage in the Roman province of Africa) spoke of "the substitution of sackcloth and ashes for a man's usual habit."
Today, ashes symbolize the same meanings though the ceremonial customs have vanished. The one exception to this is Ash Wednesday.
The word "Lent" derives from the anglo-saxon term lencten, meaning "spring." During this time we earnestly recount all that God accomplished through the work of Jesus Christ.
We experience this period every year in the life of the church, but often, we forget, or sometimes we never knew what this time of year is about. Lent as a forty-day period of focus on penitence and preparation for the Resurrection Event of Easter. Today, we tend to observe Lent as a time of penance, by abstaining from festivals, by almsgiving, and by devoting more than the usual time to exercises of the faith. In recent years, more emphasis has been placed on these aspects than the physical fasting that marked this season in the early church.
I pray that this Lenten season would be a holy and sacred time of preparation for the celebration of the greatest day in human history; the resurrection of Jesus Christ.

title: Student seeks to share Choptank River history
author: NIAMBI DAVIS Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Student seeks to share Choptank River history

 May 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: NIAMBI DAVIS Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Local News 
 
 967
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Kennedy Thomason grew up as an avid reader of historical fiction.Now, after working towards a degree in history, Thomason is sharing her historical interests with countless others, thanks to her family's river cruise business.
The 2019 graduate of Ridgely's North Caroline High School carried her love of history to Chesapeake College, where she graduated with an associate's degree in liberal arts, followed by a transfer to Washington College in Chestertown to major in American studies.
"It's the liberal arts version of a history major," she explained, pointing to the Washington College website description as "the exploration of U.S. culture and American national identity from cross-disciplinary perspectives in order to help students develop a rich understanding of the American experience."
"I chose this major because I'm particularly interested in how our history influences the society in which we live," she said. "Understanding the human experiences that have led us to this point is vital to figuring out where we go from here. The study of history is the key to solving the labyrinth of social, economic and political problems we face today."
At the Starr Center for the American Experience, Thomason works as a digital archiving intern under the supervision of Melissa P. Kemp, the center's digital archivist and historian.
She scans, archives and uploads content into the Chesapeake Heartland archive, which features local African American families and their personal collections of family photos, home videos, yearbooks and other mementos they've collected over the years.
"I've learned a lot about digital history and its importance, as well as how tedious it can be," Thomason said.
For Thomason, the rewards of her Starr Center experience are many. "It's the confidence boost and sense of community that comes from association with professors and students who are just as passionate as I am. At school I feel a sense of belonging and I'm exposed to opportunities that I never knew were available," she said.
She considers the most challenging aspect of student life as striking a balance between college, work and life. "I am a unique undergraduate, especially for a Washington College student, because I have a two year old daughter. Most of the students around me at school still live at home or in dorms and are accustomed to only being responsible for themselves and their studies. Commuting from about an hour away, having a little person depending on me, a household to keep up with, and finding time to work has added many struggles that most of my peers do not have to navigate. But I wouldn't change it for the world!"
As the oldest of the Thomason family's five children, Kennedy counts her parents as inspiration.
"I remember watching my mother wrangle five children. I learned a lot from my mom and I admire her and look up to her. She and my dad supported all five of us doing five different things. We have always been a very tight-knit family unit with parents who have provided immense support. I could not do what I do without them. They keep my daughter (whose name is Sailor) when I need them to. Our family has always functioned as a unit working towards whatever goal we have, that day, that week, whenever."
When her family purchased Denton's Ellen B from Captain Bill Behlke, it was a given that the River City Cruise Company would be a family affair. Thomason immediately planned to add history as part of the river tours.
"I love the Choptank River," she said.
Aware of the deep historical roots she was certain that many Eastern Shore residents knew of the area's history and wanted to learn more.
"I'm a huge proponent of accessibility to history, which means I'm always trying to think of ways to bring history to the public rather than waiting for the public to seek it out," she said. "The river tours are just one aspect of my advocacy."
The first year of the River City Cruise Company was a great success. "I had the time of my life on each trip," Thomason recalled.
Her favorite guests were the people who came along for the ride but found themselves fascinated by the stories of the Choptank's history and heritage.
"I also loved seeing people from our community learn more about the land. Although I love and appreciate the out-of-towners that come and enjoy everything the Choptank has to offer, seeing locals being able to connect their lives with the past is truly special. One thing that I tell each cruise is there's no reason that people, states or oceans away should know more about our land than us."
This year, she's revamping the script and expanding the talking points to make each cruise truly unique. "I never want someone to feel that they came once and can't come again. I always want people to take away something new, even if they've taken the tour ten times."
Recently, Thomason was awarded funds to complete her own Choptank River History project from the Gerda Blumenthal Grant through Washington College's chapter of Phi Beta Kappa.
Over the summer she'll publish a series of blog posts in conjunction with the Caroline County Historical Society's website that will focus on ways the Choptank has shaped the greater Caroline County community.
"My motto for the project has been that people tend to think of rivers as borders, but, historically, the Choptank has been the center," Thomason said. "What exactly this project will look like I am still trying to work out, but I am excited about it. I plan on having at least one public event and my research will lead to a more robust history tour."
This fall Thomason will graduate from Washington College. She's still trying to figure out what she wants to do post-graduation. Whatever she chooses, the study of history will benefit.
Visit River City Cruise Company on Facebook, email them at riverruncruise@gmail.comor call 410-673-8201.

title: QACHS wins inaugural Maryland High School Skeet Team Championship
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
QACHS wins inaugural Maryland High School Skeet Team Championship

 June 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Sports 
 
 455
 Words 

 Read News Document

 SUDLERSVILLE — Queen Anne's County High School Clay Target Team came away with the victory against skeeters from Kent Island High School Clay Target Team and the Easton High School Clay Shooting Team during the inaugural Maryland State High School Skeet Championship at Sudlersville Skeet Club June 7.Queen Anne's County High School brought home the championship with a team total of 460, followed by Easton High School with a score of 439.
Shooting skeet throughout the morning, the three high schools also competed in a "War on the Shore" Trap Tournament for bragging rights in the afternoon, and students earned individual honors in their respective divisions.
Despite a morning downpour, "the kids persevered and conquered the weather adversities to finish up in the sunshine," Queen Anne's County High School Clay Target Team Head Coach Nathan Powell said.
"We are ecstatic with the performance of our student athletes, and the great competition from Easton and Kent Island. All of these student athletes are amazing young adults. The growth and expansion of our league continues across the Mid-Shore, and we look forward to competing with even more teams next year," he said.
Kent Island High School was the first public high school in the state of Maryland to establish a skeet team. With Easton and Queen Anne's recently established clubs, there were finally enough for a tournament, Kent Island Clay Target Team Head Coach Sean Connolly said.
Student athletes couldn't be more excited to pit their skills against local schools, he said.
A non-traditional sport that focuses on hand eye coordination, clay target shooting is an inclusive, unique and growing outlet for kids who might not otherwise compete in sports, he said.
Coming in second overall for the championship was Easton High School, which also won first place in their conference during the Maryland State High School Clay Target League earlier this year, notable as the club is only in its first year, according to Head Coach Joe Cap.
"The fact that we've come this far is pretty exceptional," he said, "Practice makes perfect, and the students put in a lot of hard work and a lot of hours. It's very exciting and a long time coming."
The sport has seen support and sponsorship from the local community, and the team also does a lot to pay that forward, according to Cap, including visiting county government departments, the sheriff's office, and the Waterfowl Festival.
Seeking to expand youth shooting sports across Maryland, the skeet coaches are happy to help schools seeking to establish their own clubs.
"We have done a lot to grow this sport in a short time, and we aren't done yet. Whoever has interest, we'll help them out," Connolly said.
"The more teams and the more kids we have, the better for everybody," Cap said.

 Former president Donald Trump has been charged like mobster and drug kingpin in Georgia, like an anarchist and foreign spy in Florida and like a post-Civil War Ku Klux Klan member in Washington D.C. as he faces now a quartet of criminal charges in the run-up to 2024 election.Trump was indicted by a Fulton County, Georgia grand jury along with 2024 campaign cohorts and attorneys - including Rudy Giuliani, Jenna Ellis and White House Chief of Staff Mark Meadows - over attempts to reverse President Joe Biden's 11,779-vote win in the Peach State.Part of that indictment includes racketeering charges conventionally used against organized crime syndicates and criminal gangs."The indictment alleges that rather than abide by Georgia's legal process for election challenges, the defendants engaged in a criminal racketeering enterprise to overturn Georgia's presidential election result," Fulton County District Attorney Fani Willis, a Democrat, said during a late-night news conference Monday, Aug. 14, announcing the indictment of the former president and leading 2024 GOP White House candidate.The indictment includes RICO (Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations), making false statements and other election meddling charges. The criminal charges to making false statements, like some of other federal allegations against Trump, will face First Amendment free speech counterarguments.Across the U.S., RICO cases have commonly been used against organized crime syndicates and criminal gangs including John Gotti's Gambino Crime Family, the Hells Angels, Latin Kings and the Cowboy Mafia, which used shrimp boats to smuggle illegal marijuana in the late 1970. There have been RICO charges used in some corporate and other corruption cases including 2022 indictments of some current and former soccer officials associated with FIFA and CONCACAF.In Georgia, RICO convictions could potentially bring prison terms of 5 to 20 years.According to the Associated Press, the Trump indictment includes criminal charges related to "attempting to persuade Georgia lawmakers to ignore the will of voters and appoint a new slate of electoral college electors favorable to Trump." "In one particularly brazen episode, it also outlines a plot involving one of his lawyers to access voting machines in a rural Georgia county and steal data from a voting machine company," the AP writes.Like with his federal indictments and charges in New York of filing false business claims to cover up alleged hush money paid to porn star Stormy Daniels and Playboy model, Karen McDougal, Trump lambasted the charges as politically motivated falsehoods aimed to undermining his 2024 White House bid."Can you believe it? This failed District Attorney from Atlanta, Fani Willis, where murders and other violent crime soars daily to new record highs, is charging me with 2020 Presidential Election Interference. No, Fani, the only Election Interference was done by those that Rigged and Stole the Election," Trump said in a statement on social media platform Truth Social. "Those are the ones you should be going after, not the innocent people that are fighting for Election Integrity!" Ellis and Guiliani, who served as Trump campaign lawyers, say they are being charged criminally for providing legal advice. "The Democrats and the Fulton County DA are criminalizing the practice of law," Ellis said in a social media statement.U.S. Justice Department Special Prosecutor Jack Smith has invoked federal grand juries in Florida and D.C. to indict Trump via the 1917 Espionage Act over his alleged misappropriation of classified documents and a post-Civil War law aimed at violent harassment by the Ku Klux Klan over the Jan. 6 Capitol riot and efforts to derail Congress' certification of Biden as the 2020 election winner.The Espionage Act has been previously used against Julian Assange, Edward Snowden, Julius and Ethen Rosenbereg and early 20th Century anarchist writer Emma Goldman.All told, Trump, 77, could potentially be jailed for the rest of his life if convicted and sentenced aggressively by state and federal judges.Tung Yin, a law professor at Lewis & Clark Law School in Portland, Oregon, said jury selections will be very important in the cases against Trump and prospective jurors may hide their love, disdain or other views toward the former Republican president."That person might give very bland answers during jury selection," XXX said. "It would be very hard to ferratt someone like this out. you get one person out of 12 you have a hung jury." The timing of the trials could run into and potentially after the 2024 U.S. presidential campaign elections.Yin sees the classified documents case where Trump is accused of improperly taking classified materials from the White House to his Florida estate as the stronger of the federal prosecutions.If convicted, Trump, the leading opposition candidate currently to President Biden, could potentially be jailed.For example, Jan. 6th charges in D.C. (which Biden won over Trump 92% to 5%) could result in Trump going to a federal prison for between 57 to 71 months, according to an estimate from Yin. That's between just under four and almost six years.Politically, as expected, Trump-aligned Republicans criticized the Georgia indictment while Democrats and progressives hailed the effort to convict and potentially imprison the bombastic populist former president.

title: Hogan Visits Port Street
author: Tom McCall

Hogan Visits Port Street

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News

 EASTON — Port Street got a distinguished visitor at the Neighborhood Service Center. Former Gov. Larry Hogan is running for the open U.S. Senate seat and stopped in Easton Friday to talk with people at the service center.He visited the facility on 126 Port Street and asked questions.
The Responsible Father Initiative, founded by Corey Pack and co-facilitated by Lou Dorsey, is an outreach program to help men become better fathers. It is a nonprofit and is all confidential. It provides food, clothing and first month's rent to people in need. These men gave Hogan the tour of the center.
Pack spoke to the governor about what they teach.
"We go over what is called the three E's. Emotion, energy and expression. And we talk about effective listening skills," Pack said. "We run through the 7/38/55 rule. 7% of the way we communicate is verbally. 38% is with our tone and 55% is with our body language."
The governor listened closely.
"I did not realize that," Hogan said. "That is an important lesson for me to learn."
He listened to more about the program.
"We try to develop more nurturing and caring fathers in this program. Most of the guys grew up in a home without a father. Some have been incarcerated with no contact with their children. It is great for them to see their children and establish a relationship with their children," Dorsey said.
Hogan recognized that a lot of men needed these services and saluted their dedication to helping these men flourish.
"It sounds like you guys are doing really important work here," Hogan said.
One of the Neighborhood Service Center workers asked Hogan to run for president. He smiled.
Hogan toured spaces intended for children. Then he went into the kitchen and in another room saw where they store clothes to give away.
At the end of tour, he was give two T-shirts and a coffee mug that touted the Neighborhood Service Center.
After his visit he stopped to do an interview in the parking lot. Hogan said his campaign is focused on the economy and crime.
"We are meeting voters every day," he said. "The people of Maryland know me after eight years of being governor."

title: Common sense degrees needed
author: Staff Writer
content:
Common sense degrees needed

 March 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 391
 Words 

 Read News Document

 This past weekend, I was enjoying my morning tea when I got a curious phone call. The gentleman knew me by my nickname, and I quickly became a good listener. Trying to place the voice it took me a few minutes to realize who it was a long-time multigenerational family friend. Let's call him Mike. I would later reflect on what an honor it was for me.For the better part of an hour, he regaled me with stories of yesteryear (none, surprisingly, set in the famed bygone watering hole of that name), featuring my father, grandfather and great-grandfather. My eyes swelled as he began to bring the good old days back to life, first in black and white, then in color. Some stories I had had a taste of, but most were new to me. What gentlemen they were.
I share that story to preface this one. While enjoying the company of "The Thursday Brotherhood" the topic of today's social climate came up. All of our comments were true and valid in their own way; I can only imagine that each generation feels the same, that in any moment in history, there are good times and not-so-good times.
The conversation brought back memories of my great-grandfather Walter Wood; he was the chief of police for then little old Easton. He called it "my town," and used his platform to serve with understanding as only he could. One quality of old Walter I heard about more than a few times was his sensible approach to life. My dad called it his C.S. (common sense) degree.
As it goes, he would leave home after supper, head to the firehouse, and open the door to the locals who needed shelter for the night. Today, we call them homeless. He would lock the door and call it a night. In the morning, the routine played out in reverse. What a novel solution.
Today, we share the same challenges as our predecessors, updated for the 21st century. How we approach them and resolve them is up to us, let's call it perspective. Sometimes what is old is what's new again. Having a bit more compassion and understanding for our neighbors can't be all wrong. Just maybe if we all use our C.S. degrees a bit more, we can all wake up and go to sleep with a smile.
ROO WOOD
Wittman

title: City of Cambridge confirms Dri-Dock Recovery and Wellness Center can be in new location
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
City of Cambridge confirms Dri-Dock Recovery and Wellness Center can be in new location

 February 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 856
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The City of Cambridge has determined that, under the city's zoning requirements, Dri-Dock Recovery and Wellness Center is allowed at its new location on Maryland Avenue.The center's move from 524 Race St to 103 Maryland Ave caused city officials and Cambridge residents alike to question whether the new location is consistent with the city's zoning code.
The Dorchester County Health Department, which runs the center, did not receive a zoning certificate from the city before moving to 103 Maryland Ave.
The center provides recovery support, advocacy and a substance-free environment. According to the County Health Department, it is a place that those recovering from a substance use disorder or mental health disorder can go for voluntary and free services.
"We're there to help people and to try and help resolve problems that arise in the area," Donald Hall, the county's director of behavioral health, said about what Dri-Dock does.
Hall said Dri-Dock opened its doors on Maryland Avenue on Jan. 22. The center plans to have a grand opening, where people can come in and ask questions, once it is fully unpacked.
While Dri-Dock settles into its new digs, the city has been reviewing whether the Health Department properly followed the city's zoning requirements.
Cambridge City Manager Tom Carroll said that although the Health Department shouldn't have moved without a zoning certificate, the city believes the center is permitted in its new location.
To come to this answer, Carroll said it was a matter of determining exactly what the space is used for and whether it complies with the city's zoning requirements.
If the city had determined the center was not in compliance with zoning requirements, Carroll said the city would have taken action.
Gene Lauer, who is on Cambridge's Planning and Zoning Commission, said he was surprised to learn that Dri-Dock had moved its location.
Before learning of the city's determination in regard to zoning, Lauer said in an interview that he had looked through the permitted uses for the district that the new location of Dri-Dock is zoned in. He said he did not see that clinics or treatment clinics were permitted.
Carroll said that after the city met with the Health Department, it became clear that the center is essentially being used as an office for peer counseling.
Hall said the center does not keep medications on the premises or give medications out on-site.
Lauer said checking zoning should be one of the first steps when it comes to moving a business.
"Because there are no guarantees after that," he said.
Hall said the Health Department had reached out to the city before moving, providing its license and asking what it needed to do to "expedite the situation."
"That response was a little slow getting back to us," he said. "So we ended up having to move."
Being a part of government, the Health Department did everything they could to meet all the laws and regulations, Hall said.
The move to Maryland Avenue has been two years in the making for Dri-Dock. Because the center was on the second floor at its Race Street location, it didn't meet Americans with Disabilities Act requirements, Hall said.
Along with that, the center experienced issues with leaking, heating and cooling and plumbing at the Race Street location.
CONCERNS FROM THE COMMUNITY
Hall said he has heard concerns from residents that Dri-Dock's move to Maryland Avenue could affect property values. He said that he understands the concern, but doesn't think this will be an issue.
"We are very conscious that we are in a community," he said.
In a Jan. 22 letter to his constituents, Commissioner Brian Roche expressed concerns with the new location's "visibility and exposure," bringing up the city's comprehensive plan — a plan that establishes the city's goals to guide growth and development in an "environmentally sustainable manner" in Cambridge.
Roche said the comprehensive plan discourages facilities like Dri-Dock from being in retail storefronts on the city's gateways and in its "downtown commercial core."
Carroll said the comprehensive plan guides the city's Unified Development Code.
"If there is a disconnect between the Unified Development Code and the Comprehensive Plan, then we need to amend the code to line up with the comprehensive plan," he said. "The plan is on top, the code follows. And so if there's any inconsistency, you amend what follows."
In his letter, Roche said the exposure might also be unwanted by those utilizing the center.
"I question that the most highly visible public storefronts in our city are suitable locations for those seeking medically and behaviorally sensitive, personal treatment," he wrote.
Roche also mentioned crime as a concern, saying that there had been a "significant number" of complaints and criminal activity at the center's prior location of 524 Race Street. He attached a police report to his letter that lists the 30 calls for service from Aug. 1, 2021 to Nov. 30, 2023.
Acknowledging the move was a recent one, Hall said that since Dri-Dock has moved to Maryland Avenue, people haven't been "lingering in the area." He said the goal of Dri-Dock is to help the community.
"Our target population is Dorchester County residents," he said. "These aren't folks who are being bussed in. These are people who live in the community, who walk those streets everyday."

 EASTON - Angie Webb wasn't sure what she did.But Saints Peter and Paul High's freshman knew the way her field hockey teammates were celebrating it must have been something good.It also proved to be the difference Tuesday, as Webb ripped the game's lone goal into the right side of the cage with 3:50 remaining in the first quarter, helping the Sabres to a 1-0 victory over Easton."It was a beautiful goal," Sts. Peter & Paul head coach Debbie McQuaid said after the Sabres improved to 10-2 with their fourth straight victory, the last three by shutout.Webb gained possession of the ball from about 25 yards away from Easton's cage near the 4-minute mark of the first period. She circled left, then moved right before unloading a hard drive from the left side that got past Warrior goalie Alli Newman before banging into the far right corner of the cage."My teammates basically helped us all get up the field," Webb said. "I just took it and I don't know what really happened.I was just really determined to get that goal. I knew I had to get off a shot real quickly. I just hit it and it went in. I was really shocked." Easton (5-4) earned two of its nine penalty corners in the final 1:15 of the first quarter, getting one shot off that was wide of the mark. Both teams each picked up one corner in the second quarter, but could not capitalize.The game remained even through the third, as the Warriors picked up three more corners, with Easton's Bis Johnson firing wide left.Sts. Peter & Paul had one corner in the third, with Gennie Webb shooting wide right."They came out and they scored on us, and it was a beautiful goal," said Easton head coach Kim Neff, whose team lost its second straight by shutout. "I do feel like the rest of the game we picked up our pace, we had good passing.I felt like our defense and middies played a really great game."They just struck first and we just couldn't capitalize on our opportunities," Neff continued."We had plenty of corners. We had plenty of shots. We just couldn't put it in today." The Sabres earned their fourth and final corner with 11 minutes remaining but didn't managed anything on goal. Easton had two more corner chances, the last with a minute remaining but could not get the equalizer."We really had the determination to win," Sts. Peter & Paul's Jules Stepp said. "They're our friends, and even though they're our friends, we like to have our friendly competition with them."I really think we communicated well and we looked up and we passed to each other," Stepp continued. "And we played a little bit of short and long ball together. And our defense, every time they got the opportunity to get the ball they cleared it out to the side and they recovered. They were on their 'A' game today." But McQuaid thought it took a little while for that 'A' game to materialize."Defense held solid," said McQuaid after goalie Maddie Maloney and company registered their sixth shutout of the season. "They were a little befuddled in the first half and not marking the way they were supposed to. It took them until the second half to start marking the way they were supposed to.Both teams played hard. Lot of skill on both sides.K. title: CWDI responds to Cambridge commissioners' lawsuit
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
CWDI responds to Cambridge commissioners' lawsuit

 May 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 865
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc. Executive Director Matt Leonard sees the lawsuit filed earlier this month against CWDI by the Commissioners of Cambridge as a threat to the progress of the Cambridge Harbor project."We had no choice but to respond," Leonard said in a press release May 14. "The city's lawsuit has its facts wrong and threatens the significant progress CWDI is making on behalf of the community to finally realize the 30-year vision for Cambridge's waterfront."
On May 14, CWDI and CWDI Holdings filed a response to the lawsuit filed against them and Yacht Maintenance Company in Dorchester County Circuit Court on May 1.
The lawsuit, which was amended May 3, alleges CWDI is in violation of a transfer agreement it entered into with the city in June 2021. It seeks $75,000 in damages and requests temporary, preliminary and permanent injunctions stopping defendants from transferring any portion of the property in violation of the covenants of the 2021 transfer agreement.
According to court documents, CWDI's May 14 response to the suit argues that the city's complaint "is the product of the well-publicized frustrations of the recently departed city manager," Tom Carroll. The response alleges Carroll has "sought to undermine CWDI" for the past eight months.
CWDI's response replies to the commissioners' claims about the property transfer agreement and the right of CWDI Holdings to be in possession of the property.
In the lawsuit filed May 1, the commissioners mention Section 6E of the transfer agreement, which states, "no portion of the property may be transferred unless the proposed use of the subject parcel(s) is 'shovel ready' (with permits, financing and groundbreaking within 90-days of closing)..."
The May 1 suit also mentions Exhibit C of the agreement that "CWDI will not transfer, subdivide or encumber all or any portion of the property" until reaching a definitive agreement with a developer or developers. That developer must come from a developer request for proposal process, which is outlined in the transfer agreement.
The commissioners argue in the May 1 lawsuit that CWDI violated this in March 2022 by transferring city-donated property to CWDI Holdings, a limited liability company.
CWDI states in its response that the city and CWDI agreed to CWDI creating CWDI Holdings to hold title to property named in the property transfer agreement. CWDI also states this was agreed to in a 2022 amendment to a 2014 state transfer agreement.
In response to city allegations that CWDI has not gone through the request for proposal process to choose a developer, CWDI alleges in court documents that Exhibit C of the transfer agreement gives leeway to seek a master developer or combination of individual project developers for all or parts of the Cambridge Harbor project. CWDI states it issued a request for proposals, called "Request for Expressions of Interest for Redevelopment," on July 15 and issued a press release Nov. 22 summarizing proposals it had received.
In its response, CWDI discusses its plans to sell a piece of property from the 2021 transfer agreement to Yacht Maintenance. In the court document, CWDI states that it has been transparent with its intentions regarding Yacht Maintenance. It says CWDI would "routinely" update the city on the status of negotiations to convey the property to Yacht Maintenance.
CWDI's response states that the lot line revision needed for the sale of the property had been finalized and executed by both parties and delivered to Cambridge's Planning and Zoning Department on April 29.
"CWDI cannot conceive of any legitimate explanation why, more than two weeks later, the document has not yet been signed and recorded," the court document says.
The press release — sent out the same day as the response was filed — states CWDI is tasked with developing the waterfront using a "community-first approach consistent with the community's long-term vision. It says the realization of that vision is threatened by the city's actions.
The press release says the city eliminated "baseless claims" that CWDI illegally transferred property from its amended lawsuit on May 3.
"Someone advising the city commissioners must have finally read all the transfer documents, and not just the one the city used in their original filing," CWDI Board President Angie Hengst said. "So they pulled that claim in their amended filing."
The press release also states that the amended lawsuit does not contain language asserting there could not be an imminent hotel deal.
The lawsuit filed May 1 mentions CWDI's "imminent" agreement with a boutique hotel developer, which Hengst said was nearing signing at a CWDI Board of Directors meeting March 20. The lawsuit states it is "highly unlikely" that the deal is imminent because "any established hotelier would conduct significant due diligence," which includes inquiring the city about various aspects of the project. The lawsuit says the city has not received any inquiries.
"Whoever advised the city commissioners that there was no way CWDI could have a hotel deal ready to sign clearly has no idea how property development works or community development or economic development," Leonard said in the press release.
Hengst said that with CWDI's response to the lawsuit filed May 14, the board hopes the city commissioners have all of the facts to withdraw the lawsuit "and return to a more collaborative path with us and the other partners."

title: Brutal treatment of beautiful field

Brutal treatment of beautiful field

 I live in the Greens at Cross Court. Across from the entrance to the complex is an open field about the size of a football field.For most of the years that we have lived here that field was left in its natural state. That meant lots of wild flowers (chicory, daisies, black-eyed Susans, Queen Anne's lace, Joe Pye, milkweed, etc.).Also birds were among the inhabitants, especially redwing blackbirds, as well as many butterflies (swallowtails, monarchs, buckeyes, fritillaries, cabbage whites, blues, morning cloaks).Now twice a year it is mowed down to an ugly field of clumps of vegetation.And why? title: Removal of Safe Space stickers draws criticism
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
Removal of Safe Space stickers draws criticism

 May 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 396
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Calvert County School Board member Melissa Goshorn's comment at the panel's April meeting proved to be prophetic."I recognize it's going to make a lot of people unhappy," Goshorn said just prior to requesting that Superintendent of Schools Andraé Townsel to remove "Safe Space" stickers from school buildings.
Goshorn based her request on anecdotal information she received at a National School Boards Association conference during what she described as a "bone-chilling session" presented by the Beau Biden Foundation.
The story relayed to session attendees dealt with a principal who was arrested on child sex abuse charges and may have gained children's confidence by having a "Safe Space" sticker on the office door.
The sticker is widely used as a sign that LGBTQ students will not be discriminated in that space.
"I think we need to have them removed," Goshorn said.
School maintenance staff removed the stickers and the predicted unhappiness manifested itself during the board's May 8 meeting when 19 of the 20 speakers addressed the issue during the public comment segment. While a handful of the speakers indicated support for the sticker removal, many expressed opposition.
Sheri Tardio of Prince Frederick called the issue "manufactured outrage. Safe space stickers do not promote ideology. Diversity is a fact."
"You are not hiding your biases very well," said Stacy Tayman, president of the Calvert Association for Educational Support Staff.
"Removing stickers is not a violation of First Amendment rights," said school board President Jana Post in her closing comments, adding that the April discussion "was twisted" into an LGBTQ issue.
"Real safety comes from a culture of trust," Post said.
At the conclusion of public comments, board member Paul Harrison made a motion to discuss "a flag policy" at a future meeting. That policy would likely be aimed at setting parameters for displays of flags, posters and decals in school buildings. The motion passed unanimously.
Supervisor's post
The school board unanimously approved the appointment of Marc Watson as supervisor of health, physical education and athletics. The Indiana University of Pennsylvania graduate is a familiar face in Calvert County where he has previously served as a teacher, coach and principal.
Most recently, Watson served as principal of King George High School in Virginia.
Watson told the board he was looking forward to "continuing to create this wonderful environment of learning and athletics" in Calvert County.
In recommending Watson for the appointment, Townsel said the returning administrator will provide "training and mentorship for coaches."

title: White House OKs Maryland wind energy project
author: KATHARINE WILSON Capital News Service
content:
White House OKs Maryland wind energy project

 September 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KATHARINE WILSON Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 959
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — Offshore wind energy is coming to Maryland, and with it, union jobs.The Biden administration on Thursday approved Baltimore-based US Wind's project to build offshore wind turbines about 10 miles off the coast of Ocean City, Maryland.
The offshore wind farm could generate over two gigawatts of wind energy and power over 718,000 homes, according to the Department of the Interior.
President Joe Biden said in a statement that the wind energy industry had been "struggling to gain a foothold" in the years before he came into office.
"From manufacturing and shipbuilding to port operations and construction, this industry will support tens of thousands of good-paying and union jobs, provide reliable clean power to homes and businesses, strengthen our power grid against outages, and help reduce pollution — all while protecting biodiversity and marine ecosystems," the president said.
Maryland Energy Administration Director Paul Pinsky called the Biden administration's action "an important step forward in the effort to bring clean, renewable energy production to Maryland's coast."
"Today's announcement underscores the careful, comprehensive and collaborative environmental analysis that has gone into these projects," Pinsky said in a statement.
The Maryland project is the tenth commercial-scale offshore wind energy project approved by the Biden administration. Combined, the projects are projected to generate 15 gigawatts of clean energy, half of Biden's goal of 30 gigawatts of offshore wind-produced energy by 2030.
The Maryland project includes up to 114 wind turbines, four offshore substation platforms and a meteorological tower. There will be three phases to the US Wind project, two of which — called MarWin and Momentum Wind — have already received offshore renewable energy certificates from the state.
Energy is set to start flowing in December 2028 from the first phase of the project. The final project is expected to be completed in late 2027 or early 2028, according to the plan submitted by US Wind.
The approval is a win for Maryland environmental groups and the state government, which have been working for offshore wind power in the state for around 10 years.
Starting in 2013, the Maryland legislature passed a series of bills to set offshore wind energy projects in motion.
The state set a goal in 2023, through the Promoting Offshore Wind Energy Resources Act, to generate 8.5 gigawatts of power from offshore wind by 2031.
This goal has hit some road bumps along the way, including the withdrawal of Denmark-based Ørsted's planned offshore wind projects in January.
US Wind won the competitive lease sale of the 46,970 acres of federal ocean waters in 2014.
"By moving away from reliance on dirty fossil fuel energy and building renewable energy, Marylanders will be able to breathe cleaner air and benefit from new clean energy jobs," Maryland Sierra Club Chapter Director Josh Tulkin said in a statement Thursday.
Jamie DeMarco, the federal campaigns coordinator for the Chesapeake Climate Action Network, said in an interview with Capital News Service that the Maryland wind farm is a milestone in moving offshore energy generation forward in Maryland.
"This is a huge undertaking to build an entire machine to deploy offshore wind, but once that machine is built, it'll be able to hum and crank out new domestic energy, and clean energy that's going to help us clean the air and meet our climate goals," DeMarco said.
Offshore wind turbines have been coming online across the East Coast, DeMarco said, but this will be the first operational offshore wind facility in Maryland.
Environmental advocates aren't the only celebrating parties. Union officials are touting the jobs set to be created by the wind farm.
Almost 2,680 jobs annually over seven years could be created during the development and construction phase of the wind farm, according to the Interior Department.
US Wind's planned permanent offshore wind components production facility, called Sparrows Point Steel in Sparrows Point, Baltimore — the former home of Bethlehem Steel — is forecast to generate jobs for steelworkers.
The Baltimore Bethlehem Steel mill, which closed in 2012, was once the largest steel producer in the world. Sparrows Point Steel will bring steelworker jobs back to Maryland, DeMarco said, in a way that hasn't been seen since the closure of Bethlehem.
Jim Strong, the offshore wind sector assistant for the United Steelworkers International Union, told CNS Thursday that the facility is expected to bring in over 500 jobs. The project will help not only steelworkers, Strong said, but other union trades as well.
"It's about addressing our climate crisis, about creating new green energy jobs — these will be high paid union jobs," Strong said.
Strong has served as a liaison between the union and US Wind. He said that the Sparrows Point facility has the opportunity to become a "central hub" for monopile production on the Atlantic Ocean. Monopiles, steel cylinders, are used for wind turbines, bridges and other projects, he said.
US Wind is a subsidiary of Italian company Renexia SpA.
The project has some detractors, like Rep. Andy Harris (R-Maryland), who represents the Eastern Shore.
"Offshore wind industrialization comes at a heavy cost to our marine life and environment, and is an incredibly expensive way to generate electricity," Harris said on X in July. "We should never allow foreign owned companies to control our energy supply — much less harm our environment while doing it."
The federal Bureau of Ocean Energy Management's director, Elizabeth Klein, said in a statement that the Maryland project "reflects the best available science and invaluable insights from Tribes, government agencies, local communities, industry leaders, ocean users, and environmental groups gathered during our extensive environmental review process."
"As we continue to support the undeniable momentum we see along our coasts, our focus remains on fostering responsible energy development, while protecting marine life and ecosystems," she said.
Democrats in the state, including Gov. Wes Moore, have been supportive of the project. Moore signed a memorandum of understanding with the federal government in June supporting offshore wind production.

title: Hawaiian outrigger canoes making waves in the Chesapeake
author: JEREMY COX Bay Journal
content:
Hawaiian outrigger canoes making waves in the Chesapeake

 February 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JEREMY COX Bay Journal | Section: Local News 
 
 631
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Skipjacks, deadrises, log canoes, tall ships, bugeyes — the Chesapeake Bay has no shortage of iconic boats. But if a core group of devotees has anything to do with it, a vessel closely associated with the South Pacific could be next.The outrigger canoe is practically synonymous with Polynesian and Hawaiian cultures. Many Americans of a certain age, though, likely received their notions about outriggers from the closing credits of the original version of the TV crime drama Hawaii Five-O, which showed a sequence of muscly men vigorously paddling through waves.
That depiction — of brute strength and more than a whiff of masculinity — continues to loom over the sport of outrigger racing in the popular imagination. But the brand practiced by Maryland's Kent Island Outrigger Canoe Club tends, by intention, toward inclusivity and working in harmony.
"People of all ages and abilities can do this," said Bill Key, 72, a longtime member. "You can't screw it up. We're thrilled to have you out here no matter what."
To that end, during routine club practices, members are often found welcoming newcomers who want to try their hands at the ancient sport. This spring, they hosted a series of outings explicitly geared toward coaxing novices onto the water, with the hope of boosting membership.
So, there I was on a Sunday morning in April, standing with a strange-looking paddle in my hands and absolutely no idea what I was getting myself into.
The first thing you notice about an outrigger canoe is how long and narrow it is. Single and tandem versions are available. But, like the one in the Hawaii Five-O outro, the craft I boarded could comfortably seat six adults. Most outriggers in this class measure more than 40 feet from stern to bow, roughly the length of a school bus, but the main hull might be a mere 16 inches across.
This is where the "outrigger" part comes into play. Two arms (iakos in Hawaiian) project from one side of the canoe. These connect to a float (the "outrigger" or, in Hawaiian, the ama). Without these second hulls, the vessels would be highly unstable in the open seas.
Now, let's turn to the paddle. The shaft isn't straight like a traditional canoe oar or kayak paddle; it's slightly bowed, and the blade is angled back a bit to compensate for the bend. At the opposite end of the paddle is a t-shaped handle. Your palm wraps around it, kind of like a bicycle handlebar. Your lower hand should be gripping the shaft just above the blade. It feels more like digging into the water than sweeping through it.
The outrigger club here traces its history back 25 years, when John Fulton, who had recently returned to Maryland after a few years living in Hawaii, raised enough money to purchase a communal outrigger canoe.
"It's the state sport of Hawaii," he said. "Just about everybody does it."
The sport has long since migrated to the mainland United States, but its presence on the East Coast remains limited. The nationwide parent organization for outrigger canoe racing chapters lists 70 clubs operating in the three continental states that border the Pacific Ocean. The East Coast boasts a mere 17 clubs.
The Kent Island club, the only outrigger group with a Maryland address, counts about three dozen active members. They compete in races up and down the East Coast and host their own event over Labor Day weekend, a 35-mile relay race in which paddlers circumnavigate Kent Island.
From what I could gather, outrigger canoe racing tends to attract experienced standup paddleboarders or kayakers looking for a team environment.
"This is a great way (to) get out on the water with people who become your friends," said longtime member Nancy Wallace. "I think I knew one person when I first started. It becomes a family."

title: Caps fill void, acquire Thompson
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Caps fill void, acquire Thompson

 June 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: News 
 
 751
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Tampa Bay Lightning and Washington Capitals were active Saturday during rounds 2-7 of the NHL draft, each making multiple moves to shake up their rosters for next season and beyond.Tampa Bay sent two-time Stanley Cup-winning defenseman Mikhail Sergachev to Utah and depth forward Tanner Jeannot to Los Angeles in moves that cleared more than $11 million in salary cap space. That could be enough money to keep captain and face of the franchise Steven Stamkos or make a significant free agent signing, and it will go a long way to providing room to lock up cornerstone defenseman Victor Hedman with a long-term contract extension.
The Lightning got younger on the blue line by receiving 24-year-old defenseman J.J. Moser, along with forward prospect Conor Geekie and two draft picks for Sergachev, who was signed through 2031 making $8.5 million annually. A 2025 second-rounder and a fourth this year allows Tampa Bay to restock its prospect pool after making eight consecutive playoff appearances, winning two titles and reaching the final three times.
That contending window remains wide open, and general manage Julien BriseBois now has flexibility to retool on the fly with free agency opening Monday. Stamkos staying is a possibility, and now the Lightning have the opportunity to pursue one or more of the top wingers available, a group that includes Jake Guentzel, Patrick Kane and Jonathan Marchessault.
The Capitals already did their big-name hunting last week by acquiring highly paid center Pierre-Luc Dubois from the Kings for goaltender Darcy Kuemper. On Saturday, they filled that void in net by acquiring Logan Thompson from host Vegas for a pair of third-round picks.
Thompson figures to split time with Charlie Lindgren in a tandem costing less than $2 million total next season, with a year left on each goalie's contract. Thompson, 27, was an All-Star and played 37 games for the Golden Knights during their 2022-23 championship run before getting injured before the playoffs.
"I got a lot more that I can prove in this league and I'm hoping that I get that opportunity with Washington," said Thompson, who was in bed when he was informed of the trade and hurried to the Sphere for a previously scheduled autograph signing. "Actually, it was a good alarm clock. I woke up to that and then obviously get ready and come down, and I knew it was going to be an interesting day."
Long before getting his name engraved on the Stanley Cup, Thompson got his first foray into the NHL Capitals development camp in the summer of 2018. He played for Washington at back-to-back prospect showcases, went to training camp with the American Hockey League's Hershey Bears in 2019, starred for the ECHL's South Carolina and earned his first contract as a result.
"I'm thankful for the Washington goalie department every day," Thompson told The Associated Press at 2023 All-Star Weekend. "They're the reason why I'm here. They're the only team that gave me a chance three years ago. If it wasn't for them, I wouldn't be here today."
Washington also traded fourth-line winger Beck Malenstyn to Buffalo for the 43rd pick, taking U.S.-born defenseman Cole Hutson, and traded up in the third round to select Ilya Protas, the younger brother of Capitals forward Aliaksei Protas. Malenstyn, 26, is a restricted free agent with arbitration rights who had 21 points in 81 games during his first full NHL season and gives the Sabres Buffalo valuable forward depth as they try to end the league's longest playoff drought.
Looking to end the longest Stanley Cup drought, the Toronto Maple Leafs took a step toward upgrading their defense by acquiring the rights to pending free agent Chris Tanev from Dallas for a 2026 seventh-round pick. The trade gives Toronto the first crack at signing the valuable 24-year-old top-four defenseman.
Vegas moved quickly to replenish goalie depth by acquiring Akira Schmid from New Jersey along with young forward Alexander Holtz in a trade that sent Paul Cotter and a third-rounder to the Devils. Among the other moves, St. Louis traded Kevin Hayes and a '25 second-rounder to Pittsburgh for future considerations to shed the remainder of the his contract, and Boston sent Jakob Lauko to Minnesota for Vinni Lettieri in a swap of centers that also involved draft picks.
The Sabres after getting Malenstyn began the process of buying out the contract of forward Jeff Skinner, GM Kevyn Adams confirmed at the conclusion of the draft. The buyout saves Buffalo $7.5 million next season while spreading out money owed to Skinner against the cap through 2030.

title: Civil rights leader who preached nonviolent protest dies
author: Staff Writer
content:
Civil rights leader who preached nonviolent protest dies

 June 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 451
 Words 

 Read News Document

 LOS ANGELES — The Rev. James Lawson Jr., an apostle of nonviolent protest who schooled activists to withstand brutal reactions from white authorities as the Civil Rights Movement gained traction, has died, his family said Monday. He was 95.His family said Lawson died on Sunday after a short illness in Los Angeles, where he spent decades working as a pastor, labor movement organizer and university professor.
Lawson was a close adviser to the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., who called him "the leading theorist and strategist of nonviolence in the world."
Lawson met King in 1957, after spending three years in India soaking up knowledge about Mohandas K. Gandhi's independence movement. King would travel to India himself two years later, but at the time, he had only read about Gandhi in books.
The two Black pastors — both 28 years old — quickly bonded over their enthusiasm for the Indian leader's ideas, and King urged Lawson to put them into action in the American South.
Lawson soon led workshops in church basements in Nashville, Tennessee, that prepared John Lewis, Diane Nash, Bernard Lafayette, Marion Barry, the Freedom Riders and many others to peacefully withstand vicious responses to their challenges of racist laws and policies.
Lawson's lessons led Nashville to become the first major city in the South to desegregate its downtown, on May 10, 1960, after hundreds of well-organized students staged lunch-counter sit-ins and boycotts of discriminatory businesses.
Lawson's particular contribution was to introduce Gandhian principles to people more familiar with biblical teachings, showing how direct action could expose the immorality and fragility of racist white power structures.
Gandhi said "that we persons have the power to resist the racism in our own lives and souls," Lawson told the AP. "We have the power to make choices and to say no to that wrong. That's also Jesus."
Years later, in 1968, it was Lawson who organized the sanitation workers strike that fatefully drew King to Memphis. Lawson said he was at first paralyzed and forever saddened by King's assassination.
"I thought I would not live beyond 40, myself," Lawson said. "The imminence of death was a part of the discipline we lived with, but no one as much as King."
Still, Lawson made it his life's mission to preach the power of nonviolent direct action.
"I'm still anxious and frustrated," Lawson said as he marked the 50th anniversary of King's death with a march in Memphis. "The task is unfinished."
Civil rights activist Diane Nash was a 21-year-old college student when she began attending Lawson's Nashville workshops, which she called life-changing.
"His passing constitutes a very great loss," Nash said. "He bears, I think, more responsibility than any other single person for the civil rights movement of Blacks being nonviolent in this country."

title: Honoring ancient grains - Old Wye Mill welcomes visitors, local vendors to historic flour mill
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
Honoring ancient grains - Old Wye Mill welcomes visitors, local vendors to historic flour mill

 August 23, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: A1 | Section: News 
 
 447
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WYE MILLS - Outside, the steel wheel, driven by water descending from the mill pond across the road, powers the massive 140-year-old millstones.Indoors, the millstones rotate constantly inside their wooden housing, creating a hypnotic rumble as they pulverize the ancient grain called einkorn wheat into a fine powder.A gentle breeze stirs the flour into occasional soft wisps that rise from the large wooden hopper in the historic Old Wye Mill.With temperatures in the low 80s and low humidity, the weather was perfect for grinding grain during the Ancient Grains and Local Products Festival Saturday, Aug. 19, in Wye Mills, named for the flour milling operation.The mill, established in 1682, is the oldest continuously operated water powered grist mill in the U.S., and one of the oldest buildings in Maryland.Volunteers were on hand from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. to greet a steady stream of visitors and man the small gift shop where bags of stoneground corn meal, buckwheat flour, grits and einkorn wheat flour were for sale. Cookbooks and salt-glazed pottery also were sold.Retired middle school teacher Andy House of Bowie has been a volunteer since 2001, but has served as one of a handful of volunteer millers for about six years. He welcomed the low humidity that affects both the wooden structures and the grain."When everything works, it's a relaxing place to be," House said. "It's working perfectly today." Local vendors set up tents and displays outdoors on the tree-shaded lawn, and volunteers sold homemade baked goods indoors. Local honey, grass-fed beef, wines and produce were on sale.Old Wye Mill is open from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. Wednesday to Saturday and 1 to 3 p.m. Sunday, May through October. For more information, visit www.oldwyemill.org.

title: Towns need to balance pride in past with future
author: BRANDON WRIGHT
content:
Towns need to balance pride in past with future

 May 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BRANDON WRIGHT | Section: Columns 
 
 805
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Recently, I listened to a webinar about the challenges of planning, land use and economic development in rural areas. Communities frequently struggle to grow and still maintain their character. Balancing economic growth with the community's heritage is among the most significant challenges for elected officials because the two are often intertwined.An industry of consultants has grown up to help communities meet these challenges. Like the consultants, I believe a balance can be reached.
Maybe I am too much of an optimist, but I think opposing groups can find common ground if they are honest and transparent. I served as chief of staff in the Maryland Department of Planning nearly 10 years ago. I met with town council members, county commissioners and local business leaders, all vested in making their communities strong and vibrant. My confidence comes from listening to their hopes, dreams and goals for their communities.
I met with the consultants, too. Everyone wanted the same for the community — the absolute best.
Compromises that are in the best interests of all the various constituencies and stakeholders can be forged, even in rural Maryland like the Eastern Shore. There is no place like it. Its ecosystems and economies are different, even from other rural parts of the state. So much of the economy is dependent on the Chesapeake Bay and the rivers that feed into it. It is teeming with myriad species of animals on land and sea.
The motto of Federalsburg, my hometown in Caroline County, is "Pride in the Past, Faith in the Future." Unfortunately in towns like Federalsburg, more emphasis is placed on the past than the future. Local officials, sometimes pressured by citizens, have these gauzy memories of a better time and place in the community's past and yearn to get back to it.
However, in doing so, they strip decision-makers of any chance at finding the right balance between the past and future, choking off opportunities to attract large employers, employees and all the businesses that spring up to support them both.
As a young boy, I fished for bass and perch on the Marshyhope Creek, the northwest fork of the Nanticoke River. I heard the story that the DuPont Company was looking to build its new nylon factory in the area, and the Marshyhope Creek made Federalsburg an attractive site. Unfortunately, DuPont built its nylon plant on the Nanticoke River in Seaford, Delaware, less than 10 miles from Federalsburg. The plant was constructed outside the town, and Seaford quickly became a company town. The contrast between the two towns is dramatic.
Federalsburg missed out again, this time on AquaCon. An international salmon farming operation would have brought several hundred well-paying jobs, jobs with health care and all the other benefits that help smooth the rough edges of life. AquaCon would have increased revenue to the town, support for existing small businesses and all the different services that make a small town tick.
Town officials, under pressure from citizens, said no to this opportunity. Rather than work with the company to better understand the project and address concerns, the town leaders said no and now another community will benefit from these jobs and the economic development that comes with it.
According to state data, Caroline County is among the most economically depressed counties in Maryland. We can't lay all the blame at the feet of elected leaders for that. I know many of them, and each one cares deeply for the communities they serve; otherwise, they wouldn't do it. The blame, however, should be shared with the voters that elected them and the voters who pushed the elected leaders to say no to investments in the towns that would spur economic growth over fears of the unknown and fears of something different, a break from the past.
Because the citizens share the blame, they are responsible for turning their communities around.
Our rural communities are blessed with resources that other towns and cities envy. We have kind, friendly people who care for each other. We have the greatest renewable resource of all — an unending stream of smart and talented young men and women graduating from our high schools and colleges, prepared to make the world a better place. Let's do everything we can to keep them here.
Let our legacy be that we found that balance that everyone strives for and leave the next generation and the generations that follow a community poised for growth, good jobs and continued access to outstanding education. Let's be sure we live up to the motto, "Pride in the Past, Faith in the Future."
Brandon Wright grew up in Federalsburg and graduated from Colonel Richardson High School in 1997 and Salisbury University in 2001. He was the chief of staff at the Maryland Department of Planning from 2015 to 2017. He now lives in Annapolis, but his family still resides just outside of Federalsburg.

title: Planners not sold on 365-unit development near new Easton hospital
author: Konner Metz
content:
Planners not sold on 365-unit development near new Easton hospital

 June 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 739
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — An application for a 365-unit residential development near the in-construction regional medical center in Easton has been submitted to the town's Planning Commission for review, though it's drawing criticism from some town and county officials.The project, Fox Chase Estates, is proposed on 112 acres of land off of Airport Road nestled within the Easton Technology Center. Developers are seeking town approval through Easton's planned unit development process, which would allow the homes to be built on the commercial-zoned land.
The developers are Easton Sunrise Partners LLC and Scott Wagner, a Talbot County businessman and a former Republican member of the Pennsylvania State Senate. They previously aimed to build warehouses on the site, but in recent years plans shifted to residential — an effort that Shore Regional Health President and CEO Ken Kozel supports, according to Wagner's attorney, Lawrence Scott.
"We are trying to build a residential community that meets the need of the hospital," Scott said Tuesday, noting that Wagner and Kozel have met to discuss the project.
In a statement Wednesday, Kozel said affordable housing availability is "essential" to recruit and retain health care workers in a rural community like Easton. The hospital is not legally or financially involved with the proposed development, Scott said.
At an hours long meeting Tuesday, Planning Commission members were nowhere near ready to provide a positive recommendation on the proposal.
"It feels like we're being the Planning Commission for the hospital and not for the town," said member William Ryall. "And that gives me a lot of concern."
Victoria McAndrews said the plans are "overwhelmingly suburban." Michael Ports, the commission's vice chair, said a lack of connectivity from the proposed development — which sits at the northernmost part of town limits — to Easton's core is a "non-starter."
Philip Toussaint, commission chair, said parts of the plan significantly fall short of meeting Easton's comprehensive plan, which sets the framework for how the town facilitates growth. That comprehensive plan is undergoing an update currently, and McAndrews said such a large project should wait for that update.
Scott said Tuesday that developers have met individually with Town Council members and Mayor Megan Cook multiple times and that the 365-unit project meets affordable housing needs that the town and its residents are asking for.
THE UNITS
Application documents show that developers are planning for a variety of units, including single-family homes, three-story townhomes and multifamily buildings, along with two commercial buildings.
The 365 units are broken down as follows: 108 single-family detached homes, 137 three-story townhomes and 120 multifamily units, the latter of which are contained in four four-story buildings.
The density is well below the maximum permitted by the town's planned unit development standards. According to developers, 185 of the 365 units would be affordably priced.
"We're doing that without even the statutory forcing of us to do it," Scott said, adding that developers have a "bidding war" from home building companies to take on the project. "The market is working on its own."
APPROVAL PROCESS
Fox Chase Estates still has a handful of steps before it is approved by Easton officials. With significant pushback already, it's likely to be a lengthy process.
In staff analysis of the application, concerns were raised about the site plan, which only includes one main vehicle access point to the 365-unit development. An emergency exit stretching west to Goldsborough Neck Road did not satisfy town staff. Scott said developers would prefer not to add that as a main access point but will consider it.
"We really want two access points to any project like this," said Town Engineer Rick Van Emburgh.
Talbot County Engineer Ray Clarke criticized the project and the lack of communication between developers and the county. Clarke said it'll put an undue stress on Airport and Goldsborough Neck Roads and added concerns that the homes will be in the runway protection zone for Easton Airport.
"We need to be very, very careful when we're looking at these types of development," Clarke said. "This was general commercial as originally planned. We were told three or four years ago it was going to be warehouses."
On Tuesday, the Planning Commission opted to place a pin in the matter and revisit it on July 17. Commission members may then provide a recommendation.
Once the commission makes its recommendation, council members will consider the application and hold a public hearing before any decision. While the council may take the commission's decision into account, the five council members have the final say, with a majority required for approval.

title: CCTC AMP students present designs - Rashad Wilson's winning design adorns dartboard cabinet project

CCTC AMP students present designs - Rashad Wilson's winning design adorns dartboard cabinet project

 Page: 1A | Section: News

 RIDGELY - The seventh cohort of Advanced Manufacturing Program students at Caroline Career and Technology Center recently presented design ideas for their current project, a dartboard cabinet.The winning design was created by Rashad Wilson, and was inspired by the doors one might find hanging in a saloon in the Old West."Rashad's dartboard design offers a new challenge for the class and me," teacher Keith Hale said.Although the students possessed the software and the capability to machine a three-dimensional object like the steer skull and horns, they had never attempted it before. "This design is more challenging than designs created by previous classes," he said.This particular project was generated three years ago when an AMP student approached Hale with the idea of manufacturing dartboard cabinets. Hale and the class were excited to make this idea a reality.Since then, AMP cabinets with dartboard with darts included have been one of AMP's most popular products, selling out even before they were presented.Each time AMP students manufacture a product, they follow the same template.It begins with research, mood-boarding and a product pitch. With dartboards, students research the history, rules and professional leagues in the game of darts. Then each student must come up with a design for the project, followed by drafting their design and placing it on a Mood Board.This Mood Board becomes a visual they can refer to as they present their product pitch.Business partners, school officials, parents and former students are then invited to watch the students' product pitches Oct. 26.One by one, students manage the difficult task of individually pitching the details and merits of their designs to the class and guests in attendance.At the end of the presentations, everyone votes and a design is chosen.The next step in the process is called "napkin sketching," which is a sketch of the product views and dimensions.These sketches are then taken to the computer aided drafting lab, where more accurate prints are made. From those prints, numeric commands are created that will drive a computer numeric control machine, which is a robot programmed to cut pieces out of stock material.Once complete, an audience is once again assembled for student presentations of the finished products, which are also offered for sale.

title: Letter had no good reasoning
author: Staff Writer
content:
Letter had no good reasoning

 January 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 397
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Sometimes you publish letters to the editor that contain strong political views that are based on false information or bad logic or both.When a political view is based on good reasoning, I don't feel the need to respond. But I do feel the need to respond when a writer gets published with no good reasoning. Such is the case with Mr. Adrian's letter "Gone down a dark road," in Sunday's 14 January edition.
His letter is filled with false statements. For example, he claims that Democrats control elections to push some kind of agenda. There is no evidence for that. Quite the contrary. Mr. Adrian somehow completely missed the well-known information that Republicans are involved in managing elections. There are hundreds, if not thousands, of examples.
Even the head Republican, Donald Trump, knew that when he called the Republicans who control elections asking them to alter votes in 2020. As another example, Mr. Adrian seems to claim that harvesting crops in the fall leads to harvesting ballots. I don't think there is any evidence for that.
But what really gets me is the use of questions for arguments. This illogical method of argument is a tool of conspiracy theorists and despots for thousands of years. "When did you stop beating your spouse?" is the classic retort to that entire form of reasoning.
Mr. Adrian received a document about mail-in ballots and points out he could print it. "What could possibly go wrong?" he writes as if that question is a legitimate argument against the entire process. Without evidence, the question makes no sense, any more than me asking Mr. Adrian when he stopped beating people. Mr. Adrian should read about how the Arizona Republican Party spent millions of tax dollars on a month's-long audit of ballots that only showed Mr. Biden's votes were undercounted. Georgia audited their elections three times by hand counting ballots and found no fraud. These are just two facts out of hundreds of examples that belie the assumption underlying Mr. Adrian's question.
Mr. Adrian poses many other questions that assume evidence where none exists. And he ends his letter with the question, "Which political party controls the Board of Elections anyway?" as if that is a reason for everyone to doubt elections. It is not.
All available evidence is that elections in Maryland are fair and honest. People should appreciate that and take the time to vote.
MICHAEL DAVIS
Easton
