 Sitting around a lunch table at Harrison's Harbour Lights on Wednesday, pioneers of Talbot County's advanced life support program told me about their vision for comprehensive cardiac response efforts.Some surely saw it as a far-fetched goal back in 1985, as people were accustomed to sometimes 20-minute wait times for first responders, even during serious cardiac emergencies.
But a group of five Easton firefighters and select hospital and county partners believed there was a gap to fill in saving lives. They voluntarily manned a life support unit 24/7, 365 days a year.

author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com

Marriott awards top honor to Easton Fairfield Inn

 August 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Business

 EASTON — The Easton Fairfield Inn & Suites has been recognized as the 2023 Hotel of the Year by Marriott out of more than 1,000 Fairfield hotels worldwide.Tucked next to Chipotle off of U.S. Route 50 and Chapel Road, the hotel is managed by Hill Hospitality, a hotel development and management company. Chad Hill, the company's vice president, said the 82-room hotel stands out in more ways than one.
"This is not a prototypical Fairfield hotel," Hill said. He emphasized its cleanliness, customer service and customized designs that give the hotel a small-town, Eastern Shore feel.
Every year, Hill said Marriott checks into each hotel for a random inspection. Marriott assesses each hotel based on a set of standards, while separately soliciting feedback from recent guests. Based on these evaluations and guest review scores, a small percentage of hotels receive the Diamond Award, a recognition from Marriott of the highest performing tier of Fairfield hotels.
Of the 1,118 hotels evaluated, the Easton Fairfield Inn & Suites was rated fourth in intent to recommend, fifth in staff service and seventh in cleanliness.
The Easton Fairfield was recognized with the 2023 Diamond Award, marking its second consecutive year and third since opening in 2015. However, this year, the hotel went a step further when Marriott recognized it as Hotel of the Year within the Fairfield brand.
According to Cristina Shockley, Hill Hospitality's director of operations, the Easton hotel is a popular destination for corporate stays and those in town for weddings.
Shockley added that many of the employees are familiar with the Eastern Shore and its history and charm, a benefit for guests that are visiting for the first time. Some team members have been at the hotel since it opened, she said.
"We're so fortunate to have an incredible team," Hill said of the team that hovers around 23 employees.
Since the hospitality group is based in Easton, Hill said it's special to have the hometown property recognized at such a high level. Hill Hospitality manages six hotels, two each in Maryland and South Carolina, and one each in Maine and New York. Two additional hotels are in the works, including one in Fruitland that will open in June 2025.
"Every guest is given the opportunity to enjoy the charming small-town atmosphere that the Easton team provides when staying at our hotel," Shockley said in a written statement. "The Hotel of the Year award is a testament to the team's unwavering commitment to give the ultimate in guest service. title: Local student wins national essay contest
author: DERECK SARIER Special to the Bay Times Record Observer / Star Democrat
content:
Local student wins national essay contest

 March 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DERECK SARIER Special to the Bay Times Record Observer / Star Democrat | Section: Entertainment 
 
 443
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Viana Johnston, an eighth grade student attending Lighthouse Christian Academy in Stevensville, has been recently recognized as the national middle school winner of a Bill of Rights Essay contest hosted by the Stanley M. Herzog Foundation.The Herzog Foundation is a national organization dedicated to "advancing Christian education." The foundation enriches Christian (K-12) education by creating and leading various programs.
One of these programs was the 2023 Bill of Rights Essay Contest. All middle and high school students enrolled in a Christian school or those homeschooled in the U.S. were eligible to participate. Winners were selected from one middle school and one high school. Each winner would go on to receive $250 from the Herzog Foundation. The winners' schools also received an additional $250.
Participants were asked to answer these questions in three pages or less, "What made the Bill of Rights so revolutionary and unique when it was ratified? How has the Bill of Rights shaped our country?"
In an excerpt from Viana's eloquently crafted three-page essay, the middle school winner wrote, "The Bill of Rights is famous for that little, life-changing word: freedom, but what most people don't realize is that these documents weren't written overnight. Real people struggled, wrestled, and mulled over each word and phrase that went into the Bill of Rights, until it was finally ratified on December 15, 1791. Not only was it composed through much time and consideration but it secured the rights of people today granting our blessed country to grow, expand, and enter new times of innovation. It summarized what we stood for then and stand for now. It lets a person breathe, work, and earn their way to success."
The Herzog Foundation announced Viana, daughter of George and Cathy Johnston, as the middle school winner of the contest in December. Johnston received the prize money and a trophy for her achievement.
In a release announcing the winners, Herzog Foundation Chairman Todd Graves said, "The Bill of Rights was ratified over 230 years ago and still stands as a beacon for our most fundamental rights as Americans. It's crucial that all young students understand the significance of this founding document."
Kathy Guerra, head of Lighthouse Christian Academy, stated the school was initially in disbelief, as this was the first time their school had made an entry to a contest of this magnitude. However, they were not surprised that Viana had won, as she is a gifted writer who creates masterworks of art with her words. "Viana is an inquisitive, energetic, and ambitious student," says Guerra, who "seeks to excel in all of her subjects."
To learn more about the Herzog Foundation and the programs it has to offer, visit www.herzog foundation.com.

title: rest of mike's story
author: Staff Writer
content:
rest of mike's story

 September 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Rest Of Mikes Story 
 
 710
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FOCUS ON THE BASERyan Waite, a veteran campaign consultant and vice president of public affairs with northern California-based consulting firm Think Big, said the political parties and most campaigns are focused on ginning up and turning out their voter bases and don't tend to engage with low-propensity voters."They put resources where it is going to make the most difference. Typically, you are looking at people who have previously voted, who are kind in that soft middle," said Waite, who has mostly worked on Republican campaigns.
Waite said while social media can help engage more voters and could help engage nonvoters, especially young ones, the medium presents challenges.
"You are competing with everything else. The slice of time you get in front of them is very very small," he said of the social media content streams.
Negative campaigning, coarse social discourse and misinformation on key issues have also magnified on social media leaving voters and nonvoters distrustful of content and disparate and sometimes ideological information sources.
"It's hard for average voters to figure out what's going on," said Waite.
In an Aug. 26 letter to the House Judiciary Committee, META Platforms chairman and CEO Mark Zuckerberg said the Biden-Harris administration "repeatedly pressured" Facebook and Instagram to censor dissenting content (including humor and satire) related to COVID-19.
The White House defended those actions as helping protect public health from misinformation.
Recent surveys show low levels of trust in politics, the media and government, as well as plenty of economic stress stemming from the post-pandemic inflation wave.
A June survey by financial firm Credit Karma and research firm Qualtrics found 68% of Americans don't believe official economic data touting job gains and easing inflation after post-pandemic spikes in prices.
Another recent poll by Gallup and the Walton Foundation shows Gen Zers (ages 12 to 27) have little trust in the media, government and politics. But they showed strong turnout in 2020 and are expected to also show up in November, said Craig Snyder, campaign director for Haley Voters for Harris (a group that hopes to get GOP supporters of former South Carolina Gov. Nikki Haley to eschew Trump).
NEW ENERGY?Snyder said Harris' campaign should energize younger voters more than the matchup between Trump and President Joe Biden.
"They weren't excited about a race between two 80-year-old men," said Snyder, noting that Democratic enthusiasm for Harris will also generate GOP energy for Trump.
Harris was installed at the top of the Democratic ticket after Biden, 81, was pressured to quit the race by donors and party power players over concerns about his age.
Snyder said voting groups such as suburban women, Black and Hispanic men, along with voters on both sides of Israel's war in Gaza against Hamas could tip the race in battlegrounds such as Michigan, Wisconsin, North Carolina and Pennsylvania.
Independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s endorsement of Trump could also shift his voters, many of whom are disaffected by COVID policies (including vaccines), in key states.
Snyder also sees another contingent of nonvoters beyond the disaffected and those with logistical barriers.
"There's a third group," he said. "They just don't connect politics to their lives."
GOTV EFFORTSPolitical organizations on both sides do have get-out-the-vote (GOTV) efforts across the country, including some aimed at first-time and nonvoters.
Conservative groups — such as Christians United for Israel — hope to turn out evangelicals for Trump and Republicans. That includes working with churches across the country on support for Israel and voter mobilization.
Democrats look to college campuses, as well as Native Americans, Blacks and Hispanics in key races.
In Montana, Nick Marroletti, coordinated campaign director for the state Democratic Party, said grassroots turn-out efforts have included knocking on 100,000 doors and making 97,000 phone calls supporting U.S. Sen. Jon Tester, who faces a tough challenge from Republican Tim Sheehy.
'LACK OF FAITH'Mara Ostfeld, a research scientist at the University of Michigan, analyzed voting sentiments in Detroit and found Latino voters, in particular, have lower turnout propensities.
Ostfeld agrees that nonvoters, especially lower-income ones, don't see the outcome of elections impacting their daily lives.
"There is a disconnect," Ostfeld said. But she also said that doesn't mean nonvoters are not engaged or connected to their communities in other ways and don't follow politics.
"It's not like they are disinterested or disengaged," Ostfeld said. "There is just a lack of faith in the political system in particular."

title: Natural Resources Police use thermal imaging to rescue lost kayaker in Talbot County
author: Konner Metz
content:
Natural Resources Police use thermal imaging to rescue lost kayaker in Talbot County

 July 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 344
 Words 

 Read News Document

 BROAD CREEK — Police and firefighters teamed to locate a lost juvenile kayaker last weekend in Talbot County.On July 4 around 10 p.m., Maryland Natural Resources Police were informed of a lost kayaker in the Broad Creek area, which is on the west side of the county south of St. Michaels. Officials said he was on the water for "several hours" and around three miles from home.
Using thermal imaging cameras, a Natural Resource Police aviation unit quickly found the lost person — in around five minutes, according to Sgt. John Buchanan, chief pilot for NRP. Buchanan was in the aircraft with tactical flight officer Christian Helwig.
Buchanan said the kayaker left out of Grace Creek.
"I think it got dark on him, and he didn't know where he was," Buchanan said.
Once located, police used a spotlight to direct a rescue boat from the Tilghman Island Volunteer Fire Company toward the juvenile.
A video posted to Facebook by Natural Resource Police shows the aircraft hone in on the kayaker and direct the fire boat to retrieve the juvenile.
Buchanan said such a rescue isn't too common, but it become somewhat prominent during boating season.
"(The) Chesapeake Bay and the tributaries are very large," Buchanan said. "When you start thinking about the different rivers and creeks and stuff off the Chesapeake Bay, we go out on different search missions like that probably a few times a month."
The pilot emphasized Helwig's expertise is crucial to such rescues. Helwig handles the thermal imaging camera, which can expose subjects in dark conditions, as well as a mapping system to pull up addresses and latitudes and longitudes.
"He's gotten really good with it, he's worked really hard at it," Buchanan said. "He's made us as a team very successful going out and doing these search missions."
Buchanan advises those going out on the water, especially alone, to be prepared with a charged cell phone and other equipment in case of emergency.
"Have a life jacket if you're out at night," he said. "Obviously have some kind of flashlight. And know the area, that's probably the biggest thing."

title: A single candlelight can chase darkness away
author: Ken George; Ridgely Church of the Brethren
content:
A single candlelight can chase darkness away

 September 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ken George; Ridgely Church of the Brethren | Page: B8 | Section: News 
 
 265
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The book of Lamentations, attributed to the prophet Jeremiah, is a sad book that expresses sorrow and regret over the destruction of Jerusalem and the temple, over the people turning away from God and over the desolation of their country at the hands of the Babylonians.The definition of the word "lament", according to the Mirriam-Webster dictionary, is "to mourn aloud, to express sorrow" or to "regret strongly".There are five chapters in Lamentations; and, yet, in the middle chapter, amid all this sadness and regret, there lays a ray of hope. We read in Chapter 3, verse 21-23, "But this I call to mind, and therefore I have hope: the steadfast love of the Lord never ceases, His mercies never come to an end.They are new every morning; great is Your faithfulness!" We often find ourselves lamenting the state of the world today.Injustices against minorities, human trafficking, mass shootings and other heartbreaking occurrences seem to dominate the headlines of the news. Even so, amid all our trials, troubles and tribulations, we are reminded that the sun peeks out from the clouds, and a single candlelight can chase the night away.In John 8:12, Jesus tells us that He is "the light of the world", and those who follow Him "will not walk in the darkness, but will have the light of life." With God's word, and with Jesus as the light of the world that we follow, we have the hope that the "steadfast love of the Lord never ceases. His mercies never come to an end." In the end, it will be all right.

title: It'S Time For Christmas Casseroles
author: Marie Savage; Country Cooking
content:
It'S Time For Christmas Casseroles

 December 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Marie Savage; Country Cooking | Page: 16 | Section: News 
 
 1361
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Remember the excitement on Christmas morning when we were children - getting out of bed at 4 or 5 a.m. trying to come downstairs.The fun began and soon we had to dress and go to Grandmom and Grandpop's house to gather with the rest of the family to have a large country style breakfast.A lot of time was lost being away from our gifts at home those mornings until the later breakfast casserole was born.Christmas morning became perfect. Families would gather mid-morning (around 10 or 11 a.m.) bringing their favorite breakfast casseroles to share.The children of all ages got to enjoy their gifts before traveling. Some years, it would be at the grandparents' place but other members began taking turns also.Enjoy today's recipes to share with everyone and send some of your favorites to me at mmsavage21145@gmail.com so I can share with the readers.PANCAKE CASSEROLE Cooking spray, pancakes, 6 large eggs, 1.5 cups heavy cream, 1 cup whole milk, 25 cup granulated sugar, 1 tsp vanilla bean paste, .25 tsp kosher salt, unsalted butter and maple syrup (for serving).Lightly coat a 13-by 9-inch baking dish with cooking spray. Arrange pancakes in a baking dish in three rows, overlapping slightly, starting at a long end. Whisk together eggs, cream, milk, sugar, vanilla and salt in a bowl. Slowly pour mixture over pancakes.Cover and refrigerate for at least 8 hours or up to overnight. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees.Bake the casserole, covered, in a preheated oven for 25 minutes. Uncover and continue baking until the center is set, about 25 minutes. Let stand for 5 minutes. Dot with pats of butter; drizzle with syrup.CHEESY SAUSAGE, EGG AND HASH BROWN CASSEROLE 3 tbsps olive oil (divided), 8 ounces ground pork sausage, 1 sweet onion (diced), 1 poblano pepper (seeded and chopped), 1 red bell pepper (seeded and chopped), 1.5 tsps kosher salt (divided), 2 cups refrigerated diced potatoes, .75 tsp garlic powder, 4 ounces your favorite shredded cheese, 5 large eggs, .25 cup heavy whipping cream, 1 tbsp minced fresh chives. Preheat the oven to 425 degrees with an oven rack about 6 inches from heat. Heat 1 tbsp of the olive oil in a 10-inch cast-iron skillet over medium-high.Add sausage. Cook, breaking up sausage into pieces with a wooden spoon, until golden brown and just cooked through, about 4 minutes. Remove sausage to a medium bowl with a slotted spoon; set aside. Do not wipe the skillet clean. Add sweet onion, poblano chile, red bell pepper, and .5 tsp of the salt to the skillet. Cook over medium-high, stirring occasionally, until onion is tender and peppers have charred in spots, about 8 minutes. Remove with a slotted spoon to bowl with sausage. Wipe the skillet clean.Heat the remaining 2 tbsps of olive oil in a skillet over medium-high.Add diced potatoes to the skillet in an even layer.Cook, undisturbed, until browned on bottom, about 5 minutes. Add ½ tsp of the salt. Continue cooking, stirring occasionally, until golden brown and crispy on most sides, about 5 minutes.Remove from heat.Return sausage and pepper mixture to skillet and add garlic powder. Stir to combine. Stir in ½ cup of the cheese until just combined.Whisk together eggs, cream, and remaining ½ tsp salt in a medium bowl. Pour over mixture in skillet, and tilt pan to allow eggs to distribute.Top with remaining ½ cup each of the cheeses. Bake in a preheated oven until eggs have set and cheeses have melted, about 8 minutes.Increase oven temperature to broil, and broil until cheeses have turned golden brown, 2 to 3 minutes. Remove; let stand for 5 minutes.Sprinkle with chives. Slice and serve immediately.BISCUITS AND GRAVY CASSEROLE 1 (1-lb.) pkg. ground pork sausage,1/2 cup chopped yellow onion (from 1 small onion),1/4 cup plus 1 Tbsp. unsalted butter, 1/3 cup (about 1 1/2 oz.) all-purpose flour,3 cups whole milk,6 ounces pepper Jack cheese, shredded (about 1 1/2 cups),3/4 tsp kosher salt,1/2 tsp black pepper, Cooking spray,1 (25-oz.) pkg. frozen Southern-style biscuits (12 count) (such as Pillsbury Grands),2 tbsps minced fresh chives. Preheat the oven to 350°F.Place sausage and onion in a large skillet over medium, and cook, stirring often, until sausage crumbles and is no longer pink and onion is translucent, 6 to 8 minutes.Transfer mixture to a plate lined with paper towels to drain. Wipe the skillet clean. Reduce heat to low, and add 1/4 cup of the butter to the skillet; cook, whisking often, until melted. Whisk in flour until smooth. Cook, whisking constantly, 1 minute. Gradually whisk in milk; increase heat to medium, and cook, whisking constantly, until thickened and bubbly, 5 to 6 minutes. Whisk in shredded cheese, and cook, whisking often, until cheese is melted and mixture is smooth, 30 to 40 seconds. Stir in sausage mixture, salt, and pepper.Transfer mixture to a lightly greased (with cooking spray) 13-x 9-inch baking dish. Arrange biscuits on top of sausage mixture. Bake in a preheated oven until biscuits are golden brown and gravy is bubbly, 30 to 35 minutes. Microwave remaining 1 tbsp butter in a small microwavable bowl on HIGH until melted, about 20 seconds.Remove the casserole from the oven; brush biscuits with melted butter, and sprinkle with chives.Let stand for 10 minutes before serving.SLOW COOKER CINNAMON ROLL CASSEROLECooking spray,1/2 cup granulated sugar,1/2 cup packed light brown sugar,1 tsp ground cinnamon, 2 (16.3-oz.) cans refrigerated southern homestyle biscuits (such as Pillsbury Grands!Southern Homestyle), biscuits separated and cut into fourths (about 64 biscuit pieces total),1/2 cup (4 oz.) salted butter, melted, plus 2 Tbsp. butter, softened, divided,4 large eggs,1/4 tsp kosher salt,2/3 cup plus 2 to 3 Tbsp. half-and-half, divided,2 tsp vanilla extract, divided,1/2 cup chopped toasted pecans,1 (3-oz.) pkg. cream cheese, softened,2 1/4 cups (about 9 oz.) powdered sugar, divided. Line bottom and sides of a 6-quart slow cooker with aluminum foil; lightly coat foil with cooking spray. Stir together granulated sugar, brown sugar, and cinnamon in a small bowl. Toss together biscuit pieces and 1/2 cup melted butter in a large bowl until biscuits are coated. Working in batches, add biscuits to granulated sugar mixture, and toss to coat; transfer biscuits to prepared slow cooker. Sprinkle any remaining sugar mixture over biscuits in a slow cooker.Whisk together eggs, salt, 2/3 cup of the halfand-half, and 1 tsp of the vanilla in a bowl until well combined; pour over biscuits in a slow cooker.Sprinkle with pecans.Beat cream cheese and 2 tbsps softened butter with an electric mixer on medium speed until thoroughly combined, about 30 seconds. Add 1 cup of the powdered sugar and remaining 1 tsp vanilla; beat until smooth, about 1 minute. Gradually add remaining 1 1/4 cups powdered sugar to cream cheese mixture alternately with 2 tbsps of the half-and-half, beating on high speed until frosting is smooth, creamy, and a little loose, about 1 minute, adding remaining 1 tbsp half-and-half, 1 tsp at a time, if needed to reach desired consistency. Drizzle half of the frosting over the biscuit mixture in the slow cooker. (Cover remaining frosting and set aside until ready to serve.)Cover slow cooker; cook on low until center of casserole is set and biscuit bottoms are browned, 3.5 to 4 hours. Drizzle casserole with remaining frosting; serve warm.TEXAS TWO STEP CASSEROLLE11 oz canned mild chiles (drained), 8 corn tortillas (cut into strips), 12 oz bulk breakfast sausage (cooked and drained), 1 medium yellow onion (diced), 1.5 cups shredded pepper jack or cheddar cheese, 8 eggs, .5 cups heavy whipping cream, .5 tsp salt, .5 tsp freshly ground black pepper, .5 tsp garlic salt or powder, 1 tsp ground cumin, 2 small Roma tomatoes sliced, .5 tsp paprika, sour cream (optional), pico de gallo (optional). Lightly coat a 13-by 9-inch baking dish with non-stick spray.Spread half the amount of chiles in an even layer in the bottom of the dish.Add half of the tortilla strips. Add half of the sausage and onion. Add half of the cheese. Repeat a second time. In a medium bowl, whisk the eggs, cream, salt, pepper, garlic salt and cumin together until well combined.Pour over the casserole.Arrange the tomato slices on top. Sprinkle with paprika. Cover and refrigerate overnight. The next morning, heat the oven to 350 degrees. Uncover and bake the casserole 40 minutes or until the center has set and the edges are lightly browned. If desired, serve with sour cream and pico de gallo. 
 
 Caption: METRO CREATIVE SERVICES
 
Marie Savage said making breakfast casseroles saved her family a lot of time Christmas morning.

title: Lakeside wastewater treatment plant is complete
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Lakeside wastewater treatment plant is complete

 June 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 1257
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TRAPPE — The Lakeside wastewater treatment plant is built, running and ready for the next step in the Lakeside development plan, which is transferring ownership to the town of Trappe.Two Lakeside transfer agreements were presented during a recent Trappe Council meeting. These agreements are the first steps in eventually passing over ownership of the wastewater treatment plant to the Town of Trappe.
This controversial project has faced lawsuits, petitions and an array of public outcry over environmental concerns, but it is an essential step in moving forward with the Lakeside development.
First proposed over 20 years ago, the planned 2,501-unit Lakeside at Trappe development spans more than 850 acres off of U.S. Route 50. The development is slated to include a mix of single-family homes, townhouses and apartments, and commercial and retail spaces.
Trappe's existing plant has the capacity to take on wastewater from the development's first 120 homes. That flow will eventually be diverted to the new wastewater treatment plant serving the development, a plan approved by county legislation and via an MDE wastewater discharge permit.
Spray irrigation systemThe new plant, set with enriched nutrient removal technology, uses a spray irrigation system to discharge treated wastewater onto nearby fields.
According to the Pennsylvania Water Science Center, the sprayed wastewater either evaporates into the air, soaks into the soil or percolates through the soil and recharges the groundwater.
Robert Rauch, president of Rauch Inc., a project management and civil engineering firm for Lakeside, said spray irrigation has been recognized for years by states and the federal government as a preferred method of treated wastewater disposal.
"It is an exceptional re-use method of disposal that recharges groundwater and can provide needed nutrients to agricultural ground covers," he said. "Generally, spray irrigation does not require the highest levels of treatment, so valuable nutrients are available for plants to reduce farmers' costs for additional commercial fertilizer."
Raunch said this is based on Lakeside's developer's voluntary election to provide enhanced nutrient removal level treatment to avoid groundwater nutrient increases. The MDE discharge permit establishes strict limitations on the discharge of treated wastewater, which results in the application of a fraction of the nutrient uptake requirements of the grass planted in the irrigation field.
Raunch said that due to the high quality of the Lakeside wastewater effluent and the nutrient needs of the ground cover, there is no practical scenario in which the spray irrigation of treated effluent will negatively impact surface or groundwater.
"Ironically, the nutrient levels of the treated effluent will be so low that the farmer will have to apply fertilizer to the spray irrigation field to maintain a vigorous and healthy crop cover," he said.
Alan Girard, advocacy director of the Chesapeake Bay Foundation, argued that nutrients absorbed into groundwater could eventually discharge into nearby impaired rivers and streams like the Choptank River.
"I don't think people understand that the state is claiming that there will be zero discharge of nutrients to groundwater," Girard said. "The state has already demonstrated that there's a link between groundwater and surface water and surface letters that are tarred right near the discharge. So the state needs to be accountable for that issue."
The Chesapeake Bay Foundation and ShoreRivers filed separate petitions for judicial review of the permit in, citing concerns about the spray irrigation of treated wastewater and specifics of a nutrient management plan not being made available during the permit's public comment period in 2020.
Matt Pluta, Choptank riverkeeper and director of riverkeeper programs for ShoreRivers, said that the wastewater issue has been a concern for ShoreRivers due to the existing Trappe plant and how poorly it has been functioning and treating the wastewater before discharging it into Trappe Creek.
According to Pluta, the Lakeside Plant is making noticeable improvements that were not seen in the old Trappe Wastewater Plant.
"I'll go on and say that one thing that's very clear and obvious is that there will be more treatment from this new plant," Pluta said. "The wastewater will be treated to a cleaner standard. That's what we want to see. We support that. The thing that concerns us with the new plan is just the method of discharge. That's where they'll be spraying the treated wastewater onto nearby farm fields."
Pluta said the way the state permits spraying the treated wastewater onto nearby farm fields is under what he calls "legal fiction or false assumptions." When someone is spraying wastewater on a farm field, that wastewater gets taken up by the plants.
Through studying agricultural practices, Pluta has learned of the impacts of runoff and pollution on groundwater. He said there are different incentives for someone operating a wastewater treatment plant compared to farmers caring for local crops.
Pluta stated that no farmer is applying nutrients to their crops every day throughout the whole growing season. There is an incentive for wastewater treatment operators to focus on controlling their volume and not so much on a healthy crop, which Pluta said is concerning for the sake of adding too much pollution to these fields.
Each farm that receives spraying from the plant needs a nutrient management plan on how many nutrients can be put on the fields. Those plans were not public information, but because it was part of the treatment process, ShoreRiver argued to make that information public.
It was through the 2020 filed lawsuit that the permit was remanded to the Maryland Department of the Environment, which issued a new permit with fewer homes and less wastewater.
A separate lawsuit was filed against MDE by concerned residents in May 2022 asking to revoke the permit and suspend any work with a sewage system as inconsistent with the county's comprehensive plan. Though the suits was ultimately dismissed last June, MDE issued a revised discharge permit for Lakeside, approving a significantly smaller wastewater treatment plant.
The revised permit allows for an average flow of 100,000 gallons per day. A vast decrease from the 540,000 gallons per day initially requested by the developer.
OversightIn part due to the outcry and lawsuits made by residents and environmental organizations, a wave of resolutions were brought forward to better address concerns involving the Wastewater Treatment Plant.
One that stood out to many was Resolution 338, which amended Talbot County's Comprehensive Water and Sewer Plan. It requires an amendment to the comprehensive plan for any future expansion of the new Lakeside wastewater treatment plant.
Though this was deemed favorable to the environmental organizations, there were many, including members of Trappe's council, that opposed the Lakeside resolutions.
During a public hearing before the vote of Resolution 338, Brian Schmidt, Trappe Town Council president, commented opposing the resolution and stated that the county was treating Trappe differently than other towns, hurting the municipality's growth.
"We did not ask this council to intervene," Schmidt said. "MDE is the controlling authority in matters of wastewater discharge, not the county. Disguising growth legislation as wastewater discharge is not proper procedure is only impeding the town's authority to control its own growth."
Next stepsDuring the June 5 Trappe Town Council meeting, two Lakeside transfer agreements were presented. These agreements are the first steps in eventually passing over ownership of the wastewater treatment plant to the Town of Trappe.
According to Showalter, Once the initial phase of the wastewater treatment plant is complete and turned over to the town, the developer remains responsible for any deficiencies between the costs of operation and maintenance and the sewer revenues collected by the Town from Lakeside residents. Additionally, the developer remains responsible for the incremental expansion of the wastewater treatment plant as the capacity is utilized.
Further discussion on the transfer agreements will be discussed and reviewed during the Town Council's next executive session.

title: As avian flu spreads, local businesses grapple with increased egg costs
author: Konner Metz
content:
As avian flu spreads, local businesses grapple with increased egg costs

 February 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 460
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Steve Mangasarian's is paying double what he used to for wholesale eggs.He says the price has been rising steadily since the pandemic. The recent spread of avian influenza virus, or avian flu, is accelerating that trend.
Mangasarian, the owner and chef of Breakfast in Easton, buys eggs from a vendor that sources locally. Due to the avian flu threatening poultry flocks nationwide, egg shortages are impacting businesses.
"The entire supply, nationwide supply, has been curtailed because of this. There's a shortage, even though I'm using local, fresh eggs," Mangasarian said. "Everybody's getting squeezed."
Mangasarian, like some other business owners, has been forced to raise prices. At Breakfast in Easton, he's added a 50-cent surcharge to an order of eggs and a 75-cent surcharge to an order of pancakes.
"It is my intention to make this temporary," signs in the restaurant read.
Avian flu outbreaks across the nation have afflicted egg supply, with the worst impacts felt in western and midwestern states. But local flocks have been affected as well.
Per the Maryland Department of Agriculture, five commercial poultry farms on the Eastern Shore have experienced outbreaks, including three just last month. Several other cases were reported in Delaware.
The virus can spread easily between flocks, though the risk for bird-to-human transmission is low at present.
According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the average cost for a dozen eggs was $4.15 at the end of 2024. One year earlier, the average cost was $2.51.
The current mark is nearing record costs seen during the avian flu outbreak in 2022. And U.S. Department of Agriculture projections predict a 20% increase in egg prices for 2025.
For Mangasarian, the sharp rise in egg prices has been a significant challenge. In past years, lower egg wholesale prices helped him "subsidize" a low return on bacon. That's flipped, however, as his returns on bacon now make up for tight egg returns.
At the Easton Diner on U.S. Route 50, manager Tiff Haddaway says it costs around $1,000 more per week to purchase eggs due to the recent shortage and wholesale prices. As of now, customers aren't seeing an upcharge.
"The owner is trying to not pass it onto the customer," Haddaway said.
Steve Andrews, owner of the Bagery, says customers aren't experiencing any increases since the business' local, free-range producer hasn't been hit by the avian flu.
Andrews, a backyard chicken flock owner for more than 15 years, did note that egg production costs have risen in past years due to increasing feed prices.
"We foresee that all producers, which get their day-old chicks from just a handful of operations, will all be increasing their demand to replace the culled flocks," Andrews wrote. "If any of the hatcheries themselves have an outbreak, this could indicate that egg prices have not peaked and could rise even further."

title: One proves enough for Easton

One proves enough for Easton

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports

 Words

 EASTON — Both coaches obviously wanted victory, and after 80 minutes of heated, physical play in the latest installment of the Easton-St. Michaels High soccer rivalry, Warrior head coach Avery Brice breathed a sigh of relief as his team continued its late-season surge."Good game. One-oh. Got the result," Brice said after Rodrigo Fresco's goal in the fifth minute Wednesday night proved enough for a 1-0 Easton victory over the Saints.
And though St. Michaels suffered its fourth loss in five games, Saints head coach Pat Hambleton may have gotten something he was looking for as well — momentum.
"We've had a hard stretch," Hambleton said after his team's third one-goal loss in 10 days, which included a 3-2 double-overtime defeat to two-time defending North Bayside champion Queen Anne's County. "I asked them, 'Just give us momentum. Create momentum so we can move forward. Win, lose, draw, figure out a way to play well. Work hard. Find something to carry on for tomorrow (a 9-0 victory Thursday over Cambridge-South Dorchester) and then carry on into the playoffs.'"
The Saints (6-4-1 overall, 2-4-1 North Bayside) may have found that momentum, playing the game's last 35 minutes, 54 seconds a man down after one of its players received a red card while an Easton player was given a yellow.
"I thought down (to) 10 men, I felt like we had the upper hand, and I felt like we were the man up," said Hambleton, who argued Easton should have also received a red.
"Couldn't be more proud," Hambleton added of his team. "We took them out of their game. They were sitting six guys in the back for the last 20 minutes terrified of our attack and our pressure. And I thought the second half was a completely different game than the first half."
With 4:28 elapsed in the first half, Fresco got a ball on the right side and parked it past Saints keeper Lucas Greenwood for the game's lone goal and a 1-0 Warrior lead.
The remainder of the game featured a string of highlight-reel saves by Greenwood (10 saves) and Easton goalie Sam Hutchison (eight saves).
Greenwood leaped to punch a ball away with 26:10 remaining in the first half. Hutchison stopped St. Michaels' Abel Delgaudio just 50 seconds later. Greenwood lunged left to foil Luke Stanco a little over 5 minutes later. St. Michaels' Connor Wheeler then struck a direct kick that Hutchison reached before colliding with Delgaudio. Greenwood made another stop a moment later, and Hutchsion responded with another save before a second collision 5 minutes later, leaving Brice pleading with his team, "You need to wake up."
The game was mostly played between the 18s in the second half, though both keepers continued to come up big. Easton had a chance to pad its lead 9 minutes into the half, but Emmet Fox drove a shot off the left post. Hutchison picked up another save, when he knocked away a ball on a Saints corner. Greenwood maintained the one-goal difference, smothering a ball off a wild scramble with an Easton player leaping over him.
"We just need to be consistent in the back and then take care of the ball a little bit better," said Brice, his team 6-5, 6-2 after its fourth win in five games.
For Hambleton, it was a familiar theme.
"The story of the second half of our season is we're winning games off the scoreboard," Hambleton said. "And that doesn't count."

title: Lions tighten their grip on North
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Lions tighten their grip on North

 April 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 EASTON — Noah Palmer offered somewhat of an explanation for his latest victory."My curveball," Queen Anne's County High's senior right-hander said with a game-winning smile. "I don't know what to say. I haven't been throwing it all year. It's been iffy. But I came out of the gate and it came out of my hand amazingly. And I was able to throw a split-finger today amazingly, too. I just threw it and it hit spots. That's all I got to say."
Palmer didn't have to say much more late Tuesday afternoon, as he yielded five hits in six-plus innings to help Queen Anne's to an 11-8 victory over Easton, drawing the Lions closer to their first North Bayside title since 1980.
Winners of five straight, Queen Anne's (8-6 overall, 5-1 North Bayside) can clinch the North championship with victories over Cambridge-South Dorchester and Kent County.
Colonel Richardson (11-5, 5-2), which blanked St. Michaels 3-0 yesterday behind Jordan Regulski's complete-game three-hitter, still remains in contention in the North. Should the Lions lose one of their two remaining division contests and finish tied with Colonel, the Colonels would win the North via their 8-1 victory over Queen Anne's in the only head-to-head meeting between the two schools this season.
Kent Island (7-8, 5-2) also has an outside shot. Though they lost to Queen Anne's in the second meeting between the two schools — which counts toward the division standings — the Bucs defeated Colonel and hold the tiebreaker between those two schools.
Easton (10-5, 4-3), which was in the running for its first North crown since 2007, got two first-inning runs against Palmer (5-2) but then was held scoreless by the Lions ace until the bottom of the sixth inning.
"Credit goes to their pitcher," Easton head coach Albert Pritchett said of Palmer, who struck out six and walked two before being relieved in the seventh. "He did a great job. After the first couple of innings he really settled in, working on his pitches, threw strikes."
Palmer and Easton's Kayden Webb (4-1) were locked in a pitcher's duel, tied at 2-2 heading to the top of the sixth.
That's when the Lions busted the game open, scoring six runs on five hits.
With one out, Noah Cramer walked, moved to second on a low pitch and scored the go-ahead run on Chance Hegedus' double down the left-field line. Ethan Keppler singled, sending Hegedus (3 for 4, three runs) to third. Hegedus got caught in a rundown between home and third. Warrior catcher Colin Mooney ran Hegedus back before throwing the ball to third baseman Garrett Fink. But with no one covering home, Hegedus raced across the plate for a 4-2 lead.
Webb was relieved after Brendan Parsley singled. Dustin Blue walked the first man he faced before Travis Sutch (4 for 4, three RBIs), whose solo homer off the left-field pole tied the game at 2-2 in the third, singled through the right side, plating two runs for a 6-2 lead. Two batters later, Dulin Clark belted a two-run double for an 8-2 lead.
"I think we're hitting pretty good right now," Travis Sutch said. "Definitely a big improvement over the last couple games. Everybody's starting to get going now, especially the bottom of our lineup."
Easton ended its scoring drought in the bottom of the sixth. Dylan Cassell doubled and scored when Blue sent a shot over Parsley's head in center field. Chase Raab's sacrifice fly made it 8-4. But Palmer got a strikeout and groundout to end the inning.
"He did a great job today," Queen Anne's head coach Rick Sutch said of Palmer. "He knew this was a big game. We went into it knowing that we were in the driver's seat as far as the Bayside North. He knew how big this was and he had at least five days off, so he was fresh.
"Usually Noah doesn't let anything bother him so once he got the lead I wasn't really too concerned," Coach Sutch added. "Webb's a good pitcher on the other side, so we knew we had to get to him early to get to the bullpen. But Noah did a great job. He controlled the game."
Queen Anne's tacked on three runs on five hits in the seventh, stretching their lead to 11-4.
The Warriors pieced together their biggest inning in the seventh, with Mikey O'Connor hitting a two-run single and Carter Mooney sending a sacrifice fly to center to make it 11-8 before Clough induced a game-ending groundout.
Notes: Webb tripled in the first and Colin Mooney doubled in the seventh for Easton.

title: Cambridge commissioners remove solar cap
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Cambridge commissioners remove solar cap

 July 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester

 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Cambridge City Commissioners adopted an ordinance at last week evening's meeting to amend the city's unified development code to exempt medium, large and community solar energy projects from the town's current 350-acre cap.The move essentially removes the cap, which was implemented in 2014, paving the way for a community solar project from Pivot Energy, a Denver-based renewable energy provider and independent power producer. Commissioners unanimously voted in favor of the ordinance to remove the cap.
The plan for community solar was first introduced to commissioners in December, 2024, when Pivot Energy's lawyer Anthony Kupersmith said getting rid of the cap would be critical to the project's success.
Cambridge City Planner Brian Hermann presented Pivot Energy's community solar proposal to commissioners again last week. "The community solar projects are designed to provide opportunities for residents of the community who don't own their house, or are living in the woods and have shade, or don't want to look at solar panels," Hermann said.
Community solar is a way for multiple individuals to share in the benefits of a single solar installation, according to the U.S. Department of Energy. "The term refers to the pooling of resources to develop a community-scale solar energy project that provides the benefits of solar energy to a group or neighborhood," the USDE website states.
After around an hour of questions from commissioners, Mayor Lajan Cephas thanked the gentlemen from Pivot Energy and attempted to move on to the next agenda item, but Commissioner Roche had one more question he 'demanded' be answered before voting on the ordinance.
"So at the end of the day, how do we know, and how does the state know that this power is actually for its intended purpose, which is to lower the utility rates of, in many cases, income constrained individuals, or the community, where it's located?" Roche asked.
Kupersmith told Roche this word isn't neutral and lends authority to regulatory oversight from the Public Service Commission through an application, bonding, subscriber certification and annual reporting to ensure benefits, especially for low- and moderate-income customers.
Hermann and Pivot Energy representatives were uncertain of how many acres they will need for the new community solar project, but it will exceed the current cap. Kupersmith and Pivot Energy Development Project Manager John Shields made it clear that if the city does not remove the cap, Pivot Energy is willing to go to the state, which can supersede the city's code.
Commissioners asked if there were decommissioning protocols for the end of the project's life or in case of damage. The decommissioning plan and bond would follow the city's existing zoning rules and Public Service Commission standards.
When it comes to what exactly the community solar project will look like, Pivot Energy is keeping its options open.
Shields said at the current moment, there is not a drawn-up project plan. "We'd rather kind of look at it more holistically if we can," Shields said.

title: With some rules, a civil discussion is possible
author: DAVID REEL
content:
With some rules, a civil discussion is possible

 October 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 587
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Last week, my wife and I hosted a visit from a longtime friend who I met before starting elementary school and have known ever since.Before he arrived, we agreed that because we have different opinions on issues in the political arena, we should avoid any discussion on politics while he was here.
We knew there are increasing numbers of family members, friends and acquaintances who are not on speaking terms due to strongly held and diametrically opposing political positions.
Instead of discussing politics, our time together was filled with talking about a wide range of other matters.
We talked about where he and I grew up, the schools we attended and all the changes that have occurred there.
We also discussed the challenges and opportunities we experienced with raising a family and long-distance relocations made necessary by job changes.
We talked about other childhood friends who died too soon and those who have recently died or are experiencing serious health problems.
Before his visit ended, we decided with some trepidation to discuss politics.
We did so with five rules:
Listen respectively to other points of view, even if we disagree strongly with them.Embrace the idea that listening is more than waiting for your turn to talk.End every discussion on strongly held differences of opinion with "you may be right."Not all discussions are a debate with a winner and a loser.Disagree without being disagreeable.
Following our rules was not always easy.
It was always worthwhile and meaningful.
For example, we discovered that we shared common ground with deep concerns over the steadily decreasing levels of civil discourse in our society.
As a result, shortly before my friend left to return home, we discussed Robert Putnam's book "Bowling Alone: The Collapse and Revival of American Community."
Written 25 years ago, "Bowling Alone" is still relevant today.
The book's unusual title is based on Putnam's research showing the number of people who bowl alone had increased, but those who bowl in leagues had decreased.
He suggested that when people bowl alone, they do not have opportunities to participate in the social interaction and civic discussions that might occur in a bowling league environment.
Putnam also wrote about the measurable declines in membership and participation in religious organizations, labor unions, parent–teacher associations, military veterans' organizations, fraternal organizations and community service organizations.
Putnam did acknowledge that some organizations and issue advocacy groups had increased their membership rolls, but they rarely focus on fostering face-to-face interactions that build what Putnam called social capital. Instead, they focus instead on fund raising, collecting dues, marketing services, lobbying and sending periodic news updates to their members.
Putnam also drew a distinction between two different but equally important types of social capital.
One type is "bonding" which occurs within a homogenous demographic group.
The other type is "bridging" which unites people from different groups.
Putnam concluded a lack of social capital undermines the active civic engagement that a strong democracy requires from its citizens.
I now know my friend's visit was more than a get-together to talk over old times, catch up on current times and ponder on the future.
In all our discussions, including those with civil discourse on politics, we built social capital.
It was unexpected opportunity to think about and evaluate what I can be and should be doing to help address the lack of civil discourse and to help increase social capital in our society.
The answer is clear.
Going forward, I must consistently strive to:
Respectively consider all points of view.Listen with more than waiting for my turn to talk.Say regularly "you may be right."Limit discussions as debates.Disagree without being disagreeable.Always look for opportunities to build social capital.

 CHESTER - Fishing along the Bay was the theme of the 11th Stars & Stripers fly-fishing event last month for veterans resumed at the Kent Island Yacht Club in Chester. A record 63 veterans participated.The event, sponsored by Project Healing Waters Fly-Fishing, Inc.(PHWFF), headquartered in La Plata, had not been held since 2019, prior to the COVID-19 pandemic.Concerns for the health of everyone, especially veterans still recovering for wounds, was the main reason for delaying the resumption of the event.A record number of privately owned boats, 36, were provided by qualified boat captain "guides" to take the veterans out fly-fishing at different locations around the Chesapeake Bay. The boats, veterans and guides departed early Saturday, Aug. 19, all going out by 7 a.m., fishing until 11 a.m.Founded in 2005 by Navy veteran Ed Nicholson of southern Maryland, PHWFF was founded especially for wounded veterans returning from Iraq and Afghanistan. PHWFF hosts over 200 such events nationally, from coast to coast; 85% of all donations to the foundation go directly to support these events.The first Stars & Stripers began as part of PHWFF in 2009, led by veteran Roger Carlson, of Edgewater, with only five veterans and five fishing guides. Carlson eventually turned over leadership of this local event to the late Vietnam veteran, U.S. Army Major (retired) Dr. Ed Fulton, who became a successful orthopedic surgeon in civilian life. Fulton hosted the event at Dominion Marina for seven years, until his unexpected death in May 2017. With his marina sold, the event was relocated to the Kent Island Yacht Club.Fly-fishing enthusiast Mark Eustis, of Davidsonville, has managed the event since 2017. Pulling together the support of local businesses and the immediate fraternal community to continue a first-class fishing experience for these veterans, Eustis recognized the aid received from the Kent Island American Legion, Centreville Post 18, Queenstown Post 296, Grasonville VFW Post 2576 and the Kent Island Elks, Lodge 2576, in Stevensville.Under the leadership of Elks member Lorraine Sincavage, the organization provided 11 volunteers to serve a wonderful luncheon for the veterans, their families and boat guides following the morning of fishing.Local businesses, Fisherman's Crab Deck and Harris Seafood, Inc., provided steamed crabs, and the Yacht Club provided pulled pork with all the side dishes.For the third time, Hardee's, under the Cato family's franchise ownership, using its "Stars for Heroes" program, collected donations for this event from their 23 locations around on the Eastern Shore of Maryland and Delaware. Hardee's presented a check toward next year's Stars & Stripers event for $9,375. The restaurant also provided breakfast sandwiches to the attendees.Eustis had high praise for the continued support from the community. He had hoped back in 2019 to "continue to grow the event", having more veterans participate, pushing that number to 60-65. That was achieved this year.If interested in more information about Project Healing Waters Fly-Fishing, either as a participant or volunteer, visit their site projecthealingwaters.org.

 CHESTERTOWN — The "Science of Photography" as captured by the artist's eye will be on full display for those who appreciate what is revealed through the camera and life's lens when a new exhibit opens in Chestertown on Wednesday, July 3.The exhibition, which runs through Aug. 28 in the interior public areas of the Heron Point Retirement Community, will display the works of seven talented photographers who have a knack for chronicling the exquisite beauty and inherent charm associated with living in and among the environs and the inhabitants of what is known as the Delmarva.
Barbara Finneson, a representative of Heron Point's Art Interest Group, said she is personally very excited to view the work of this particular collective of artists. "This is a special group," she said, noting that it is based in Salisbury, and includes the works of Mike Morris, Libby Morris, Kenneth Jones, Tony Burton, Latoya Drummond, Samuel Everett and Seldon Dix.
This group of photographic professionals and friends has been known to do whatever it takes, whether that means chasing 3 a.m. sunrises, enduring bitter cold, or patiently waiting for just the right light and conditions to evolve, to get the perfect shot.
"These Delmarva artists," according to the statement provided by the Art Interest Group, "…are dedicated to capturing the unique beauty and essence of Delmarva through their lens. Their collection of work showcases the diverse landscapes, vibrant communities, and rich cultural heritage of the region, applying their individual perspectives and artistic styles. They create a fresh and innovative approach to documenting the natural wonders and human stories of Maryland's Eastern Shore."
Finneson, who is a 20-year resident of Heron Point, said her community always has the good fortune to have artistic works on display in its common areas by talented resident artists and others from the community at-large. Heron Point residents, she said, are oftentimes so inspired by what they see in these exhibitions, they have been known to start painting for the first time at the age of 80, and they particularly look forward to these special collections.
While the opening will take place on July 3 at 10 a.m., the artists themselves will be on-hand for a special gathering on the afternoon on Sunday, July 14 from 2 to 4 p.m. to speak to visitors about their creative process. The community is encouraged to come and participate in the discussion.
This exhibition will be open to the public daily from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. from June 3 through Aug. 28, with many works available for purchase. Heron Point of Chestertown is located at 501 East Campus Avenue, Chestertown. Call 410-778-7300 for more information.

title: Kerns, Queen Anne's thinking they have the goods for another long postseason run.
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Kerns, Queen Anne's thinking they have the goods for another long postseason run.

 December 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 2164
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It wasn't a prediction.It was just something Mike Kern believed.
"If we can get out of the region, I think we have a good shot at states," Kern said of Queen Anne's County High's girls soccer team.
That was at the outset of the season. The Lions did get out of the region, then went on to become the first Bayside Conference school ever to win a girls state soccer championship.
Now, as the girls basketball season approaches tip-off, Kern again strongly believes if Queen Anne's can get out of its region, it has a chance to do well at the state level.
"We're very multi-dimensional," Kern said. "All of our guards can penetrate and shoot. And then our post players are very dangerous inside. They move well. They're very athletic. So I think the sky's the limit for them. The biggest thing is play as a team. We learned that in soccer. If we play as a team and aren't selfish, and do the little things, I think we can do really well."
Getting out of the Class 2A East Region II could prove more difficult than in soccer. Kent Island still has Sydney Riska and Lacey Dauses. Wicomico returns the bulk of the team that handed the Lions their only three losses last season, including bouts for the Bayside Conference and 2A East Region II championships. And Parkside has improved.
But this Queen Anne's team is different.
Not only does Kern return the majority of a team that went 20-3 and won the North Bayside championship, he welcomes two additions who have the potential to be impact players in juniors Damya Henry, a transfer from Cambridge-South Dorchester, and Cheyanne Hollis — daughter of Queen Anne's boys head coach Jeff Hollis — who has been sidelined by injury the past two seasons.
"With our core coming back, plus those additions, I think we stand a good chance of challenging them this year," Kern said of Wicomico. "Damya gives us that defensive pressure. She reads well. Anticipates well. And she's quick. So she definitely helps on the defensive end.
"And Chayenne, she's a true post player; and that will free up Bea (Holthaus) and Lucy (Taylor) a little bit having her in there," Kern continued.
Then there's the core group. Seniors RJ Ensor and Lucy Taylor return along with sophomores Laila Coles, Kariana Hickson, and Holthaus, the 2023 North Bayside Player of the Year.
"The thing about our team right now, I feel like we can score so many different ways," Kern said. "We have pretty good shooters. We can get the ball inside. We can drive. We're a very multi-dimensional team. And Bea herself is very multi-dimensional. She can play outside, go inside. She can drive.
"I'm not worried about us being able to score this year," Kern added. "My biggest focus so far is making sure we play good defense. One of the things that we've done well over the years is we've been a really good defensive team. And I feel like we have so much energy on the offense, that we kind of rest on the defense. And we can't do that with good teams. So we have to play up-tempo defense the entire game."
Kent Island remains Queen Anne's biggest challenger, though Cambridge-SD, with the senior core of Le'Asia Todd, Destiny Johnson and Tejanae Ballin have the potential to give Queen Anne's a battle.
Here's a look at this season's teams.
CAMBRIDGE-SD
Head Coach: Shamya Johnson.
Who's Where: Le'Asia Todd (Sr., C); Destiny Johnson (Sr., G); Tejanae Ballin (Sr., PG); AzEyera Johnson (Sr., F); Skyla Ali (So., F); Jade Ballin (So., F); JaNaya Stanley (Jr., G); Tonyia Brooks (Sr., G); Aamiyah Wilcox (Sr., C); Neveah Adams (Fr., G); Montiasha Jackson (So., G); Amari Winters (Fr., F/C); Kennedy Bourne (So., F); Kamryn Bourne (So., F); D'Asia Mack (So., G).
Outlook: Todd can reach 1,000 career points in Thursday's opener against Crisfield, and together with Destiny Johnson and Tejanae Ballin makes the Vikings a favorite in 1A East Region II.
And though Coach Johnson thinks Cambridge-SD can again reach the 1A state quarterfinals, one of her biggest challenges is keeping her team's intensity and discipline up from start to finish.
"That was the conversation we had tonight,' Coach Johnson said Tuesday in a phone interview. "'You all got it. You've got the pieces. But you all don't have the discipline. And that's the difference.'"
Johnson also knows her team needs to play great transition defense and create points off turnovers if it hopes to challenge Queen Anne's and Kent Island.
COL. RICHARDSON
Head Coach: Tom Corsey.
Who's Where: Jaz Jackson (Jr., G); Monae Ross (Sr., C); Selina Austriville (So., F); Tybria Williams (Sr., G); Ella Downie (So., F); Angelina Algre (Fr., C).
Outlook: Corsey thinks the 6-foot-5 Algre can develop into an inside force.
"She's a work in progress," Corsey said. "She's a presence. She's learning, but I'm going to get her there."
This is one of the younger teams Corsey's coached, but the goal is another 10-win season with eyes on upsetting a 2A school.
EASTON
Head Coach: Lesley Staehli.
Who's Where: Sam Murphy (Sr., G); Serenity Velez (Jr., G); Maia Bailey (Fr., G); Ki'Mauri Lewis (So., G); Jordyn Wilson-Colbert (So., F/C); Myles Booker (Sr., F/C); Dakota Dietrich (Sr., G); Addison Knox (So., G/F); Stella Kabler (Jr., G); Taylor Bowen (Fr., F/C); Addison Chandler (Sr., G/F).
Outlook: The Warriors are an interesting mix.
Velez returns as one of the team's top scorers, and Murphy has transferred from Saints Peter and Paul.
"She is one of the scrappiest people I have ever played against the last four years that I've been coaching defense wise," Staehli said of Murphy. "Now it's awesome to have her with us because she barely comes out."
Bailey, daughter of Marty Bailey, who has come over from the boys team to be an assistant, could be one of the Bayside's top newcomers. And then there is a list of talent that includes Knox, Kabler and Bowen, who helped the Warriors reach the state field hockey semifinals this past season, and Chandler, a force on the Easton soccer team.
"We're going to be fast," Staehli said. "Everybody has talent. I think we're going to shock a lot of people this year with the fact (they're) not expecting a lot of athletic people to come back into the program with us having no jayvee last year. There's certain teams we'll struggle with, but I think we're going to be pretty good."
KENT COUNTY
Head Coach: Tyray Johnson.
Who's Where: Kate Cannon (Sr., C); Talicia Wright (So., PG); Jane Cleary (So., F); Love Jackson (Jr., SF); Kaliyah Smith (Sr., SF); Ariyana Green (So., SF); Saniyah Jones (So., C); Tameeia Savage (Jr., SF); Juliette Camilli (Jr., SG); Sanorra Parker (Fr., SG); Abigael Lachance (Sr., SF); Emerence Boutaud (Jr., PF).
Outlook: Johnson begins his fourth season with the biggest roster he's ever had at Kent with 12. Though still young, experience was gained last year, especially with Wright, who returns at point guard.
"We turned the ball over a lot last year," Johnson said. "She (Wright) stepped up toward the end of the season. So a lot of the mistakes she made early on we won't really have them this year. So it's going to be less turnovers for us."
Speed and defense will be critical if the undersized Trojans are to improve on last season's five-win mark.
KENT ISLAND
Head Coach: Dave Plumer.
Who's Where: Sydney Riska (Sr., F); Lacey Dauses (Jr., G); Abigail Staton (Sr., PG); Ellie Burnside (Sr., G); Machaela Thomas (So., C); Avery Eaton (Sr., G)
Outlook: Lilli Dauses graduated and Makayla Kropfelder transferred to Broadneck. But don't expect the Bucs to fall far from the top.
The smooth-playing Riska was a double-double machine last season, and Lacey Dauses gained confidence with her ability to attack the rim and draw contact. Add Thomas, a 6-foot-2 center, who could create problems for opponents, and Burnside, the first player off the bench from last season.
"I think Lacey had grown as a player and in size," Plumer said. "Obviously Sydney had a big year last year, and now adding another 6-2 center to play along side of her is going to benefit her as well. Who are you going to guard? Machaela's got great footwork. She just needs playing time to get better.
"I think we got to run," Plumer continued. "I mean we're guard heavy. We do have a big player inside but I think we're going to be a running team. We just got to play. There's talent there. It's going to take them a month or two to get them up to speed. But they can play."
NORTH CAROLINE
Head Coach: AJ Jackson.
Who's Where: Taryn Brandt (Sr., G); Jasiyah Henry (Sr., G); Emma Keating (Sr., F); Ashley Kercheval (Sr., F); Megan Rogers (Sr., G); Kaitlyn Thompson (Sr., C); Sarah Brown (Sr., G); MyKira Allen (Jr., F); Yariah Dowell (Jr., G); Irma Sanchez (Jr., G); Nevaeh Irby (So., G).
Outlook: The Bulldogs lost the majority of their scoring from last season with the graduation of Precious Phillips, Chloe Escoe, Ashleigh Lawry and first-team all-North Bayside pick Selaya Garrison.
Jackson will lean heavily on Henry, a four-year varsity starter, for scoring, along with Keating and Dowell.
"Getting back to the fundamentals," Jackson said Caroline's key to success. "Rebounding, boxing out, good passes. The basics. So far I've loved what I've seen in preseason. The girls are buying in. There are some things we need to improve on, but the girls are working hard."
NORTH DORCHESTER
Head Coach: Dontele Pinder.
Who's Where: Remedy Wongus (So., G/F); Areinya Taylor (Sr., G); Ziya Patton (Sr., F); Diamond Newbill (Fr., G); Sammir Holland (Fr., G); Destiny Wongus (Fr., G).
Outlook: An assistant at Colonel Richardson the past eight seasons, Pinder begins his first head coaching job with plenty of optimism.
"I feel like we have a great core group," Pinder said. "We're kind of in the middle of the transition, where we have some of our key seniors that are leading, but we have a good group of freshmen that I feel like are going to be productive in the beginning. I'm excited and I think they're excited about the change. Hopefully we can make some noise here in the North."
QUEEN ANNE'S
Head Coach: Mike Kern.
Who's Where: Damya Henry (Jr., G); Cheyanne Hollis (Jr., F/C); Bea Holthaus (So., F); Laila Coles (So., G); Kariana Hickson (So., G); Taylor Jordan (So., G); RJ Ensor (Sr., G); Lucy Taylor (Sr., C); Sydney Pinder (Jr., F); Keilah Reed (Jr., G); Abby Robinson (So., G); Dillon Simpler (So., G); Lex Kern (So., G).
Outlook: With practically everyone back from last season, as well as the additions of Hollis and Henry, it's not surprising Kern thinks the potential is there to do well at the state level, if Queen Anne's can advance out of the region.
"We've never had a team that can all shoot," Kern said. "We've had teams where we had one true shooter and that's it. We might have a kid who could drive. We had Kendall Moxey (Queen Anne's career leading scorer) who could play the post. But we've never had a solid (team) that can shoot from so many different area's of the court."
That's a combination that could have the Lions driving deep into another postseason.
ST. MICHAELS
Head Coach: Jonathan Matthews.
Who's Where: Jordyn Beckett (So., F/C); Hanna Corkran (So., F/C); Aleah George (So., F); Rebeca Martinez (Jr., G); Evelyn Mautz (Fr., G); Kayla Montoya (So. SG); Olivia Patrick (Jr., G/F); Alayna Porter (Fr., G); Maddisyn Roe (Jr., G); Bella Simmons (Fr., G); Kendall Rosenberger (So., C); Tess Weller (Jr., PG); Shayla Frink (Jr., C); Kaelyn Hicks (Fr., G/F); Maleia Loffland (Fr., G).
Outlook: Another former Colonel Richardson assistant, Matthews begins his first head coaching job hoping to build on what former head coach Mark Potter started.
"Mark gave us a good start from last year for the ninth graders that are 10th graders this year," Matthews said. "We're still working on some of our developmental things, but I think in the long run we'll be all right. I have high hopes for them."
SAINTS PETER & PAUL
Head Coach: Katie Murphy.
Who's Where: Avery McCall (Jr., F/C); Annie Albright (Jr., G); Lucy Rankin (Jr., G/F); Hazel Spurry (Jr., G); Emma Hainey (So., G); Kaylin Palmer (So., F/C); Bridget Gilman (So., G); Tara Foley (So., G/F); Ryleigh Briddell (So., C/F); Veronica Pool (So., G); Natalee Lyons (Fr., G); Caroline Jallade (Fr., C/F).
Outlook: While the Sabres and Delmarva Christian have met for the Eastern Shore Independent Athletic Conference title the last three seasons, Murphy thinks this season could be more wide open with Worcester Prep, Gunston and Salisbury School pushing to improve.
"Everyone is a threat," Murphy said.
Murphy admits it's been somewhat hard to gauge her team's potential because she hasn't had her full lineup for games or practices.
And though the losses of Morgan Quade (graduation) and Sam Murphy (transfer) will hurt, the Sabres have a solid core with McCall, Albright, Rankin, Hainey and the continuing emergence of Palmer and Gilman.
"We finally have everybody back and we're working on a few things to find out who those (starting) five are," Murphy said. "They want to learn. They want to get better. Working together as a team is where we are right now."
