title: Candy hearts and other Valentine's treats
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Candy hearts and other Valentine's treats

 February 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1552
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The big day is here, and the traditions of flowers and chocolates still holds their spots as number one favorites for all ages.My favorite Valentine's Day memories are of the elementary school parties — the cute cards and little candy hearts. The girls would gather and compare the message candies from the boys.
What fun that was. Then came high school, and the stakes were higher. The cute juvenile cards turned into single rose buds and candy.
No matter how you celebrate this special day — with or without candy — just tell that special person (or persons) "happy Valentine's Day."
HEART SHAPED PIZZA
1 pound store-bought pizza dough, 1 tbsp olive oil (plus more for brushing), 16 slices pepperoni, All-purpose flour (for dusting), 1/2 cup prepared pizza sauce, 1 cup shredded low-moisture mozzarella. Put the pizza dough in a medium bowl and coat well with the olive oil. Cover with plastic wrap and allow to sit at room temperature for 1 hour. Meanwhile, put a large inverted baking sheet on the lowest oven rack and preheat the oven to 500 degrees. Fold a pepperoni slice in half and use a pair of kitchen shears to trim the edges into the shape of half of a heart. When you unfold the pepperoni slice, it will be a whole heart. Repeat this process with the remaining pepperoni, then set aside.
Divide the pizza dough into 2 balls. On a lightly floured surface, stretch 1 ball of dough into a 10-inch round. Transfer the dough to a piece of parchment paper, then slide the parchment and dough onto a second inverted baking sheet. Use a pair of kitchen shears or a paring knife to cut the pizza dough into the shape of a large heart, discarding the dough scraps. Spread half of the sauce on the dough in a thin layer and scatter half of the mozzarella on top. Top with half of the pepperoni slices. Use a pastry brush to brush the exposed edges of the dough with olive oil. Carefully slide the parchment onto the preheated baking sheet and bake until the crust is golden brown and the cheese is bubbling, 6 to 8 minutes. Let cool for 1 to 2 minutes before slicing. Repeat to make a second pizza.
SURF AND TURF
1/4 cup chopped fresh parsley, 2 tbsps chopped fresh chives, 2 tbsps extra-virgin olive oil, Kosher salt and freshly ground pepper, 6 jumbo shrimp (peeled and deveined, tails intact), 2 tbsps extra-virgin olive oil, juice of 1/2 lemon, 2 tsps chopped fresh thyme (plus 2 to 3 sprigs), freshly ground pepper, 6 slices pancetta (about 2 ounces), 1 10-ounce piece beef tenderloin (trimmed), sea salt, 8 asparagus spears, 1 tbsp unsalted butter. Pulse the parsley, chives and olive oil in a mini food processor until smooth. Thin with water, if necessary, and add 1/4 tsp each salt and pepper. Transfer to a small bowl, cover and set aside. (This can be done up to 2 hours ahead.)
Toss the shrimp, olive oil, lemon juice, chopped thyme and pepper to taste in a bowl. Wrap each shrimp with a piece of pancetta. Preheat the broiler. Arrange the shrimp on a foil-lined broiler pan. Season the beef with sea salt and pepper, press the thyme sprigs into the meat and set aside. Snap off the tough ends of the asparagus. Put the asparagus in a microwave-safe dish with 1/4 cup water and a pinch of sea salt. Heat a medium ovenproof skillet over high heat and add the butter. When the foam subsides, sear the beef until golden brown, about 3 minutes per side. Using tongs, hold the meat and brown the sides. Transfer the skillet to the broiler and cook until a thermometer inserted into the beef registers 125 degrees for medium rare, about 4 more minutes. Transfer to a cutting board to rest while you cook the shrimp. Broil the shrimp until the pancetta is crisp, about 2 minutes per side. Meanwhile, microwave the asparagus until tender, about 2 minutes. Slice the beef into 4 pieces. Serve with the shrimp, herb oil and asparagus.
CLASSIC SPAGHETTI AND MEATBALLS
1 pound spaghetti, 1 pound ground beef, 1/3 cup breadcrumbs, 1/4 cup finely chopped parsley, 1/4 cup freshly grated parmesan (plus more for serving), 1 large egg, 2 garlic cloves (minced), Kosher salt, 1/2 tsp. red pepper flakes, 2 tbsp. extra-virgin olive oil, 1/2 cup onion (finely chopped), 1 (28-oz.) can crushed tomatoes, 1 bay leaf, freshly ground black pepper.
In a large pot of salted boiling water, cook pasta until al dente. Drain. In a large bowl, combine beef with breadcrumbs, parsley, parmesan, egg, garlic, 1 tsp salt and red pepper flakes. Mix until just combined, then form into 16 balls. In a large pot over medium heat, heat oil. Add meatballs and cook, turning occasionally, until browned on all sides, about 10 minutes. Transfer meatballs to a plate. Add onion to pot and cook until soft, 5 minutes. Add crushed tomatoes and bay leaf. Season with salt and pepper and bring to a simmer. Return meatballs to pot and cover. Simmer until the sauce has thickened, 8 to 10 minutes. Serve pasta with a healthy scoop of meatballs and sauce.
VALENTINES DAY SUGAR COOKIES
2 1/2 cups all-purpose flour (plus more for dusting), 1/2 tsp baking powder, 1/2 tsp kosher salt, 1 1/2 sticks unsalted butter (at room temperature), 3/4 cup granulated sugar, 1 tsp pure vanilla extract, 1 large egg. For Icing: 3 cups confectioners' sugar, 1/4 cup plus 2 tbsps milk, 1 1/2 tsps pure vanilla extract, red gel food coloring, pink gel food coloring, sprinkles (optional). Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Line two baking sheets with parchment paper.
For the cookies: Combine the flour, baking powder and salt in a medium bowl and set aside. In a stand mixer fitted with the paddle attachment, beat the butter, sugar and vanilla on medium-high speed until light and fluffy, about 3 minutes. Add the egg and mix until fully incorporated, about 1 minute. Reduce the speed to low, add the flour mixture and mix until well combined, scraping down sides of the bowl with a rubber spatula as needed, about 2 minutes.
Divide the dough into 2 equal pieces. Working with 1 piece at a time, roll the dough on a lightly floured piece of parchment paper until it's about 1/8-inch thick. Using heart-shaped cookie cutters, cut the dough and place the cookies on the prepared baking sheets about 1 inch apart (a small off-set spatula is really helpful when transferring the cookies). After both pieces of dough have been rolled out and cut, combine the dough scraps and re-roll and cut to utilize as much of the dough as possible. Bake until the cookies are just barely golden around the edges, rotating halfway through, 12 to 14 minutes. Transfer the cookies to wire racks to cool completely.
For the icing: Whisk the confectioners' sugar, milk and vanilla in a medium bowl until smooth. The consistency should be similar to that of slightly thinned yogurt and should coat the back of a spoon. Adjust with additional confectioners' sugar or milk, if needed. Place 2 tbsps of icing into each of 2 small bowls. Add 4 drops of red gel food coloring to one bowl and 2 drops of pink gel food coloring to the other and stir until fully incorporated. Using a small spoon, drizzle a small amount of each color over the white icing and then repeatedly drag a toothpick through the icing until you create a marbled effect.
Working with one cooled cookie at a time, carefully dip it face-side down into the icing and allow any excess to drip off before placing the cooking back on the cooling rack. Add additional red and pink icing to the bigger bowl of icing as needed to maintain the marbling effect.
HOMEMADE CANDY HEARTS
1 1/4-ounce packet unflavored gelatin powder, 1 tbsp light corn syrup, 1/2 tsp vanilla extract, 1/8 tsp salt, 2 1-pound boxes confectioners' sugar (plus more for kneading), assorted food coloring (for tinting), assorted extracts (such as peppermint, strawberry or almond) for flavoring, cooking spray. Whisk the gelatin, corn syrup, vanilla, salt and 1/2 cup boiling water in a stand mixer bowl until the gelatin dissolves. Using the paddle attachment, beat in the confectioners' sugar on medium-low speed, 1 cup at a time, to make a stiff, sticky dough.
Transfer the dough to a clean surface and knead, adding more confectioners' sugar as needed (up to 1 cup), until the dough is smooth, pliable and slightly tacky, about 5 minutes. Divide the dough into 4 pieces. Flatten 1 piece into a disk. (Cover the rest with plastic wrap.) Add a few drops each of food coloring and extract to the center of the dough; fold in the sides and pinch closed, then knead until the color is distributed.
Lightly coat a large piece of parchment paper with cooking spray. Roll out the colored dough on the parchment until 1/8 to 1/4 inch thick. Cut into hearts using 1-inch cookie cutters; transfer to a parchment-lined baking sheet. Repeat with the remaining dough, using different colors and extracts. Let the hearts sit at room temperature, uncovered, until dry and hard, about 24 hours, flipping them halfway through. Write messages on the hearts using food decorating pens. Store in an airtight container for up to 1 week.

title: Safe Chain Solutions to settle alleged counterfeit HIV drug claims
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Safe Chain Solutions to settle alleged counterfeit HIV drug claims

 February 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Local News 
 
 754
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Over two years of civil litigation against Cambridge-based pharmaceutical distributor Safe Chain Solutions relating to its alleged implication in a counterfeit HIV drug scheme has reached a settlement, according to federal court documents.A consent judgment and permanent injunction filed Feb. 20 in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York is awaiting a signature from a federal judge, which will formally settle Gilead Sciences Inc's complex lawsuit against the local pharmaceutical distributor and its founders, brothers Charlie and Patrick Boyd.
Gilead is a biopharmaceutical company that develops and markets a variety of medications, including drugs that treat or prevent HIV.
The complaint, originally filed in 2021 and amended in 2022, alleged Safe Chain's involvement in the distribution of authentic-looking bottles of two of Gilead's HIV medications, Biktarvy and Descovy, to pharmacies across the country.
Gilead's deeper investigation into the alleged scheme revealed that some of the bottles contained completely different drugs not used to treat HIV. Some of the bottles reportedly contained quetiapine, or Seroquel XR — an antipsychotic used to treat schizophrenia, bipolar disorder and major depressive disorder, according to the amended complaint.
The complaint alleged that some of the counterfeit bottles purchased from Safe Chain, which were received by pharmacies and later reported to the pharmacies by customers, came with falsified pedigrees, or documentation, that claimed to trace the drugs back to an authentic source.
The consent judgment and permanent injunction will prohibit Safe Chain from selling any Gilead product in the United States, including a number of Gilead's HIV medications.
Under the terms of the agreement, Gilead will have the right to have an independent firm audit Safe Chain's purchase and sales records for all products bought and sold after the consent judgment is entered, according to the document.
The firm will not provide information to Gilead unless it relates to Gilead-branded products or non-compliance with the order.
Additionally, Safe Chain will be required to relinquish its rights to over $2.7 million in frozen assets, which includes over $1.9 million of Safe Chain's funds in an equitable trust account and money in the brothers' personal investment and life insurance accounts.
If a court finds that Safe Chain violated any terms of the consent judgment and injunction, the company would be required to pay Gilead 100 times the wholesale acquisition cost of the Gilead product sold, according to the document.
The wholesale acquisition cost for Biktarvy is over $3,000. Descovy is over $2,000.
Despite the lawsuit's allegations, Safe Chain believes that the drugs "were actually legitimate Gilead products that had been diverted into the stream of commerce," said August Matteis, an attorney for the the company.
In counterclaims against Gilead, Safe Chain alleged that Gilead's accusations were "false and defamatory" and that Gilead was "motivated by trying to destroy the secondary market for its drugs," he said.
According to Matteis, Safe Chain believes Gilead sued the company in "an attempt to cover up the fact that thousands of bottles of Gilead HIV drugs entered the stream of commerce due to poor oversight of Gilead's free drug access program in Florida."
"There has been no judicial ruling on Gilead's claims against Safe Chain or on Safe Chain's counterclaims against Gilead," he said. "Safe Chain agreed to settle this case to end the legal costs associated with this litigation and to get back to running its business."
Gilead's lawsuit was not the only documentation explaining concerns with Safe Chain.
A June 2023 warning letter issued by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration detailed the company's violations of the Drug Supply Chain Security Act. It followed the FDA's monthlong inspection of Safe Chain's Cambridge facility from April to May 2022.
Specifically, it called the company out for not having adequate verification systems required under law that "may have resulted in suspect product entering the supply chain" rather than being quarantined, according to the letter.
The letter also confirmed that Safe Chain purchased products from other drug wholesalers that were not authorized, failed to maintain records of suspect product investigations and failed to respond to notifications of illegitimate products.
The Feb. 20 injunction prohibiting Safe Chain from selling Gilead products ensures that Safe Chain "will never again be a source of counterfeit versions of our medicines," according to a Gilead spokesperson.
"This is the latest result of years of work reflecting our longstanding commitment to protect patients and the public from bad actors selling counterfeit and illicit versions of Gilead's medicines," the spokesperson said in an email. "This includes working closely with the FDA, FBI and prosecutors to dismantle this counterfeiting network, deter bad actors, and thwart illegal pharmaceutical distribution."

title: Delaware city evaluating ‘Pallet Village’ for homeless people
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
Delaware city evaluating ‘Pallet Village’ for homeless people

 July 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 976
 Words 

 Read News Document

 City officials in Newark, Delaware are in the early stages of evaluating whether a transitional housing village of small cabins could be a solution to local homelessness.Council members John Suchanec and Corinth Ford visited such a village in Georgetown, Delaware and suggested that a similar idea could be implemented here.
"We truly felt the experience was transformative," Suchanec said. "The approach that Georgetown has taken is starting to shape up to be a model for how you would deal with homeless sheltering."
Georgetown's Pallet Village was built in 2023 by the nonprofit Springboard Delaware. It consists of 40 small one-bedroom cabins, as well as shared bathhouses. It's become known as the Pallet Village because the cabins are produced by a company called Pallet.
"Our goal is to get unsheltered people out of the woods, get the help they need and move on to permanent housing or some form of self-independence," said Judson Malone, executive director of Springboard Delaware.
Malone said there are many reasons that people stay in the woods rather than go into traditional homeless shelters. Maybe they don't feel safe in a group shelter, they can't be with their partner, they can't bring their pet or they can't bring all their possessions.
"The most impactful thing you will do for them immediately is a lockable door with heat and air conditioning in a secure community, and that's exactly what we provided," Malone said. "Within two weeks, you'll see a difference in their demeanor simply because of the trauma that they experienced in the woods."
The Pallet Village does not require residents to be sober.
"We do not allow substance use on site, but best practices have shown that when people are in a safe space where they're accepted as they are, they can then begin to process the other issues in their life, including deciding whether or not to get treatment," Malone said. "We have a very high success rate of people voluntarily choosing to go to treatment."
Within a week of opening, the Georgetown shelter was 100 percent occupied and has remained so.
"People see a value in being there," Malone said. "They want to be there, and they want to get help and support."
Springboard Delaware works with 30 different support organizations to provide medical, mental heath, banking, employment and other services to people living at the Pallet Village.
"While people are unsheltered and in the woods, they almost never want those services," Malone said. "They really don't care about getting clean or sober, because getting high is how they survive a traumatic life."
The average length of stay is approximately three months, and then many residents of the Pallet Village move on to more permanent housing.
The Pallet Village cost approximately $1.5 million to build, money that came from the American Rescue Plan Act. Ongoing funds for operation has been harder to come by, however. Last year, Springboard Delaware had to lay off staff when a grant fell through and leaders were scrambling to piece together state money and private grants to keep the village open, according to reporting from Spotlight Delaware.
Malone said he is still working with the state to develop sustainable longterm funding.
Springboard Delaware has another $1.4 million in ARPA money to build a second Pallet Village somewhere else in the state.
"We've got the money in hand to do it," Malone said. "We just need a location."
If a Pallet Village were built in Newark, it would not require funding from the city, Malone said.
Ultimately, Springboard Delaware envisions building five to seven Pallet Villages around the state by the end of the decade.
"We have a vision, and we believe that homelessness is solvable," Malone said. "This is not the whole solution, but it's a huge part of it."
During a city council meeting last month, several council members expressed skepticism.
"Obviously, we all want to be compassionate, we all want to be empathetic, and we all want to help solve this problem," Mayor Travis McDermott said. "But we have realistic hurdles that we would have to overcome, and even with our best intentions, we can't escape it."
One big question, he said, is where would a Pallet Village be located.
"People are not going to want you to use the land behind their house to build this," McDermott said. "That's just a simple fact."
Councilman Jay Bancroft expressed similar thoughts.
"I hope we'll be very sensitive to local opposition that is likely to be an issue," Bancroft said. "I think this idea of making it look suitable to the neighbors is important for this education campaign, for us to take steps that we've been talking about for a long time"
Councilman Jason Lawhorn noted that the Georgetown Pallet Village was built near where there was already a large established homeless encampment. He said it's important to understand the scale of homelessness in Newark to better understand whether a Pallet Village would be utilized here.
He added that city staffers are already overworked and questioned whether the city should have a role in creating a Pallet Village.
"I love the program," he said. "I have reservations about how we execute it in Newark."
Suchanec asked his colleagues to direct City Manager Tom Coleman to prepare a report on whether there are any city-owned properties that could potentially be used for a Pallet Village. He suggested looking at underutilized parks as well as a piece of land the city recently purchased off Paper Mill Road, between the city's electric substation and White Clay Creek.
Ultimately, the council decided that in order to not burden city employees, each council member will compile of list of possible locations in their district for further study.
"You can find so many reasons to say no for something," Suchanec said. "The easy thing is to say no or to convince yourself this is something not worth doing. All I'm saying is take a baby step. Find out if we have any locations in this city where something like this could happen."

 CAMBRIDGE - The Honorable Donald F. Johnson, 80, of Cambridge peacefully went home to be with Jesus on Saturday, October 14, 2023. He was born on December 6, 1942, in Cambridge, Maryland to the late Arthur N. Johnson and Emma (Parks) Johnson Moore.Donald graduated from Cambridge High School, Class of 1960. He earned his B.S. in 1964 from Salisbury State College and his J.D. in 1969 from University of Baltimore School of Law. He was the Assistant States Attorney for Anne Arundel and Dorchester Counties from 1969-1974. Then he entered private practice until he was appointed Circuit Court Judge for Dorchester County in 1984. During his 20 years serving as the County Administrative Judge for the 1st Judicial Circuit, he was a panel chair for the Health Claims Arbitration Board and a member of the Attorney Grievance Commission. He was a past president of the Rotary Club of Cambridge and on the Board of Directors for the Dorchester General Hospital. He was a member of Grace Methodist Church, Rotary Club, Dorchester Historical Society, Barcca Class, Maryland Bar Association and Dorchester County Bar Association. He enjoyed sailing, woodworking, traveling, spending time with his family, antiquing, and visiting historical sites.He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Joan Shimer Johnson of Cambridge, a daughter Emmajane Olinde and husband Greg of Fruitland, a son Donald F. Johnson, Jr. and wife Amy Dukes of Wilmington, NC, three grandchildren Grace Olinde, Victoria Olinde and Mason Olinde and fiancée Brooke Planner, two brothers Wayne A. Johnson and wife Donna of Cambridge and Jeffrey L. title: Cambridge nursing facility faces complaints about care
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Cambridge nursing facility faces complaints about care

 May 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 1614
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — When Dorchester County native Danny Frazier lived at Mallard Bay Nursing and Rehab in Cambridge, he loved having visitors.From high school buddies to family members, Frazier — who moved into Mallard Bay in his mid-60s after receiving an ALS diagnosis — treasured those visits, his sister Debbie Linthicum said.
Those visits were among the only reasons Frazier stayed at Mallard Bay from June 2023 until his death in May 2024.
"We talked a few times about moving him to another facility because we were so dissatisfied," Linthicum said. "And his biggest concern was, he said, 'I really love when people come to see me, and I'm afraid if I'm in Easton, it's a little bit of a further drive, they may not come.'"
Linthicum said when Frazier lived at Mallard Bay, he experienced inadequate care from staff, particularly when it came to food. She said when Frazier was no longer able to feed himself, there were instances when staff would bring his food but not feed it to him.
They are not alone in their experience with Mallard Bay.
From a lack of care for residents to staffing problems, residents, their family members and former staff members say they have tried to advocate for the residents of Mallard Bay but have not seen change. On top of that, it has been 2½ years since the last federal inspection of the facility, and the state agency responsible for overseeing nursing homes faces a lawsuit alleging it has failed to inspect nursing facilities and allowed complaints against facilities to pile up.
Former Mallard Bay geriatric nursing assistant Deanna States-Meninger said she spoke with Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard about the facility and filed a complaint against the facility with the Maryland Office of Health Care Quality.
States-Meninger said that when she worked at Mallard Bay, management wouldn't do anything in response to her complaints.
"I would go down the chain, and it seemed like it just got pushed off," she said.
In an April interview with The Star Democrat, Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) confirmed Mallard Bay had been reported to the state. He said the Office of Health Care Quality, which is within the Maryland Department of Health, was looking into the complaint.
Key Health, which manages Mallard Bay, originally agreed to an interview and was sent a list of questions from The Star Democrat. However, the company later canceled the interview and sent a statement sharing its goals.
"Since Key Health began managing the facility in November 2022, we've worked hard to build a warm, supportive environment where residents feel valued and staff feel proud," the statement said. "... Like in any healthcare setting, we may occasionally hear concerns, but we always take them seriously. However, the voices of those with positive experiences — of recovery, comfort, and dignity are vast."
The statement said Key Health remains "fully transparent with regulators," accountable to its standards and committed to "every person who calls Mallard Bay home."
According to the U.S. Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, reviews for Mallard Bay are middling.
STEPHEN'S STORY
After a swimming accident this past summer left Stephen Nowlan, 54, paralyzed from the torso down, he spent three months in Mallard Bay's rehabilitation program.
Although he was excited to go there after hearing about "how incredible it was," he said it ended up being nothing like he expected.
Nowlan said there were not enough staff for the number of residents, and he would often wait a long time to receive help or care.
On his first day at the facility, Nowlan spent a long time waiting for his medication in pain. He said when he finally received his medication, the staff member who brought it didn't administer it.
"She put my pills on my table," he said. "But I can't move. … She put them on the table and left."
Nowlan said that when he shared his concerns with the higher-ups at Mallard Bay, they gave him "all kinds of excuses."
"I mean there's no excuse," Nowlan said.
Although Nowlan said he had good physical therapists and a few good aides, he often found himself waiting for care or simply not getting enough of it.
Nowlan said there were occasions when he spent physical therapy sessions getting a shower from the physical therapists because the care staff hadn't given him a shower.
He left Mallard Bay in December after three months because his insurance stopped covering his stay.
About eight months after his accident, Nowlan said he is able to move again but is considered quadriplegic because he has altered sensation in every part of his body. He attends physical therapy three times a week and expects to walk again one day.
BRITTANY'S STORY
Brittany Fletcher's father Michael Prager, 76, has lived at Mallard Bay since September.
Fletcher said her father had brain surgery for normal pressure hydrocephalus in early April and his doctors asked him to go on the Mediterranean diet for his brain health. According to the Cleveland Clinic, the Mediterranean diet "emphasizes plant-based foods and healthy fats."
That is not what Prager is being served at Mallard Bay, Fletcher said.
"They are giving him sugar drinks and cake, and the meals are very starchy," she said.
Fletcher said her father is learning to walk again. She said Mallard Bay left him alone in the shower, even though he is a fall risk.
And Fletcher said she has not had a great experience when it comes to communicating her concerns to Mallard Bay and its management.
Fletcher said she has thought about moving her father to a different nursing home, but funds are limited, which makes that harder to do.
"And I'm assuming anywhere is better than this at this point," she said. "But I don't know."
DEANNA'S STORY
Deanna States-Meninger said that after six weeks working as a geriatric nursing assistant at Mallard Bay early this year, she quit her job.
States-Meninger said she made the decision due to a culture of neglect and lack of care, consistent understaffing, overworking and unresponsive management.
According to the Code of Maryland Regulations, the ratio of nursing service personnel on duty providing care to residents of a nursing home may not be less than one to 15. States-Meninger said there was one night when she was left to care for an entire floor of 45 patients by herself for four hours.
"It made me feel like I was a failure," she said, "like I couldn't answer all the bells and help the people when they needed it."
According to the U.S. Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, the nursing staff turnover in a given year at Mallard Bay averages 71.2% compared to the 41.6% state average and the 47.5% national average.
States-Meninger called her job at Mallard Bay an "awful" one.
"I can't tell you how many nights I left in tears," she said.
DEFICIENCIES FOUND
According to the U.S. Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, Mallard Bay has an overall three-star rating, scoring "above average" (four stars) for health inspections, "much below average" (one star) for staffing and "below average" (two stars) for quality measures.
Concerns with the 160-bed facility pre-date Key Health taking over in November 2022.
In August 2022, seven deficiencies were found during a federal inspection, including failure to report incidents of alleged abuse to law enforcement, failure to serve meals as requested by residents and failure to provide treatment or services to prevent or heal pressure ulcers.
In an email April 30, Maryland Department of Health Director of Communications Chase Cook confirmed the 2022 federal inspection report is the most recent inspection report. This means there have not been any federal inspections since Key Health took over management.
In Maryland, the Office of Health Care Quality within the state's Department of Health is responsible for the oversight of nursing homes, which includes licensure, certification and investigation of complaints.
Last year, a lawsuit was filed against the Maryland Department of Health alleging the department has allowed more than 100 nursing facilities to go without an annual inspection for more than four years and allowed thousands of un-investigated complaints against nursing facilities to pile up.
According to the class action complaint, the plaintiffs argue that when the department fails to complete its oversight responsibilities, "dangerously poor-quality care within nursing facilities goes undetected and uncorrected."
The Department of Health has not responded to questions from The Star Democrat about Mallard Bay, the department's process for addressing complaints against nursing homes and how it ensures nursing homes in Maryland are safe for its residents.
In 2018, the Maryland General Assembly passed the Maryland Nursing Home Resident Protection Act to ensure complaints are addressed in a timely manner.
Specifically, the bill requires the Maryland Department of Health conduct a full inspection of each licensed nursing home in the state at least once a year and initiate investigations into complaints alleging actual harm within 10 business days of receiving the complaint.
The bill states the department shall receive 50 new full-time positions within the Office of Health Care Quality over a five-year period. These hirings were supposed to begin in fiscal year 2020, months before the COVID-19 pandemic shut down the country.
Sen. Stephen Hershey (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, and Caroline), who was a sponsor of the 2018 bill, said in an email that this is an issue he still has concerns about. He mentioned a bill passed by the Maryland Senate this year — which he also sponsored — that requires the Department of Health to report inspection data to General Assembly committees.
"We've been extremely concerned with the lack of responsiveness from the Department of Health's efforts to ensure residents and families that nursing homes can provide safe, high-quality care," he said.
Hershey said consistent oversight is important when it comes to determining whether nursing facilities are providing high-quality care.
"Regulatory agencies must work collaboratively to ensure bad actors cannot operate unchecked and that residents receive safe, quality care," he said.

title: Vote 'yes' on Question A — support public safety
author: PETE LESHER
content:
Vote 'yes' on Question A — support public safety

 October 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: PETE LESHER | Section: Columns 
 
 478
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Four years ago, Talbot County voters overwhelmingly approved a temporary increase in the property tax revenue cap by an "extra penny." Our public safety operations were facing a recruitment and retention crisis because of low pay and inferior benefits compared to surrounding jurisdictions.Talbot County has made enormous progress with the "extra penny" on the property tax since 2022. Sheriff's deputies' pay is competitive and sheriff's deputies now are on the state-sponsored LEOPS retirement program, allowing them to retire after 25 years. These benefits, in conjunction with solid leadership, means the Sheriff's Office can fill open positions. Deputies now retire from the department – a once-rare circumstance – rather than leaving to work in other jurisdictions.
Likewise, our Emergency Services compensation has increased.
Pay for paramedics, emergency medical technicians and 911 dispatchers is more competitive than in 2020 — though we need to monitor this against surrounding counties, and paramedics are now eligible for the LEOPS retirement program, a popular benefit. The county has stepped its sixth advanced life aupport ambulance crew to a seven-day, round-the-clock unit, helping us keep response times within the critical 8-minute standard.
The county is planning a new ambulance station near the Chapel District Elementary School, which will help reduce response times in the northeast corner of Talbot County, where we have struggled to meet the 8-minute standard.
Our County Detention Center has faced staffing shortages, forcing mandatory overtime to operate the facility safely. The County has responded by boosting correctional officer salaries and budgeted to convert their retirement plan to the more robust state-sponsored CORS program.
The state of Maryland mandates what we spend on our court system and the minimum that we must spend on public schools. While the state allows the county to exceed its property tax cap to fund schools, there is no state mandate to fund the sheriff's department or ambulance services or road repairs. And so these critical county services may suffer if the property tax cap restricts revenues and forces cuts.
All of the funds raised by the "extra penny" on the property tax since 2022 — and more — has gone to boosting public safety. The "extra penny" runs out in 2026. The Talbot County Council unanimously authorized a ballot question to renew the "extra penny" for seven more years, out of concern public safety costs will continue to rise faster than the 2% property tax cap.
Voting for Question A allows the County Council the option to levy the "extra penny" for seven more years — through fiscal year 2033. Even with this "extra penny," over the last four years or for the next seven years, Talbot County maintains the lowest property tax rate in the state of Maryland.
If you support public safety and emergency services, vote for Question A. Do it for your family's safety. Do it for your neighbors. Do it for your own good. Vote for Question A.

author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
St. Michaels businesses prepare for tourism drop in the fall

 August 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 377
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — The summer tourism season comes to an end after Labor Day. For multiple businesses in St. Michaels, it could mean a slow down in business.Businesses in St. Michaels are preparing for the fall and winter months by cutting back on some costs.
"It's something that we know is coming every year," Craig Schury, owner of Pemberton Pharmacy & Gift St. Michaels, said. "This year has been a little more difficult than most, so we're prepared. We pair down our staff a little bit and we try to keep our merchandise pretty tight. If we control those cost, we know we can be alright."
According to some business owners in St. Michaels, this year's tourism season has not been as good as previous years. While data specific to this year's tourism in St. Michaels is not yet available, domestic tourism nationally has seen a slow down.
According to Bank of America, their aggregated card data showed softer lodging, tourism and airline spending in 2025.
Some St. Michales businesses plan shift merchandise to fit with upcoming seasons in hopes of keeping revenues up.
"We have less families in the fall, more couples, more anniversaries, more getaways, baby moons once the kids are back in school," said Courtney James, manager for The Preppy Redneck store.
"So, it's a different vibe in that a lot of people stop on their way to the beach in the summer and they have more families. Boating season also goes into October. So, a lot more people when it's cooler come out on their boats, um, which is a different vibe too. Each one brings kind of a different vibe."
While the shift in merchandise and savings is key for business, the one major factor business owners hope to continue to see during the fall and winter months is support from the local community.
"It's paramount," said Jay Hudson, owner for Blue Heron Coffee. "We're here for the community, so having the community support throughout the winter means the world. I look at the community as more of the sustainable business model, they're here every day, so their support means all the world. Tourism kind of comes and gos, but to have the community support, not just through the winter, just in general, means the world to a business."

author: Bill Haufe

 CENTREVILLE — Jeff Hollis said he wasn't nervous, especially with seniors Vince Gilberto and Collin Woolford in the game."I always feel like with Vince and Collin on the court that somebody's going to make a winning play," said Hollis, Queen Anne's County High's boys head basketball coach.
Hollis was right. Somebody did make a winning play, and that somebody was freshman Jadereon Thompson.
Fouled with 1 second left, Thompson hit the first of two free throws Tuesday night to lift top-seeded Queen Anne's to a 66-65 victory over No. 2 seed Easton in the Class 2A East Region II championship.
The Lions (18-4), who have won six straight since a Jan. 30 loss at Easton, now wait for the Class 2A field to be reseeded, and will likely host a state quarterfinal either Friday or Saturday. Easton finishes the season 15-7.
"Really elated. It's been three years coming to this game and we've lost two of them," said Hollis, whose season was ended by Wicomico the past two years in the region final. "So to finally win one feels really good."
Down 32-31 at halftime, the Lions looked well on their way to victory as they outscored Easton, 22-7, in the third quarter to carry a 53-39 lead into the fourth.
But behind Marshall Bailey, who scored 17 of his game-high 27 points in the fourth quarter, Easton rallied as the sophomore guard scored on a drive with 4 seconds remaining to tie the game at 65-65.
On the ensuing inbounds pass, Gilberto threw a pass three-quarters of the court to Thompson, who drove straight to the basket and was fouled with 1 second left on the clock.
"I was either going to get the layup or get fouled," Thompson said.
During a timeout prior to his free-throw attempts, Thompson said all his teammates came up to him offering him encouragement.
"It felt great," Thompson said. "I had to knock 'em down to win the regional final."
Thompson hit the first, then watched the second attempt bounce and get rebounded by Gilberto to seal the win.
"He's really not a freshman," Hollis said of Thompson. "He's a freshman in age, but he's not a freshman. He's been building to this point. He's just an exceptional kid and an exceptional athlete."
Easton outscored the Lions 26-13 in the fourth quarter.
"I thought we were going to overtime," Warrior head coach Dionte Hynson said. "I'm proud of the kids. Helluva comeback. We had to dig deep. We had to play solid D. I'm not taking anything away from Queen Anne's but our kids played their butts off tonight."
Diontye Copper's 3-pointer with 6:27 left in the third quarter pulled Easton even with the Lions at 35-all. But Queen Anne's outscored the Warriors 18-4 over the final 5:39 of the quarter to build a 53-39 lead, with Woolford (12 points) scoring seven points in the run.
"We just couldn't score any points third quarter," Hynson said.
Bailey, who was 8 of 9 from the foul line, hit a pair of free throws to start Easton's fourth-quarter comeback, drained two 3-pointers and continuously attacked the rim, scoring or drawing contact.
"He's a great player," Hollis said of Bailey. "Hat's off to Easton. I thought their players and their coaching staff did a great job. They weathered the storm when we got up on 'em. They came back.
"But our kids made the final winning play," Hollis added. "We talk about it all the time. Things happen during a game. Who's going to be the man that makes the final winning play. We've had that a couple times this year."
Gilberto had 14 points for Queen Anne's, Nickai Gross and Hollace Branch each had 10, and Thompson finished with nine.
Rayan Haq had 10 for Easton and Kyree Acree eight.

title: ‘It’s certainly over’ for aid-in-dying bill this year
author: SAPNA BANSIL Capital News Service
content:
‘It’s certainly over’ for aid-in-dying bill this year

 March 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SAPNA BANSIL Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 577
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Lawmakers have tabled a fiercely debated bill that would have granted terminally ill Maryland residents the right to end their lives, a setback to supporters who hoped it would finally pass this year.Senate President Bill Ferguson (D-Baltimore City) said in a press conference Friday that the measure had not won enough support among the 11 members of the Senate Judicial Proceedings Committee to move forward this term. Ferguson indicated he was unwilling to bring the bill for a vote if it was likely to fail.
"For this year, it's certainly over," said Senate Judicial Proceedings Committee Chair Will Smith (D-Montgomery), noting the bill would have fallen one or two votes shy of passing his committee.
Although Democratic leaders — from Gov. Wes Moore to Ferguson and Smith — all previously expressed support for the bill, they said there would be no last-ditch efforts to change lawmakers' minds on an issue that is deeply sensitive for both supporters and opponents.
"I told every member of this committee that on issues like this, it's a vote of conscience," Smith said. "It's so personal. It's such a tough issue … In order to come to me and say, 'Hey, look, I'm expressing unreadiness, I cannot vote for this bill,' I would honor that."
This bill, known as the End-of-Life Option Act, sought to make Maryland the 12th jurisdiction to legalize medical aid in dying, which provides patients with incurable illnesses the option to die by self-administering lethal medication. Patients would have been eligible if they had less than six months to live, were of sound mind and made a series of oral and written requests.
As the Senate and House considered companion bills over the past few weeks, the issue became the subject of contentious debate and hours of testimony. Proponents said aid in dying was a matter of dignity and bodily autonomy, while opponents expressed religious, ethical and moral concerns.
The bill's failure elicited strong emotions from its supporters on Friday, many of whom have experienced years of setbacks on the issue.
"It's gut wrenching," said Sen. Ariana Kelly (D-Montgomery), a member of the Judicial Proceedings Committee and a bill co-sponsor. "The proponents of this bill have come before the legislature, year after year, explaining why it's necessary. I have a broad community of constituents back at home and friends and colleagues who I see in Annapolis who are gutted … People feel this very personally."
Among those who testified in support of the bill was Diane Kraus, a 59-year-old Baltimore woman living with metastatic breast cancer. She said she wanted to have the option of medical aid in dying in the event her condition became terminal.
"I'm really disappointed," Kraus said in a phone interview. "I don't want to have to move out of state in order to be able to use this."
But one opponent said the bill's demise was the right outcome.
"I'm actually very pleased," said Sen. Mike McKay (R-Allegany, Garrett, Washington). "I know that it's a very, very personal piece of legislation that affects each of us much differently than (Republicans) to (Democrats) or rural to suburban … There's just people (who) weren't comfortable moving forward."
While the bill has met its end for this session, lawmakers said they anticipate reintroducing aid-in-dying legislation in upcoming terms.
"This is one that in time, maybe things will change with more education and more discussion," Ferguson said. "And so it's best to just know that it's just not happening this year."
Angelique Gingras contributed reporting for this story.

title: Moore says budget will balance, protect school funding
author: KIERSTEN HACKER Capital News Service
content:
Moore says budget will balance, protect school funding

 January 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KIERSTEN HACKER Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 930
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Gov. Wes Moore unveiled a budget proposal on Wednesday that would balance the books and protect the state's ambitious reform plan for Maryland public schools, without raising taxes in the fiscal year that begins in July.The $63.1 billion plan would balance the books where officials had projected a shortfall, in part by returning some programs to spending levels closer to those of the pre-pandemic era. The plan proposes leveraging state debt and dipping into rainy day funds.
The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's sweeping education plan of 2021, will be fully funded, state budget officials said Wednesday. Moore, a Democrat, said his administration crafted the budget plan in partnership with lawmakers, community leaders and other "village elders."
"We wanted to make sure that this proposed budget had everyone's fingerprints on it," Moore said in his public announcement of the new plan. "Because this budget is not just a reflection of an administration. This budget is a reflection of our shared aspiration."
Those aspirations will now go to the Maryland General Assembly for debate. Lawmakers have set a target of early April for passing a budget, and the state Constitution requires that it be balanced.
But the joint Republican Caucus will look closely at where funding transfers in the proposed budget are coming from, House Minority Leader Jason Buckel, R-Allegany, told Capital News Service.
While he said he is pleased that the Moore administration kept total spending similar to that of years past, he expressed concerns about the possibility of fees for certain businesses or tax hikes down the road. Buckel said he'll keep worrying about that possibility until the legislature adjourns.
"All in all, it's a mixed bag, I think, and we'll look forward to working with the governor and working with the Democratic leadership here to try to make the budget as good as possible," Buckel said.
Senate Minority Leader Stephen Hershey suggested he worries about the possibility of fee increases down the road.
"While it is a relief that the governor's budget spends less than last year and does not raise taxes, the number of fee increases proposed by his administration through legislation and the regulatory process is concerning," said Hershey, a Republican representing Kent, Cecil, Queen Anne's and Caroline, in an email release. He and other Republicans contend fee hikes are coming through the administrative pipeline.
"Taxes aren't the only way to raise revenue," Hershey said, "and state government should not be in the business of nickel and diming Maryland's families and small businesses."
The only fee increases currently in the budget plan are in the Department of the Environment, and those would generate roughly $3.5 million in revenue, according to a spokesman for the governor's office.
Working together to approve a balanced budget had been shaping up as no easy task. The state's spending had been projected to outpace revenues starting in the coming fiscal year, according to a recent report from the Department of Legislative Services.
But Moore has now proposed a plan that would instead balance the 2025 budget, saying it is a step in the right direction toward addressing the state's structural deficit in the years beyond that.
His budget flips the expected cash shortfall of $1.1 billion to a positive cash balance of $103 million in fiscal 2025, according to Helene Grady, Maryland's secretary of budget and management.
Moore said his budget prioritizes public safety, affordable housing, child care, education and public service. It also raises pay for state employees.
"We know that budgets, they're moral documents," Moore said. "Where we choose to invest actually defines our values. And it dictates the course of our future."
State budget officials said they avoided wide-ranging cuts across the board, hiring freezes or salary freezes. Rather, state agency heads went through an intense process and found areas to trim, and several agency budgets will be lower this year than they were the year before.
Moore said he proposed a record $127 million for local police agencies, citing the importance of supporting law enforcement and getting "more boots on the ground" to solve crimes and keep repeat offenders off the streets. Other investments would go toward the prevention of gun violence and support for crime victims.
While addressing public safety, Moore acknowledged the debates about juvenile justice likely to come during the legislative session, announcing an increase in funding to the Department of Juvenile Services. He didn't specifically discuss any cuts made to juvenile services programs.
Affordable housing and child care would receive significant funding under the proposal. Those are two areas Moore claimed are the biggest strains on Maryland residents. Access to housing and child care allow for increased participation in the workforce as Maryland tries to grow its economy, he argued.
"Access to child care doesn't just affect your child and your family," Moore said. "It changes the trajectory of our state's fiscal health."
Options for job training in innovative industries and public service were a priority. Through Moore's budget, the state is on track to increase the number of Service Year Option and Maryland Corps participants to 500, as required by law.
The Blueprint for Maryland's Future will be fully funded in the coming fiscal year, budget officials said, but its money problems are far from resolved. Prior to the beginning of the legislative session, the Department of Legislative Services report projected the state would exhaust the Blueprint balance in fiscal 2027.
"It's not inaccurate to say, 'Hey, we funded the Blueprint, or at least the state's portion of the Blueprint, for today,'" Buckel said. "But I also think it's completely honest to say the blueprint looming large over the next four or five years, blows billion-dollar holes into our state budget."

title: NEW HEIGHTS
author: Bill Haufe
content:
NEW HEIGHTS

 March 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 804
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As March Madness is set to tip off, three of the most recognizable names in college basketball are in the women's tournament: Caitlin Clark, Angel Reese and Paige Bueckers.Clark drew record crowds and ratings all season long. Reese has LSU in contention for a second straight national championship. Bueckers is finally healthy and doing things on the court for UConn reminiscent of her freshman season when she was the AP Player of the Year.
Throw in a few stellar freshmen like JuJu Watkins and Hannah Hidalgo and the game is reaching heights it's never seen.
"One thousand percent we've seen a shift in just the perception of women's college basketball in general," USC coach Lindsay Gottlieb said. "It doesn't have to be at the detriment of men's college basketball. The increased coverage and star power these players have; they are legitimate, popcorn-worthy type of players."
For countless seasons, the buzz around the NCAA tournaments have often been on the men's game. The one-and-done stars, the juggernaut blueblood programs, the buzzer beaters and athleticism all getting more attention. The women's game has pretty much all of that too, and the ratings and attendance this season suggest casual fans are fully engaged with a game that boasts star power and an increasingly high level of play.
It helps that the women's players stick around for three, four or even five years without the chance to leave early for the pros so fans get to know them and watch them grow. Three years ago, Clark said she thought women's players should be allowed to turn pro after their freshman year, like the men can.
Instead, she stuck around and had a record-setting year that grabbed the nation's attention.
"It's really, really evident that there's stars out there in this game," UConn coach Geno Auriemma said. "Whereas before I think they were there, but nobody wanted to acknowledge it and appreciate it as much. ... They're just really good. Everybody is going around telling everybody how good they are. They're all visible."
ESPN said it just saw the most watched women's college basketball regular season in more than 15 years, with viewership up 37% on its platforms from last season. That doesn't really even include the Clark effect as Iowa's star wasn't on the network much this season. Iowa's ratings on Fox Sports were the highest in a generation.
ESPN plans to show all of Iowa's games, including a few on ABC, as far as the No. 1 seed advances in the tourney.
"It's not just UConn and Tennessee on TV," Auriemma said. "Those kids are on TV a lot. They're in the limelight a lot. They know how to handle it because they're used to it now."
Clark, who broke the NCAA all-time scoring record this season, has helped six different networks reach all-time viewership marks for women's basketball over the past year, starting with last season's NCAA championship game that drew nearly 10 million viewers.
"I kind of get to be in the spotlight and I get to change people's viewpoint of how they see women's basketball," Clark said before the season. "The amount of people that have come up to me and said, 'I've never watched women's basketball before before you and your team ... .' Some people could take that as a negative. But to me that's a positive. We're finally getting them to turn on the TV and watch it, but not only watch it once. They're coming back for more."
People aren't just watching, they are also coming to games too. All five of the power conferences had huge crowds for their tournaments. The SEC and Big Ten had their best attendance ever. The Pac-12, ACC and Big 12 weren't far behind.
"The big names continue to put up big numbers and people are watching and the media is paying attention," Bueckers said. "The tournament will be great and will continue the rise of women's basketball."
Fans who pack the arenas are also sticking around afterward, hoping to get a coveted autograph. The importance of the moment isn't lost on the game's stars. Clark, Reese, Bueckers, Watkins and many others spend time postgame signing and taking pictures with not only young girls, but boys, too.
"There were 400 people in the stands before she got here and now we're selling out," Gottlieb said of Watkins. "We've got NBA players who want to see her, WNBA players, musicians and actors too. Regular fans also, it's a diversified crowd. Little boys and girls who ask me if I know JuJu. Could they meet Juju? Grown men you run into in downtown LA."
Even when Clark leaves for the WNBA after the NCAA Tournament, the future of women's basketball is still strong with Bueckers, Watkins, Hidalgo and many other up-and-coming players.
"It's going to get even better. So many kids coming out of high school are just unbelievably good," Auriemma said.

"All I could think about was my nieces or some other younger generation, laying in that bed and being spoken to that way and not knowing how to advocate for themselves. And that made me really angry. So it is kind of my theme this year is just, please advocate for yourself," Hannawald said.

 EASTON — A Cambridge woman was handed a three-year sentence after pleading guilty to altering physical evidence in the shooting death of 23-year-old Antonio Smith.Judge Broughton Earnest handed down the sentence following a plea hearing on May 22. Chadnee Harris, 33, will serve 236 days followed by one year of probation, with the remainder of the sentence suspended.
Harris originally faced charges of of acting as an accessory after the fact of first- and second-degree murder and acting as an accessory after a felony for the same incident. The charges were amended to one count of altering physical evidence.
The charge stems from a shooting in the parking lot of Sidetracked Saloon in Easton on Sept. 30. Officers who responded to the incident just before 2 a.m. found Smith in the parking lot suffering from a gunshot wound to the head. Smith was transported to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Easton, where he was pronounced dead.
On May 20, Kevron Chase, 35, of Cambridge, pled guilty to first-degree murder for Smith's death. A sentencing hearing for Chase is set for July 19.
According to previous Star Democrat reporting, in charging documents, police said the bar's security camera footage showed Chase and Harris standing between two cars near the entrance of the bar and Smith approaching the two.
According to the documents, Chase pulled a handgun from his waistband area and pointed it at Smith. Chase put the handgun back toward his waistband area and then appeared to hand the gun to Harris, police said.
After a fight broke out, Harris reportedly walked toward the men. A crowd that had gathered quickly dispersed. According to the charging documents, Smith appeared to duck behind a car and Chase walked toward Smith, pointing a handgun at him. The officer who reviewed the footage wrote in charging documents that they saw a muzzle flash from the gun and Smith collapse in between two cars.
At Chase's plea hearing on May 20, Talbot County State's Attorney Joseph Coale said Chase then left the scene and drove to Cambridge, where he disposed of the handgun in the Choptank River.
Chase and Harris were later found during a traffic stop on Race Street in Cambridge. They were both detained by police.

 EASTON — Talbot school officials took a deeper look at state test scores last week, indicating upward trends in math and English for some grades and dips in others.At a work session on Sept. 15, Helga Einhorn, assistant superintendent of school leadership and student success, presented to Talbot Board of Education members breakdowns of 2024-2025 Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program scores by grade and student group.
The presentation showed increases from the previous year in English proficiency for third and fourth grades, but drops for fifth and eighth grades. Math proficiency spiked year-to-year for fourth, sixth and seventh grades, but the number of students proficient algebra significantly fell.
The deeper dive came after the state released test score data for the 2024-2025 school year last month. While proficiency rates increased statewide, Talbot County students saw mixed results. English proficiency dropped to 45.4%, 16th in the state and the largest year-to-year decrease (1.9%) of all districts.
In math, 18.9% of students were proficient, 18th in the state and nearly even with the previous year's mark. Other counties, such as Dorchester, saw notable gains, rising spots in the statewide rankings.
Two days after the Sept. 15 work session, Talbot Board of Ed Member Deborah Bridges said at a monthly meeting that the district's results kept her up at night.
"After our work session on Monday night, I couldn't sleep," Bridges said. "Our scores, it upset me so much. And I wondered, what are we missing? What is going on in our schools?"
Board members largely agreed that the results aren't a matter of pointing fingers at teachers or staff. Instead, they are focused finding solutions to fix some of the problem areas.
Board President Emily Jackson said at the work session that she hopes school officials can begin to pinpoint some reasons behind the data trends.
"If I look at us, and we're going down, whereas a neighboring county who has a similar population of kids and they're going up, I want to know why," Jackson said.
Einhorn said while the state tests are an "important measure," it's one of many ways to assess academic achievement and growth.
"This is one assessment given at a single period of time, which does not always accurately reflect what students know and what they're able to do overall," Einhorn said.
ENGLISH
Fifth and tenth grades suffered the largest proficiency drops of 5.6% and 10%, respectively. But fourth grade proficiency rose to 50% in the most recent results. And while third grade proficiency dipped from last year's 47.9% mark, it's still at 43.6%, an improvement over a 35% rate two years ago.
"This really speaks to the work that this board has invested in early literacy, and starting to see that trend move up," Einhorn said at the work session.
Meanwhile, most student groups followed the district's overall trend of slightly decreasing in English proficiency. Asian students fell from 68.9% to 51.2%, while Talbot's multilingual learners dropped from 8.7% to 5.1%.
MATH
One of the sharpest drops came in Algebra II proficiency: 32.8% of students passed the state test in 2023-2024; only 7.1% passed in 2024-2025.
Einhorn acknowledged that as an "area of need." She noted that new math standards for K-8 will go into effect next school year. And in two years, the district will begin integrated algebra courses, infusing geometry concepts, she said.
Fourth grade rose nearly six percentage points to 32% proficiency this past year, while seventh grade had a similar hike from 11% to 17%.
By student group, one result stood out: Black students in the district remain under 5% proficient in math. Einhorn admitted the shortcoming.
"The less than 5% is indicating that we are still underserving our Black students and that we still need to continue looking at strategies that better prepare them to show what they know and are able to do in mathematics," Einhorn said.
Board Member Dyshekia Strawberry said she'd like to see the district work with community partners to specifically tackle the gap in math proficiency for Black students.
Board members thanked Einhorn for presenting the detailed trends, acknowledging that there's work to be done to get some of the numbers going in a positive direction.
"We have to do better, and we're open to hear how we're going to do that," Jackson said.

title: Stepping into the past - Museum explores Tubman's life through murals
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Stepping into the past - Museum explores Tubman's life through murals

 December 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 941
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - In the back of the Harriet Tubman Museum and Educational Center on Race Street, one wall acts as a window into Tubman's life.Inside the museum, on one side of the wall, Tubman is painted as a young girl, about 13-years-old, at the Bucktown General Store.
"This was a pivotal time in her life," Linda Harris, the museum's director of events and docent, said. "It was considered her first act of defiance." Outside the museum, on the other side of the wall, Tubman is an adult, holding out her hand.
"(She's) coming back, rescuing family and those that wanted freedom," artist of both murals, Michael Rosato said.
Harriet Tubman, an abolitionist and social activist who was born into and escaped from slavery in Dorchester County in the 19th century, became well-known for her work on the Underground Railroad, a network of routes and safe houses that helped enslaved people escape to their freedom.
Inside the museum, the mural of a young Tubman and the Bucktown Store covers the entire wall - and the other three walls in the room.
With canvas and paint, Rosato has transformed the back room of the museum into the Bucktown Store, a significant place in Tubman's history.
The story goes that Tubman was asked to go to the Bucktown Store to get something for the master.
"And she didn't want to do it," Bill Jarmon, president of the Harriet Tubman Organization, said.
"Part of it had to do with the fact that she wasn't presentable." It had to do with her hair, Jarmon said. So she covered her hair with a cloth made from flaxseed.
When Tubman got to the store, she heard a noise at the backdoor and saw a young boy struggling to get away from his master. When the boy escapes and runs toward the door, Tubman is told to stop him. But she doesn't. She steps out of the way to let him go through. "Her first act of defiance," as Harris said.
As the boy escaped, Jarmon said, a two-pound weight was thrown at him.
However, the weight hit Tubman in the forehead instead, knocking her unconscious.
Harris considers Tubman's head wrap to be a very important piece of this story.
"She wraps her head in this linen made of flaxseed, which in fact - what I'm reading and what I believe now - cushions the blow from that two-pound weight being hurled at her," Harris said.
"Imagine if she had fixed her hair that day. She'd be dead." Sitting in the back room of the museum Wednesday, Dec. 20, Jarmon and Harris pointed to different parts of the room as they told the story. When they officially open this part of the museum - which they hope to do in January - visitors will feel even more immersed in the story.
They plan to put in wood floors and counters to resemble the store. And as they tell the story of Tubman's first act of defiance, Harris said she and her husband will play code songs, songs enslaved people used to share messages.
Eventually, Harris hopes to offer virtual reality goggles to visitors when they enter the room.
"We're going to make this thing come alive," she said.
The idea to do this all started when Harris learned that she would no longer be able to take visitors on tours inside the original Bucktown Store.
Harris said that considering how pivotal the store was in Tubman's life, she couldn't have people visit and not learn the story.
"So I said, 'Well, let's put it in the museum,'" Harris said.
To begin the project, Rosato, who lives in Church Creek and has been an artist for 33 years, went to the store and took photos of the walls.
"Every square inch of the walls and what was on the shelves," he said.
After that, he took the photos back to his studio on Race Street and put paint to canvas.
"(I) just started to recreate the store as close as possible and in a somewhat realistic fashion so when you're in that space you feel as though you can take things off the shelves," he said.
After completing each wall on the canvas, he would bring the canvases to the museum and glue them to the walls so that it looked as if he had painted directly on walls of the museum. To make it look as realistic as possible, Rosato had to consider light, shadow and perspective.
"When you create a painting that you want to look real and dimensional, you have to understand perspective and find the right vanishing point," he said.
"So when you're standing right in the middle of that room, every wall you look at, all the lines converge to a certain point. And that's what gives it a sense of depth." The project, which Rosato worked on in the fall, took between one and two months to complete.
He said that once it is open to visitors, he hopes they will get a sense of the rich history of Tubman's experience in Dorchester County.
"The possibility of being able to stand there and reflect back like, 'I'm in the store where she is.
This is what happened,'" he said. "And then going outside and seeing (adult) Harriet Tubman. This is the outcome."

title: Caroline Commissioners pass bills, approve roads projects
author: Connie Connolly
content:
Caroline Commissioners pass bills, approve roads projects

 February 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly | Section: Local News

 Words

 DENTON — Road paving projects, legislative picks and pans, and zoning decisions formed the bulk of the Caroline County Commission meeting at 9 a.m. Tuesday, Feb. 13, in Denton.After a lengthy discussion with Deputy County Administrator Daniel Fox and Roads Superintendent Bryan North, the commissioners settled on beginning paving projects for two county roads.
Wolf Road near Henderson and a short dirt section of Jones Corner Road at Concord will be paved with tar and chip, and paid for with leftover American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 funding.
Two roads affected by flooding are awaiting better weather and materials. Fox said he will be getting a purchase order to the commissioners next week for $122,000 to buy the precast concrete needed to improve the River Road site. Unusually high tides have prevented work on Gilpin Point Road, although the replacement pipes are on hand.
Legislative actionsThe commissioners introduced legislation to change zoning requirements for solar energy systems in the R-Rural District, repealing subsections in Section 175 of the county code, and "reenacting the same with amendments." The legislation is Bill 2024-003.
Originally proposed in October 2023, public comment prompted the county Planning Commission to recommend changes. Screening requirements, including working with a licensed landscape architect and providing for a variety of buffers were not changed.
Also unchanged was the restriction on placing commercial solar on the portion of acreage that was used for transfer development rights. Road right-of-way setbacks were increased.
The second reading and public hearing for Bill 2024-003 is set for Feb. 20 at the County Commission meeting. The third reading is scheduled for March 12, with an anticipated effective date of April 26.
Two other pieces of legislation were read for the third time and enacted unanimously. Legislative Bill 2024-001, authorizes additional projects to be funded from the proceedings of the Consolidated Public Improvement and Refunding Bonds of 2019.
The projects are roof replacements for Federalsburg Elementary School, North Caroline High School and Preston Elementary School, as well as a new HVAC system for the Fretterd Center in Denton.
The bond proceeds were reallocated since the commissioners are not pursuing the renovations of the county detention center, anticipating the eventual construction of a regional detention center.
Legislative Bill 2024-002 revised stream buffer requirements for both perennial and intermittent streams, increasing them from 25 to 50 feet.
State legislation
Commission Vice President Larry Porter and Public Information Officer Jennifer Reibly have attended Maryland General Assembly legislative session updates with various groups.
The commissioners will send letters of opposition and directives to the lobbyists to oppose bills that "take away local autonomy" such as House Bill 1407, which would preempt a county's authority to decide if and where to place solar arrays, Porter said.
Porter recommended opposing a statewide school emergency response bill, consulting with the Recreation and Parks Department regarding legislation that would require counties to replace certain playground surface materials and opposing funding cuts to community colleges.
Because the county "has been a catalyst" for lithium battery safety, Porter recommended supporting House Bill 468/Senate Bill 530.
The commissioners discussed other pending legislation. To view the meeting of the commissioners, watch the video posted on the commissioners' website, usually within 48 hours of the meeting.
Agendas, videos and transcripts of commission meetings are posted at carolinemd.org.

title: There are other options open to poultry farmers
author: DR. ASHA SUBRAMANIAN
content:
There are other options open to poultry farmers

 January 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DR. ASHA SUBRAMANIAN | Section: News 
 
 726
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As a physician, I have been following closely our country's bird flu crisis. I was saddened but not surprised to learn that, within days of each other, bird flu was detected for the first time on an Eastern Shore poultry farm and our country experienced the death of its first patient from H5N1 bird flu in Louisiana.My colleagues and I are watchful for symptoms of bird flu and are hopeful that Maryland does not join the list of states in which more than 60 human cases of bird flu have been detected. I applaud our public health officials for doing what they can to keep the bird flu from spreading but the reality is that the virus has sickened dozens of people, decimated poultry populations and infected dairy cows.
Thankfully, our state is doing a good job of monitoring for the virus. But now is the time to take a hard look at the food production system that puts farm workers in close contact with sick birds and cows, the Standard American Diet that demands it and the health ramifications of both.
From a doctor's perspective, shifting food production away from intensive animal agriculture can benefit public health. Facilities with large numbers of animals in a small amount of space are a concern for public health because they provide ideal conditions for viruses to spread, evolve and possibly acquire the ability to more easily infect people. Intensive animal agriculture was implicated when influenza viruses H1N1, H5N1 and N7N9 jumped from animals to people, according to research published in Frontiers in Microbiology.
The life of a contract chicken grower can be challenging, and some of them are repurposing their chicken houses to grow crops. I was not surprised to learn that North Carolina poultry farmers Dale and Paula Boles switched from chickens, converted their 500-foot-long poultry barn to a greenhouse and now grow organic vegetables. They are not alone. In Southwest Arkansas, farmers Jennifer and Rodney Barrett are transitioning from raising poultry and cattle to growing mushrooms.
These farm transitions aren't easy. The government should provide financial and technical support. Maryland could help its farmers with a program like the one established by lawmakers in Vermont who provide grants to farmers who wish to diversify or transition from one type of farming to another. On a broader scale, U.S. Sen. Cory Booker has introduced legislation that would require the U.S. Department of Agriculture to provide grants to livestock farmers to pay off related debt and to transition the property to alternative agriculture activities. Maryland's U.S. Sens. Van Hollen and Alsobrooks should support this legislation to help ensure that it passes.
According to the USDA, "Maryland is small, but it reaches from the Atlantic Ocean to the Appalachian Mountains, providing a suitable environment for a variety of agricultural commodities," which means lots of opportunities for farmers. Sweet corn, hazelnuts, watermelons, grapes, as well as apple, cherry and peach orchards are just a few promising options.
Shifting away from animal agriculture helps our environment and improves worker safety as well. Maryland's poultry farms are a primary source of water, air and land pollution. Improving the water quality in the Chesapeake Bay is another reason to increase acreage of fruit and nut trees. One way to keep phosphorous and other pollutants from flowing into rivers is to install riparian buffers of trees and shrubs to intercept polluted water running off of fields where chicken litter has been applied. Trees that are suitable for riparian buffers, like hazelnuts can also provide income to farmers.
I have found for myself and my patients that removing animal products from the diet improves health too. A plant-based diet focused on fruits, veggies, legumes and grains grown in Maryland can help maintain healthy weight, lower blood pressure and improve heart health.
I know this from my own personal experience and from treating patients with diet-related diseases, and the scientific literature tells the same story. A recent study with 22 pairs of identical twins found that a plant-based diet improves heart health in as little as eight weeks. The twins following a plant-based diet experienced lower LDL, or "bad" cholesterol, and they lost more weight than the omnivore twins.
Government grants and other assistance should also be available if Maryland poultry farmers or egg producers would like to switch to growing crops and planting orchards, which will also benefit human health and the environment.
