 Maryland small business owners will get help with legal, accounting and financial services under a new $10 million grant from the federal government, officials announced last week.The Treasury Department is awarding the money this fall as part of the American Small Business Opportunity Program.
The award came as good news to Maryland Gov. Wes Moore, who used to run his own small business helping underserved students navigate college.
"When people would tell me it's really hard to build a business in Maryland, my response to them was always the same: I know, I had to do it myself," Moore said in a Monday press call announcing the grant.
"This is going to help more Marylanders turn ideas into jobs and businesses," Moore said, "and turn individuals into job creators."
The money is meant to fuel local growth and provide innovative resources to disadvantaged start up businesses in the state, according to a Treasury press release.
This federal funding will go to the Maryland Technology Development Corporation, an independent instrument of the state that provides funding, insight, resources and connections to early stage companies.
"There are three 'T's' that every entrepreneur faces: they face a challenge of time, a challenge of talent, and a challenge of treasure," said Troy A. LeMaile-Stovall, CEO of TEDCO.
The program, he said, will "give them access to talent that they need to grow and scale their enterprises."

content:
Deepening Divides - Democrats Split Over 'Anti-Zionism Is Antisemitism' Measure; Poll Shows U.S. Racial, Generational Differences Over Israel-Hamas War

 December 11, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 3 | Section: News

 Read News Document

 The U.S. House of Representatives approved a measure Wednesday declaring that "anti-Zionism is antisemitism" prompting a split among Democrats.A majority of House Democrats did not vote for the measure as a public opinion poll from Gallup shows substantial divides among Americans over the Israel-Hamas war in Gaza by age, race and political persuasion.
Whites, older voters and Republicans tend to back Israel in its war against Hamas after the Oct. 7 terror attacks while younger Americans, people of color and Democrats disapprove of Israel's air strikes and ground invasion of Gaza aimed at the Islamic militant group, according to a poll released Nov. 30 by Gallup.
The congressional measure condemning antisemitism passed with support from 216 Republicans and 95 Democrats. The resolution's most controversial component was plank equating anti-Zionism with antisemitism.
Zionism is a movement and belief system that supports the Jewish state of Israel in the Middle East.
"Zionism is the movement for the self-determination and statehood for the Jewish people in their ancestral homeland, the land of Israel," according to the Anti-Defamation League.
Thirteen Democrats voted against the measure and 105 Dems voted 'present' or did not vote neither supporting nor opposing the resolution.
One Republican - U.S.
Rep. Thomas Massie of Kentucky - voted against the anti-Zionism/antisemitism measure. Another four GOP lawmakers did not vote.
"Anti-Zionism isn't antisemitism," Massie said in a social media statement pointing to congressional remarks by U.S. Rep. Jerrold Nadler, D-New York, that some Orthodox and other Jews are not in agreement with modern Zionist constructs.
Nadler, the House's most senior Jewish members, said some Orthodox Jews believe only the Messiah can establish a new state of Israel and the measure can label progressive Jews and others critical of controversial judicial reforms in Israel as antisemitic.
Nadler and U.S. House Majority Leader Hakeem Jeffries, D-New York, were among those voting present on antisemitism measure.
The 13 Democratic no votes came from progressives who have been critical of Israel's war in Gaza against Hamas and U.S. support for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu after the Islamic militant group's Oct. 7 attacks.
Opponents of the measure - which referenced rises antisemitic vandalism and violence - included U.S. Reps. Jamaal Bowman and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York, Rashida Tlaib of Michigan, Ilhan Omar of Minnesota and Pramila Jayapal of Washington "We must be steadfast and clear in condemning antisemitism. The extreme GOP resolution on the floor today had no Democratic cosponsors and inappropriately said all anti-Zionism is antisemitism. Muddying the waters about what antisemitism is, is completely wrong and unhelpful," said Jayapal who had to clarify recent comments about whether she condemned Hamas' rapes and violence against women and girls in the Oct. 7.
GOP SUPPORTS MEASURE U.S. Rep. Andy Harris, a Republican representing the Eastern Shore, voted for the antisemitism measure along with Maryland Democratic U.S. Reps.
Steny Hoyer, David Trone, Dutch Ruppersberger and Kweisi Mfume. Maryland Democratic U.S. Rep. Jamie Raskin and John Sarbanes voted present.
House Republicans overwhelmingly backed the resolution which labels some pro-Palestinian slogans as antisemitic.
"More Jews were murdered on October 7th than on any other single day since the Holocaust.
Let that sink in. We have even seen members of this very body repeat blatantly antisemitic rhetoric and spread lies about Israel and her right to exist. Let me be absolutely clear: such hate has no place in the halls of Congress nor our national discourse. It is our fundamental responsibility as leaders and Members of Congress to condemn and fight these horrific acts of hate and discrimination against the Jewish community," said U.S. Rep. David Kustoff, R-Tennessee, one of the main sponsors of the resolution.
GOP backers of the measure point to a rise in antisemitic incidents and pro-Hamas and pro-Palestinian rhetoric that calls for or insinuates the destruction of Israel. They also point to the 106 no or present that did not support the measure - 105 of them from Democrat.
"The world has seen a drastic rise of antisemitism since October 7th that is deeply disheartening and extremely concerning," said U.S. Max Miller, R-Ohio. "Elected leaders must have the courage to condemn and fight all forms of domestic and global antisemitism.
While I am glad this resolution passed the House today, I am disappointed that 106 of my colleagues failed to take this opportunity to condemn antisemitism forcefully." AMERICA DIVIDED The Gallup poll released Nov. 30 shows significant splits over the Holy Land war by race, political party and gender.
The polls shows 71% of Republicans back Israel's war against Hamas in Gaza versus support from 36% of Democrats.
Fifty nine percent of men approve of Israel's war in Gaza versus 44% of women, according the Gallup Among people of color, 64% disapprove of Israel's attacks against Hamas in Gaza while 61% of whites backs Netanyahu's efforts to dismantle the militant group.
There is a similar split my age with 67% of younger Americans (ages 18 to 34) disapproving of Israel's war against Hamas and 63% of voters 55 and older backing the Israel Defense Forces' military effort.
Palestinian health authorities in Hamas-controlled Gaza say more than 17,000 people have died since Holy Land war stared in October Israeli officials say Hamas fighters killed more than 1,200 people and took more than 240 hostages in the Oct. 7 terror attacks.

 CAMBRIDGE — The Cambridge City Council voted unanimously at a meeting on April 8 to make David Deutsch acting city manager upon Tom Carroll's exit and to approve a contract with Mercer Group Associates for recruitment services for the next city manager.On March 18, Carroll submitted his resignation from the city manager position. He said his last day with the city would be no later than May 17.
The reason for this decision, he said, was his concerns with Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc.'s Cambridge Harbor project, a project to develop the space along the Cambridge waterfront.
In a March 19 interview with the Star Democrat, Carroll said he had accepted a city manager position for the City of Lexington, Virginia.
With the council's April 8 vote, Deutsch will take over as acting city manager on a temporary, part-time basis beginning in May. He will not work more than 40 hours per month at a $125 per hour, and his travel expenses are not to exceed $1,000 per month.
In an April 3 memo to the mayor and commissioners, Carroll said this schedule will economize Deutsch's work and put more responsibilities on Cambridge's Assistant City Manager Brandon Hesson.
Deutsch is a senior associate at Mercer Group Associates and a former city manager. According to Carroll's memo, Deutsch served as Cambridge's acting city manager in 2021 and 2022, and he helped Cambridge with its city manager search in 2022.
"Mr. Deutsch has the necessary credentials and familiarity with Cambridge and the organization," Carroll said in his memo.
Deutsch will also lead the recruitment for the next city manager, according to the memo. This recruitment contract with Mercer Group Associates will cost the town $21,800 and up to $5,000 in reimbursable expense.
Before voting on the contract and appointment of Deutsch, Commission President Lajan Cephas asked Carroll, laughing, "Can you leave some of your DNA so it can be replicated?"
"I'll do my best," Carroll said in response.
Following the news of Carroll's resignation, Cephas called Carroll a gift to Cambridge in an interview with the Star Democrat. She said that he has made a lasting impact on the city.

 January 31, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BILL PEAK Talbot County Free Library | Section: Life 
 
 696
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On Monday, March 3, at 6 p.m., in the Easton branch of the Talbot County Free Library, it will be my honor to interview Paula Johnson about her newest book, "Julia Child's Kitchen: The Design, Tools, Stories, and Legacy of an Iconic Space."Full disclosure: Johnson is a lifelong friend of mine. She is also a distinguished curator at the Smithsonian's National Museum of American History. Among her many curatorial triumphs, it was Johnson and co-curator Rayna Green that brought Julia Child's kitchen to the museum in 2001. Almost a quarter of a century later, it remains one of that institution's most popular exhibits.
I was one of the lucky fellows who received a copy of Johnson's new book when it came out in October.
Initially, truth be told, I wasn't sure what I would think of a book about a kitchen, fool that I am. Anyone who knows Julia Child, read her books or watched her television shows, knows that a book about Julia Child's kitchen is a book about Julia Child.
It's been a long time since I've had so much fun reading a book.
And the word "fun" is apt. Again and again in the book, as people recall cooking with Child in her kitchen or a meal they shared there, the word they use to describe both their host and the place is "fun."
Which is not to say that serious labor did not take place in that kitchen.
The book makes it clear that Child and her husband Paul were both workhorses. In the early television shows, the sponsoring public television station, WGBH Boston, couldn't afford retakes or editing. Julia had to begin upon a complicated recipe, carry it through, instructing all along, and arrive at a finished product that she could take a bite out of in just 28 minutes flat. The cameras shut off at 28 minutes, and there was no going back.
To accomplish this feat of legerdemain, she and Paul would practice for hours at home before a show, choosing which elements of a recipe to demonstrate, deciding how to demonstrate those elements and carefully working out the language to use in explaining them.
The whole thing was choreographed from beginning to end and different stages of the cooking prepared in advance so that, "through the magic of TV," they could be displayed at the proper time as if just pulled from the oven.
Yet somehow, Julia always came across as relaxed and enjoying herself. And it wasn't a guise.
One of the things I found most endearing about "Julia Child's Kitchen" is the way sections on subjects such as the kitchen's organizing principles inevitably end up revealing the love Paul Child felt for his wife, the care he took in setting up that kitchen and showcasing her art. In letters to his brother, Paul sometimes referred to his wife as "Julie."
Julia called her kitchen "the soul of the house," and her nephew, Alex Prud'homme, called the table where meals were served in that kitchen "the center of the universe."
Unsurprisingly for that time and a family of their class, the Childs had a formal dining room, but Julia's preferred place to serve friends a meal was the kitchen. Julia's unpretentious attitude toward entertaining (and herself) is made clear in her explanation for the placement of that kitchen table, "I want the dining table in the middle of the room because, like a sheepdog, I need to be right there in the midst of everyone."
That statement is so characteristic of the woman we meet in Johnson's book. Julia Child never fails to charm, yet somehow she never seems to patronize or fawn.
The book itself is like a party at Julia's house. You meet fascinating people, hear terrific stories, experience a magical place, and, at the very least, get to imagine yourself enjoying extraordinary meals.
Speaking of stories, I can tell you from long experience that the author of "Julia Child's Kitchen" is a great storyteller in person as well as in her writing. And so I ask the pleasure of your company on March 3 at 6 p.m. for an evening in Julia Child's kitchen, courtesy of the Smithsonian's Paula Johnson. Trust me, you're in for a real treat.

title: Event highlights video games that explore travel, adventure
author: Staff Writer
content:
Event highlights video games that explore travel, adventure

 June 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 477
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Smithsonian American Art Museum presents its annual exploration of video games and art, SAAM Arcade 2024, on Saturday, July 27, from 11:30 a.m. to 7 p.m. This program is part of the museum's ongoing commitment to the study and interpretation of video games as part of the national visual culture.This year, the popular celebration of creativity and innovation in games focuses on the theme of "Adventure Awaits." This daylong event features video games that celebrate the theme of travel, exploration and the exciting possibilities of visiting real and imagined new worlds.
The centerpiece of the event is the independent developer showcase, which this year features nine games. In addition, MAGFest, a non-profit organization dedicated to the appreciation of games and video game music, is providing a variety of classic arcade and console games featuring cars, travel and new worlds to play.
The titles selected for the "Indie Showcase" include:
"Hair Nah" by Momo Pixel, reflecting on the experience of Black women while traveling;
"A Highland Song" by inkle, set in the Scottish Highlands, where players test their survival skills;
"Atuel" by Matajuegos, focuses on the ecosystem of Argentina's Atuel River Valley;
"Skábma-Snowfall" by Red Stage Entertainment, where players transform from Sámi reindeer herders to traditional healers;
"Sophia The Traveler" by Memo Gogo Studio, explores Venice, Italy;
"Journey" by thatgamecompany, navigates a desert and the remains of a forgotten civilization;
"Spiritfarer" by Thunder Lotus Games, where players travel by sea and become ferry masters, caring for and befriending spirits on their way to the afterlife;
"Isles of Sea and Sky" by Cicada Games, where castaway survivors journey across ancient islands; and
"Morgan: Metal Detective" by Studio Morgan, where players discover lost treasures on an island through metal detector work.
From 11:30 a.m. to 1 p.m., the sound levels in the space will be reduced so attendees with sensory needs can enjoy the offerings, and throughout the program, noise-cancelling headphones will be available to borrow. American Sign Language interpreters will be available during the program.
Musical performances by Triforce Quartet will be at 2 p.m. and 5 p.m. A special themed scavenger hunt will be available so visitors can explore the museum's galleries and connect video games to objects in the museum's collection.
An additional activity created by the museum is Side Quest, a game where participants ask developers questions and win prizes. Detailed event information and a full list of the featured games are available on the museum's website.
The Smithsonian American Art Museum was one of the first art museums in the United States to acquire video games as part of its permanent collection. Video games create compelling participatory and social spaces, imagined by artists and designers and activated by players whose individual interactions are uniquely required to complete the experience.
For more information about the Smithsonian American Art Museum, go to americanart.si.edu.

title: Talbot school board sees test scores, improvement initiatives
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Talbot school board sees test scores, improvement initiatives

 September 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 836
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — State test scores released last month show a slight increase in math and English proficiency levels at both the district and state levels.Talbot County's Board of Education discussed that trend and others during a work session on Monday, taking a first deep dive into the test results from 2023-2024's Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program.
In English, 47.3% of Talbot County Public Schools students tested proficient, a jump of 2.8% from 44.5% in 2022-2023. In math, 18.3% of students were proficient, up 1.1% from 17.2% the year prior. The district slots in 14th and 18th, respectively, in those categories among the state's 24 districts.
ENGLISH TRENDS"One of the things that the board is always interested in is how does Talbot County Public Schools compare to other districts in the state," said Helga Einhorn, assistant superintendent of school leadership, while presenting the English results. "And I wish that I could give you better news and say that we have flip-flopped the map, but if you compare this year's results to last year across the state, you will see very little change. There is not a single district in the state who is leapfrogging in improvements on this map."
Einhorn and Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi emphasized that the district internally tracks student learning levels. This is done at benchmarks throughout the year.
"I can assure this board that more than 47% of our students are mastering grade level standards," Einhorn said of the English proficiency rate. "It's just that they are not showing it across the state on this particular assessment."
Some positives for the English rates included third grade proficiency and the growth for certain cohorts and subgroups. Third grade English proficiency saw a significant jump from the 2022-2023 school year.
Einhorn pointed out that in 2023, sixth grade students were 40.1% proficient. That same group of students came in at 43.8% proficient on the seventh grade test. "For that cohort of students, it's growth," Einhorn said.
Einhorn said all student groups saw growth in English rates, though Black students had the smallest increase.
"We are reaching every student in some sense, in some capacity," Board President Emily Jackson said of the subgroups. "Maybe not as well as we could, but we're getting there, we are making growth, and that's what I want to see."
MATH TRENDSIn math, the district has many initiatives to increase proficiency. Einhorn said the number of elementary math coaches has increased from three to six, along with an addition of one middle school math coach.
The district is implementing an adaptive testing program called Measures of Academic Progress for kindergarten through eighth grade to track student growth.
In 2023-2024's state test scores, TCPS students showed increases across the board.
"We see slight increases for each one of our student groups," Einhorn said. "We have less of an increase for our Hispanic and Latino students. And we still continue to have fewer than 5% of our Black students and our multilingual learners proficient in mathematics."
For proficiency levels below 5%, the state does not indicate exact percentages. Of the 24 districts, the Talbot district is one of three below the 5% mark in math proficiency among Black students, and one of nine districts below the 5% mark in math proficiency among multilingual students.
Einhorn and Jackson each thanked the Talbot County Council for its commitment in funding education, particularly the math coaches in elementary schools.
"When you see movement like we did in third grade," Jackson said, "I think that we are making really intentional, really important, really good funding decisions that have a big impact on learning."
EXPERT REVIEWSAs required by the state's education initiative, Blueprint for Maryland's Future, experts vetted by the Maryland Department of Education will be reviewing school districts across the state. Einhorn said state reviewers will be visiting three elementary schools in Talbot County this year.
Those schools will be Chapel District Elementary, St. Michaels Elementary and White Marsh Elementary. They were chosen for separate reasons. Einhorn stated: Chapel for reviewers to look at literacy instruction, St. Michaels to review practices for multilingual learners and White Marsh due to success in state testing.
"They had significant growth in their math achievement across all grades in this last MCAP assessment," Einhorn said of White Marsh Elementary. "So they want to know what White Marsh is doing well."
Jackson asked how the district can take lessons learned from these three schools to its largest elementary school, Easton Elementary.
"Can you speak to how we plan to address that?" Jackson asked. "How do you take what you've learned at a very small, very specific population and duplicate it or replicate it at a school like Easton Elementary?"
"One of the things that we do even though it's a larger school, we have committed the same types of resources but just on a larger scale," Einhorn said. "So while our smaller elementaries might have one math coach, we see multiple math coaches to be able to service the number of classrooms that we have at Easton Elementary."
Einhorn said other schools in the district will have state reviews in the next year or two.

author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Five counties unite for recovery awareness event at Church Hill Park

 September 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 534
 Words

 CHURCH HILL — Standing united as one community in support of recovery and awareness across the area, Mid Shore Behavioral Health, Inc. hosted its annual five county collaborative Going Purple Together at Church Hill Park Sept. 27.Organizations and agencies from neighboring counties of Queen Anne's, Talbot, Kent Caroline, and Dorchester came together to show the community all the resources available for substance recovery, mental health, addiction, and support.
Annually supporting recovery across the Mid-Shore region, the 2025 Going Purple Together event offered a blend of, fun, education and community engagement, with local vendors, activities, and the message of continually learning about substance abuse, overdose, recovery, peer support, and prevention.
Highlighting important community resources in a fun, casual environment, festivities were complete with DJ, food trucks, giveaways, family fun activities and performances by Hula Hoop Love.
Building awareness through engagement
Recognizing substance abuse awareness and prevention is more nuanced than "Just Say No" community engagement is the first step in addressing issues.
By building awareness in a fun environment, the community can be proactive and not reactive, said Queen Anne's County Circuit Court Judge Lynn Knight, a founder of the Queen Anne's County Circuit Court Assisted Recovery and Treatment program.
Ten years ago substance abuse resources did not exist in the county like they do today, and the growth in support is tremendous, she said.
Personal stories of recovery
Showcasing the possibilities of recovery straight from those who have lived it first hand, peer support specialists shared their personal experiences to help inspire and encourage those in need.
One such peer, Kaylee Whitby, of Federalsburg, noted for the longest time her personal story was a continual cycle riddled with active addiction, treatment, jail, and legal issues.
Finally after an attempt on her own life, Whitby fought to give herself a new way of living because "it was obvious my way was not working."
Through continual effort and the support of peers, Whitby was able to join in recovery services that finally made a lasting impact on her recovery journey and ultimately her life.
Whitby voiced gratitude for the opportunities offered through supportive recovery houses, including security, accountability, growth, and networking connections still part of her life today.
"Recovery saved my life," she said. Because of recovery Whitby learned to surrender and make amends to rebuild relationships. Whitby was able to be the mother that her children deserved and be the person she wanted to be.
Knowing there were others out in the community with their own similar experiences helped shape Whitby and she was eager to pay that forward to inspire others and be part of that journey.
"Today I chose to live," Whitby said.
Comprehensive support services
Understanding the many avenues that go hand in hand with recovery, organizations connected the community with the tools for support including behavioral and mental health, social services, gambling help, out and inpatient services, as well as resources for loved ones of those facing diseases of addiction.
Mid Shore Behavioral Health, is proud to continually work closely with community and county health departments and administration to erase stigma and further advocacy said Alisha Saulsbury, forensic mental health program manager.
Seeing people smile proud of themselves on their recovery journey makes it all worthwhile, Saulsbury said.
More information about Mid Shore Behavioral Health can be found at midshorebehavioralhealth.org.

title: Easton Town Council passes cannabis ordinance
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Easton Town Council passes cannabis ordinance

 April 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 532
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Nearly two months since opening a public hearing on the topic, the Easton Town Council has passed an ordinance revising the Town Code to regulate zoning for cannabis-related uses.At its meeting Monday, the council voted to pass Ordinance 809 with amendments.
The amended ordinance permits the use of dispensaries through special exception in the central business commercial zoning district and the general commercial district. It also permits, through special exception, cannabis growing and processing facilities in the industrial zoning district and the business commercial zoning district.
On-site cannabis consumption establishments are prohibited in all of Easton's zoning districts under the ordinance.
The passing of the ordinance comes about nine months after the state's approval of various recreational cannabis uses took effect. In November, the council passed a six-month moratorium on businesses looking to produce or sell cannabis within the town limits, which expires May 9.
"If we don't vote today, we must at the next meeting in order to be handled before our moratorium expires," Council President Frank Gunsallus said at the meeting Monday.
The council waited to vote on the topic while the General Assembly discussed the topic in Annapolis. At the council meeting April 1, Easton Town Planner Lynn Thomas said the Maryland Senate had passed a bill that is different from the House of Delegates. He said said that, considering the General Assembly would be adjourning, the town should have the information it needs to vote at April 15's Town Council meeting.
At the meeting Monday, Easton Director of Planning and Zoning Miguel Salinas said that House Bill 805, which deals with cannabis restrictions, had gone through the Senate and House of Delegates and is now awaiting Gov. Wes Moore's signature.
Salinas listed the amendments to Easton's ordinance, including a separation requirement of a half mile between dispensaries. Salinas said that is in House Bill 805.
Salinas said other amendments to the ordinance include the addition of parking standards for dispensaries and the addition of a requirement that a professional engineer or equivalent qualified professional certify that that the proposed odor measures established effectively eliminate outdoor odors.
Before voting on the ordinance, Ward 2 Council Member Don Abbatiello asked that they change the ordinance to permit cannabis growing and processing facilities in the industrial zoning district through special exception, rather than just permitting it.
"There's one industrial area in particular that is off of Dover Road that backs right up to an entire neighborhood," Abbatiello said. "I'm sure that those individuals would at least like the opportunity to share their concerns or joy that a growing facility is going in that area."
Abbatiello said this change would not prohibit growing and processing facilities from the industrial zoning district, it would just give residents "an extra opportunity" to voice their thoughts.
Gunsallus made a motion at the meeting to approve the ordinance with the amendments from the town and the amendment requested by Abbatiello, which passed.
At the end of the meeting, Abbatiello thanked Thomas, Salinas and Town Attorney Sharon VanEmburgh for their work on the ordinance.
"This has been a long process," he said. "It's been a difficult process. And I really do appreciate all their effort to give us the best information so that we can make a decision."

title: Where has grace gone in winning?
author: Staff Writer
content:
Where has grace gone in winning?

 October 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 207
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I understand competition — athletic, business and political. I've engaged in them all, and I value each for the lessons they teach. Losing, when it happens, can even make you stronger.In debate or sport, you must prepare. You must know your opponent's strengths and weaknesses, and you must have a strategy. And win or lose, you are judged not only by the outcome but by how you carry yourself. I learned long ago: You lose with honor, but you win with grace.
So I ask — where has grace gone? Where has decorum gone? Today it seems acceptable to shout down opponents, to sneer and label, to point fingers instead of making points. These are tactics we would scold in children, yet they are now common currency in our politics.
I always valued the end of a contest, when you could shake hands, smile and respect the person across from you — even if you didn't like them. The best opponent was never the one I agreed with, but the one I could respect.
The true test of character, in debate or in life, is simple: Would I welcome this person as my next-door neighbor? Increasingly, I fear too many of today's loudest voices would fail that test.
DAN McKEW
Easton

title: Things to remember if buying or selling this spring
author: MID-SHORE BOARD OF REALTORS
content:
Things to remember if buying or selling this spring

 May 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MID-SHORE BOARD OF REALTORS | Section: Real Estate 
 
 524
 Words 

 Read News Document

 If someone is buying or selling this Spring, they may have noticed a few new ways of doing things since the last time they went through this process, noted Michelle Abplanalp, president of Mid-Shore Board of Realtors.There are several real estate changes that went into effect in August related to showing homes and compensation.
For buyers, a written buyer agreement is now required. Buyers and their Realtors will need to reach an agreement regarding how the agent will be paid for their services and put it in writing before seeing a home. "However, don't get hung up on signing this agreement," Abplanalp said. "This agreement can be specific. It can be to see one specific home, it can be for one day or one week, whatever you negotiate."
Before signing this agreement, buyers should ensure it reflects the terms they have negotiated with their Realtor and that they understand exactly what services will be provided and how much these services will cost, the Board of Realtors said.
The buyer agreement must include four items:
A specific and clear disclosure of the amount or rate of compensation the agent will receive or how this amount will be determined must be stated.
The compensation rate must be objective and stated as an amount, a flat fee, a percentage, or an hourly rate. The compensation cannot be open-ended.
The agreement prohibits the Realtor from receiving compensation for services from any source that exceeds the amount or rate agreed to by the buyer.
The agreement must note that the Realtor fees and commissions are fully negotiable and not set by law.
These written agreements apply to both in-person and live virtual home tours but do not apply to open houses or inquiries about services. The home seller may agree to offer compensation to their Realtor, or the seller can offer to assist with closing costs or home inspections.
For home sellers, the offers of compensation (when a seller or a seller's agent shares compensation with a buyer's agent) cannot be shared on Multiple Listing Services. MLSs are local marketplaces used by both buyer and seller agents to share information about homes for sale. Offers of compensation are still an option but are now communicated off the MLS should a home seller choose to pay the buyer's agent fee.
Sellers may consider doing this as a way of marketing their home or making their listing more attractive to buyers.
Per Abplanalp, whether buying or selling, the Realtors compensation or fees remain fully negotiable and are not set by law. Realtors have agreed to abide by the Realtor Code of Ethics and to provide clear and transparent discussions with their clients about compensation.
"What's important to know is these practice changes provide consumers on both sides of a residential transaction with additional choice and transparency," Abplanalp said. "It helps to have this discussion upfront so there are no misunderstandings. I have found that my clients appreciate knowing what I will do for them, what services I provide, and at what cost."
The Mid-Shore Board of Realtors mission is to advocate for its members and the public to preserve the right to own, transfer and utilize real property. For more information, visit midshoreboardofrealtors.com.

title: Maintaining parental rights
author: Staff Writer
content:
Maintaining parental rights

 December 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 376
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I write in response to Ms. Lena Gill's letter of Nov. 30. In referring to the recent election, Ms. Gill states that the newly elected Talbot County school board members Ann O'Connor and Karla Wieland-Cherry are also members of Moms for Liberty. Ms. Gill describes the Moms as a "conservative national group" who advocate for "changes in curriculum and policies."First of all, both Mrs. O'Connor and Mrs. Cherry have repeatedly stated they are not members of Moms for Liberty; they merely participated in a debate sponsored by the Moms in which, to her credit, Ms. Jurrius also took part.
Secondly, Moms for Liberty is a support group for parents, teachers and citizens who are concerned with the education of the next generation. They provide resources for parents as well as information in educational trends throughout the country. While I have never attended one of their meetings, I do receive their newsletter and follow them on social media. Plus I have numerous friends who regularly attend the meetings.
Their agenda is to maintain parental rights through grades K through 12. Additionally, Superintendent Dr. Sharon Pepukayi, and even some of her staff, have attended three or four meetings. If it was so extreme why would they continue to return? Why is this continually portrayed by the Left as a terrible thing?
Thirdly, I wish Ms. Gill had been more specific when mentioning the "changes in curriculum and policies" that the Moms are advocating. Is she referring to better scores in English and mathematics, which the Moms advocate? Is she referring to less violence in the schools and classrooms, which they also advocate? Does she mean the schools' dispensing of contraceptives to children, opposed not only by the Moms but also by many parents?
As for the mention of concentration camps, in 2019 Trump was criticized by the Left for detention centers that had been built by Obama. Remember the children in cages? That happened under Obama, too. Trying to conflate Trump with the Nazis by mentioning "concentration camps" is actually a horrific insult to the millions of victims of the real Nazis. Plus everyone was trying to escape from Hitler's Germany. If America was so bad under Trump, why did people still risk their lives and fortunes to live here?

title: Hispanic Heritage Month celebrated in Kent County
content:
Hispanic Heritage Month celebrated in Kent County

 October 10, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 679
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN - The lilting chorus of Cuban folk song "Guantanamera" filled the cafeteria of H.H.Garnet Elementary School in Chestertown Thursday, Sept. 21.Local resident and artist Fredy Granillo strummed his guitar as he taught the song to students that morning as part of the Celebración del mes del la Herencia Hispana in the county.The Celebration of Hispanic Heritage Month was brought into schools during September through partnerships with the Kent County Local Management Board and the Kent Cultural Alliance.The two organizations were joined by others in holding a variety of community events including art programs and a block party centered around Hispanic heritage."The Kent Cultural Alliance was honored to work with the Kent County Local Management Board and E(Ñ)E: Alianza para la Cultura y Comunidad Hispana, to create a month long celebration of the contributions of Kent County's Latino community," said John Schratwieser, executive director of the Kent Cultural Alliance."Celebrating those who contribute so much to our economic health and our quality of life, and doing that through art, music, food, dance and the written word, is paramount to the mission of the KCA." For Granillo, who also is a Kent County Public Schools parent, getting to share his family's cultural touchstones with students is a valuable experience.Granillo grew up in El Salvador. He and his wife Kent County Local Management Board Director Rosemary Ramsey Granillo moved to Chestertown when their son, a fourth grader at Garnet, was 2.Granillo found the community friendly and inviting, but he still faced hurdles - first being the language.He learned English and he helped his son with the language.There were additional cultural differences for Granillo as well, such as food, and he sees other families having similar experiences when they move here."I was lucky because I had the opportunity to visit Chestertown first," Granillo said. "So I knew about the artistic community in town and that was something that made me feel like I could live here." For students who move to Kent County from other countries, school can pose a big challenge.Beyond learning math standards, science, social studies and other subjects, they also have a new language to learn - and Kent County Public Schools has staff members dedicated to helping those English language learners.Granillo said programs like Hispanic Heritage Month are important for both students born and raised here and those who have moved to the area from other countries.It gives those students from other countries an opportunity and a space to share their culture with their new peers.Granillo spoke about how celebrations in other countries are often built around specific foods, activities and games - not unlike the American custom of eating turkey on Thanksgiving."I think it's really important for schools to have a space where these kids can show other kids what they like to do in their countries, because that gives you a perspective on the world," he said."When you are a kid, you need to understand the world is more than Chestertown or the town where you live." As part of Hispanic Heritage Month in Kent County Public Schools, there were lessons and school announcements teaching students about the culture.Galena Elementary School, for example, held a daily Hispanic Heritage contest, with questions that students could answer by looking at information posted throughout the building.Teacher Tracey Kendall-Parent works with local English language learners in Galena Elementary School. She took to the morning announcements throughout the month to provide information about countries where students' families are from."I think that's a beautiful experience for everybody, not just for the kids," Granillo said of the Hispanic heritage lessons. "And it's going to make these kids from other countries feel like they live in a space where they can celebrate their culture and their identity too."

title: Local K-9 units work to overcome retirements from cannabis law
author: Konner Metz
content:
Local K-9 units work to overcome retirements from cannabis law

 May 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 917
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — In just a handful of months, K-9 Knox is making an impact at the Easton Police Department.The nearly 2-year-old black lab completed training in January. In 2025's first quarter alone, she was deployed 17 times, making six drug arrests alongside her handler, Pfc. Mark Schinault.
"She has that drive for her reward, her toy after she does a good scan," Schinault said. "That means the world to her, so she's very driven to work."
Knox is part of Easton's new guard of K-9s. Last year, three dogs trained in marijuana detection were forced into early retirement due to the legalization of recreational cannabis use legalization in Maryland, which took effect July 2023.
Easton is not the only agency looking to rebuild its K-9 team in the wake of the legislation. Across the state, law enforcement agencies are working to fund and fill their K-9 units, which serve crucial roles not only in deterring crime, but also in connecting with the community.
Police officers largely agree that dogs trained to sniff marijuana can't be used to detect drug offenses any longer, nor does the dogs' expertise hold up in court.
"I really didn't want to go down the road because I didn't want to be challenged in the courtroom," Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble said.
Knox joined K-9 Waylon in Easton, and soon two other young dogs not imprinted on marijuana will fill out the town's K-9 unit. Lt. Tim Larrimore said it has been a "complete rebuild" for the unit since the law passed.
Trained dogs can sometimes cost around $14,000, Larrimore said. Younger, untrained pups are significantly less, though they require major time commitments for training and certification.
Across the state, the work of K-9 dogs — depending on their training — often includes drug sniffing, tracking of suspects or missing subjects, and explosives detection. Knox is certified in drug detection and on her way to certification in tracking.
Schinault and Knox completed more than 60 hours of one-on-one training before she was certified in drug detection. Easton opted to go with untrained dogs to save costs and build rapport between K-9s and officers.
While Maryland K-9s are no longer sniffing for marijuana, Larrimore says their work is more important than ever in combating drug offenses.
"This odor of marijuana was enough before 2023 to give us probable cause to search. Now that's out," Larrimore said. "So now you need the ability to smell something that the human nose isn't necessarily good at detecting. It's the dog that gets you there."
PLAYING CATCH UP
Kent County Sgt. Scott Lockerman has a passion for not just his K-9 partner, Khari, but for all police dogs across the state. He is president of the Maryland Police K9 Foundation, a nonprofit that helps police agencies buy, train and protect their four-legged workers. The foundation paid for one of Easton's new dogs.
Lockerman said that after the legalization of cannabis, there was roughly a 60-40 split of agencies that could quickly get their K-9 units back on track versus those that were more affected by unexpected retirements. But he said progress is being made across all departments.
"Most of the agencies were able to replenish the dogs," Lockerman said.
At the Dorchester County Sheriff's Office, one K-9 retired early after the cannabis law was passed, while multiple dogs retired shortly before. The agency worked ahead to bring in replacement dogs not trained to detect marijuana so the state legislation didn't present too many challenges.
"We saw it coming," Sheriff James Phillips said. "It was on the horizon."
Six K-9s currently work for the Dorchester Sheriff's Office. Three can assist in patrols and narcotic detection, two work in narcotics only, and one bloodhound specializes in tracking. Phillips said the office has adequate funding to fill its seventh and final spot for a K-9 trained in detecting explosives.
Funding often comes from grants, local donations, organizations such as the K9 Foundation and county councils. Phillips said it's "mind-boggling" how generous people have been in donating dogs to the Sheriff's Office.
In addition to purchasing the dogs, agencies pay for safety equipment (like bulletproof vests) and health payments. Departments are also on the hook for vet costs incurred by retired dogs, per state law. For a retired K-9, departments could pay up to as much as $2,500 a year, capped at $10,000 per dog.
Larrimore, the Easton lieutenant, says that hasn't yet presented a major funding challenge, though it could down the road.
"It hasn't hit us yet," he said. "These dogs are just retired last year. They're young, they're healthy."
COMMUNITY IMPACT
When the highly-skilled dogs aren't working a case, they're often out in the community showing more of their friendly side.
In Dorchester County, Sgt. Steve Twilley says the K-9 unit bridges the gap between the Sheriff's Office and the community. The dogs especially help police build trust with kids.
"Next thing you know, that kid's come to you for help instead of lashing out or doing something at school," Twilley said.
Schinault and Knox attended a recent Coffee with a Cop event this spring. Schinault said they're very involved with community policing efforts.
Phillips and Twilley say the same is true in Dorchester County. Whatever dollar amount is spent on police dogs, Phillips says, comes back to the Sheriff's Office "10 times over because of the relationships that we build with the kids and the people."
"I think an agency that's trying to do today's police work and doesn't have the K-9 ability out there, I don't think they're a full police agency," Phillips said. "I think it completes the police agency by having the K-9s."

title: Cost for pedestrian trail bridge connector estimated at 8 million
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Cost for pedestrian trail bridge connector estimated at 8 million

 December 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 321
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — An overview of the pedestrian bridge plans to connect the Cross Island and South Island trails were presented to the Queen Anne's County Commissioners Nov. 26.In conjunction with the Parks and Recreation Department, Southern Kent Island Trail Extension Project staff obtained preliminary construction cost information for a pedestrian bridge crossing over MD Route 50, Chief Roads Engineer Shane Moore said.
Engineering consultant Kimley-Horn was contracted to complete a preliminary evaluation of several Route 50 pedestrian crossing locations east and west of the Route 8 overpass.
Utilizing the MDOT cost estimator to estimate a pedestrian crossing construction costs, As part of this evaluation Kimley-Horn estimated a pedestrian crossing construction cost at the Cracker Barrel location at $8.1 million, Moore said.
Construction only cost estimates were taken from similar type projects including Virginia's Tysons Old Meadow Pedestrian Bridge over Route 495 at $8 million and the Lane Place Pedestrian Bridge over Route 295 at between $10.8 and $12.4 million, according to Moore.
Several locations have been selected for a preliminary study through Kimley-Horn but there has been no final decision yet, according to Moore.
For safety, pedestrian bridges have to be built at a higher elevation than a typical vehicle overpass, Moore said.
With the commissioners' approval, Public Works staff will work with the BMC and RK&K Civil Engineering to develop a scope of services and costs for a final location study of the County's proposed MD Route 50 pedestrian bridge crossing.
Next steps include meeting with Maryland Transportation Authority and the State Highway Administration to begin discussions to nail down a final location for the construction of a pedestrian crossing, Moore said.
Queen Anne's County currently has about $120,000 in Baltimore Metropolitan Council (BMC) monies to be used for this study. In addition, BMC has also federally approved pre-established consulting contracts with RK&K, Moore said.
Federal and state partners have been supportive of this project to serve as alternative transportation connecting the county, County Administrator Todd Mohn said.

title: New acts, old favorites to highlight Rock Hall FallFest live music
author: BOB FORD Special to the Kent County News
content:
New acts, old favorites to highlight Rock Hall FallFest live music

 October 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BOB FORD Special to the Kent County News | Section: Music 
 
 675
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Rock Hall FallFest returns Saturday, Oct. 11, for the 28th edition of the annual one-day festival that celebrates the opening of the commercial oyster season along with the bayside town's tradition of presenting and supporting live music.The "return" of the oyster will be honored, as always, with thousands of hand-shucked oysters on the half shell, complemented by street-fair food and assorted drink offerings.
As for the music, which will play continuously on alternating Main Street stages during the 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. event, two newcomers will join the performance schedule in addition to some old favorites, including the always-popular Catonsville High School Steel Band.
Leading off the lineup on the Mainstay Stage will be Austin, Texas, singer-songwriter Andrea Magee, making her FallFest debut. She will be followed by The Llama Dalis, an eclectic, innovative art-rock quartet that also will perform at FallFest for the first time.
The oysters and the music are just the start. Main Street, transformed into a pedestrian-safe thoroughfare, will be lined with craft and artisan vendors and Rock Hall's array of quaint shops. A food truck convention will set up near the base of Main Street, and a Kids Kourt will feature games, prizes and entertainment for children.
Admission is free, as is the plentiful parking near the festivities. The nonprofit event donates all proceeds to Rock Hall organizations and projects. The main beneficiaries over the years have been the Kent County Waterman's Association scholarship fund and The Mainstay, the iconic music venue that books acts year-round on the Tom McHugh Stage.
The Llama Dalis, founded more than 30 years ago by brothers Michael and Dave Biddison, are a Pennsylvania-based band that reunites for festivals. Michael Biddison, on acoustic guitar, handles most of the lead vocals, while Dave plays drums and sings on the rest of their mostly original repertoire. Bob Taylor plays bass, and Steve Wheelock is the lead guitarist.
Taylor played FallFest last year with Philip Dutton's band, The Good Stuff, a classic country cover unit, and encouraged the Dalis to join the lineup this year.
"We play a high-energy show for all the dancing fools," Taylor said, "but a lot of our pieces are dreamy, thoughtful stuff. My daughter calls us jam band funk."
The Llama Dalis members have all performed in other bands over the years, but they always reunite to play fresh tunes written by the Biddison brothers and to revive a catalog influenced by the full spectrum of rock music. As for the name?
"Well, the Dalai Lama was a good guy, and Salvador Dali was an interesting character," Taylor said. "We have a song called 'Hair on Fire' that comes from a Zen teacher back in the day who said you have to seek enlightenment like a man with his hair on fire. That's us — a little Zen, a little absurdist."
Magee, a multi-instrumentalist, was born and raised in Belfast before pursuing her musical dreams in the United States in 2014. Her music blends folk, rock and Celtic styles, and she has toured with legendary artists including Brian Wilson, Brian Setzer and Jeff Bridges.
Magee is the festival director for She Rises Fest, an annual event that celebrates women in music and the arts. Her nonprofit, Music Helps, provides workshops for children at Helping Hand Home for Children in Austin, a support and housing service for children who have experienced abuse and neglect.
"Music is about community, connection and giving back," Magee said. "It's the threads that weave us together, and I'm honored to be part of that tapestry."
Other acts taking the stage at FallFest include the Catonsville High School Steel Band, returning for its 25th anniversary appearance; Pat Wictor and Bob Beach, blending acoustic guitar and blues harmonica; Kent County's own hard-rocking guitarist Blake Thompson and his Family Band; and the hometown favorites, The Singing Captains, who will close the show with classic pop songs.
Rock Hall FallFest is a feast for the ears, for good appetites and honest thirsts, and for those who enjoy a throwback day of music, oysters and small-town charm.
For more information, directions and a full lineup, visit www.rockhallfallfest.org

title: Stroke of pen loses 75 years of science leadership
author: LENA GILL
content:
Stroke of pen loses 75 years of science leadership

 June 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LENA GILL | Section: Columns 
 
 713
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The U.S. higher educational system may in future years lose $38 billion a year. This is the estimated annual contribution by foreign students. In the school year 2023-2024 it was estimated that 1.1 million foreign students were studying at universities across the U.S., and they generally pay full fare or do work/study. They supported about 378,000 academic jobs.Now we risk driving them away.
On April 19, CNN reported that thousands of international students across the country were informed by email that their student visas were revoked. Six days later the Trump administration decided to restore 1,400 student visas. How many students did not have their visas restored is unknown. We do know that Secretary of State Marco Rubio had a list of about 300 students that he planned to expel. The National Immigration Project is challenging the visa cancellations in court.
Apart from the money that these foreign students bring in, why would we care? Because foreign students began many of the successful startups in Silicon Valley. We care because much research in science done at our universities has brought the U.S. to a revered leadership position in the world in medical science research.
With a stroke of the president's pen this may all disappear. The best brains in the world will not want to come here anymore. Research in advanced cancer treatments, drugs to treat Alzheimer, sudden crib deaths as well as CRISPRs use in treating genetic blood disorders by cutting out a person's faulty DNA will not continue without federal support. The U.S. inventors of CRISPR won the Nobel Prize in chemistry in 2020. We will be taking a giant step backward in the sciences.
In the 20th century up to World War II, Germany won about 30% of the Nobel Prizes in science. The second runner-up was Great Britain with 20% of the Nobel Prizes in science. The U.S. was way down the list with only 6% of the Nobel Prizes in science.
What turned the tide was Adolf Hitler who drove many of the best German scientists, artists and architects (some of them Jewish) to U.S. universities in the 1930s, where they were welcomed. The second German brain drain happened immediately after the war when U.S. intelligence invited physicists like Wernher von Braun (inventor of the German rockets) to the U.S. to work for the space program. The U.S. emerged from the war economically, technologically and militarily better than the rest of the world.
What really propelled the U.S. into today's leadership position was the futuristic vision of what could come, if the U.S. government funded basic research at universities small and large around the country with a promise to keep the government's hands off. The academic freedom and competition created by this decision attracted the best brains from around the world.
Since 2000, the U.S. has won 72 Nobel Prizes in science, of which about 30% were won by immigrants. Great Britain won 16, Germany 7, France 5, Japan 9, Israel 5. Canada, Australia.and Norway won three each.
This rosy picture will change fast if the Trump administration continues to threaten leading universities with withdrawal of funds and academic freedom. Harvard University, which so far has not backed down, was threatened with cancellation of its not-for-profit designation. $2 billion in research grants were withdrawn by the administration. Foreign students' and researchers' visas are being revoked. 27% of the students are from abroad. Attacking an elite university may appeal to the MAGA base, but it is still difficult to understand why President Trump wants to destroy the foremost academic institution in the US!
The Trump administration also is threatening withdrawal of funds from our other world-renowned science research facilities, the National Institutes of Health and the National Science Foundation. A science publication asked its readers if they were affected by government harassment and withdrawal of funds. If so, were they considering moving their research elsewhere? 75% of the 1,600 who responded said they were considering it.
With a stroke of the president's pen, we have lost 75 years of leadership in the sciences.
California, Texas, Illinois, Massachusetts and New York will see the most economic impact. Maryland also will suffer, as we are home to Johns Hopkins Hospital, the site of original cancer research and treatment, and the University of Maryland Medical Center with its world-renowned Shock Trauma Center.

 DENTON — The Caroline County Historical Society wants to rebuild a working relationship with the County Commissioners so they can get some help funding for different projects to help bring tourist to the town."We have in and around Preston a five-mile radius the most significant components of the Underground Railroad in the United States," lifetime member of the historical society Mick McCrea said.
The Linchester Mill historical sight offers many trials and buildings to where Harriet Tubman and other prominent individuals lived.
"We have actual buildings you can literally walk in the footsteps of people where they stayed in the homes where they got freedom from," McCrea said.
Another suggestion made by historical society board member David "Gene" Harris that the Linchester Mill pond be restored for many reasons.
"If we ever had a major fire, the Linchester Mill pond would be an ideal spot to recharge their fire trucks," Harris said.
The County Commissioners want to establish a working relationship as well, a big component is funding and both sides will plan to work together in the future to help with the Linchester historical sight.
Potential Regional Detention Center updateThe potential Regional Detention Center came up in discussion again for the commissioners.
The center would be located at the former Eastern Pre-Release Unit site at 700 Flat Iron Square Road near Church Hill and would house detainees from Caroline, Queen Anne's and Kent counties. It aims to address the growing need for modern and efficient detention facilities in the region, where counties are struggling to finance renovations or replacements of their aging detention facilities.
The commissioners said they still have not received exact numbers for how much everything will cost and how much the county will save by joining the agreement with the other counties.
Caroline County Commission Vice President Larry Porter suggested that the county should do an independent evaluation of the operating cost.
"This decision is going to depend on the operational cost and I'm talking long range operational cost," Porter said. "Would it make sense for us to engage someone to do an independent evaluation of these operating cost?"
The county also want numbers crunched on transportation, employment and other things.
"The biggest question we all have is the operating side of the detention center," Deputy Administrator Daniel Fox said.
The county will have Fox run an independent evaluation to get some calculated numbers to the administrators.

title: Preston man sentenced to 15 years for stabbing
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Preston man sentenced to 15 years for stabbing

 February 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Crime 
 
 415
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — A Preston man was sentenced Thursday to 15 years in prison for the February 2022 stabbing of a then 25-year-old woman.Agreeing with a recommendation from the prosecution, Caroline County Circuit Judge Heather Price handed Mark William Thompkins a 30-year sentence with all but 15 years suspended. He will receive credit for 714 days, or nearly two years, already served, according to court records.
Thompkins, 26, pleaded guilty last October to one count of attempted second-degree murder.
Price also referred Thompkins to the Patuxent Institution, a treatment-oriented, maximum security correctional facility.
"I believe that it was an appropriate sentence," said Caroline County State's Attorney Sloane Franklin, who prosecuted the case. "Unfortunately, the mental health system is broken and failed both the victim and Mr. Thompkins."
Thompkins' defense attorney, Jesse Hicks, could not be reached for comment.
Thursday's sentence comes nearly two years after the young woman was stabbed near Holly Park Drive and Gilpin Point Road in Preston shortly before 3 p.m. on Feb. 17, 2022.
During the Oct. 30 plea hearing, Franklin said trash collection workers near the scene first saw the woman sitting in the driver's seat of her vehicle with a man, later identified as Thompkins, seated behind her.
Thompkins began striking the woman with his fists, then brandished a knife to stab her neck.
The woman ran from her vehicle and collapsed in the front yard of a nearby house. Thompkins cradled her while holding the knife to his own throat, Franklin said.
A witness attempted to help the victim, but Thompkins threatened them, pointing the knife at them and yelling for them to get back.
Multiple law enforcement agencies, including the Caroline County Sheriff's Office, Maryland State Police and Maryland Natural Resources Police, responded to the stabbing.
Franklin said Thompkins punctured his own neck with a knife while running to the woods to evade officers.
After 15 minutes and the use of multiple non-lethal methods, including a taser, a state trooper was able to knock the knife out of Thompkins' hand to detain him, police said.
Both Thompkins and the woman were flown to the University of Maryland Shock Trauma Center in Baltimore for treatment of their injuries.
After his arrest, a judge found Thompkins incompetent to stand trial in April 2022. He was committed to the Maryland Department of Health until August 2023, then transferred back to a local detention center upon being found competent, according to court filings.
Following his release, Thompkins will be placed on five years of supervised probation. He will also be required to complete mental health treatment.

title: Talbot County approves senior task force
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot County approves senior task force

 August 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 329

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Council passed a resolution to create a Senior Citizens Task Force amid calls to address a rise in senior homelessness.Council OK'd the task force 5-0 at its meeting Tuesday after hearing from senior care and housing experts at a work session last month. Council member Lynn Mielke originally brought forth the resolution earlier this summer.
Mielke said she's pleased the task force was established and looks forward to serving on the body. Council Vice President Pete Lesher thanked Mielke for leading the effort.
"I look forward to working with the folks that we'll be calling together for that," Lesher said.
The task force will make recommendations to the County Council on housing, health care, transportation and meal services for homeless seniors.
It will consist of representatives from the following entities, among others: Commission on Aging, Delmarva Community Services, Talbot Interfaith Shelter, Neighborhood Service Center, Talbot County Health Department, Easton Town Council and County Council.
At the July 29 work session, Talbot Interfaith Executive Director Julie Lowe cited an increase in calls from seniors as evidence that homelessness is growing.
In 2023, the shelter received 15 calls from men 55 and older and 14 calls from women 55 and older. One year later, those marks increased to 30 and 23, respectively.
This year, the Easton-based shelter has already received 19 calls from men and 13 calls from women in that age range, Lowe said.
Other nonprofit and health care leaders advocated for the task force's creation at that meeting. They said it's especially needed to help align local nonprofits, county boards and the health department.
"There isn't anybody who is behind all of these organizations pushing to keep everybody connected," said Rachel Smith, chair of the county's Commission on Aging. "And that's what we found is one of the biggest problems. We have all these organizations out here that are doing so much great work, but then we've got to figure out a way to connect so we can help all these people."

title: Harris speaks to Dorchester Chamber after rally calling for town hall
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Harris speaks to Dorchester Chamber after rally calling for town hall

 March 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 748
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Hours after a rally was held questioning Rep. Andy Harris' (R-Md. 1st) loyalty to his constituents, Harris told Dorchester Chamber of Commerce members inside the Hyatt Regency Chesapeake Bay Golf Resort, Spa and Marina that his office is here to help them."We can make your business run easier," he said during his keynote speech for the chamber's 79th annual business meeting and dinner. "We can work through the bureaucracy. Please get in touch with my office. We're more than happy to help you."
Earlier that evening, protesters lined the sidewalks of U.S. Route 50 outside the Hyatt, calling on Harris to hold a town hall and questioning whether Harris' allegiance is to his constituents or to Elon Musk and the Trump administration. The rally was organized by Cambridge Indivisible, a chapter of a national organization that aims to elect progressive leaders.
Speaking to members of the media after the chamber dinner, Harris said he didn't believe many of the people at the rally were his constituents.
"They're brought in by buses," he said. "I don't know where those buses come from. And we know that the national Indivisibles are involved. So we believe that a lot of those people aren't even constituents."
Harris said he heard from a Washington, D.C., organization's leader "who knows what's going on" that people at the rally were getting paid to be there. He said he would not name who told him that.
"This is astroturf," he said. "This is not grassroots."
Cambridge Indivisible Founder and Chair Michelle Fowle said many of those at the rally were her neighbors who live in Cambridge.
"He's just a liar," she said about Harris.
Harris said he will be holding a virtual town hall on March 25 so he can communicate with constituents from all over his district.
"If these protesters want to call in, if they want to get on my town hall, I will answer that question on my town hall," he said. "But I'm not going to hold a town hall for 100 people when I could hold a town hall and reach out to 5,000 people who don't have to leave their homes, get bused in by some entity paying for that bus."
Harris said he is "laser focused" on working for his constituents and advancing the Trump administration's agenda.
"Who also won the district with high numbers," he said about President Donald Trump (R) getting elected in November.
In Dorchester County, Trump won 55.99% of the vote, according to the Maryland State Board of Elections.
During the rally before the chamber dinner, protesters brought up concerns with recent mass firings of federal workers. Suzanne Sullivan said she has concerns about what the firings will do for the local economy. Sullivan, who lives in Dorchester County, is the wife of environmental scientist Jake Shaner, who was recently fired from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.
Harris told media after the dinner that most companies layoff employees every three to five years. He said that with federal tax cuts, the federal government will grow the economy so there are "plenty of jobs for every American."
"Look, do I feel for everybody who's laid off?" he asked. "Absolutely. Private industry, public government. It's a personal family setback. That's exactly why we have unemployment insurance and we have the social net until these individuals find another job."
HARRIS' KEYNOTE SPEECH
During his keynote speech, Harris touched on a number of issues relevant to Dorchester County and the Eastern Shore. He spoke about the importance of the agriculture industry, low-cost energy and the H-2B visa program.
Harris also brought up the need for blue catfish processing centers to help reduce the population of the invasive species in the Chesapeake Bay. He said federal funding will be available to entrepreneurs who want to build processing plants so the catfish can be considered a commercially viable seafood product.
Harris said two things the county should focus on are addressing drug and alcohol addiction and making sure every child is reading on grade level.
"And we can certainly provide help from the federal government," he said. "But I'll tell you, some of the best solutions are at the local level."
Harris, who lives in Cambridge, said it is a pleasure to represent the people of the Eastern Shore. He said he lives a "blessed life" where he can be at Mar-a-Lago one night and eating at Cindy's Kitchen in Cambridge the next morning.
"It's like the best of both worlds," he said. "And to be honest with you, I like Cindy's better. But don't tell the president that."
